webTitle: Three months of rising football violence

fields.headline: Three months of escalating violence
fields.standfirst: Hooliganism is alive and kicking
fields.trailText: November 1 2000
fields.body:
November 1 2000

Sheffield Fans fight as United concede an injury-time winner to Wednesday at Hillsborough in the Worthington Cup in the first Sheffield derby for six years.

November 8

Milan Leeds fan stabbed in city centre on the night before Champions League match against Milan. Seven Leeds fans arrested in other incidents.

November 11

Bergamo Railway station severely damaged and 10 police injured during fighting after Atalanta beat Brescia 2-0 to take lead in Italy's Serie A.

December 10

Palermo Sicilian fans fight with each other and police after Palermo lose at home to island rivals Messina in a third division promotion match.

December 14

Milan Molotov cocktail is thrown at the coach carrying the players of Internazionale outside their own San Siro stadium after they go out of the Italian Cup to Parma 6-1 on aggregate.

December 16

Sheffield 300 fans riot in city centre after league match between United and Wednesday. 33 arrests.

December 16

Burnley After defeat by Blackburn Rovers in the teams' first meeting for 17 years, Burnley fans riot in their own town centre. 33 arrests.

December 17

Argentina A 17-year-old boy dies from a rubber-bullet wound after fans and police clash during an Argentine second division match between Almirante Brown and Deportivo Moron in the province of Isidro Casanova. On the same day the Buenos Aires derby between Racing Club and Independiente is abandoned in the 85th minute after fighting in which one fan receives a stab wound and 22 others are injured.

Dec 19

Den Bosch Three days and nights of rioting after fan shot dead by police.

December 21

Strasbourg On a day of incidents in the French first division, stones and other objects are thrown throughout the meeting of Strasbourg and Metz. The match is abandoned in the second half after a firecracker hits an assistant referee, Nelly Viennot. Other incidents at Marseille v Monaco, Lille v Bastia and Paris St-Germain v Troyes.

January 10 2001

Athens AEK Athens are banned from playing in their own stadium for four matches after their fans throw missiles and invade pitch in a Greek Cup tie with Olympiakos.

January 13

Rochdale Leeds and Manchester United fans, en route to Maine Road and Bradford respectively, meet and fight on neutral ground in Rochdale.

January 13

Burton upon Trent Two coach-loads of fans from Bishop Auckland invade Burton Albion's pitch twice during FA Trophy tie.

January 27

Manchester Coventry City fans invade home area of main stand at Maine Road after Manchester City take the lead in injury-time.

January 28

Nicosia Nine injured, missiles thrown, dressing rooms besieged and extensive damage to Nicosia's main stadium at end of Cyprus League match between Omonia and Olympiakos, after home fans object when referee blows final whistle 30 seconds before end of the four minutes allotted for injury-time.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Volcano puts the amusement arcades in the shade

fields.headline: Volcano puts the amusement arcades in the shade
fields.trailText: I've never managed anyone more explosive than Paolo di Canio, but sometimes that's the nature of a phenomenal match-turning talent.
fields.body:
I've never managed anyone more explosive than Paolo di Canio. He was so liable to erupt when I had him at Sheffield Wednesday that I nicknamed him the Volcano. But there's no doubt that with the temperament comes a phenomenal talent.

On his current form for West Ham he has to be a candidate for player of the season, and although we had our ups and downs at Wednesday I have to say he is one of the three most skilful players I've worked with.

I'd put him on a par with Paulo Futre when he was in his prime at Atletico Madrid and had just become European footballer of the year, and with Lawrie Cunningham when he was really flying for West Bromwich Albion.

People with Paolo's match-turning flair have always been favourites of mine. You only have to look at the equaliser he scored against Charlton last week and the way he kept his head to get the winner at Old Trafford on Sunday to see what he can do for the team.

Without doubt he played a big part in keeping Wednesday up when I was there in 1997-98. I particularly remember the brilliant goal he scored at Everton to win the game 3-1 and make sure we were safe. He went past about three defenders and the keeper and from being under the cosh suddenly it was game, set and match.

Of course Paolo was frustrating at times and you have to be a certain type of manager to handle him. Plenty wouldn't go near him but Harry Redknapp is like me in that he'll tolerate certain things and let a player try tricks that don't come off provided he wins you enough matches.

It's when people don't produce and become an amusement arcade that you leave them out, but I never felt that was a problem with Paolo. Before Harry took him to West Ham I had wanted to sign him for Nottingham Forest but the money wasn't available.

Paolo is an extremely good professional in terms of his training, but with his volatile temperament you never know when he might explode. From time to time he would fly off the handle at players and some would bite back. If the defence had conceded a goal, for example, he might be very expressive and critical of those he held responsible.

By the time of the Paul Alcock affair against Arsenal I had left Wednesday but I wasn't over-surprised at what happened because Paolo had almost done the same to another referee, Gary Willard, when he got sent off under me in a cup tie against Watford.

He got into a big argument with the linesman over a throw-in and, when Willard came over and showed him a yellow card, Paolo turned and virtually ran at the referee. On the bench we thought he was going to accost him and were screaming: "Don't do it!" He didn't, but Willard switched his card from yellow to red and we were down to 10 men after 25 minutes. We won on penalties after a 0-0 draw but that didn't make our cause any easier.

There are times when Paolo seems to think the world is against him but, despite being a bit off the wall on the field, on his own front he's fairly together. I think he's got a designer-clothes outlet just outside Rome and property in Egypt in the Sharm el Sheikh area, and I remember he was very much into his son's education.

He can be a bit of a joker and he's certainly an extrovert, and West Ham obviously suits him. He's playing to fans who like his style of play and a manager who encourages it.

When he was bearing down on goal at Old Trafford I didn't think he'd do anything but score despite Fabien Barthez's bizarre attempts to put him off. I understand, though, that he was upset at some of my television comments before that.

The point I was making was that I was disappointed in him because he was doing a lot of his work in the defensive half of the field; it was good for the team but it wouldn't pose Manchester United many problems.

I'm sure Sir Alex Ferguson was happy to see him there and I felt he might have got himself into more forward areas when the opportunity arose. Probably the first time he moved into a striking area he got the winner.

I fancy West Ham are going to need a top-of-the-range performance from Paolo to get past Sunderland in the fifth round. And after his statement that he will commit suicide if he can't win a trophy for West Ham, he may feel this is an opportunity not to be missed.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sally
fields.trailText: I have just been made redundant and want to get into the job world you have left behind. Mad or what? But the idea of a six month period travelling is sooooo tempting!
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

It really is inspiring to discover you on this webpage. I am the same age and agree with Kate about the "way women of our generation reinvent themselves".

I have just been made redundant and want to get into the job world you have left behind. Mad or what? But the idea of a six month period travelling is sooooo tempting!

I'm sorry I don't have any travel tips or contacts to give you but I will be travelling vicariously through your reports back to us.

All the very best, enviously...!

webTitle: Mr Wimpy,  Mr Music, and Mr Motivator

fields.headline: Mr Wimpy,  Mr Music, and Mr Motivator
fields.trailText: HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT III)
fields.body:
HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT III)

1. Think about all the negotiations that have taken place between Wimbledon and Coventry City. If this transfer isn't on, it's off. On, off. On, off. On, off. On, off, on, off, on, off, on ... ooh, feel dizzy.

2. Stop staring through kebab shop window at revolving spit of meat. Go home to sort out impending move instead.

3. Flick through papers, all of which report how Coventry will pay the Dons £2.5m with £2.5m to come after appearances. Great! Drink 17 pints of high-energy drink to celebrate. Fall asleep immediately.

4. Awake to find everything has gone pear-shaped. One fried peanut-butter and syrup sandwich too many, perhaps. And not only that, the transfer to Cov has fallen through again!

5. Listen in stunned disbelief as Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson cites a "purely technical reason" for the deal's collapse. "It is an absolute rule of this club that every player is insured for the full amount of the transfer fee and associated costs. For historical reasons, and nothing to do with John Hartson's current situation, we have been unable to secure the necessary insurance cover."

6. Shake head as Richardson wishes you "great success" in the future. Allow jaw to crash to floor. Express surprise that parts of one's body can move so fast.

7. Shame to waste the opportunity of an open mouth. Mmm, chips.

CHRYSALIS OFF

Chris Wright has a lot to answer for. He managed Jethro Tull. He encouraged Midge Ure to make records. And he ruined a whole generation of young men's eyesight by discovering Blondie. For these crimes, not once has he said sorry. But running Chrysalis Records is one thing, being chairman of Queens Park Rangers is another, and after being told in no uncertain terms by irate Loftus Road regulars to sod off, he is resigning as chairman of the once-successful West London club.

"I have reiterated both publicly and privately that as soon as I felt I had lost [the fans'] confidence I would immediately resign and withdraw from the activities of the club," Wright self-righteously announced this morning. And so, following recent "unsavoury incidents around the directors box" - ie. unsolicited opinions being given by the great unwashed in the cheap seats - the chairman of holding company Loftus Road plc has decided that "it is abundantly clear that time has now arrived".

Of course, considering the club may soon be playing at Second Division level for the first time since 1967, a bit of passionate banter from supporters witnessing their team being pulled apart by upwardly mobile neighbours Fulham is the least Wright could have expected. Sadly, his gesture may not be enough to arrest QPR's slide, because there's nobody lined up to take over. "I will continue to provide whatever financial support is necessary until the company identifies my ultimate long-term successor," Wright generously promised. That'll be more scrabbling about the Ryman League for bargains, then.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We had to break a plank of wood with our hands - it was a square block of wood - and you looked at it and thought 'I can't do that'. But he said we were all going to break it before the two hours were over. We're thinking 'no way', but two hours later we held the planks up and we actually broke them with our hands. It was like something you would see in the Karate Kid!" - Manchester City defender Richard Dunne reveals his side's pre-match preparation for Wednesday night's visit from Liverpool.

MARC ARCHES AN EYEBROW

During the three seasons Marc Overmars graced the Premiership, the Fiver cannot recall a single time he bottled out of a challenge, went missing during an away trip or was attacked by his team-mates for not trying in the 3-2 defeat against Coventry on December 26 1999. Which is no doubt why the speedy winger today took it upon himself to offer Liverpool striker (and former Barcelona team-mate) Jari Litmanen a pep-talk about how to handle the rough, tough world of English football.

"What advice would I give him? Well, he must keep himself in good condition for the relentless pace of English games and the amount of fixtures one is required to play there," Marc chirped quite reasonably on his official website. "He must also make an effort to acclimatise to the 'English way' of doing things," he continued, without making a single reference to booze, vindaloo or booze. Then, without so much as an arched eyebrow, he announced: "I don't like it when I see foreign players in England moaning and complaining about the way the game is played there. They should just put up or shut up."

But before the Fiver could think of two types of black kitchen utensil around which to construct a damning sentence, Marc was speeding off again. "If a player doesn't like playing over winter and thinks there should be a winter break they shouldn't go to England," he warned. "That's the way they play the game there and it's no secret that you have to play some tough games in tough conditions." And as we all know, when the going gets tough, some people just never get going.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have added Benfica's Robert Enke to their list of goalkeeping targets, according to reports.

Joe Kinnear could be set for a return to the game as director of football with Luton Town.

NEWS IN BRIEF

West Ham have snapped up 18-year-old centre-half Alessandro Zamperini from Roma on a free transfer.

Dave Bassett has denied reports that he will replace Gerry Francis as manager of QPR.

Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic is on the verge of completing a three-month loan move to Blackburn Rovers.

Aston Villa manager John Gregory has confirmed his interest in Ajax striker Shota Arveladze but insisted that no contact had been made with Ajax or the player's agent Ivan Benesh. "We have seen Arveladze in action, along with quite a few other players," said Gregory, "but we haven't spoken to anyone about him and we haven't discussed anything with his agent."

Manchester City manager Joe Royle has revealed he has received several offers to take Paulo Wanchope on loan - but no firm bids.

Aston Villa have launched an appeal against the straight red card handed out to Darius Vassell in the FA Cup tie with Leicester City last weekend.

Arrigo Sacchi has retired from football management because of stress. The Parma manager, announcing his resignation at a packed press conference today, said: "It's a bitter decision but during the match against Verona I felt ill due to stress and accumulated tension. It was an alarm bell. I thought my two years out of the game would have recharged my batteries. Evidently that's not the case. I've realised how difficult it is to coach."

Lazio goalkeeper Angelo Peruzzi, 30, has admitted he could retire at the end of the season because he is not enjoying football any more.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.50am)
"Hello. I'm the Fiver's dentist. The TV and Radio section hasn't had a check-up for over two years now, which goes against all British Dental Association recommendations. Now, open wide."

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)
[scrapescrapescrapescrapescrapescrapescrape scrapescrapescrapescrapescrapescrapescrape scrapescrapescrapescrape]

Premier League Preview (12midnight, 5am)
"Hmm, yes, yes."

Sky Sports 2: Live Second Division Football - Wigan v Walsall (7pm, 3.30am)
[taptaptaptaptaptaptaptaptaptaptaptapscrapescrape scrapescrapescrapescrapescrapescrapetaptap]

Sports Centre Football Hour (10pm, 4am SS1)
"Hmm, yes, yes, I'm afraid I'm going to have to drill several holes in the last programme. Brace yourself."

Hold The Back Page (11pm, 5am)
[drilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrill drilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrilldrill]

"If only you'd bothered to floss regularly."

webTitle: '15 children died in care of Haringey'

fields.headline: '15 children died in care of Haringey'
fields.trailText: Fifteen children have died unnaturally over the past 10 years while in the care of the London borough of Haringey, it was claimed today.
fields.body:
Fifteen children have died unnaturally over the past 10 years while in the care of the London borough of Haringey, it was claimed today.

The figures, reported in the London Evening Standard, have been described as "ghastly" by one councillor.

This latest revelation follows the Anna Climbie case, in which a young girl was tortured to death by her guardians while under council supervision.

It will increase the concerns that case raised about the ability of Haringey social services to look after vulnerable children.

The Standard reports that officials have yet to confirm in what circumstances some of the children died, and that the council refuses to reveal details of some of the deaths. Haringey will not say whether disciplinary action was taken or what recommendations social services inspectors made afterwards.

The council has resisted accusations of covering up the deaths, and is quoted as saying that it would be "inappropriate" to reveal details so long after the events.

Councillor Peter Forrest, who has campaigned for details to be made available, is quoted as saying: "One death is far too many and the fact that 14 other children have died in the last 10 years as well is ghastly. I am concerned that Anna's death was part of a pattern of failure as evidenced by these multiple deaths."

webTitle: Travelling in Iran with a friend

fields.headline: Travelling in Iran with a friend
fields.standfirst:
I am a 26-year-old girl and this summer I would like to visit Iran with a male (platonic) friend. I have heard that there are very strict rules about non-married 'couples' and that we could run into all sorts of problems, from visas to hotel rooms. However, going with a girlfriend, I fear, would be worse. Can anyone advise?
Malika Browne
fields.trailText: I am a 26-year-old girl and this summer I would like to visit Iran with a male (platonic) friend. I have heard that there are very strict rules about non-married 'couples' and that we could run into all sorts of problems, from visas to hotel rooms. However, going with a girlfriend, I fear, would be worse. Can anyone advise?
fields.body:
 I travelled around Iran for two weeks in August 1999 with a male companion, and only once had problems with a hotel. We were asked to leave one hotel when they saw we had different arrivals dates into the country on our passports (my travel companion had come from Australia and we'd only met up once we were in Tehran). I managed to convince them we were married and they relented but as soon as we went to pay individually for the room they realised we weren't married at all. After that, they wouldn't even rent us separate rooms because they were afraid of the reaction of the religious police and they apologetically asked us to leave. We simply went to another hotel nearby (where the police did come and take down our passport details after we'd checked in). We travelled constantly for two weeks, staying in many different hotels and only had this experience once, so you are unlikely to have problems.

After the above experience, we changed tactics when booking into hotels: in order to be a more convincing "couple", Anthony, my travel companion, would always pay for the room himself and then we'd settle up afterwards, out of sight of the hotel management. It's far more convincing than both going into your money belts and paying half each.

As far as covering up goes, the previous reply is incorrect: you are definitely not required to wear a burka. You are required to cover up well and I would recommend getting one of the long black coats Iranian women wear, and you need a headscarf too. I found this perfectly comfortable and I'm sure it was less hot than trying to adapt Western clothes as I just wore shorts and a little top underneath. Iranian women are compelled to dress this way every time they go out of the house, I felt it was only respectful to them that I do the same. Several times I was thanked or complimented by people in the street for observing proper "hejab" (modest dress).

Iran was a fantastic country, the mosques are stunning and the people are without doubt the most hospitable I've ever come across. I have kept in touch with several Iranians I met and while I was there and I can't wait to go back again later this year and travel on my own.
Candi Bain

 I travelled through Iran with my girlfriend (and two kids) in late 1998 on the way to India and Pakistan, and then back again in mid 1999. We had no problems at hotels at all regarding our non-married status, although we had heard the same rumours as you. We met several other westerners travelling with girfriends and boyfriends (and platonic friends), and none reported problems on these grounds. We also met two pairs of girls travelling together - they did attract some attention, but had no real problems (Pakistan can be a different story for women).

Visas were problematic, and took a lot of time. The easiest thing to do is get a five day transit visa, but we went for a 14 day tourist visa; it took about six or eight weeks from the London embassy. They were pretty liberal, and had no problem with us travelling as an unmarried couple, although the presence of the kids may have helped. If other people suggest this is a problem, you could apply separately. Once we got to Iran we had no problem extending the visa for a further 14 days (Shiraz is a good place to do this). If you want to do that, it's worth talking to other tourists that you meet there for the latest info. In the UK, good up to date advice is available from the overland truck companies, eg Exodus and Dragonman, although you may need to pretend that you are interested in one of their trips. Alternatively, one of the specialist tour operators that take trips to Iran should be able to offer good advice. Far more difficult getting a return visa from Pakistan - again, it took seven weeks, and several people we met were turned down (disastrous if you are driving as there is no other feasible land route).

Finally, enjoy it - we though Iran was a fascinating place. Difficult enough not to be overrun by tourists, very friendly people, lots of interesting stuff to see etc. You will need to cover your head with a scarf and wear very baggy clothing (a coat), or an Iranian chador. In summer it can get pretty warm in all that stuff. Your male friend will have it a lot easier, although no shorts etc.

Hope this helps,
Nigel Muir

 From what I have heard, via a friend who goes there on business, being an unmarried couple would be problematical and furthermore, as a women you would be compelled to wear a burka.
Ann Eastman

webTitle: Watching the solar eclipse in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Watching the solar eclipse in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst:
Does anyone know of low-cost, low-impact trips to Zimbabwe for the total solar eclipse on 21 June 2001? I am aware of many trips costing £1,700 or more, but was looking for something more affordable, possibly by breaking up the components of the trip and not buying a package. Local contacts rather than international agents would be useful.
Doug Stratton
fields.trailText: Does anyone know of low-cost, low-impact trips to Zambia (or Zimbabwe) for the total solar eclipse on 21 June 2001? I am aware of many trips costing £1,700 or more, but was looking for something more affordable, possibly by breaking up the components of the trip and not buying a package. Local contacts rather than international agents would be useful.
fields.body:
 Try a journey with Harry Steyn of Oasis Safaris, in neighbouring Botswana. We spent several days with him in the Okavango Delta, ending up at Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe, travelling in a converted Land Rover 101 and camping in the bush. Harry is an entertaining and knowlegable guide and driver, and after seeing a wide variety of wildlife in the day, his stories around the camp fire in the evening were fascinating. Meals were cooked on the camp fire, which also was our source of hot water: bucket showers under the stars are interesting! Presumably costs are kept down by some participation by the clients, eg putting up the tents and gathering firewood (but no washing up or cooking), which adds to the feeling of a real safari. Tel. 020 7387 1211 (ask for Rob) or email oasis.safaris@info.bw
Tanya & Edmund Hoare

 I did a well organised safari 18 months ago with Drifters Adventure Tours. They are based in Johannesburg but they cover most of Southern Africa and while they are a package, they were well priced and very efficient. It is possible you could do the eclipse with them. Their address is Drifters Adventours c.c., PO Box 48434, Roosevelt Park, Johannesburg 2195, South Africa. Tel. (+2711) 888 1160, fax (+2711) 888 1020, email: drifters@drifters.co.za
Rachel DeLisser

 Why don't you put together one of your own? You can fly to South Africa on SAA (020 7312 5000) and then up to Zambia on Nationwide (the regional airline) or to Zimbabwe on Air Zimbabwe (020 7491 0009) to Harare and on to Victoria Falls. You can book accommodation using information in the guides published for the Automobile Association of South Africa - available in the UK (020 8954 4672). Unless you want five star accommodation the whole way there are many amazing places to stay at under £50 per night per room.
Vanessa Sand

 You might initially have a look at Bradt Travel Guide's excellent Africa and Madagascar Total Eclipse 2001 & 2002 guide. It is a comprehensive collection of information regarding how to and where to see the African eclipse, and the accommodation information is updated regularly on the Bradt Travel Guides website at www.bradt-travelguides.com. If you are after a low impact eclipse trip with a reputable independent operator then Dragoman (01728 861 133) still have places available.

 There is a backpackers hotel in Lusaka, Zambia called Chachacha's and they can pick you up on arrival at Lusaka airport. There are cheap dorms or you can camp in a safe garden. They even have cooking facilities so it should fit a budget trip. They provide heaps of travel information and you can get anywhere from there easily.
Louise Kerbiriou

 Dragoman (01728 861 133, www.dragoman.co.uk has places available on its five-week trip from Nairobi to Harare departing May 28, spending June 21 40km north of Lusaka. The tour costs £1,055 plus $485 (£330) kitty and includes transport, meals and crew. International flights extra.
Amanda Hammerton

 Doug Stratton can organise his own trip. He can fly to South Africa on SAA (020-7312 5000) and then up to Zambia on Nationwide (the regional airline) or to Zimbabwe on Air Zimbabwe (020-7491 0009) to Harare and on to Victoria Falls. He can book his own accommodation using the guides published for the Automobile Association of South Africa, available here in the UK from 020-8954 4672. There are many amazing places to stay at under £50 per night.
Vanessa Sand

 There are few places to stay in the Zambezi Valley on both sides of the border, but one that I have worked at caters for all. It is called Gwabi Lodge on the Zambian side, and is three kilometres up from the Zambezi on the Kafue river. It is run by the Wardle family and is 11 kilometres from Chirundu. It has the most wonderful view anyone could wish for, a pool on the terrace and a bar with a restaurant. You can either camp or have a chalet. The best way to get there is to drive, but it's not impossible to get there by bus. The address is:

Gwabi Lodge

Chirundu

PO box 30813

Lusaka

Zambia

fields.headline: Car insurance cover while abroad
fields.trailText: Does anyone know of an insurance company offering either a UK policy with the possibility of a hire car extension for overseas travel, or independent policies for overseas car hire?
fields.body:
For a recent fortnight's car hire in Cyprus, the optional collision damage and theft etc insurance supplements were far more than the rental. Indeed, just two weeks' cover cost almost as much as a full year's insurance on my almost identical car at home. Does anyone know of an insurance company offering either a UK policy with the possibility of a hire car extension for overseas travel, or independent policies for overseas car hire?

Patrick Boylan

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sarah
fields.trailText: Sounds like you're having a good time. I was in Oz last November and we visited Uluru amongst other places. When you are there try and get on an Anangu tour of the rock - the tours are led by Aboriginal guides and are really good
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

Sounds like you're having a good time. I was in Oz last November and we visited Uluru amongst other places. When you are there try and get on an Anangu tour of the rock - the tours are led by Aboriginal guides and are really good and also are led in small groups rather than big busloads. Also visit Kata Juta if you get the chance and do the Valley of the Winds walk - the view at the end is amazing.

Cheers, Sarah Robinson

fields.headline: Dropping in on Kuala Lumpur
fields.standfirst: At first Sue  scarcely notices her transition from East Malaysia to West; she continues to enjoy the peace of the rainforest, and finds herself in yet another cave. However a visit to Kuala Lumpur, where she climbs the KL Tower only to find people hurling themselves from the top, soon serves to highlight the differences...
fields.trailText: Kuala Lumpur: At first Sue scarcely notices her transition from East Malaysia to West; she continues to enjoy the peace of the rainforest, and finds herself in yet another cave. However a visit to Kuala Lumpur, where she climbs the KL Tower only to find people hurling themselves from the top, soon serves to highlight the differences...
fields.body:
Selamat hari tahun baru Cina!

This week I have reluctantly said goodbye to East Malaysia and crossed to the peninsular, West Malaysia. On Saturday I spent the day with Jeremy and Gay touring Miri and the long deserted beach, while my washing dried. While travelling, I've found that small things can give disproportionate pleasure. On returning from Mulu Park, for example, I had my first hotel room with a bath as well as hot water. Although normally a shower person I lazed in my first bath for two months, unperturbed that, like most of Malaysia, the water had a browny red tinge. Bliss. I decided that I was not going to be embarrassed by the ring left on the bath. Similarly, having the opportunity to wash my sleeping sheet (an essential piece of equipment) was a real treat.

So on Sunday, all sparkly clean, it was off to Niah National Park for a couple of days. The hostel accommodation was great, better than most of my hotels, with polished wood and gleaming tiles. I had a four bedroom dorm to myself. As seems to be usual at this time of year, there were few visitors, only Claus, a mature German who seemed to have taken root there and gone native, and was out collecting wild fruits at the crack of dawn, and a young English couple from Bolton.

Niah's main attraction is another huge limescale cave, measuring 250m across at the mouth, home to swifts and bats. It takes a good hour to walk round. This time I had hired a flashlight at the café across the river, which consisted of a light attached to a homemade wooden case holding four huge batteries - clumsy and heavy, but effective. The cave was awesome, with white rocks resembling huge bones scattered about at random. Off the path were little twinkling lights inside the shelters of the locals, who gather the swifts' nests for the famous bird's nest soup, and the guano, which is used for fertilizer. They climb up bamboo poles tied together to the roof of the cave, 60m above. You were occasionally aware of them as they hopped about the rocks. No hopping for me as, despite being extremely careful, I again slipped on the planking, this time with a backside covered in wet mud and bat droppings to show for it.

On the way back the Malay skies opened, as they do most afternoons. I sheltered in a cave formed by an overhanging rock with a stream at the bottom. As I watched the rain, eating rambutan, I again felt that peace and contentment that rainforests seem to give me. The next morning I had a wonderful walk, during which I met a snake, saw a red humming bird and watched a large monkey climb down a tall tree only a few yards away. In fact, I spent so long standing still watching things that I missed my boat back to Batu Niah, which meant negotiating another one - by which time, of course, I had missed the bus back to Miri and had to wait two hours for the next one. This must have been my bumpiest bus ride yet. Not for the first time over the last couple of weeks I had cause to thank my mother's family genes for providing me with the "Scott's behind", which has plenty of padding. Many times I was actually launched into the air. The female ticket collector sitting in front of me not only managed to sleep for an hour but then spent the second hour totally redoing her hair and makeup. How she managed to accomplish this was a total mystery to me (as was the poster on the front windscreen, which read "Stop dengue fever. Use polystyrene beads"). So it was another good trip to round off my stay in Sarawak. Sadly, there was no time to go to Sabah; perhaps when I win my next trip round the world!

On Tuesday evening I was off to Kuala Lumpur, always referred to as KL. I had been told that the in-flight magazine had a very good street map of KL. I felt a bit embarrassed tearing it out with a Malaysian either side of me, but I need not have worried, as after the meal the young man on my left methodically cleaned the metal cutlery and then put it in his pocket. The lady to my right also slipped something into her bag, although I couldn't quite see what it was.

Anxious about arriving late at night and not being able to check out a room before taking it, I had booked into the YWCA. The lady on the phone promised me the night watchman would be waiting for me with a room ready. When I got there, no sign of life in any shape or form. Refusing to panic, I rang and rang the doorbell until a nice American resident came and let me in. I was about to crash out on the settee when the night watchman finally arrived. I would not want to be him next day when the mother-hen type warden got hold of him.

So the last couple of days I have been exploring KL. I like it; it has tall buildings and is a busy city, but it hasn't lost its character. As usual, China town has an abundance of vibrancy, colour and chaos. Through the website, I met up with Feliz, resident in KL for many years, who kindly invited me to stay for a couple of days. Coincidentally, she also originates from Bolton. She lives in a suburb that proudly boasts the Pyramid shopping mall, with a monstrous sphinx/lion at the entrance.

Yesterday, I did the tall buildings of KL. First to the famous Petronas Towers which, by virtue of their aerials, claim to be the tallest buildings in the world. Following email advice from Dale I chose to actually go up the KL Tower which has a viewing level nearly 300m up. I wondered what all the gasps were until I saw several spread-eagled bodies hurtle past the window. I had unknowingly hit on the day they were having a display of sky diving off the top of the tower. It was frightening to see how late they left it to open their brightly coloured parachutes. I was mesmerised by it and joined in the competition among the spectators to try and catch a shot of a body flying past. My digital camera soon had a flat battery as time and time again I wasn't quite quick enough. I returned to the bottom to catch them landing with awesome accuracy, with my ordinary camera.

So I now have to decide how to spend my remaining time here. The consistent email advice from the two Clares, Nancy, Dale and e-kiloh has convinced me that I should try the National Park (I am off there tomorrow), Pangor Laut, Malaka and the Cameron Highlands. My sister and her husband are coming to KL next week as part of their holiday, so I will have to leave some things to do with them. It will be good to see them. They are also bringing me a new tape from my daughter.

I also had an email from a couple I met on the plane on my first flight to Bombay, which I have tried to answer, but unfortunately my reply was returned. It seems such a long time ago, although it's only two months. That makes me a third of the way through my wonderful trip already. I am not going to think about it! Jumpa lagi, kawan-kawan.

This must have been my bumpiest bus ride yet. Not for the first time over the last couple of weeks I had cause to thank my mother's family genes for providing me with the "Scott's behind", which has plenty of padding. Many times I was actually launched into the air. The female ticket collector sitting in front of me not only managed to sleep for an hour but then spent the second hour totally redoing her hair and makeup. How she managed to accomplish this was a total mystery to me (as was the poster on the front windscreen, which read "Stop dengue fever. Use polystyrene beads"). So it was another good trip to round off my stay in Sarawak. Sadly, there was no time to go to Sabah; perhaps when I win my next trip round the world! On Tuesday evening I was off to Kuala Lumpur, always referred to as KL. I had been told that the in-flight magazine had a very good street map of KL. I felt a bit embarrassed tearing it out with a Malaysian either side of me, but I need not have worried, as after the meal the young man on my left methodically cleaned the metal cutlery and then put it in his pocket. The lady to my right also slipped something into her bag, although I couldn't quite see what it was. Anxious about arriving late at night and not being able to check out a room before taking it, I had booked into the YWCA. The lady on the phone promised me the night watchman would be waiting for me with a room ready. When I got there, no sign of life in any shape or form. Refusing to panic, I rang and rang the doorbell until a nice American resident came and let me in. I was about to crash out on the settee when the night watchman finally arrived. I would not want to be him next day when the mother-hen type warden got hold of him. So the last couple of days I have been exploring KL. I like it; it has tall buildings and is a busy city, but it hasn't lost its character. As usual, China town has an abundance of vibrancy, colour and chaos. Through the website, I met up with Feliz, resident in KL for many years, who kindly invited me to stay for a couple of days. Coincidentally, she also originates from Bolton. She lives in a suburb that proudly boasts the Pyramid shopping mall, with a monstrous sphinx/lion at the entrance. Yesterday, I did the tall buildings of KL. First to the famous Petronas Towers which, by virtue of their aerials, claim to be the tallest buildings in the world. Following email advice from Dale I chose to actually go up the KL Tower which has a viewing level nearly 300m up. I wondered what all the gasps were until I saw several spread-eagled bodies hurtle past the window. I had unknowingly hit on the day they were having a display of sky diving off the top of the tower. It was frightening to see how late they left it to open their brightly coloured parachutes. I was mesmerised by it and joined in the competition among the spectators to try and catch a shot of a body flying past. My digital camera soon had a flat battery as time and time again I wasn't quite quick enough. I returned to the bottom to catch them landing with awesome accuracy, with my ordinary camera. So I now have to decide how to spend my remaining time here. The consistent email advice from the two Clares, Nancy, Dale and e-kiloh has convinced me that I should try the National Park (I am off there tomorrow), Pangor Laut, Malaka and the Cameron Highlands. My sister and her husband are coming to KL next week as part of their holiday, so I will have to leave some things to do with them. It will be good to see them. They are also bringing me a new tape from my daughter. I also had an email from a couple I met on the plane on my first flight to Bombay, which I have tried to answer, but unfortunately my reply was returned. It seems such a long time ago, although it's only two months. That makes me a third of the way through my wonderful trip already. I am not going to think about it! Jumpa lagi, kawan-kawan.

webTitle: Ulster peace hopes pinned on IRA making gesture

fields.headline: Ulster peace hopes pinned on IRA making gesture
fields.trailText: Hopes of an imminent breakthrough in the Northern Ireland peace process faded last night when it emerged the British and Irish governments were still waiting to hear if the IRA was prepared to make a historic gesture on disarmament.
fields.body:
Hopes of an imminent breakthrough in the Northern Ireland peace process faded last night when it emerged the British and Irish governments were still waiting to hear if the IRA was prepared to make a historic gesture on disarmament.

Officials on both sides of the Irish Sea still hope that a deal, which would save the Good Friday agreement, can be reached within a week. It is understood, however, that Tony Blair told the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, he still did not know whether the IRA was "ready to deliver". The prime minister has held talks with all the main players in the past 48 hours, as London and Dublin step up their efforts to broker a deal between the Ulster Unionists, Sinn Fein and the Social Democratic and Labour Party. The two governments hope to choreograph a three-point plan involving:

 a major scaling down of the army's presence in borders areas of Northern Ireland;

 an IRA commitment to reopen talks with the international disarmament body, coupled with commitments on the "modalities" of decommissioning - how weapons will be dismantled;

 a commitment by the SDLP and Sinn Fein to take up their places on the new policing board.

After meeting Mr Blair on Wednesday, the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, said he was confident all sides were narrowing their differences.

However, a senior Ulster Unionist said: "The prime minister is still not sure that the IRA are ready to deliver.

"We cannot have a form of words from the IRA. There is no point in doing this unless we get something really serious. They will have to do more than re-engage with the De Chastelain [disarmament] commission."

An Irish official said negotiations had reached their most difficult point: whether Sinn Fein and the IRA could turn their backs on 70 years of history and offer a deal on disarmament.

One source said: "Decommissioning is the Rubicon for republicans which will mean dismantling their past. Taking their seats on the police board is about the future, but it also means buying into the state."

Mr Trimble said he had made little progress in his talks last night with the prime minister. There was a "limited window of opportunity" to reach a deal before the election, and his party demanded cast iron commitments on decommissioning to remain in the power-sharing executive. "I would like to see matters come to a head sooner rather than later," he said.

British and Irish officials have kicked around ideas on decommissioning methods, such as concreting over several arms dumps or putting chemicals on weapons, and they would want the IRA to start serious discussion on these with General John de Chastelain. If republicans responded positively it is understood the prime minister could signal the start of a choreographed sequence of events with a major speech.

He would expect the IRA to contact Gen de Chastelain immediately and, as simultaneously as possible, there would be some security scaledown.

fields.headline: Car sharing services
fields.standfirst:
Does anyone know of a service that puts people doing a journey with a car in touch with people wanting a lift to their destination?
Sue Lumsden
fields.trailText:
Does anyone know of a service that puts people doing a journey with a car in touch with people wanting a lift to their destination?

Sue Lumsden
fields.body:
 While I don't know of any such nationwide organisation in the UK, I know this exists in Germany and New Zealand. Several years ago, I travelled extensively through Germany with the organisation City Link. Both drivers and would-be fellow travellers phone in with their requests a few days before they want to travel, and City Net phone them back once they have found a driver/passenger via computer matching. Alternatively, you can go to the office directly. Women can choose to drive/go with another woman only. Before passengers start the trip they are given a print-out with the car registration number, the name and address of the driver. The passenger/driver phone each other to arrange the pick-up place. In many cases I was picked up from where I was staying and delivered to my next address, even if it meant a detour for the driver. City Net also arranges for trips abroad, ie to the Netherlands, Britain, Belgium, France etc from Germany. Most other continental countries have a similar system to City Net. I believe it doesn't exist in UK because of complications with insurance companies. It's time to adjust regulations to make the organised giving and getting of lifts possible.
Ursula Hilton-Jones

 There are such agencies all over Germany called "Mitfahrzentrale". I have used this many years ago and the agency will take a commission from the driver (if I can remember rightly) and also set out how much the driver can charge the passenger depending on the kilometres of the journey. You will find them in the telephone directories, or try www.gelbeseiten.de (German yellow pages) and look under 'Mitfahrzentralen'. Some are part of a network and others are independent. As a passenger it is advisable to register with as many as possible. The German agencies may have details about agencies in other countries.
Andrea Woelke (Mr)

 Liftshare.com is the UK's most successful lift-sharing scheme, with over 10,000 members. We help councils and business across the UK not only to implement effective car sharing schemes but also to build integrated transport communities.

Sharing a car is the untold answer to many peoples transport needs. We have developed a secure and successful way of finding people travel companions and we hope that you will support the scheme

Ali Clabburn

Managing Director

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-three

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-three
fields.standfirst: Blue Square must be daft. They've given us £400 to squander on their betting site. Here are the latest punts
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £180.93
Sean Ingle = £45.43
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £34.34
Paul MacInnes = £28.15
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £180.93
Sean Ingle = £45.43
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £34.34
Paul MacInnes = £28.15

Scott Murray: Coventry v Arsenal - No goalscorer £5 @ 8/1

This one's got "low scoring" written all over it. Coventry don't have a goalscorer worthy of the name, while Arsenal have got several multi-million pound international strikers (but don't have a goalscorer worthy of the name).

Neither side lets in too many, either, so I decided to plump for the 0 or 1 goals at 13/8. But will you just take a look at what's happened to me? I've become a greedy fat gannet and I'm chancing my arm (wing?) on the longer odds. It'll serve me right, etc. and so on.

Incidentally, the most boring match I ever witnessed was this very fixture during - I think - the 1987-8 season. Twenty-two oafs skidding helplessly around an icy pitch not so much as two passes strung together not a chance created, never mind a goal Perry Groves and Brian Kilcline and, foolishly, I sat through the whole shebang. Two hours of my life - stolen! You owe me this, you footpads!!!

Sean Ingle: AZ v Feyenoord: Feyenoord to win £11 @ 10/11

As Mao Zedong so wisely put it, the longest journey begins with a solitary step. Which is why I have decided to forsake the pleasures of a high-odds treble (even though Luton, Leeds and Fulham to all win offers nearly 20-1, yes 20-1!!!) or the strange allure of a no goalscorer bet in the Bologna v Internazionale match (which pays 13-2) for a simpler - albeit less profitable looking - punt.

Feyenoord are top of the Dutch league. They have - as Channel 5's coverage never tires of telling us - the best players and the best squad in Holland. Admittedly they lost away at SC Heerenveen in midweek, but I can't see lightning striking twice. Meanwhile, their opponents AZ are in lowly eleventh position and lost 5-0 in their last home game against PSV. If this was England, and Manchester United were at somewhere like Charlton or Southampton, the odds on an away win would surely be closer to 4/6, which is why the price of 10/11 on Feyenoord must offer excellent value.

Paul MacInnes: Southampton to beat Newcastle at half-time - £10 @ 4/1

Whether it's desperation, boredom, or just sheer plain loserdom, I'm going out on a limb this week. £10 is enough to buy you lots of things and, in fact, I can be bought for a tenner too. But I'm going to casually chuck it away on this wager which, despite the usual mixture of statistics that seem to be so favourable, is going to do nothing to end my interminable winless streak.

But, for the record, here's the stats. Southampton are on a decent run, with only one defeat in seven. They have only failed to score away from home on four occasions this season (against Manchester United, Spurs, Arsenal and Leicester). What's more, they have scored the first goal in a match 14 times this season, the fifth-best record in the Premiership. Newcastle have been up and down at home with three defeats to their name. Admittedly, the Saints haven't won at St James's Park since 1997. But then, I'm not backing them for the win.

Oh, it all sounds so convincing.

Rowan Foggitt of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Walsall to win at Wigan £5 @ 5/2

Being a bit of a Cambridge United fan, who is enjoying their freefall due to having an open points spread position on them, the Second Division is where I'm looking to find a badly needed winner this week. But although the bookies spend less time pricing this market, the men in big sheepskin coats appear to have left us with scant value this week.

Lowly Luton have not picked up a point since Boxing Day and should not give Rotherham, who travel as well as any in the league, too much trouble. Evens is tempting. Bournemouth will give Colchester a good hiding, but the 4/6 on offer is quite skinny. And Northampton, whose away form is more than respectable, are not badly priced at 4/1 to win at Stoke.

But we will turn to tonight's match for the chosen punt. Although Wigan are looking good, top-of-the-table Walsall can be had at 5/2 to turn them over. Try getting that on Manchester United!

fields.headline: Wenger wins appeal
fields.trailText: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has won his appeal against a 12-match touchline ban for violent and threatening behaviour.
fields.body:
Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has won his appeal against a 12-match touchline ban for violent and threatening behaviour.

But Wenger has been reprimanded and fined £10,000 by the FA's appeal board after being found guilty of the lesser charge of misconduct following a clash with fourth official Paul Taylor after Arsenal's match against Sunderland on August 19.

An FA statement said: "After due consideration, the board unanimously concluded that the more serious charge of violent and threatening behaviour should be dismissed but the charge of misconduct was proven.

"As a result the original penalty imposed no longer applies. The board has decided that Mr Wenger should receive a reprimand and be fined £10,000 and pay the costs of the board."

After the verdict Wenger expressed his delight at having been cleared of the main charge conduct, declaring: "That was very important for me."

"When you get a 12-match ban and you have my clean disciplinary record, you have to look at why you got such a ban," he admitted. "That was something terrible for me and put me in a guilty position towards my club."

"I was determined to defend my case. It was stressful for everyone. But the most important thing is I've got this out of the way and I can do my job and concentrate on tomorrow's game at Coventry."

Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein added: "Obviously there was the new evidence which came up at the appeal which was very important. We're very grateful that the FA took that mind and thanks is due to our legal team."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Andy
fields.trailText: I've been following your travel exploits with a great deal of interest over the last eight or nine weeks as I'm a 46 year old about to depart on my own somewhat delayed gap year. As the time to leave draws ever closer and last minute panics set in, some words of advice would be much appreciated.
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

I've been following your travel exploits with a great deal of interest over the last eight or nine weeks as I'm a 46 year old about to depart on my own somewhat delayed gap year/ walkabout/journey of a lifetime as a single traveller, leaving the UK on February 10, and flying into Mumbai. My route plan will also take me from India into Nepal, so many thanks for your insights, photos etc., but from there I go on to Thailand, Vietnam, China,and Hong Kong before heading south for Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, New Zealand, and then finally home via the Pacific Islands, Hawaii and the US (fortunately I've got almost to play with and don't have to rush back to work, having taken a package from Essex County Councils' Community Education Dept. a little while ago).

As the time to leave draws ever closer and last minute panics set in, some words of advice from your good self would be much appreciated.

How are you managing to cope with issues such as security for both yourself and your belongings? Travelling (effectively alone) must make it difficult when you want to do something or go somewhere and have a large backpack in tow? Are you managing to get sufficient support from fellow travellers? Does this give you real peace of mind when someone says they'll keep an eye on your stuff??

How are you managing to access more remote local currencies? Travellers cheques? Hole in the wall machines?(are there any anyway?) by using a Credit Card or cash or a combination of the above? Would you recommend taking sterling or dollars or both as the best way of accessing local money ?

Finally, once you're on the travel trail I'm sure you must continue to get loads of advice about where to stay and what to see, do etc. However, it must have been a godsend to have somewhere to lay your head ( and after a long flight) on that first night in Mumbai. Can you recommend a particular hotel or hostel at least for the first couple of nights, in order to get your bearings and potentially meet up with other like minded souls? I'd be very grateful for any thoughts you might have with regard to these issues.

Many thanks and best wishes for your onward trip.

Andy Dykes

webTitle: Health in the midst of hardship

fields.headline: Health in the midst of hardship
fields.standfirst: While international attention turns to the devastating earthquake in Gujarat, relief work continues in El Salvador, where aid workers are still tackling the aftermath of January's quake
fields.trailText: While international attention turns to the devastating earthquake in Gujarat, relief work continues in El Salvador, where aid workers are still tackling the aftermath of January's quake
fields.body:
Aid work in El Salvador's earthquake zone continues apace, although the media spotlight has rightly shifted to Gujarat where utter devastation has left 300,000 homeless and at least 20,000 dead.

For aid workers, there are no instant fixes. Humanitarian emergencies are complex operations needing thorough analysis, coordinated action and well-targeted, appropriate assistance that usually lasts for several months.

Since I arrived in San Salvador shortly after the January 13 earthquake, Oxfam's activities have spread out systematically to the provinces it earmarked at the start.

Shiny galvanised steel water tanks, 27 at the last count, have sprung up in Usulutan, Sonsonate, La Libertad and La Paz. My engineer colleagues also need to clean and repair wells and unblock springs that the quake and the dry season between them have wrecked. After water, food and shelter, the priority is to prevent disease and promote good health practices. Jane Bean, an experienced health specialist with Oxfam, had hardly landed when she was whisked into the countryside to see what issues she needed to work on.

There, the earthquake has made a hard life even harder. She found little evidence of basic public services of water, health, sanitation or education, unlike the urban areas.

For her the lack of water at this particular time of year is a mixed blessing. While it keeps at bay diseases like dengue fever or malaria, it makes basic hygiene difficult at the best of times and now almost impossible.

In rural areas, a low level of awareness of safe hygiene practices is common - water carriers and water storage units are dirty, hand washing just doesn't happen and there is a lack of sanitation. Add to that the fact that many of the kids playing around in the dirt are covered in bites which when scratched become infected easily.

Breaking the mould needs imagination. So, Jane and colleagues from an experienced health group called Provida are using a network of 70 health professionals to try to instill some changes as a result of the quake. Their messages spell out the benefits of protecting and conserving precious water supplies and of safely disposing of faeces.

Luckily, the health team also has Alberto, an Italian with a knack for graphic art. He's created educational materials that can be used at community meetings, drama groups and "charlas", where they'll spread their message. The Oxfam/Provida project aims to reach 12,000 families (50,000 people) during its six-week campaign.

It's a start in a country where poverty is widespread in rural areas. In emergencies you feel there's always more that could be done. When people with very little are dealt a blow that leaves them with even less, it's tough to provide only a small solution in the face of such need.

fields.headline: A twist in the tale
fields.standfirst: Heinz Holliger's opera based on Snow White is a breathtaking success, says  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: Heinz Holliger's opera based on Snow White is a breathtaking success, says Andrew Clements
fields.body:
Heinz Holliger: Schneewittchen
Banse/Kallisch/Davislim/ Widmer/Groschel/Zurich Opera/Holliger (ECM, 2 CDs)
*****
£22.99

The Swiss musician Heinz Holliger, born in 1939, is the greatest oboist of our time, but the fact that he is also one of the most intriguing and accomplished composers of his generation is only now beginning to gain ground, thanks at least in part to ECM, which over the last decade has steadily championed Holliger's cause. Now, in an exceptional set that is as immaculately performed and recorded as it is meticulously documented, they have released the biggest and most impressive of his recent scores: his first full-length opera, Schneewittchen, premiered in Zurich in 1998.

Holliger took his libretto for this deconstructed version of Snow White from a turn-of-the-century play by the Swiss poet Robert Walser, who received so little attention during his lifetime that he eventually abandoned writing altogether, and spent the end of his life in an asylum. It's typical of Holliger to be drawn to a writer whose life and work are inextricably intertwined. His career as a composer has been a series of preoccupations with different writers - his first work to attract international attention was the 1967 Siebengesang, a sort of hybrid song cycle and oboe concerto to texts by Georg Trakl, while his major projects of the 1970s and 1980s were a cycle of instrumental and choral works dwelling on the life of the poet Holderlin and a trilogy of chamber operas based upon Samuel Beckett. In the 1990s he focused on Walser, which resulted in a song cycle before Holliger began work on the opera.

Walser treats the archetypal characters in the Snow White story as different facets of his own character; there are no dwarfs, alas, but the Queen, the Prince, the Huntsman, the King and Snow White herself go over the events in the fairy tale from new, more knowing perspectives. The narrative is tortuous; there is no catharsis, no resolution. It is spare, intense and often raw-nerved, and Holliger matches its intensity and teasing symmetries with a score of quite breathtaking imagination and crystalline control. He emphasises the compound personality of the protagonists in the opening bars by treating them as a single voice, only gradually allowing them to separate into their own vocal registers.

Their lines leap and dart with improvisational freedom, while the instrumentation surrounds them with a web of delicately coloured counterpoints, with embedded quotations from Couperin, Berg, Schumann and Holliger's own music. The inward-looking world of the text is constantly pushed, expanded and questioned. It is an extraordinary achievement, and a stage work of rich allusiveness and strange, disquieting power. The performance, conducted by Holliger, is masterly, and Juliane Banse in the title role nothing short of superb.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Claire
fields.trailText: I am so glad you are going to Pangkor Laut - it is pure relaxation. Unlike some of the very interesting adventures you have been involved with, Pangkor Laut should be perfect for spending a little time off. Please take a photo of a water monitor lizard, and put it up for my husband and I to look at.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

I am so glad you are going to Pangkor Laut - it is pure relaxation. Unlike some of the very interesting adventures you have been involved with, Pangkor Laut is a bit of a luxury bubble, but it should be perfect for spending a little time off. Please take a photo of a water monitor lizard, and put it up for my husband and I to look at. We went there on our honeymoon, but I also visited Pangkor Laut as a toddler with my parents, before the resort was built. Emerald Bay is one of the most spectacular beaches in the world, and you will have a lovely time.

In the meantime, your travels have inspired me to explore more of Malaysia (where I was born) - your writing has made it seem so close.

Best wishes Claire and Hal, (also hailing from Cambridge).

fields.headline: Unions attack 'pathetic' pay rise
fields.trailText: Union leaders savaged the pay rises awarded to their members today as "stunningly complacent" and a "pathetic patchwork of piecemeal measures" as the Local Government Association questioned the government's ability to deliver the promised increases.
fields.body:
Union leaders savaged the pay rises awarded to their members today as "stunningly complacent" and a "pathetic patchwork of piecemeal measures" as the Local Government Association questioned the government's ability to deliver the promised increases.

The basic rate rise of 3.7%, with more for London teachers, new recruits and less experienced members of staff, was attacked by David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, as "both too little and too late". "3.7% will do nothing to stop the surge of experienced senior staff leaving the profession," he added, going on to describe the teachers' pay review body as a 'government poodle".

However, LGA chairman Graham Lane suggested that council tax bills would have to rise by 10% to accommodate the rises. The Department for Education and Employment costs the rises at £564m for England and Wales.

Teaching unions also compared the pay settlement unfavourably to the recent award of 10%, and a maximum 35-hour week, for Scottish teachers. "It is completely illogical and outrageous for teachers in England and Wales to have unlimited working time whilst their colleagues in Scotland are being given an overall limit of 35 hours per week together with guaranteed preparation time," said Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers.

But education secretary David Blunkett claimed such a deal would be "difficult and cumbersome to administer." Instead, he produced a detailed analysis of what he described as a reduction in "needless bureaucracy". The number of documents sent to secondary schools last year had been cut by two-thirds, he said, and the largest item sent to primaries was the Grammar Guide - "designed to improve pupils' writing skills, which was widely welcomed."

The recent outcry over teacher shortages in secondaries, where the proportion of unfilled vacancies have risen to 0.8%, has led to a raft of initiatives to encourage new and returning teachers in key subjects. These groups will benefit most from today's announcement, with a significant increase in the London allowances and incentives for teachers prepared to commit themselves to a stint in a more challenging school.

About 150,000 teachers are expected to receive performance pay-related increases worth £2000 this year. These were delayed after a court challenge from the National Union of Teachers last year ruled that the scheme was unlawful.

Today the NUT general secretary, Doug McAvoy, said the government was "living in another world" if it believed the rise could solve the recruitment problem, adding that would-be trainees could earn far better salaries elsewhere.

webTitle: The pay rises at a glance

fields.headline: The pay rises at a glance
fields.standfirst: The DfEE guide to the pay settlements in England and Wales
fields.trailText: Who benefits from the rises? Where and why?
fields.body:
When is the pay rise due?
In April.

Who's going to benefit most?
The biggest beneficiaries will be newly-qualified teachers in inner London whose starting salaries will be £20,000. The inner London allowance has been increased by 30% to acknowledge the city's higher property prices and cost of living - but also to attract more young teachers into areas with a high staff turnover and sometimes difficult conditions.

What about the rest of London?
The outer London allowance rises by almost £500 to nearly £2000. Just outside that is the 'fringe area' where teachers will get £175 more (around £760).

What if you don't teach in London?
The rises vary between 3.7% - for experienced teachers at the top of the pay scale, heads and advanced skills teachers - to 5.9% for new recruits. The rest of the profession will receive something in between the two figures.

Where does performance pay come into all this?
Nearly 200,000 teachers applied for a £2000 performance-related increase last year, and about three-quarters are expected to get it.

But the government will still set salary levels?
Not in every case. Heads will be able to able to offer up to £5000 extra in salary - if they can afford it - to recruit teachers of maths, modern foreign languages and other subjects where there is a shortage. They can also offer staff bonuses to stay in a 'challenging' school for a given period.

I heard that Scottish teachers are getting a lot more.
They are. A 10% flat-rate pay rise awarded by the Scottish parliament and a three-year deal worth 21.5% - plus a guaranteed maximum 35-hour week with 25 hours teaching - is well above the inflation rate of 2.9%. However, salaries have traditionally been much lower in Scotland and the pay of a newly-qualified teacher will still be only £16000 this year, significantly less than in London

webTitle: Teacher recruits to get 6% pay boost

fields.headline: Teacher recruits to get 6% pay boost
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Salaries for new teachers in England and Wales will rise by 6% from April as part of a pay package to be unveiled today which the government will say can help schools ease recruitment problems and reward good teachers.
fields.body:
Salaries for new teachers in England and Wales will rise by 6% from April as part of a pay package to be unveiled today which the government will say can help schools ease recruitment problems and reward good teachers.

Staff in London will also receive increases above the basic rise of 3.7% for all teachers to be announced by David Blunkett, the education secretary.

With the overall pay bill increasing by about 4%, ministers are using the extra money to target critical problems. The government is still failing to meet its targets for recruitment as graduates are attracted by higher salaries offered elsewhere. Ministers are also putting in place measures to support recruitment in areas, particularly in the south-east, which find it hard to attract teachers because of the high cost of housing.

Most new graduate teachers begin on a salary of £16,050. A 6% rise will increase their pay to about £17,000.

All teachers in the capital will receive an increase in the London weighting of about 30%. Added to the extra starting salary, some new teachers in London will earn more than £20,000.

Headteachers will also be given the freedom to reward staff with payments of about £5,000. The move is aimed particularly at helping schools in recruitment blackspots to attract staff in subjects where there is a shortage of teachers.

Mr Blunkett has accepted the findings of the school teachers review body, which makes recommendations on pay.

Ministers accept that vacancies in the home counties are unusually high this year. A new scheme is being piloted to give public sector workers in expensive areas interest-free loans to buy their first homes.

More than 150,000 classroom teachers at the top of their scale, earning £23,958, are also receiving pay rises of £2,000 backdated to last September.

Most of the 200,000 teachers who applied for the threshold payments under a new performance-related pay scheme will receive them. Unions insist these payments should be seen separately from the overall pay deal.

With the forthcoming general election in mind, ministers will say that a classroom teacher who earned about £21,500 in 1997 and who has won the threshold payment will now earn nearly £27,000. Starting salaries will have increased by more than £3,000 nationwide and by about £4,000 in London.

However, the flat-rate rise has already been condemned by teacher unions as "paltry". The National Union of Teachers has called for a 12.5% rise and an independent inquiry into teachers' pay.

The unions say recruitment problems are not confined to London and the south-east. Supply teacher agencies around the country have reported more inquiries than ever.

This week the Department for Education and Employment's emergency unit to deal with shortages was called into action to help a school in Middlesbrough, Brackenhoe sec ondary, which had to send more than 100 pupils home for three days after illness hit staffing, which was already down because of two vacancies.

Scottish teachers last month won a 10% flat-rate pay rise and a deal that will see them earning 21.5% extra in three years. Ministers say that teachers north of the border have long lagged behind on pay. Starting salaries in Scotland are going up 10% to £16,005 this year - still behind England and Wales - and will reach £18,000 by August 2003.

Classroom teachers at the top of the scale are going up to £25,644 this year and £28,707 by 2003. Scottish teachers have also been promised a maximum 35-hour working week and the phasing-in of a maximum 25 hours "contact time" in front of the classroom. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said that a similar deal on conditions in England and Wales "could transform the atmosphere overnight".

The NUT and NASUWT are balloting members in London on action that would see them refusing to cover for absences caused by schools being unable to fill staff vacancies.

The number of teachers in post has increased by 7,500 since 1998. The number of trainee teachers has gone up by 2,250 this year, the first rise for eight years.

webTitle: Welsh NHS plan to widen access to free prescriptions

fields.headline: Welsh NHS plan to widen access to free prescriptions
fields.trailText: Wales has taken a further step away from Westminster control with the announcement of a radical NHS reforms package that includes plans to make free prescriptions more widely available than in England. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Wales has taken a further step away from Westminster control with the announcement of a radical NHS reforms package that includes plans to make free prescriptions more widely available than in England.

The Welsh NHS plan proposes to freeze prescription charges at current levels and provide free prescriptions and dental checks to all under the age of 25. In England, free prescriptions are available to those under 18 or in full-time education.

The reforms programme also includes the retention of community health councils - the local patient watchdog bodies that are to be abolished by England for being too outdated.

First minister Rhodri Morgan will today formally introduce the plan as "re-launch of the NHS in Wales" that will transform the health of Welsh people and drive up the quality NHS services.

But the Welsh NHS confederation, which represents trusts and health authorities in the principality, warned that the reforms must be fully costed, and must be properly funded.

The plan abolishes Wales' five health authorities and effectively brings NHS strategic planning under direct control of the Welsh assembly.

A raft of initiatives will be introduced to put patients at the centre of health care provision and decision making, and to give local authorities more of a say in health planning.

The health authorities' commissioning role will taken on by GP-led local health groups - the Welsh equivalent of English primary care groups.

The plan also heralds the closure of "traditional" local hospitals and their replacement with new forms of secondary care provision. A health and well-being partnership council, chaired by assembly health minister Jane Hutt, is to be created to implement the reforms.

webTitle: Former Melody Maker editor joins Later

fields.headline: Former Melody Maker editor joins Later
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Mark Sutherland, ex-editor of Melody Maker, has joined men's magazine Later as deputy editor. By Dan Milmo.
Feb 1: IPC reviews men's title
fields.body:
Mark Sutherland, ex-editor of the defunct rock weekly Melody Maker, has joined men's magazine Later as deputy editor.

The IPC monthly is undergoing a revamp in a bid to open up its target market of ageing Loaded readers.

Mike Soutar, IPC managing director, has admitted that Later needs a "killer application" to take it above its current ABC circulation of 77,000 copies.

"I'm very pleased to be joining a great magazine like Later, especially at such an exciting time for the title," said Mr Sutherland.

Mr Sutherland lost his job when Melody Maker was merged with weekly rival NME at the end of last year.

IPC's music and sports portfolio was recently renamed IPC ignite! as part of a senior management shake-up.

"We are particularly pleased to welcome Mark to the title as we were committed to retaining as much editorial talent as possible when we merged Melody Maker with NME. This is the most tangible proof of that talent," said Eric Fuller, publishing director of Later.

Mr Fuller added that Later needs to improve its performance, but it remains the only men's magazine devoted to the thirtysomething market.

"We are out there defining the market and there is no one else that we can learn from. We have a bigger circulation than Esquire and Arena, but we want that to grow," he said.

fields.bodyText: Mark Sutherland, ex-editor of the defunct rock weekly Melody Maker, has joined men's magazine Later as deputy editor. The IPC monthly is undergoing a revamp in a bid to open up its target market of ageing Loaded readers. Mike Soutar, IPC managing director, has admitted that Later needs a "killer application" to take it above its current ABC circulation of 77,000 copies. "I'm very pleased to be joining a great magazine like Later, especially at such an exciting time for the title," said Mr Sutherland. Mr Sutherland lost his job when Melody Maker was merged with weekly rival NME at the end of last year. IPC's music and sports portfolio was recently renamed IPC ignite! as part of a senior management shake-up. "We are particularly pleased to welcome Mark to the title as we were committed to retaining as much editorial talent as possible when we merged Melody Maker with NME. This is the most tangible proof of that talent," said Eric Fuller, publishing director of Later. Mr Fuller added that Later needs to improve its performance, but it remains the only men's magazine devoted to the thirtysomething market. "We are out there defining the market and there is no one else that we can learn from. We have a bigger circulation than Esquire and Arena, but we want that to grow," he said.
