fields.headline: Price cuts cost Scotsman £5m
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Andrew Neil's newspaper group has reported record sales at huge financial cost, report Lisa O'Carroll and Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The relaunch of the Scotsman has cost Andrew Neil's newspaper group up to £5m with between £2m and £2.5m of that on the aggressive price-cutting strategy.

Mr Neil said while sales of his group's flagship broadsheet daily have rocketed by 33% - breaking the 100,000 barrier for the first time in the title's history - there had been a significant financial cost.

At a reception held in London to celebrate the sales increase, Mr Neil said the risky strategy had been essential.

"We had to blow the paper up and start again or someone else would have blown us up," he said.

The price-cutting represents between £2m and £2.5m of the total relaunch costs which included the building of the second section S2, the development of the business section and the hiring of staff and a publicity drive.

The Scotsman's circulation between July and December last year - which Mr Neil claimed was the industry "gold standard" - now stands at just over 100,000.

This was up from 75,000 in January last year.

Sales also doubled in the difficult Strathclyde market, which is dominated by Glasgow-based rival the Herald.

Mr Neil said sales of the Scotsman would have sunk below 70,000 had he not dropped the cover price, brought in new editor Rebecca Hardy and refocused the editorial last May.

"Now we are the biggest selling newspaper in Scotland," he said. "That's something the Scotsman has not been able to say in 184 years."

For the first time, the paper has recorded a higher Scottish circulation than the combined sales of the five London-based broadsheet dailies.

The Scotsman is now the "one-stop shop" for London advertisers that want to reach the Scottish broadsheet readership, Mr Neil said.

He is also planning changes at Sunday Business, which is also controlled by the Scotsman's owners, Frederick and David Barclay.

The business paper's circulation has fallen since the cover price was doubled to £1.

Mr Neil said he wanted to make Sunday Business a commercial success to match its critical success.

The Barclay brothers want to give the paper a "younger feel" and are worried the paper's readers are too old.

Former Express columnist Topaz Amoore has joined to edit the paper's magazine section.

MediaGuardian.co.uk has learned the brothers are also considering launching a website for Sunday Business.

The site would challenge the Financial Times, which dominates the online business sector with its hugely successful FT.com.

However, to sustain credibility, a Sunday Business website would have to be maintained on a daily basis - a move that may prove prohibitively expensive.

fields.headline: The Corus crisis
fields.standfirst: Steel giant Corus is to lay off 6,050 workers, and says more jobs may be cut. But there is not much government and the unions can do about it, explains Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Steel giant Corus is to lay off 6,050 workers, and says more jobs may be cut. We explain why there is not much government and the unions can do about it.
fields.body:
Why is Corus sacking so many people?
The company says it has to cut its losses, which are running at more than £1bn a year. It cites three reasons for the losses: sagging demand for steel in the UK, cheap imports, and the expense of exporting. Both the latter are, of course, largely down to the relative strength of the pound against the currencies of important steel producing and consuming countries.

Is British steel production inefficient?
Far from it. The plant at Llanwern in south Wales, which will be most badly hit by the job cuts, is one of the most productive in the Anglo-Dutch group, which was formed by the amalgamation of the privatised British Steel and Hoogovens.

So why doesn't Corus sack some Dutch workers?
Because it's much simpler and cheaper to sack British ones. Successive governments have spent years whittling away at workers' rights, in the name of "flexibility". Job security is a no-no in the free market age.

Still, aren't the job losses a bit embarrassing for a Labour government?
Yes - and very, very badly timed: there's an election coming. And the government is genuinely furious with Corus for refusing to consult ministers on its plans.

South Wales is still solid for Labour, isn't it?
It has been for 100 years. But of late, Plaid Cymru has been making inroads. The Party of Wales (it doesn't care to use words like 'nationalist' these days) has been quick to exploit Labour's embarrassment. Its former leader Dafydd Wigley is calling on Tony Blair to take over the steel industry - though he was careful to avoid another alarming word, 'nationalisation'.

Any chance of that happening?
None whatsoever. This is new Labour, remember.

So what can the government do?
Precious little, except tidy up a little after the mess. It is barred by EU competition rules from subsidising Corus directly. It could chip in with grants for research and development, offer business rate relief, and perhaps buy some excess land. But at best such measures would be worth less than £80m to Corus - a drop in the ocean compared with 6,050 annual salaries. It's also pretty modest compared with the likely bill for unemployment benefits and other welfare payments.

Couldn't the government do something about the exchange rate?
It could, of course, come off the fence and shoo us into the euro-zone. Or it could take back control of sterling from the Bank of England, and slash interest rates to aid exporters. But neither course is politically acceptable.

How are the unions responding to the crisis?
Convenors from steel factories across the country are meeting in emergency session today. The industry's biggest union, the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, is discussing its next move. It has withdrawn its tentative offer to take over the Llanwern plant, because Corus is keeping it open, albeit in drastically scaled-down form. Urgent talks are also being held at the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union. The unions hope to persuade Sir Brian Moffat, Corus chairman, that there could be other ways to cut company losses. He has given them two weeks to come up with new ideas.

Isn't that a hint that he might think again?
No. He's not noted for that. Indeed, far from hinting that the jobs might be reprieved, Sir Brian (who once famously remarked: "I'm interested in making money, not steel") has bluntly warned that even more might be lost. Yet oddly enough he also insists that he is acting to safeguard the jobs of the 22,000 Corus workers who will remain after the cuts.

webTitle: Quake dead burned to ward off disease

fields.headline: Quake dead burned to ward off disease
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Two flights from Britain carrying emergency aid to the victims of last Friday's earthquake in western India touched down in the town of Bhuj last night as soldiers went on grimly digging bodies from the rubble, fearful that contamination may breed disease.
fields.body:
Two flights from Britain carrying emergency aid to the victims of last Friday's earthquake in western India touched down in the town of Bhuj last night as soldiers went on grimly digging bodies from the rubble, fearful that contamination may breed disease.

Other states in India have promised to help rebuild towns in the state of Gujarat to spread the enormous cost. But most observers believe that large parts of the three towns worst affected - Bhuj, Bhachau and Anjar - will simply have to be bulldozed.

The aid flights by the British Red Cross brought 10 tonnes of blankets, and tents, plastic sheeting, an emergency hospital unit and two vehicles. The "immediate" relief operation will last at least four months, such is the scale of the disaster, Red Cross officials predict.

Relief workers are now trying to distribute essential medicines and shelter to the half million people left homeless by the earthquake, which killed at least 20,000.

While aid has poured into Bhuj, the historic town closest to the epicentre, almost nothing has reached the remote villages to the north, where food and water are running out.

The International Federation of the Red Cross said it was appealing for £10m in donations.

The 60 British rescue workers left Bhuj last night. Firemen from Lancashire, Lincolnshire and Greater Manchester, they rescued six people with the help of dogs, fibre-optic cable and "vibraphones" that detect movement.

"Our brief of search and rescue is basically finished. We have not found anyone else, but I would not be surprised if after 10 days some people are still discovered alive," a team member, Mike Thomas, said.

In Bhachau, the town worst affected, teams were still retrieving the dead yesterday while volunteers from Bombay burned the bodies on pyres of wood lit by paraffin.

"Our main task is to dispose of the dead as quickly as possible," said Subhash Dalvi, one of the volunteers. "We are very concerned about the spread of disease."

At Dhanraj apartments, close to the town's obliterated market, Trambak Shah, a garment exporter from Bombay, watched Indian soldiers trying to retrieve his dead parents. He had been due to return to Bhachau last Friday, but missed his train and was delayed until after the quake.

Incredibly, rescuers are still digging out survivors who have been in tiny dark spaces without water for six days. In Bhachau a 17-year-old boy, Ghanshyam Sadhu, was rescued after 132 hours. A seven-month-old girl was found alive beside her mother's body.

"The boy had scratches on his elbows and knees but was totally OK," Nilkamal Joshi, a doctor running a field hospital in the town, said. "He was completely disoriented and thought it was still Friday evening. He was crying for water and shouting: 'The thirst is killing me. Death is better than thirst.' "

Dr Joshi, a volunteer from the city of Ahmedabad, where 500 people were killed, said there was now a fear that gastro-enteritis and diarrhoea would set in.

Yesterday householders in Bhuj's old city were busy carting away their belongings by donkey, while in Bhachau furniture, television sets, and plastic chairs were being shifted by camel.

Police officers admit that looting was widespread and that bogus volunteers had been making off with jewellery, cash, and watches from the broken shops and homes of the dead.

"There is not much we can do about it," one said.

Bhuj woke up yesterday at 5.00am to another aftershock. Electricity has been restored to some parts of the city, but there is still no running water. Most people are still sleeping outside: astrologers in Bombay have predicted another large earthquake on February 13.

fields.headline: Granada shares plunge
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Shares in Granada have dived amid fears of another profit warning from ITV's dominant broadcaster, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in Granada have plummeted amid fears of another profit warning from ITV's dominant broadcaster.

Granada shares today fell 5.7% to 197p on speculation the company will admit worsening advertising sales growth at its annual general meeting next week.

Granada's shares have almost halved in value since September, when the company first issued warnings about ad sales growth.

Granada and ITV rival Carlton Communications have found it impossible to match the bumper advertising revenues generataed in the last six months of 1999.

During that period, the dot.com boom poured money into broadcasters' pockets.

Analysts now talk of a "recession" in ITV advertising sales, with March figures expected to show a drastic double-digit decline.

February sales could fall by as much as 6.5% compared with the same period last year.

"Advertising growth was negative at the end of last year and, for the first half of this year, the comparative figures will get tougher," said one analyst.

"The growth will still be very slow."

However, ad sales growth is expected to recover in the second half of the year as the Premier League highlights move from the BBC to ITV.

The Granada Group's media and hospitality arms have now separated, with Granada Media now trading under the Granada name.

fields.headline: Hartson deal off again
fields.trailText: John Hartson's on-off transfer from Wimbledon to Coventry has fallen through again.
fields.body:
John Hartson's on-off transfer from Wimbledon to Coventry has fallen through again.

Hartson's agent Jonathan Barnett revealed this morning that Coventry's new pay-as-you-play offer for the Welsh striker, reported in this morning's papers, had never got off the ground.

Barnett said the £5m deal was based on "ifs, whats and maybes" and would not be going through. Instead Hartson would be staying at Wimbledon until the summer at least.

Coventry's chairman Bryan Richardson said that because Coventry could not obtain insurance on Hartson for the full transfer fee and "associated costs", he would not commit the club to such a deal.

"For historical reasons," he said, presumably referring to Hartson's old knee problems, "we have been unable to secure the necessary insurance cover. As a result it is with great sadness that we will not be signing John Hartson."

Wimbledon confirmed the news, with chief executive David Barnard admitting that further doubts have been raised over Hartson's fitness.

"We are naturally disappointed that we have been unable to conclude John's transfer to Coventry but we fully understand their position in relation to the insurance," Barnard admitted.

"Everyone knows that, with the exception of a cracked rib, John has been fit to train and play all season and we have no doubt that he still has a long and successful career ahead of him," he added.

Hartson's move to Coventry first broke down last month when Cedric Roussel refused to move to Selhurst Park as the makeweight in a £5m deal.

fields.headline: Nielsen: Symphony No 5
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Nielsen's Symphony No 5.
fields.body:
The two most popular and most fully achieved of Carl Nielsen's, the Fourth and the Fifth, are concerned with struggle on a massive and ultimately affirmative scale. The Fourth was realised during the first world war and the Fifth, composed in 1921 and 1922, seems to deal with the aftershocks of that cataclysm.

In the first movement the drama is brought visibly as well as musically to life in a battle between the orchestra and a renegade side-drummer, who can only be silenced by the full forces of his colleagues in the final bars. The second movement continues the struggle in a pair of sinewy, striving fugues, before the final victory is achieved, though not entirely without some shivers of anxiety.

Versions conducted by Paavo Berglund with the Royal Danish Orchestra (RCA), Neeme Jarvi with the Gothenburg Symphony (Deutsche Grammophon) and Bryden Thomson with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra (Chandos) are all in their different ways totally truthful, while for a taste of authentic performing style there is the transfer of the historic performance conducted by Thomas Jensen, who played under the composer himself (Dutton). But it is Herbert Blomstedt, with the San Francisco Symphony, who steers the steadiest, most satisfying course though the work's cataclysms and pools of tranquility.

Key recording: Blomstedt (Decca 421 524-2)

Versions conducted by Paavo Berglund with the Royal Danish Orchestra (RCA), Neeme Jarvi with the Gothenburg Symphony (Deutsche Grammophon) and Bryden Thomson with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra (Chandos) are all in their different ways totally truthful, while for a taste of authentic performing style there is the transfer of the historic performance conducted by Thomas Jensen, who played under the composer himself (Dutton). But it is Herbert Blomstedt, with the San Francisco Symphony, who steers the steadiest, most satisfying course though the work's cataclysms and pools of tranquility. Key recording: Blomstedt (Decca 421 524-2)

webTitle: Faisal Bodi attacks the media for excluding Muslims

fields.headline: We suspect a plot
fields.standfirst:
What do Jungle Janes, Big Brother and The Mole have in common? They are a Muslim-free zone

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: What do Jungle Janes, Big Brother and The Mole have in common? They are a Muslim-free zone, writes Faisal Bodi.
fields.body:
Applications for the second Big Brother show must be in by the end of next week. I confess I was tempted to apply. Not for the fame and prize money but for the chance to conduct an experiment within an experiment: how long would a Muslim last in a non-Muslim household whose residents are eliminated by a TV audience? What quality of relationship would I enjoy with my housemates? Would I fit in?

On the face of it, the Big Brother house sounds like the perfect laboratory in which to test out how accommodating and accepting our society is towards its Muslim citizens. But in practice it's a non-starter. The total surrender of privacy required of contestants makes the show prohibitive, not just to Muslims, but everybody with a sense of pride and dignity.

By default, Muslims are excluded from a hugely popular participatory programme. That's nothing new. Channel 4's latest "reality" hits, Jungle Janes and Shipwrecked, and Channel 5's The Mole, contain no Muslims either. Shipwrecked has two homosexuals, recruited no doubt to present a representative sample of young Britons. But if the intention was to get a good cross section of youngsters, the producers have been unforgivably remiss; the youth-weighted age profile of the Muslim community should have meant a preponderance of the group.

You might be right in arguing that reality programming is a lame excuse for swamping us with dumbed-down prime-time entertainment, in which case it is futile to look to them as a guide to society's tolerance levels. Be that as it may, it doesn't avoid the fact that Muslims are invisible in the cultural output of the mass media.

In fact, they might as well not exist. When was the last time you saw a Muslim character on our most popular soaps, EastEnders and Coronation Street, whom you could recognise from your own community?

Having lived in the East End of London and in Manchester, I know that you can't walk down the street in either place without seeing members of what is one of the country's most visible communities. Whether it's a mother walking her children to school draped in a distinctive headscarf, or the sound of the muezzin at the East London Mosque calling the faithful to prayer.

Yet it's all too easy to believe otherwise when we turn on the TV. Much of the action in both flagship soaps takes place in bars which automatically exclude practising Muslims being represented. But a large part of the action also takes place in the street, the markets, the stores and the workplace. Isn't there a way to weave some Muslim characters into the plots?

Of course there are plenty of ways, there's just not the will. The mass media prescribe as well as reflect. What scriptwriters and broadcasters are really saying is that they would prefer if Muslims weren't part of the mini-worlds they are creating; out of sight and out of mind. We're not talking about plain old discrimination here. It's beyond that. The mass media, particularly TV, have developed nothing short of a culture of exclusion. Muslims shouldn't exist.

The new director general of the BBC called the corporation hideously white. Because religion isn't as manifest as race, it escaped his attention that his workforce is also hideously - I would suggest incorrigibly - Islamophobic.

It is evident at all levels, in all departments. I know a senior producer, a convert, who refuses to be known by his Muslim name because he is certain it would jeopardise his progress within the organisation. The handful of practising Muslims who remain in this hostile habitat do so because they were already in contracts when they rediscovered their faith. As for journalists, producers and technical staff who are practising and want to get in - they can forget it.

It has often been mooted that Muslims should withhold their licence fee in protest. Though such a mass boycott would be hard to implement on the ground, the threat of even several thousand Muslims withholding their fee - much as people refused to pay the poll tax - would hammer home a powerful message.

Muslims dutifully pay their licence fees and buy the products advertised on commercial channels (let us not forget these have public obligations too), only to be excluded, stereotyped and misrepresented.

Why do we do it? Well, increasingly we are not and this is another reason broadcasters should sit up and take notice. With the convergence of TV and internet technologies it is becoming more feasible for us to set up television stations of our own. One, Ummah TV, based in Regent Street, is already in development. It adds to the mass of dedicated Muslim news websites that already exist to fill the void.

Giving up on the mainstream is done reluctantly. It means we have lost all hope of becoming part of the common discourse of this nation. But desperate circumstances require desperate measures. The choice facing our community is stark. If we aren't allowed to grow together, we must simply grow apart.

 Faisal Bodi is a British Muslim journalist.

fields.headline: Tube boss wins privatisation victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The new boss of London Underground, Robert Kiley, today struck a deal with the government over the plans to part privatise the tube. The deal represents a major victory for the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, in his fight to control the future of the tube.
fields.body:
The new boss of London Underground, Robert Kiley, today struck a deal with the government over the plans to part privatise the tube. The deal represents a major victory for the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, in his fight to control the future of the tube.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, will hand over partial control of the tube plans to Mr Kiley, who has been highly critical of the government's plans to sell off London Underground to a public private partnership (PPP). The decision comes after months of intense negotiation between the mayor and Mr Prescott who was reluctant to allow Mr Livingstone greater influence in privatisation plans.

Mr Prescott said: "I have asked Mr Kiley to take the lead in working up proposals for modifying the PPP. He will be working closely with the government and London Underground."

The announcement follows lengthy talks yesterday between the Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley amid heavy criticism from unions over privatisation and leaves bidders for the PPP contracts unsure about the future of their deals with the government. Mr Prescott denied that the Government had climbed down over the PPP issue in making this announcement.

The government and Transport for London, which is responsible to the Greater London Council for London's transport system, will jointly evaluate any revised proposals to decide whether they are acceptable.

Mr Kiley - appointed as transport chief by Mr Livingstone last month - has previously called the privatisation plans "unworkable" and has said in the past that there could be no compromise on rejecting the transport secretary's plans to split up control of track and trains. Mr Kiley also said that it was "disturbing" that the government had continued negotiating contracts with private companies without involving those who would manage London's transport.

Mr Kiley and Mr Prescott agreed that the public sector will be heavily involved in the modernisation of the Underground and that a long-term financial commitment is needed for it. Mr Prescott added that involvement from the private sector was still seen as a necessary part of the modernisation programme.

He said: "Bob Kiley is assembling a strong management team in Transport for London. The private sector too can contribute through the PPP to rebuilding the Underground."

Tube train drivers plan to strike on Monday over safety concerns relating to the government's privatisation plans. Mr Livingstone, an outspoken critic of privatisation, is not expected to join the strike as previously thought. He is said to be concerned that his presence on the picket line could jeopardise the tone of talks with the government.

Last month, government railway inspectors rejected Mr Prescott's plans on safety grounds, saying they "do not provide us with confidence that there is a safety management process in place to reduce the risks."

Implementation of PPP plans will be delayed for up to three months as a result of calls for more detailed talks.

"He will enter into discussion with the bidders with our full co-operation. We do not envisage this going into months of delay. It is at the first stage now and it will not take very long to decide if he has a solution for London and for Ken Livingstone," Mr Prescott said today.

He added: "We are going to look at all the details and Mr Kiley will be given all the information to make a judgement. We are not hiding behind commercial concerns."

Special report
Livingstone's London

fields.headline: Controversial council chief executive sacked
fields.trailText: A controversial council chief executive has been sacked from her £70,000-a-year job for gross misconduct after a year of wrangling over her future.
fields.body:
A controversial council chief executive has been sacked from her £70,000-a-year job for gross misconduct after a year of wrangling over her future.

An independent report concludes that relationships between Eastbourne borough council's Sari Conway and other chief officers at the authority had broken down, and lays the "major blame" at the chief executive's door.

According to a summary of the report, Mrs Conway faced three allegations: That she had adopted a "destructive, divisive and aggressive management style", maintained "inappropriate personal relationships" and failed to provide "proper leadership" on implementing the council's anti-bullying strategy.

Report author and former Association of Metropolitan Councils secretary Rodney Brooke says not all the allegations were well-founded: "I find some unjustified. Others I find relate to capacity rather than misconduct."

Mr Brooke does not, however, make clear which accusations he believes to be true.

He concludes: "The evidence before me has substantiated a sufficient number of instances of misconduct to support the council's allegation that a pattern of behaviour has been established which amounts to gross misconduct."

Mrs Conway yesterday offered to resign, but councillors refused to consider the move. At a meeting last night they unanimously endorsed the report's chief recommendation that Mrs Conway should be fired without notice.

Leader Graham Marsden said: "The council has a responsibility to ensure that Eastbourne council is properly managed and the degree of cross-party consensus in this matter shows how seriously councillors have taken their responsibilities. Her behaviour was wholly at odds with the standards required of a local authority chief executive."

Mrs Conway hit back yesterday, saying her desire to make changes in the East Sussex town may have made others feel "vulnerable". In a statement released through Unison, she said: "I only ever set out to ensure the people of Eastbourne received the highest level of service within a carefully controlled budget.

"I am proud of my many achievements in the public sector, trying to bring about change. This can cause others to feel vulnerable.

"I am sorry to be leaving Eastbourne in these circumstances and would like to thank the hundreds of people who have supported me publicly and privately throughout the last year, which has taken a heavy toll on my own and my family's health."

Mrs Conway, a former home economics teacher, was suspended a year ago on full pay following complaints from four senior council officers about her aggressive management style.

The report says Mrs Conway was a "major cause of the extraordinary length of these proceedings", which she postponed for a month due to ill health.

It adds: "A local authority controls many aspects of the life of a community. It must maintain absolute standards. The job of a local authority chief executive is high profile. It demands fortitude and commitment as well as integrity."

Mrs Conway became the council's first female chief executive in 1995, and rapidly became well known in the town, appearing on the BBC series Changing Rooms in 1999, where she swapped homes with Conservative councillor Mark Roberts, owner of the Belle Tout lighthouse at Beachy Head.

fields.headline: Boots drops men's grooming for unisex salons
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Boots is ditching its standalone men's grooming salons in favour of unisex health, beauty and fitness stores, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Boots the Chemist is to abandon its standalone men's grooming salons in favour of rolling out unisex health, beauty and fitness stores.

The u-turn comes after a boom in the male grooming product market, estimated to be worth £700m a year, encouraged companies to aggressively target men with specialised beauty products and services.

Unilever-owned Elida Faberge brand Lynx opened a men's salon on Oxford Street last September offering haircuts, manicures, massages and shaves.

Another Lynx store opened yesterday in Kingston and one more is planned.

Boots launched two pilot men's stores in Bristol and Edinburgh but has decided to turn them into unisex outlets offering a range of services including dental, optical and homeopathic treatment areas.

The unisex concept has been trialled at stores in London's High Street Kensington and Milton Keynes and will be rolled out to three other locations, including Manchester, in the spring and summer.

fields.headline: The togs of war
fields.standfirst: Throw out those ostentatious outfits you splurged on last year, guys. Conspicuous consumption has been overthrown. Adrian Clark reports on a military uprising on the catwalks of Paris and Milan
fields.trailText: Throw out those ostentatious outfits you splurged on last year, guys. Conspicuous consumption has been overthrown. Adrian Clark reports on a military uprising on the catwalks of Paris and Milan.
fields.body:
Posh & Becks, Jennifer and Puff, DJs buying Ferraris for pop stars who don't look old enough to have left school, quiz shows offering untold wealth, the airing of Elton's monogrammed laundry in court - the first year of the new century saw conspicuous consumption move into overdrive. In fashion, the buzzword was logomania. The rise of ghetto fabulous, the demise of understated: the message was, if it looks expensive and it is expensive, buy it.

But fashion speeds on and a revolution is already in the air. The autumn/winter collections for men, shown in Milan and Paris over the past fortnight, have been a battleground for change. Military is the new direction for the style-conscious man. This is a revolt on a scale not witnessed since the last utilitarian uprising over a decade ago, when the combat trouser held the power suit to ransom in reaction to the "Dynasty boom" of the 80s. Epaulettes, distressed, beaten, boiled and gunshot fabrics, lean and strict silhouettes and heavy boots are all on the front line. Camouflage is the hot new print; medals replace sovereigns.

Miu Miu, Miuccia Prada's diffusion line, Jil Sander, Roberto Cavalli, Iceberg and Raf Simons (back after a season's leave of absence) led the troops in this overwhelming trend. Miu Miu used boiled military wools for neatly proportioned coats and double-breasted field jackets. Sander's storm trooper coats brushed the floor, worn with trousers tucked into boots. Iceberg took its lead from Action Man with camouflage-print shirt and trouser combos, and knits featuring bullet holes.

Roberto Cavalli was less literal, with a more playful spin on the look: distressed battledress and army surplus separates embroidered with roses. Raf Simons layered padded flight jackets over field coats and wrapped his models' faces with guerrilla warfare scarves. Even Gianfranco Ferre, more at home with polish without the spit, put epaulettes on his architecturally structured suits and draped camouflage-printed satin parkas over the shoulders of his tuxedos.

Yohji Yamamoto looked to Red Square for inspiration, using boiled scarlet wool for high-buttoned jackets, with a soundtrack of a continuous drum roll. Marc Jacobs presented his strongest collection to date for Louis Vuitton, keeping the formula simple with luxurious reefer coats and drummer boy jackets in French navy with red buttonholes, and dress shirts in red and white stripes.

A younger, more irreverent take on the military trend came from D&G (Dolce & Gabbana's diffusion line), who added gold epaulettes to sweaters and juxtaposed Napoleonic coats with distressed jeans, and by Moschino, who reworked national flags. Meanwhile, young American designer Sandy Dalal scribbled anti-war messages across T-shirts.

Giorgio Armani hosted a party in Milan for the launch of an exhibition of military fashion through the ages, but did not himself stray from his formula of soft tailoring and toughened leather blousons. Martin Margiela offered us whitewashed jeans, suede trench coats and mismatched suits where the trousers had been washed and the jackets dry-cleaned.

Dries van Noten began his show with slick Wall Street tailoring before delving into trailer trash with roadie cut-away Aertex vests and hipster pants that flared out to a boot-cut at the ankle. This was a much more adult and camp look than we have come to expect from van Noten, famed for his schoolboy classics. As one department store buyer described the collection: "The Dries boy has finally reached puberty, realised he is gay and there ain't no stoppin' him."

Decades after he bounced on to the scene, Jean Paul Gaultier is still challenging the restrictions of men's fashion. Mixing antique lace trim with biker leathers, this collection was vintage Gaultier. Paul Smith took to the Aspen ski slopes for a colourful take on winter wonderland dressing. Bubble-gum pink bouclé coats, Fair Isle ski sweaters in candy colours and a mix of tweeds with velvet worked for him.

Also using colour to effect was Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garçons, who mixed graffiti prints in techno brights for tailoring and reworked the trench coat in dusty pink velvet, leaving the hem to brush the floor. Kostas Murkudis layered oriental silk brocade cut-off trousers over traditional suit ings, while British-based Daniel Margolin (now big in the US) paired grape and hot pink leather varsity jackets and campus knits with city suits.

Dolce & Gabbana put together a complete wardrobe for today's playboy. Horsey prints on silk shirts and velvet jackets, city boy pinstripe suits and racy formula one leather jackets owed more to the pursuits of inherited wealth than to the gigolo style the duo has flaunted in previous seasons. Donatella Versace was one of the few designers who did go down the ghetto fabulous route, with a mainline collection of quilted caramel leathers and almond-coloured, entrance-making tailoring. For younger line Versus, however, the temperature was turned up for a hard-edged, sexy take on op-art dressing.

Fendi avoided its usual explosions of colour to layer textures of earthy shades, nearly always cinched at the waist. Burberry Prorsum Collection looked strong, marrying mountaineering sportswear detailing with urban classics. Missoni took itssignature knits one stage further, mixing plain yarns with Lurex; Issey Miyake mixed stripes with ease, while Gigli showed some of the most beautiful tailoring of the season. Nicole Farhi and Prada took the "nice, wearable classics" theme too literally.

The season really belonged to two labels. Gucci, designed by Tom Ford, and Dior, now under the direction of ex-YSL designer Hedi Slimane, could not be faulted. While very different, these two collections summed up the mood of the season ahead and moved men's fashion ahead by light years.

Ford, who also created his first catwalk show for Yves Saint Laurent, presented his best Gucci collection to date. Everything was desirable and everything was luxurious, right down to the distressed jeans with a gold G embroidered on the back pocket. From the silk shirts in icing sugar pink, with a chocolate floral print, to the nappa leather flat caps, the whole experience was mouthwatering.

Dior was awarded a well-deserved standing ovation, including Slimane's ex-employer Yves Saint Laurent himself who sat at the centre of the front row. The sympathy with which Slimane's tailoring was cut was breathtaking. His leather moulded to the body, single corsages of roses hung around the models' torsos on strands of fine leather or silk ribbon, while shirts of dove grey (Dior's house colour) showed the diversity of this designer's talents. Fashion does not get much better than this.

 Adrian Clark is fashion director of Loaded.

Epaulettes, distressed, beaten, boiled and gunshot fabrics, lean and strict silhouettes and heavy boots are all on the front line. Camouflage is the hot new print; medals replace sovereigns. Miu Miu, Miuccia Prada's diffusion line, Jil Sander, Roberto Cavalli, Iceberg and Raf Simons (back after a season's leave of absence) led the troops in this overwhelming trend. Miu Miu used boiled military wools for neatly proportioned coats and double-breasted field jackets. Sander's storm trooper coats brushed the floor, worn with trousers tucked into boots. Iceberg took its lead from Action Man with camouflage-print shirt and trouser combos, and knits featuring bullet holes. Roberto Cavalli was less literal, with a more playful spin on the look: distressed battledress and army surplus separates embroidered with roses. Raf Simons layered padded flight jackets over field coats and wrapped his models' faces with guerrilla warfare scarves. Even Gianfranco Ferre, more at home with polish without the spit, put epaulettes on his architecturally structured suits and draped camouflage-printed satin parkas over the shoulders of his tuxedos. Yohji Yamamoto looked to Red Square for inspiration, using boiled scarlet wool for high-buttoned jackets, with a soundtrack of a continuous drum roll. Marc Jacobs presented his strongest collection to date for Louis Vuitton, keeping the formula simple with luxurious reefer coats and drummer boy jackets in French navy with red buttonholes, and dress shirts in red and white stripes. A younger, more irreverent take on the military trend came from D&G (Dolce & Gabbana's diffusion line), who added gold epaulettes to sweaters and juxtaposed Napoleonic coats with distressed jeans, and by Moschino, who reworked national flags. Meanwhile, young American designer Sandy Dalal scribbled anti-war messages across T-shirts. Giorgio Armani hosted a party in Milan for the launch of an exhibition of military fashion through the ages, but did not himself stray from his formula of soft tailoring and toughened leather blousons. Martin Margiela offered us whitewashed jeans, suede trench coats and mismatched suits where the trousers had been washed and the jackets dry-cleaned. Dries van Noten began his show with slick Wall Street tailoring before delving into trailer trash with roadie cut-away Aertex vests and hipster pants that flared out to a boot-cut at the ankle. This was a much more adult and camp look than we have come to expect from van Noten, famed for his schoolboy classics. As one department store buyer described the collection: "The Dries boy has finally reached puberty, realised he is gay and there ain't no stoppin' him." Decades after he bounced on to the scene, Jean Paul Gaultier is still challenging the restrictions of men's fashion. Mixing antique lace trim with biker leathers, this collection was vintage Gaultier. Paul Smith took to the Aspen ski slopes for a colourful take on winter wonderland dressing. Bubble-gum pink bouclé coats, Fair Isle ski sweaters in candy colours and a mix of tweeds with velvet worked for him. Also using colour to effect was Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garçons, who mixed graffiti prints in techno brights for tailoring and reworked the trench coat in dusty pink velvet, leaving the hem to brush the floor. Kostas Murkudis layered oriental silk brocade cut-off trousers over traditional suit ings, while British-based Daniel Margolin (now big in the US) paired grape and hot pink leather varsity jackets and campus knits with city suits. Dolce & Gabbana put together a complete wardrobe for today's playboy. Horsey prints on silk shirts and velvet jackets, city boy pinstripe suits and racy formula one leather jackets owed more to the pursuits of inherited wealth than to the gigolo style the duo has flaunted in previous seasons. Donatella Versace was one of the few designers who did go down the ghetto fabulous route, with a mainline collection of quilted caramel leathers and almond-coloured, entrance-making tailoring. For younger line Versus, however, the temperature was turned up for a hard-edged, sexy take on op-art dressing. Fendi avoided its usual explosions of colour to layer textures of earthy shades, nearly always cinched at the waist. Burberry Prorsum Collection looked strong, marrying mountaineering sportswear detailing with urban classics. Missoni took itssignature knits one stage further, mixing plain yarns with Lurex; Issey Miyake mixed stripes with ease, while Gigli showed some of the most beautiful tailoring of the season. Nicole Farhi and Prada took the "nice, wearable classics" theme too literally. The season really belonged to two labels. Gucci, designed by Tom Ford, and Dior, now under the direction of ex-YSL designer Hedi Slimane, could not be faulted. While very different, these two collections summed up the mood of the season ahead and moved men's fashion ahead by light years. Ford, who also created his first catwalk show for Yves Saint Laurent, presented his best Gucci collection to date. Everything was desirable and everything was luxurious, right down to the distressed jeans with a gold G embroidered on the back pocket. From the silk shirts in icing sugar pink, with a chocolate floral print, to the nappa leather flat caps, the whole experience was mouthwatering. Dior was awarded a well-deserved standing ovation, including Slimane's ex-employer Yves Saint Laurent himself who sat at the centre of the front row. The sympathy with which Slimane's tailoring was cut was breathtaking. His leather moulded to the body, single corsages of roses hung around the models' torsos on strands of fine leather or silk ribbon, while shirts of dove grey (Dior's house colour) showed the diversity of this designer's talents. Fashion does not get much better than this.  Adrian Clark is fashion director of Loaded.

webTitle: Lord Dubs takes helm at broadcast watchdog

fields.headline: Lord Dubs takes helm at broadcast watchdog
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Culture secretary Chris Smith has appointed Lords Dubs chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith has appointed Lords Dubs chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission.

The position has been vacant since the previous incumbent, Lord Holme, was forced to resign in October following Sunday newspaper revelations about his private life.

Lord Dubs is a former deputy chairman of the BSC and also of the Independent Television Commission.

He will serve a three-year term as BSC head, starting this month.

Lord Dubs takes the helm as the regulator faces an uncertain future.

The communications white paper, published in December, proposed the BSC be merged with other broadcasting and telecoms regulators to form a single communications watchdog.

Mr Smith said: "Lord Dubs' strong leadership qualities, experience of the broadcast media and sensitivity to the views of the public will enable him to make an important contribution to the work of the BSC."

The three-days-a-week job of BSC chairman comes with an annual salary of £49,502.

webTitle: In brief: Cate Blanchett to play Veronica Guerin

fields.headline: Cate Blanchett to play Veronica Guerin
fields.standfirst: Plus: Tarantino takes drastic measures to lure Thurman; another award ceremony launched; Haley Joel Osment honoured with gong; Tea Leoni joins star line-up for Woody Allen
fields.trailText: Plus: Tarantino takes drastic measures to lure Thurman; another award ceremony launched; Haley Joel Osment honoured with gong; Tea Leoni joins star line-up for Woody Allen
fields.body:
 The Irish Times reports that Cate Blanchett (pictured) will play Veronica Guerin in Chasing the Dragon: The Veronica Guerin Story, to be directed by Joel Schumacher. In 1996, the crusading Irish journalist was shot dead in Dublin by the pillion passenger on a motor bike. Two men have already been sentenced to life imprisonment for their part in the killing. Blanchett is having a busy time at the moment. She will be seen on screen next month in The Gift in which she plays a clairvoyant, and appears in the first part of the Lords of the Ring Trilogy, The Fellowship of the Ring, which will be out at the end of the year. She also recently signed up to appear in Lasse Hallstrom's film of E Annie Proulx's Pulitzer prize-winning The Shipping News (see earlier story).

 Without a hit for a few years, Quentin Tarantino has obviously decided to go to extremes. According to film website Popcorn, he told Uma Thurman that he wants her to kill people "for real" in his forthcoming film. When asked how the actors may feel about killing "for real", Tarantino said: "Best not to tell them right away, they'll be less likely to do the job. But then, after they're dead, and it's art, what can they say?" For her role in Kill Bill, Thurman, who had huge success in Tarantino's Pulp Fiction, has been told to become adept at fighting with a samurai sword and roller skating. It's all quite different from her last role in the period piece, The Golden Bowl.

 Some might say that the last thing that the film industry needs is another award ceremony, but the American Film Marketing Association would not agree. According to Screen Daily, the AFMA is to launch its own awards ceremony on February 22, as part of this month's American Film Market. The lucky winners include Arnold Schwarzenegger, who will be named worldwide box office champ, Renee Zellweger, who will win an achievement in acting prize, and Renny Harlin, who will be honoured for "vision in directing."

 Child star Haley Joel Osment, currently on screen in Pay It Forward, is also to receive an award. According to Variety, the 12-year-old wunderkind has been named Showest 2001's supporting actor of the year. Osment was Oscar nominated last year for The Sixth Sense (losing to Michael Caine) and will be seen next in Steven Spielberg's AI.

 Tea Leoni, the wife of X Files star David Duchovny, is to star in a new, as yet untitled, Woody Allen project. According to Reuters, Leoni is to appear with Allen in one of two films that he is developing at Steven Spielberg's studio, DreamWorks. The other project, The Curse of the Jade Scorpion, will feature Dan Aykroyd, Elizabeth Berkley, Allen himself and the ubiquitous Helen Hunt.

fields.headline: Kids' broadcasters reject BBC study
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Commercial broadcasters have dismissed claims that two new BBC channels would benefit the sector, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Commercial children's broadcasters have dismissed the findings of a BBC-commissioned study.

The report suggested the launch of two BBC children's channels would not have a negative effect on the market.

The study, from consultancy Spectrum, argued that the proposed BBC children's services would have a beneficial impact.

It claimed new channels would help to drive digital TV take-up and increase commercial children's broadcasters' advertising and subscription revenues.

But a spokesman for Nickelodeon UK said the company "does not believe the BBC will stimulate market growth".

"The BBC is making a strange claim when its says new free-to-air channels entering a crowded market will not affect its competitors," he added.

The Nickelodeon spokesman said a study it commissioned from Andersen Consulting found the proposed BBC children's services could mean up to £400m less would be invested in programming by commercial broadcasters.

"The entry of BBC News 24 into the market had a huge impact on existing services such as Sky News because most of its viewers were cannibalised from competitor channels."

"There is no lack of quality, imaginative, interactive, creative children's television provided by 14 separate services," said Disney Channel UK managing director Paul Robinson.

"The BBC should aim its proposed channels at audience sectors resistant to digital television. It should be focusing on homes without children."

The BBC is planning to launch pre-school service, called CBBC Playbox, and an unnamed channel aimed at six to 13-year-olds.

The Spectrum report concludes "the new BBC channels would be unlikely to have an impact on the revenues of the incumbent operators" and "could indirectly help the commercial channels' revenue growth".

The study is to be submitted to the department of culture, media and sport to support the BBC's application for approval for its children's channel proposals.

It also found the BBC channels would "provide a major boost for the UK's production base".

In addition, Spectrum said the new services would increase UK-originated programming and "lower imports and increase exports as these programmes are sold abroad".

fields.headline: Einstein Channel clinches US distribution deal
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: UK-based science broadcaster Einstein Channel is to sell its TV programmes to the US, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Science and technology broadcaster Einstein Channel has signed a deal to sell its TV programmes to the US.

The distribution agreement, with London-based outfit Phoenix TV, is expected to be worth around £400,000 in the first year.

Phoenix TV's US parent, Hubbard Broadcasting, owns 12 TV stations, two radio channels and the 24-hour cable and satellite service All News Channel.

"This deal gives us the chance to explore the American markets with a great partner, without having to incur all the costs associated with a complete channel roll-out," said Steve Timmins, Einstein Channel chief executive.

"It's a stepping stone to international success."

Einstein Channel launched TV service einstein.tv on Sky Digital in the UK last week.

The channel has been broadcasting in Germany since last April and is negotiating distribution deals in Russia, Scandinavia and Switzerland.

Einstein.tv also plans to launch in France, Italy and Spain this year.

The service carries five-minute reports on space, technology and science.

However, Einstein is to begin making 30-minute programmes in the next couple of months.

webTitle: Second 'railway rapist' guilty of three murders

fields.headline: Second 'railway rapist' guilty of three murders
fields.trailText: David Mulcahy was today given three life sentences after being convicted at London's Old Bailey of raping and killing three women.
fields.body:
David Mulcahy was today given three life sentences after being convicted at London's Old Bailey of raping and killing three women.

He was also found guilty of twelve sex attacks on women aged from 16 to 32 in the 1980s and was sentenced to an additional 24 years in jail for the rape offences.

Mulcahy and his childhood friend John Duffy formed a "unique but wicked bond" to rape and kill. Duffy - who was known as the Railway Rapist - was caught and jailed for life in 1988. Mulcahy, 41, escaped justice and continued to live an apparently normal life with his wife and children in north London.

But the ties were finally broken when Duffy named Mulcahy as the unidentified second man who had taken part in a series of rapes and murders of women.

The jury of six men and six women were warned by the judge to put their emotions on one side when deciding the case. "We have listened to the most dreadful accounts of what happened to those women - particularly the murders," said the Recorder of London Judge Michael Hyam.

Mulcahy, a builder, of Chalk Farm, north London had denied raping and murdering three women during 1985 and 1986.

Alison Day, 19, was strangled at Hackney Wick, east London, on December 29 1985. Schoolgirl Maartje Tamboezer, 15, was also strangled near her home in Horsley, Surrey, on April 17, 1986. Newly-married Mrs Anne Lock, 29, was killed - probably suffocated - as she returned home to Brookmans Park, Hertfordshire.

Mulcahy also denied seven other rapes and five charges of conspiracy to rape between 1982 and 1985.

Duffy, 41, was jailed for life in 1988 for two of the murders and rape but was cleared of murdering Mrs Lock. He has since named Mulcahy as his partner in 15 attacks, including the one on Mrs Lock. Mulcahy denied being his accomplice.

George Carter-Stephenson QC, defending, had said: "In a nutshell - he didn't do it." Mulcahy's wife Sandra watched from the public gallery as the verdicts were announced.

webTitle: Prisoners talk of their time in jail

fields.headline: Interview: my life behind bars
fields.trailText: Ashley Johnson, 34, incarcerated for deception and fraud
fields.body:
Ashley Johnson, 34
Sentence: series of short terms
Crimes: deception and fraud

The first time I got sentenced, it was three months in a detention centre for theft. I was 17 and the discipline did me good. I really felt when I came out I was going to make a go of it without crime. I took up a degree, but dropped out after two years because I didn't have the funds.

The next time I got caught I was 21 and went to a young offenders institute for 12 months. Again, when I came out there was no support network. There was less incentive to really change. Probation monitored but didn't help me.

This time I was more clued up, more prepared. I'm a bit of a communicator and a thinker and I used the time to plan ahead what were near-enough fool-proof crimes. You realise certain systems are easy to break through or break into. I was working out how I was going to survive, where there were softer bear traps - less police and lower punishments, so less risk.

My knowledge and connections increased while I was inside. People they tell you what they've done and how they've done it, and what the downsides are so you can calculate whether the risk is worth taking. You realise that if you deal in drugs, you get longer punishments.

I went into deception because the sentences were small and the money was big. Drugs worth £10,000 means five years. With deception, you get six months. I earned hundreds of thousands of pounds that way. I spent most of it gambling, travelling and living the playboy lifestyle, but being into deception, I also knew ways of hiding money away.

My opinion is prison really only works for people who have done several sentences. There comes a time when you think: "Bloody hell, what's happening here? I don't want to spend my life going in and out of jail." You become an old lag and start telling the young jack-the-lads about how it was for you when you were young and in jail. It hit me how much money I have spent and how much I was losing by being in prison. I had repayments and overheads I couldn't keep up.

In the end, I bullied probation and counsellors into giving me the help I needed but I think the support needs to be so much better the first time around. That's why organisations like the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders are good. They take a lot of the sweat from the statutory organisations. Confidence has also gone into the voluntary sector because criminals see the statutory services as an extension of the criminal justice system.

fields.headline: Interview: my life behind bars
fields.trailText:
Bobby Cummines, 49
Sentence: 12 years
Crime: armed robbery
fields.body:
Bobby Cummines, 49
Sentence: 12 years
Crime: armed robbery

I was convicted for my first offence at the age of 16. From then on it was a downward spiral of increasingly serious offences. I did a seven-and-a-half-year sentence, and some years later a 12-year sentence for armed robbery, which took me to most of the maximum security units in the country.

Education was what worked for me in prison. I went to Maidstone prison, where they had a brilliant education department and I started an Open University degree. They helped me explore why I was so different from everyone else, and why I was involved in violence from a young age. I had some good education officers and a probation officer at the time who was a good man and helped me work out what I was doing and where I was going.

But it was the individual officer rather than the probation service that helped. They basically did nothing for me. It wasn't that they didn't care, it's just the workload was so big that you only got five minutes. It was only the fact that I came out, got married and had a lovely little daughter that I turned my life around and took any job I could, working up from there.

When I came out, I was really affected by my record. At first I told the truth, but as soon as that happened the door was shut on me. So I thought to myself: "OK, there's only one way to do it. Don't declare it." So I didn't. Which caused another problem because then I had to make up a whole history of where I'd been for the last 12 years.

Then I got little bits of jobs, cash in hand, those sorts of things. People saw I was good and wasn't offending, so they gave me more. I did a lot of voluntary work with ex-offenders and I got the volunteer of the year award from the Society of Voluntary Associates.

Eventually, I got a full-time job and from then on I stayed in the workplace. I was made redundant but didn't go back to crime. I just got another job. I'm well on my way now. It was mostly done with support from my now ex-wife and friends I met working. When a job came up, they'd say: "Bob's good. He can do that." They trusted me, and I moved on.

Don't declare it." So I didn't. Which caused another problem because then I had to make up a whole history of where I'd been for the last 12 years. Then I got little bits of jobs, cash in hand, those sorts of things. People saw I was good and wasn't offending, so they gave me more. I did a lot of voluntary work with ex-offenders and I got the volunteer of the year award from the Society of Voluntary Associates. Eventually, I got a full-time job and from then on I stayed in the workplace. I was made redundant but didn't go back to crime. I just got another job. I'm well on my way now. It was mostly done with support from my now ex-wife and friends I met working. When a job came up, they'd say: "Bob's good. He can do that." They trusted me, and I moved on.

fields.headline: Pay-TV film battle hots up
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Competition in the pay-TV film market is to intensify with more FilmFour channels and Univeral/NTL joint venture The Studio. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Competition in the pay-TV film market is about to intensify, with the launch of extra FilmFour channels and Univeral/NTL joint venture The Studio.

Channel 4 subsidiary FilmFour is going after more subscribers with the launch of three new channels in April, while The Studio began broadcasting on NTL's cable TV network last night.

The launch of The Studio and FilmFour channels will provide extra competition for Sky Movies, which offer 11 movie channels to digital subscribers for around £15 a month.

The new FilmFour services will be offered as a package with the existing FilmFour channel for £6 per month.

FilmFour World, a channel devoted to foreign language films, will broadcast from 4pm-10pm; FilmFour Extreme, featuring more controversial films such as Caligula, will broadcast from 10pm-4am; and FilmFour +1, a service repeating the main FilmFour schedule an hour later, will broadcast between 7pm and 5am.

The time-shifted FilmFour +1 channel will screen one film less each night than the main channel, but will allow for films to fit in with the 9pm watershed, explained the FilmFour spokesman.

FilmFour is currently marketed as a premium pay-TV channel, with customers paying £5.99 a month on top of their basic subscription fee.

The Studio, which is only available to NTL's 2.2m analogue and digital cable subscribers, is being pitched as a contemporary film channel.

Universal and NTL have chosen to launch The Studio as a basic tier service - free to viewers who pay a monthly pay-TV fee - rather than a premium offering such as FilmFour and Sky Movies.

FilmFour said its new film packages will allow for even greater flexibility, though initially they will only be available on Sky Digital.

The outfit said it hoped to secure digital cable carriage for the extra services in the next few months.

The addition of the new channels is expected to lead to a stronger film buying team at Channel 4, which will be looking for wider deals with studios to cherry-pick films for the new services.

FilmFour was launched in November 1998 and claims it is ahead of its targets with more than 415,000 subscribers.

webTitle: Dispatch from Washington DC: Jesus wants me for president

fields.headline: Jesus wants me for president
fields.standfirst:
After just two weeks in the White House George Bush's 'compassionate conservatism' has already taken on a deeply religious tone, but has been well received throughout the US, finds Martin Kettle

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: After just two weeks in the White House George Bush's 'compassionate conservatism' has already taken on a deeply religious tone, but has been well received throughout the US, finds Martin Kettle
fields.body:
Never underestimate the importance of organised religion in the United States. This is a nation of believers, in which 86% consider themselves practising Christians, seven out of 10 people say that the events described in the Bible are literally true and 63% of the population says that religion can answer "most or all of today's problems".

In this respect, the US is very different from Europe and Britain in particular. So, when George Bush began saying during the election campaign that he foresaw an important role for "faith-based organisations" in such policy areas as education, prisons, welfare and social programmes, few Americans dissented. Al Gore, indeed, agreed with him. The election campaign was full of such talk from both sides.

Nevertheless, it is unlikely that many Americans are yet aware of the full significance of the role Mr Bush intends these religious organisations to play in the social policies of the future. Indeed it would not be an exaggeration to say that Mr Bush foresees a policy revolution with religion at its centre.

To understand what Mr Bush is attempting, it's also important to understand what he means - and certainly what some of those around him mean - by the phrase "compassionate conservatism".

Mr Bush's catch phrase was always a neat campaign slogan. But it was - and is - also an agenda. It's not about finding a middle course between government and the market. It's not about capitalism with a human face. It's about using government to enable religion, and more specifically to enable evangelical Christianity, to transform American society from anarchy into order.

Before this week, Mr Bush's most important utterance on the subject came in a speech in Indianapolis in July 1999. What leaps out from that speech is its evangelical tone. At its heart is Mr Bush's commitment to "the transforming power of faith". Elsewhere in the speech he extolled "the power of religion to protect families and change lives".

The Indianapolis speech revealed the intellectual debt Mr Bush owes to one man in particular. Marvin Olasky has been a Mr Bush adviser since 1993. His book Compassionate Conservatism, in which Mr Bush wrote an enthusiastic preface, was published last year. It spells out its aims vividly and with great passion.

Compassionate conservatism, Mr Olasky says, is "a full-fledged programme with a carefully considered philosophy". Its guiding star is that "Christ changes lives" and it calls for an American president who "will have to speak regularly about the importance of faith in God to poverty fighting and other social concerns".

This week, as one of his first presidential acts, Mr Bush began to act out the part that Olasky has scripted for him. After meeting some three dozen religious leaders and activists at the White House, Mr Bush announced the setting up of a White House office of faith-based and community initiatives and ordered five key government departments to set up similar internal agencies to focus their own work with religious groups.

It is now more than 18 months since the Indianapolis speech, and Mr Bush's approach to the faith-based agenda has become more subtle and conciliatory in important ways. Mr Bush has gone out of his way to say that "government will never be replaced by charities and community groups" and to stress that federal dollars will not go to "fund the religious activities of any group".

These apparent compromises won a generally respectful reception for Mr Bush's initiative this week. But the package raises a succession of explosive issues nevertheless, even if few politicians of either party seem to want to draw attention to them.

In the first place, Mr Bush's move skates deliberately close to the constitutionally guaranteed separation of church and state, which the supreme court has repeatedly upheld. For example, one of Mr Bush's chief lieutenants in this area of policy the former mayor of Indianapolis, Steve Goldsmith, has argued that government should support homeless shelters in which participation in daily prayer is a condition of entry.

Secondly, Mr Bush has yet to ensure that the "faith-based" programmes are run in compliance with, or at least compatibly with, the rules which apply to government programmes. Existing organisations must be audited and, unlike many religious organisations, are covered by anti-discrimination law. No such standards have yet been drawn up for the organisations Mr Bush hopes to encourage.

Yet perhaps the main problem Mr Bush faces is that the programme has been set up to achieve something - religious conversion - which he is increasingly forced to deny for political reasons. Olasky, however, is explicit. In his book he says that proselytising is desirable. He supports "change by conversion". It is in many respects the rationale of his philosophy.

"Marvin is an evangelical Christian and Mr Bush is an evangelical Christian," commented one activist last year. This week, Mr Bush placed that activist, John DiIulio, in charge of his new White House initiative. Mr Bush has put religious faith at the centre of American government and of the contemporary American experience. Like it or hate it, this somehow seems like a pretty historic achievement for a man who is in only his second week at the White House.

fields.headline: Playle departs Trinity Mirror Digital
fields.trailText: 2pm: Trinity Mirror Digital marketing director Jill Playle has quit suddenly, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Jill Playle, marketing director of Trinity Mirror Digital, has quit suddenly without a job to go to.

Ms Playle left last Thursday amid rumours of growing discord with the recently appointed head of the IC Network websites, Graham Mead.

It is understood Ms Playle, who was seconded from her role as marketing director on the Mirror to the new media division in June 1999, will not be moving back onto the newspaper.

"Jill has made a very strong contribution to our business and we wish her every success in the future. A successor has not yet been appointed but we are actively seeking a replacement," said David Clarke, managing director of Trinity Mirror Digital.

Ms Playle was instrumental in developing the media strategy for IC Network, although her departure comes at a time of new launches and expansion.

She was also responsible for the branding of multimillion pound ad campaigns for internet service provider IC24 and the recently launched ICShowbiz.com.

Last August, she was in the limelight for taking a lie detector test in an attempt to prove her company's unmetered deal was all it was cracked up to be.

Trinity Mirror Digital has a three-year investment of £150m from its parent company. It runs IC24, a number of regional and national newspaper websites and is about to launch ICSport and ICChoice.

Prior to joining Trinity Mirror in 1996, Ms Playle was group marketing director at the Express.

webTitle: Jerusalem dispatch: Peres muddies the election water

fields.headline: Peres muddies the election water
fields.standfirst:
Ehud Barak's fortunes in next week's Israeli election are closely tied to wild card Shimon Peres, reports Suzanne Goldenberg.
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Jerusalem dispatch: Ehud Barak's fortunes in next week's Israeli election are closely tied to wild card Shimon Peres, reports Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
For days, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, has shrugged off opinion polls forecasting he will go down in a blaze of defeat against his hardline opponent, Ariel Sharon, in next Tuesday's elections.

"I believe the people will wake up at a certain point. Maybe the real campaign will begin on Friday when Israelis realise that no other candidate will be able to appear from the flanks," Mr Barak told foreign journalists this week.

Friday dawned, and with it the expiry of a deadline for Mr Barak to step aside for the phantom candidate who has dogged his every step on the campaign trail, the Nobel peace prize laureate, Shimon Peres.

And still the poll numbers stubbornly refused to shift, giving Mr Sharon a 17 to 21 percentage point advantage. Although the pollsters did not assess Mr Peres's chances on Friday, previous surveys had him almost tied with Mr Sharon.

Mr Barak's team have been frank about the damage inflicted by Mr Peres's virtual candidacy. "This speculation about Shimon Peres replacing Ehud Barak has been disastrous because it gave us two fronts to fight on," said Elie Goldschmidt, who heads the prime minister's information campaign.

Although the veteran politician publicly disavowed any designs to oust Mr Barak, he was slow to order his supporters to end a campaign to have him enter the race, called "let Peres win". Aged 77, he appears in no mood for retirement.

"Peres is playing a nasty game here. He is going through the motions of being for Barak, but all of his orders are against Mr Barak," said Yossi Verter, the political correspondent for the liberal Ha'aretz newspaper.

For the left, and the one million Arab citizens of Israel, Mr Peres is seen as a far more credible champion of peace than Mr Barak, whose spectacular failure at the negotiation table led to the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza.

The paradox is that Mr Peres would never have made the compromises Mr Barak dared to offer the Palestinians; last July, he publicly criticised the prime minister for offering to share Jerusalem.

Mr Barak was so frustrated this week that he lashed out publicly at Mr Peres, who was once branded an "inveterate intriguer" by the late prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin. "It's time to stop playing the games we read about in Yitzhak Rabin's memoirs," he said.

Others noted Mr Peres's long friendship with Mr Sharon, forged half a century ago when both were proteges of Israel's first prime minister, David Ben Gurion. They speculated the two men were working in cahoots throughout the campaign.

As prime minister in 1984, Mr Peres was crucial to the political rehabilitation of Mr Sharon, who was forced to stand down as defence minister after he was found personally responsible for the massacre of at least 800 Palestinian refugees by Christian militias in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in southern Beirut. Mr Peres appointed his old friend trade and industry minister.

Although Mr Peres is respected internationally for championing the cause of peace, and steering Israel towards negotiations with the Palestinians a decade ago, he has never quite managed to win over his fellow Israelis. He is known as a serial loser of elections.

A slightly aloof man who favours tailored suits and a European formality, he is at odds with the rough and tumble of Israeli political life, where generals invariably fare better than intellectuals. His long political career has been a history of humiliation, with Mr Peres failing to secure a single election victory.

A final humiliation was delivered last summer in Mr Peres's upset in parliamentary elections for president, where he lost to a relative unknown rightwinger.

Mr Peres blamed Mr Barak for failing to secure his victory, and for shunting him aside in his peacemaking efforts. Saddled with the relatively lowly portfolio of minister of regional co-operations, Mr Peres was shut out of the negotiations with the Palestinians until last November when he was dispatched to meet Yasser Arafat, following a death bed appeal from Mr Rabin's widow, Leah.

Analysts say Mr Peres is unruffled by the prospect of Mr Sharon becoming prime minister on Tuesday. Although the Barak campaign has denounced the bulky general as a warmonger, many hope Mr Sharon can be tamed if he fulfills a campaign promise to enter into a national unity government with Labour.

In addition, he will inherit the same fractured Knesset, the Israeli parliament, that proved Mr Barak's undoing, meaning a Sharon government could be short-lived.

Meanwhile, within the Labour party, the knives are already being sharpened for Mr Barak, who is marching toward a historic defeat, and Mr Peres is positioning himself for the inevitable post-election leadership struggle.

fields.headline: Mission: Impossible delivers for BBC
fields.trailText: 1.45pm TV overnights: Tom Cruise and Emmanuelle Beart scored a peaktime hit for the BBC last night with Mission: Impossible pulling in nearly 10m viewers, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The dual appeal of Tom Cruise and Emmanuelle Beart scored a peaktime hit for the BBC last night with repeated blockbuster thriller Mission: Impossible attracting nearly 10m viewers.

Helped by a healthy inheritance from EastEnders, the film attracted 9.4m viewers to give it an average 36% audience share, according to unofficial overnight figures.

Even the perennial ratings hit Who Wants to be a Millionaire? only just scored more viewers, pulling in an average of 9.7m between 8pm and 9pm.

The strong repeat performance of Mission: Impossible helped BBC1 to narrow the gap between its 10pm news programme and ITV's News at Ten.

The BBC's offering attracted 5m viewers to give it a 25% share, only marginally less than ITV's 5.4m.

But elsewhere the BBC fared less well. BBC2's Horizon - on a new clue to the missing link - failed to capture the public's imagination and attracted just 1.8m viewers from 9pm.

A Channel 4 documentary on the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, scheduled in the same slot, proved more popular viewing, with 3.3m people tuning in for the first of a two-part documentary entitled Secrets of the Dead.

fields.headline: Watchdog blocks Ulster TV's bid for radio group
fields.standfirst: Special report: Towards a single ITV
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: The Irish broadcasting watchdog has blocked Ulster TV's £25m bid for County Media, reports Dan Milmo.
Nov 23: Ulster TV moves into radio
Special report: Towards a single ITV
fields.body:
Ulster TV could be heading for a courtroom bust-up with broadcasting watchdogs after it blocked the company's £25m takeover bid for Irish radio group County Media.

Following the decision by the Independent Radio & Television Commission, UTV said it was awaiting a detailed explanation of the verdict before considering its next step.

UTV, the holder of the ITV franchise for Northern Ireland, would not comment further.

But before the IRTC's ruling, UTV was understood to be considering challenging any negative decision under EU competition rules.

IRTC policy states existing media companies cannot own more than 27% of a sound broadcasting service.

UTV is expected to argue that the law is specific to Ireland and breaks EU laws allowing European companies to establish businesses in any EU member state.

Conor Maguire, IRTC chairman, recently made heavy hints that clearing the County Media takeover would go against the regulator's existing policy.

Cork-based County Media owns three radio stations: 96FM in Cork city, 103FM in north Cork and 103Fm in west Cork.

fields.standfirst: Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Online games retailer Gameplay has cut 275 jobs and hived off its non-core operations, reports Amy Vickers.
Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
Online games retailer Gameplay is the latest dot.com to feel the pinch, cutting 275 jobs and hiving off non-core operations.

The most visible casualty of the restructure will be Gameplay's eight high street @Jakarta stores.

These will close even though the company recently spent £5m on a rebranding initiative.

Of the 275 job losses, 54 will be in the company's head office in London and will affect all departments, including marketing, IT and support.

It is believed Gameplay will still employ more than 600 staff.

The company hopes the cutbacks will help it achieve annual cost savings of £12.5m.

Gameplay chairman Mark Strachan said the restructure was necessary to speed up profitability, despite the company having more than £40m in the bank from last year's float.

"This broad and decisive restructure has the single aim of bringing forward the point at which the group is profitable," Mr Strachan said.

He added he was also in talks with potential corporate partners, which may lead to new equity investments in Gameplay.

Under the restructure the company will have two core divisions - technology and boxed games - and reduce its European activity, with local websites ditched in favour of a centrally run international site.

However, the interactive TV business, in which BSkyB has a 6% stake, is to remain a core component of Gameplay's future strategy.

Dixons sold the @Jakarta stores onto Gameplay last year in return for a 12.5% stake in the games company.

At the time of the deal, Dixons talked about strong ties between Gameplay and Freeserve.

A Gameplay spokesman said the high street stores were always part of the long-term picture and were never going to be profitable in the short term.

He added while the Gameplay stores gave the company a higher profile, they had been adversely affected by the overall downturn in the boxed games market.

Games retailers have suffered from their heavy dependence on games manufacturers to launch games consoles on time and market them effectively.

A poor performance from Dreamcast last year, and delays and distribution problems with PlayStation 2, have exacerbated the problems.
