fields.headline: Interview with the chief inspector of prisons
fields.standfirst: Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, says 20,000 of our prisoners simply shouldn't be in jail. Now he feels he is being forced out of his job.  Simon Hattenstone finds out why
fields.trailText: Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, says 20,000 of our prisoners simply shouldn't be in jail. Now he feels he is being forced out of his job. Simon Hattenstone finds out why
fields.body:
Take one look at Sir David "Rambo" Ramsbotham and you know he's an army man. Not any old army man, but a top army man. The fiercely parted hair, the huge hands, the proud stature. You can't get more establishment than Mr Ramsbotham. But according to Home Office whisperers, he's a loose canon, a turn-coat - even worse, a liberal.

As Jack Straw tells Britain's judges, yet again, that he wants even more people banged up, Mr Ramsbotham is illustrating exactly why and how Britain's jail population must be cut right back.

The one word Mr Ramsbotham uses again and again is "appalled". Her majesty's chief inspector of prisons is appalled by the drug problems, health problems, overcrowding problems, funding problems, you name it. As the prison population has increased by 50% over the past 10 years, so its budget has been slashed. The biggest problem, he says, is many of the people shouldn't be in prison in the first place.

Take the elderly. "When I discover an 87-year-old on a Zimmer frame with Alzheimer's in a so-called high-security training prison on the ground that he represents a danger to the public, now I'm sorry but I think this is a nonsense." So what would his policy be? "When you reach the cut-off age, 60 or 65, the local social services should become involved. Early release on humane grounds should be considered."

Mr Ramsbotham has spent most of the past five years visiting prison after prison - unannounced. He and his team (doctors, psychiatrists, educators, work-skill people, engineers) then take up residence for a week, wander round the prison, observe, and talk to the prisoners about the problems they face.

When I ask what has shocked him most about what he has seen he returns to his first prison visit - to Holloway. There were rats and cockroaches, used tampons thrown outside windows, 15-year-old girls locked up in the antenatal unit. "I said to the midwife, 'Are those girls pregnant?', and she said, 'No.' I said, 'What are they doing here?' She said they don't know where else to put them, and I said, 'Are all the other women pregnant?' 'Oh no,' she said there's a psychotic, a psychiatrically disturbed ... I said, 'What's going on here?' She shut the door and looked at me and said, 'I'm an Ibo from Nigeria where they're meant to be less civilised than here, and I have to tell you I have never seen anything as inhuman and disgusting as the way they treat people in Holloway.' I've never forgotten that."

He talks about the number of women in prison for minor offences, mainly drugs, many of them banished from their children. Surely they would be better off rehabilitated in the community? "I couldn't agree with you more. Holloway represents all that is impossible about the imprisonment of women at the moment. The average length of stay is 28 days. What can you actually do useful in 28 days?"

Does he think the age of criminality is too young? In Norway it is 15 as opposed to 10 in Britain. "I do not believe that prison is anything other than an adult environment and children should be out of it. I'm not saying there should not be children in custody, but it shouldn't be in prison service custody."

Mr Ramsbotham approaches prisons with his old military precision. He laughs at the notion he's a liberal, says he has no politics, he just wants to see an efficiently-run service. The job, is not so different from the days when he bossed the streets of Belfast. Ultimately, he has always dealt with law and order.

Although his approach is the same, his attitudes have changed; in some cases radically. He talks about the fact that 60% of prisoners are using class A drugs at the point of entry. Obviously, this is a problem prisons are left with rather than one of their own creation. He says he has often asked himself whether the criminalisation of drugs has caused more problems than it has solved.

"I can see the arguments in legalising everything when I look at the amount of money involved in all of this. I met a man in prison the other day who has admitted assets of £56m, and he's a drug dealer. That amount of money is a very dangerous part of the corruption in prisons; the bullying and intimidation of prisoners. It can also be used as a weapon to bribe and corrupt prison officers."

Mr Ramsbotham says one of the difficulties of discussing all this with politicians is that they have no first-hand experience of prisons. Amazingly, no serving prime minister has ever visited a prison. "No minister has ever accompanied me on an inspection. When ministers go to prisons they show them what they think ministers would like to see."

We do a tally. There are currently 63,000 people in UK prisons. When you take away the kids, the elderly, the mentally ill, the asylum seekers, those inside for trivial shoplifting or drug offences, Mr Ramsbotham reckons you've stripped a good 20,000 away. While Mr Straw expects the prison population to rise to 78,000 by 2007, Mr Ramsbotham reckons it could be cut to about 40,000 now.

Mr Ramsbotham says that since he has been doing this job he has kept a statement on his desk to remind him why he is there. "It was made just before 10 o'clock on the evening of July 20, 1910, by Winston Churchill. It's the famous phrase that the mood and tenor of a nation can be judged by the way it treats its criminals, and there's a treasure in the heart of every man if only you can find it. When I look at that, and when I look at the magnanimity within that, which is something I think as a nation we've stood for, I'm frankly appalled by some of the things I've heard being said by politicians." It's not a political issue, he repeats, it's one of national responsibility.

What's his relationship like with Mr Straw? He answers elliptically. "Well I think frankly the job of home secretary is almost impossible. He's got far too many things to do. In ideal circumstances I would have liked to see as much of Jack Straw as I saw of the secretary of state for defence when I was adjutant general of the army." And how often has he seen him? "Four times last year. Each time at my request."

Perhaps they now regard him as the enemy? "Well, I would have thought as a home secretary you wanted to have your prisons run properly. Then your chief inspector should be regarded as an ally. To me, if I was home secretary my enemy would be those people working in prisons who are not doing their job."

This summer Mr Ramsbotham is due to retire. He says he has loved the job, feels significant progress has been made, such as the setting up of the youth justice board. There is so much left to do, he says. He talks enthusiastically about the thematic review of inequalities he has begun - race, gender, disability, the elderly and people with mental health problems. "I may well not be allowed to finish it."

So why is he retiring? "You'll have to ask the home secretary. I would be happy to stay." And they won't extend his contract again? "Well they've announced that I was retiring so presumably they've made up their minds." He says that he first heard his impending retirement announced in the press and no one from the home office has yet discussed it with him. Perhaps it's a measure of his success that they feel the need to see him off? "My answer to that is, OK, shoot the messenger, but the message won't go away."

webTitle: Students revolt as union bans Eminem

fields.headline: Students revolt as union bans Eminem
fields.standfirst:
Outrage at university over 'censorious' exclusion of controversial US rapper


Talk about it

NetNotes: the story in links
fields.trailText: Outrage at university over 'censorious' exclusion of controversial US rapper
fields.body:
Once it was the province of the worried parent to protect the young from the gruesome lyrics of modern musicians.

But now the role seems to have been taken over by the students' union.

Leaders of Sheffield University's union have enraged members by slapping a "censorious" ban on the controversial rapper Eminem.

The union banned the controversial American from club nights and student media after a handful of members complained about his lyrics on bludgeoning women and gays to death and abusing his "stinkin' ass mom".

The union ruled that Steel Press, Sheffield's award-winning student newspaper, was allowed to write straight news stories mentioning the singer but not to review his latest CD, the Marshall Mathers LP, or his UK tour which starts next week.

Fans have been barred from wearing Eminem T-shirts in the bar. But students said it constituted censorship and they would break the ban.

Dan Morfitt, head of music at Sure, the student radio station, said the ban was extreme and he planned to break it on Monday by playing an Eminem record "to see what happened".

"We have really got to go for it to break this ban. Of course we are against homophobia, but we're all over 18 and are unlikely to be turned into bigots by a couple of lines in a song."

He said the nationwide Student Broadcast Network, based in London, was played in breaks on Sure's frequency and it would continue to play Eminem.

Jan Webster, editor of Steel Press, which today publishes an editorial on the ban complaining of "censorship" and "the nanny state", said: "Three out of 22,000 students complained. We despise homophobia, but I am worried about political correctness when it becomes an issue of control by a small minority."

David Whitley, 21, a third year student journalist, said: "They are banning Eminem from being reviewed but the university is still allowed to sell his records in the shop. So homophobia is ok by them if they can make a profit by it."

A spokeswoman for Sheffield students' union said the shop should not be selling Eminem. She also said a referendum had been taken among students.

Andreaz Nowakowski, of the Sheffield union, said: "Our aim is to create a culture of tolerance, equality and respect for all our members."

Eminem's homophobia and misogynism spoiled that atmosphere.

Mr Nowakowski said the fact that students yesterday staged protests at the ban was "frustrating", but they would be given a chance to air their views.

The Campaign for Press and Broadcasting Freedom called the ban heavy-handed censorship, but the National Union of Students and gay rights' groups welcomed it.

Owain James, national NUS president, said: "NUS will not condone sexist or homophobic language in any way."

Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall, the gay rights group, said public debate on Eminem was needed. Peter Tatchell of OutRage! said the group was against censorship but was appalled by Eminem's lyric fantasies about killing gays and women.

No other student unions moved to join Sheffield's ban yesterday.

American homosexual organisations have organised a Rally Against Hate outside the Grammy awards ceremony in Los Angeles on February 21, where Eminem is expected to sing and collect awards.

Jack Straw In February last year, Leeds University student union voted to revoke the life-long membership of the home secretary, their former president, because of his "anti-libertarian policies".

Bacardi breezers Sheffield University, among others, has banned all Bacardi products from the student union bar in protest at US trade embargoes against Cuba, which students feel are depriving Cubans of medical and food supplies.

FHM magazine Almost every student union in Britain banned an FHM special student edition last year which featured a piece on "how to commit suicide". Other union shops have stopped stocking "lads' mags" because their cover pictures are offensive to women.

Pepsi In 1996, a group of student unions, including Cardiff, banned Pepsi because the company was working in Burma, which has a poor human rights record. Unions boycotted the drink until Pepsi pulled out of Burma.

Emap will target a new generation of rock fans next month with the launch of a music lifestyle magazine, Kingsize.

The "bleeding heart" journalism of former editor Rosie Boycott may soon be a thing of the past under new Daily Express editor Chris Williams.

News Group Newspapers is being sued for damages after publishing an allegedly stolen photograph of killer Laith Alani in the Sun.

webTitle: Will Courtney Love find time for Paula Yates?

fields.headline: Will Courtney Love find time for Paula Yates?
fields.trailText: There are conflicting stories about whether the Hole singer will star in a biopic about the tragic life of the TV presenter
fields.body:
There is confusion about whether popstar turned actress Courtney Love (pictured) will be playing Paula Yates in a film about the TV presenter's life. According to peoplenews, the Hole singer herself is actually writing the film in which she intends to star. The site reports that Love met Yates just days before she died last September. It quotes her as saying: "I was born to play Paula. This is the role of a lifetime."

However, a music site isn't quite so sure. According to Music 365, Love, the widow of ex-Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain, is too busy to play Yates. Her latest film, Julie Johnson, was premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and she is soon due to start filming 24 hours, a thriller which co-stars Charlize Theron.

She has also signed on for a starring role in Hello Suckers, in which she will play a 1900s showgirl who schemes her way to fame and fortune on the Broadway stage.

However, she apparently had to pull out of John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars, after being injured by her boyfriend's ex-wife. According to Mr Showbiz, Lesley Barber drove over her foot as part of a "20-month campaign of stalking."

 More on Courtney Love.

fields.headline: Aegis snaps up European market research outfit
fields.trailText: 12pm: London advertising group Aegis has acquired European market research company Pegram Walter. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
London-based advertising group Aegis has gained its first foothold in the European market research industry with the acquisition of Pegram Walter.

Aegis, owner of the Carat media buying agency, said today it had agreed to buy Pegram Walter in a cash and share deal worth up to £5m.

The group acquired a US market research company, Market Facts, in 1999 and also has a market research business in Asia.

But the acquisition of the London company Pegram Walter represents its first foray into the industry in Europe.

"The acquisition of Pegram Walters is another step towards our goal of building a global market research network," said Doug Flynn, Aegis chief executive.

"Over the past two years Aegis has invested significantly in developing research networks in the US and Asia-Pacific.

"This European acquisition is an excellent strategic fit and provides us with a base from which to develop further our research capability in the region."

Pegram Walters was founded in 1982 and provides a range of research services to mainly blue-chip clients.

webTitle: M&S hires former Asda fashion chief

fields.headline: M&S hires former Asda fashion chief
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Asda's former fashion guru George Davies has joined ailing retailer Marks & Spencer, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Asda's former fashion guru George Davies has done what he said he would never do - join ailing retailer Marks & Spencer.

M&S has signed up Mr Davies to design, manufacture and supply an exclusive women's wear collection for M&S.

The range will be launched in October across 100 M&S stores and will be merchandised in a specially designed part of the shop.

The range will carry low price-tags, in an attempt to help M&S compete with competitively priced high street rivals. The new brand will be aimed at women in their 20s and 30s.

The lower pricing and younger target audience will distinguish the range from M&S's upmarket designer label Autograph, which was launched last autumn.

It is not known what Mr Davies's new M&S brand will be called.

"I have always been an admirer of Marks & Spencer and the quality of its products. I passionately believe in this business," he said.

However, last November Mr Davies took a very different line in a Sunday Telegraph interview, saying he "had not had one conversation with M&S - and I won't".

"I would not go to M&S. I am not that sort of person - it's too corporate," he added.

Mr Davies's change of heart may have come about because he has been able to reach a deal with M&S that allows him to set up his own company - of which he will be chief executive - to supply the retailer, rather than work in-house.

He is credited with creating a supermarket's first credible clothing range, Asda's George label, in the late 1980s. Prior to that he worked as a designer for Next.

Mr Davies was one of a string of senior executives, including chief executive Allan Leighton, who left Asda after US giant Wal-Mart acquired the supermarket chain. He quit in November last year.

M&S has been hiring talent from outside the company in a bid to turn its fortunes around.

This week the retailer appointed Warehouse managing director Yasmin Yusuf to the new post of creative director. It had already hired Michele Jobling, previously managing director of department store Liberty, to run its children's wear operation.

Research by NOP reveals almost half the population would change the way they vote on the basis of the Peter Mandelson fiasco or similar scandals.

The Office of Fair Trading is seeking a senior PR officer to fill its new chief of communications post and lead a complete restructure of the body's PR needs.

BMW GB has hired guerrilla marketing outfit Cunning Stunts to launch the revamped Mini.

Coca-Cola GB has hired Jackie Cooper Public Relations for the spring launch of non-carbonated drink Alive.

The Royal Shakespeare Company has appointed its first director of press and public affairs. Roger Mortlock was formerly director of corporate affairs for the Community Service Volunteers charity.

fields.headline: Peugeot questions Nissan aid decision
fields.trailText: The head of one of Europe's biggest car makers has attacked the European commission's decision to approve British government aid for the Nissan plant in Sunderland.
fields.body:
The head of one of Europe's biggest car makers has attacked the European commission's decision to approve British government aid for the Nissan plant in Sunderland.

Jean-Martin Folz, the president of PSA Peugeot Citroën, described the decision as shocking and bizarre.

Speaking ahead of the opening of the group's new $600m (£405m) manufacturing complex at Porto Real in Brazil Mr Folz said: "I am surprised that a company which is making such brilliant results, from what we read in the press, needs such investment subsidy in a plant which is supposed to be one of the most productive in the UK."

Mr Folz said he could have understood the decision if Nissan had been deliberating between a European Union and a non-EU location for its investment in the production facilities for the new Micra but not when the choice was between two EU countries. "It is really bizarre, shocking."

Mr Folz is also unhappy that the EC is planning reform of the block exemption under which car distribution within the EU is exempt from some of the competition provisions of the Treaty of Rome.

The existing block exemption is due to expire next year and competition commissioner Mario Monti has said he wants to put the customer in the driving seat.

But Mr Folz said manufacturers and dealers had both said the current system was the right one and that "independent poll evidence" showed that consumers agreed.

"All the stakeholders have said they are very satisfied with the present situation. I hope the commission will listen to the opinion of concerned people and not to self proclaimed representative organisations," he said.

Peugeot's Ryton plant in the UK is currently working three shifts producing the popular 206 hatchback which will provide it with a secure future for the next few years. The key to PSA's commitment to UK manufacturing will come at the end of 2003. "At that time we have to make a strategic decision [over whether to invest £100m in a new paint shop]," Mr Folz said.

At the time the exchange rate between the pound and the euro and the relationship between sterling and the single currency "will be something we will be considering at that time".

Speaking at the official opening of the Porto Real plant - situated in the countryside between Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo - Mr Folz said that PSA was aiming for global sales of 3m vehicles this year. The new plant, which shares a site with suppliers that will provide 60% of its component requirements, is already producing the Citroën Picasso and production of the Peugeot 206 is due to start in a few months time.

The investment in Porto Real reflects PSA's determination to bolster its market share in Latin America's Mercosur's trade zone in general and Brazil in particular.

PSA is looking for sales in Brazil of 45,000 this year, which would give the group a 3.6% market share. "While these figures are still modest, our ambition is to become a major player by quickly increasing sales to more than 100,000."

Mazda will not reverse its decision to shift some production to Europe now that the euro is strengthening against the yen, Mark Fields, the firm's president, said yesterday.

The Ford Motor affiliate said in November it would start producing 100,000 sub-compact cars a year at a Ford plant in Europe from 2003 to reduce the impact of the strengthening yen on its export earnings.

Since then the euro has risen sharply but Fields said neither Mazda's profit forecast nor its plans to shift production had changed.

fields.headline: Desmond settles with website staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
5pm: Richard Desmond has avoided a court clash with former Express staff by agreeing a pay settlement with aggrieved website staff, writes Amy Vickers.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express group owner Richard Desmond has avoided a court clash by agreeing a pay settlement with aggrieved website staff.

The terms of the deal have not been disclosed and former Express Digital Media employees are refusing to give details.

However, it is believed staff yesterday agreed a settlement with administrators Seymour Pierce Investments, with money being split among website employees laid off without pay in December.

It is thought the payment only covers about a third of what staff believed they were owed.

"The matter has been settled and we're relieved it's all over so we can get on with our lives," said Michael Streeter, former editor of Express.co.uk.

fields.trailText: Reuters, the global news agency, yesterday took a 25% stake in the online financial news service Citywire for an undisclosed amount, thought to run to several million pounds.
fields.body:
Reuters, the global news agency, yesterday took a 25% stake in the online financial news service Citywire for an undisclosed amount, thought to run to several million pounds.

Mark Wood, managing director of Reuters' partnerships division, who will join the board of Citywire, said the deal provided Reuters with an interest in a comment and opinion service - something Reuters is forbidden from offering under the terms of its trust.

"Citywire will both complement and reinforce Reuters' own evolving products for private investors via the internet - an important opportunity for us," he said.

The partnership echoed a deal Reuters struck with German news provider Handelsblatt, Mr Wood said. It is thought to be part of a strategy covering several countries as demand grows from private investors for comment and analysis.

Lawrence Lever, the chairman and chief executive who founded Citywire two years ago, said the money from Reuters would mostly be spent on recruiting journalists.

The cash injection would be more than enough to take Citywire into profitability, but he would not be drawn on when that might occur.

It is understood that the investment emphasis will be on commentary and analysis of retail funds such as unit and investment trusts, with Citywire journalists able to draw on Reuters' extensive data. This is a popular area with retail investors who feel safer buying funds than shares.

Citywire will also take a role in the development of Reuters' proposed personal finance portal, Reuters.co.uk, which will carry Citywire-branded analysis and opinion.

Mr Lever, a former financial editor of the Mail on Sunday, was reported to have considered floating Citywire last year.

webTitle: Blackstone leaves door open on top-up fees

fields.headline: Blackstone leaves door open on top-up fees
fields.trailText: The education minister, Tessa Blackstone, yesterday reiterated the governmentÕs opposition to university top-up fees, but did not completely rule out the possibility that top-up fees could be introduced after the next general election.
fields.body:
The education minister, Tessa Blackstone, yesterday reiterated the governmentÕs opposition to university top-up fees, but did not completely rule out the possibility that top-up fees could be introduced after the next general election.

Baroness Blackstone conceded that student debt had risen under the Labour government, but told MPs that students were no more hard-up now than in previous years.

The minister said that there was no evidence that more students were dropping out of university since the government replaced maintenance grants with loans and introduced university tuition fees three years ago.

The comments came during the final hearing of an inquiry by the House of Commons education committee into student drop out rates. MPs have been investigating why drop out rates are so different between universities, even when they enrol similar types of students.

The minister told the MPs that top-up fees were not part of the government's policy. ÒNeither [the education secretary] David Blunkett or I are in favour of top-up fees,Ó she said. But pressed on the issue, she added: "When we get to the general election, maybe we will be able to talk to you again but it is a little way ahead.Ó

Liberal Democrat MP Evan Harris claimed that Labour had said similar things before the last election, but then introduced tuition fees and abolished maintenance grants.

During the hearing the MPs suggested that the government had tried to hide the main findings of a report published in December which showed that student debts had trebled over four years. A summary of the report by the Department for Education and Employment implied that its main conclusion was that student income had risen.

Baroness Blackstone told the MPs though that the interpretations were not inconsistent at all. ÒOf course student debt has gone up,Ó she said. ÒBut we have to really think about this in a rational way.Ó

The minister said that 75% of students were now taking out loans Ð a higher proportion than ever before. ÒWe are not making them more hard-up, because more loans are available,Ó she said. ÒStudents are always going to think they are hard-up. I think students have always had this perception.Ó

Earlier this week a university vice-chancellor estimated that thousands of students were being excluded from degree courses because of debt. But Baroness Blackstone told MPs that there was no evidence that drop out rates at universities had increased since the government introduced fees and loans three years ago.

The committeeÕs chairman and Labour MP, Barry Sheerman, said that MPs in English constituencies were Ògetting a little bit grumpyÓ that there are higher rates of spending on education in Scotland and Wales.

fields.headline: RTL in broadband tie-up with Bertelsmann
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Channel 5 owner RTL has teamed up with German media giant Bertelsmann to develop a Europe-wide broadband service, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 5 owner RTL has teamed up with German media giant Bertelsmann to develop a Europe-wide broadband service.

RTL plans to use Bertelsmann's expertise to improve its interactive TV operations in Germany, with the view to rolling them out across Europe.

Bertelsmann owns 37% of RTL Group.

Under the terms of the deal, RTL will take over Bertelsmann Broadband Group for £8m and fold it into its RTL's new media division.

Bertelsmann has been an enthusiastic supporter of the broadband revolution, which combines high-speed internet access and TV services and provides interactive opportunities including real-time betting during televised sporting events.

However, RTL admitted its broadband operations are only at the pilot stage in Germany, and it will be some time before it launches a Europe-wide service.

"We have to wait for telecoms and cable networks to become interactive. We develop the content and as soon as the door is open for interactivity our content will go through," said an RTL spokesman.

He added that in the long term RTL planned to have interactive services on Channel 5, but the UK broadcast network was not yet ready.

RTL has interests in 23 TV channels and 17 radio stations in 11 different European countries.

webTitle: Helping families through the trauma of bereavement

fields.headline: Helping families through the trauma of bereavement
fields.trailText: The Child Bereavement Trust (CBT) is a national charity founded in 1994 to train professionals to improve their support to grieving families.
fields.body:
The Child Bereavement Trust (CBT) is a national charity founded in 1994 to train professionals to improve their support to grieving families.

This month it is involved with helping grieving relatives in the aftermath of the Alder Hey report into the retention of children's organs.

In addition to this work, CBT produces information for bereaved children and families, doctors, nurses, midwives, teachers and voluntary sector workers. The charity also provides specialised training and support for professionals to improve their response to the needs of bereaved families.

CBT holds conferences for health care professionals; this year, its conference - called Baby and Child Death: Managing the Issues - will be held in London on May 15. The charity also runs courses adapted for schools and other educational establishments, team building courses and training on post-traumatic stress. It also operates a university accredited bereavement counselling course.

CBT director Jenni Thomas said: "Grief in its many forms is one of the most painful experiences that anyone can suffer. Every year it happens to thousands of families when their baby or child dies and when children experience the death of their parents or siblings."

Every year one baby in 100 dies, either before or shortly after birth - that is 18 babies a day in the UK. A further 1,000 babies die before their first birthday. More than 3,000 children between the age of one and 19 die each year as a result of accident or illness, while up to 40,000 adults between the ages of 20 and 54 die each year, many of whom leave behind grieving children or adolescents. Health care professionals who have received training from the trust could help people bereaved by such incidents.

Michael Redfern QC, chair of the Alder Hey inquiry, recommended that any professionals offering support to bereaved parents should receive appropriate training. The trust provides training in many ways including a programme called Loss, Death and Grief - Children and Young People, which is funded by the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund. The Princess attended the launch of the charity and was an unofficial supporter.

The project offers multi-disciplinary training for healthcare professionals working with young people. In an example of good practice, a group of bereaved young people is actively involved in the design and monitoring of the project. The Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund continues to provide financial support for this training.

 For more information about CBT's conference on 15 May in London, phone 01491 419800 or email jane.hutton@conference-creations.com

 CBT has developed a website, which offers help and information to young people, parents, doctors, nurses, midwives and teachers.

Its publications and details of training are also available by telephoning 01494 446648 or writing to The Child Bereavement Trust, Aston House, High Street, West Wycombe, High Wycombe, Bucks, HP14 3AG

 The charity of the month section of SocietyGuardian.co.uk will focus on small and medium sized charities. Being chosen as charity of the month is not an award or endorsement but more of a chance to publicise achievements and plans for the future. We hope that other voluntary organisations will benefit from reading about our selected charity's activities

webTitle: UK net twins couple face US court appearance

fields.headline: UK net twins couple face US court appearance
fields.trailText: The British couple at the centre of the row over the internet adoption of twin baby girls face a US court appearance after being served with a writ following an appearance on the Oprah Winfrey talk show in Chicago.
fields.body:
The British couple at the centre of the row over the internet adoption of twin baby girls face a US court appearance after being served with a writ following an appearance on the Oprah Winfrey talk show in Chicago.

Judith and Alan Kilshaw, of Buckley, north Wales, appeared on the show despite promising a court in the UK last month that they would not discuss the controversial adoption case with anyone unconnected with it.

The writ was served by lawyers acting for Richard and Vickie Allen from California, who also claim to have adopted the twins and who appeared on the Oprah show alongside the Kilshaws.

The Kilshaws, who have been summoned before a court in Arkansas, say they will fight the petition.

Host Oprah Winfrey looked uncomfortable as she sat between the Allens and the Kilshaws, who had flown out to Chicago earlier this week for a series of interviews.

In characteristic outspoken and incautious style, Mrs Kilshaw challenged the Allens to prove that they were the legal adoptive parents of the girls.

"We have documentation that we adopted them," she told them. The twins had lived with the Allens for two months before their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, tricked the couple into handing them over to her for a visit. The children were then given to an adoption broker, who sold them to the Kilshaws for £8,200.

Mr Allen said: "What is important is what is in the best interests of the girls. The legalities of the adoption is not the issue here." His response was greeted with rapturous applause from the audience.

The case has led to a debate about the ethics of adoption by internet. The Kilshaws claim they are trying to make things easier for prospective adoptive parents to be matched with children - although it would appear the publicity for the case will make it more difficult to adopt using the internet.

Two weeks ago the couple gave a voluntary undertaking to a judge that they would refrain from discussing their adoption case anywhere outside the court. It is unclear why they apparently have breached their voluntary ban.

The twins are in the care of a local authority in north Wales, pending a decision on their future by courts in the UK and the US. Ms Wecker has also said that she wants them back, but is being investigated for fraud after an allegation that she continued to claim child welfare payments.

The Oprah Winfrey show was broadcast across the US, but it is unclear whether it will be shown in the UK.

webTitle: TV channel denies show condones under age sex

fields.headline: TV channel denies show condones under age sex
fields.trailText: Carlton TV yesterday defended the screening of a documentary about a mother who allowed her daughters to have sex when they were 11, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Television producers yesterday defended the screening of a documentary about a mother who allowed her daughters to have sex when they were 11.

Carlton TV said the programme, centred on Chantal Marshall and her family, was part of a responsible current affairs series. But family campaigners said it encouraged inappropriate practices.

In the programme, Tara Marshall, who is now 14, described how she lost her virginity partly because there was little else to do in Kirby-in-Ashfield, Nottinghamshire.

Her mother, a clairvoyant, said she was not a bad parent, and her understanding attitude towards her daughters had helped keep the family strong. "I don't believe I'm a bad parent and I won't accept I am a failed parent either. I know it's controversial but I believe I can help my children if I can keep an open mind and the communication lines open."

Mrs Marshall, whose other daughters, Emma and Terri, have had abortions, said that sex among young teenagers was more common than was currently accepted. "It's really awful that children should lose their innocence so young, but I don't think we can do anything about it. Family planning services are open for under age sex."

The pressure group Family and Youth Concern expressed reservations: "For any parent to condone this kind of behaviour is bad enough, but this sounds too much like exhibitionism."

The group said that Mrs Marshall was simply using the programme to promote the careers of her daughters - they wanted to be models. It said that the programme would serve only to legitimise under-age sex.

Carlton, which produced the programme, said it was comfortable about the subject matter. A spokesman said: "The film we have made doesn't condone her behaviour, it reports it and questions it. It covers a lot of issues that are in the public domain at the moment about under age sex, and the concerns surrounding that. We haven't just pointed a camera at her."

The programme is to be broadcast in the midlands as part of the series 30 Minutes next Thursday. Mrs Marshall told her story to Channel 4 seven months ago.

fields.trailText: The two couples in the row over the internet adoption of twin baby girls appeared together on a US TV chat show, writes Helen Carter.
fields.body:
The two couples in the row over the internet adoption of twin baby girls appeared together on a US television chat show to stake their claim for the children.

Host Oprah Winfrey looked uncomfortable as she sat between Richard and Vicky Allen, from California, and Judith and Alan Kilshaw, from Buckley in north Wales. The Kilshaws, who had promised not to discuss the case, flew out to Chicago earlier this week for a series of interviews.

The children were then given to an adoption broker, who sold them to the Kilshaws for £8,200.

fields.headline: Liberia ruler drops cannibalism case
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Liberian president Charles Taylor is withdrawing a libel case he brought against a British academic for alleging that he is a cannibal, and the Times newspaper for repeating it. By Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
The president of Liberia, Charles Taylor, is withdrawing a libel case he brought against a British academic for alleging that he is a cannibal, and the Times newspaper for repeating it.

He is trying to place an advertisement in British newspapers saying he has been forced to withdraw because of the high cost of pursuing the case in London.

But the statement also shows that he has realised that a trial would examine his central role in one of Africa's most brutal civil wars of the 1990s, marked by the wholesale murder of civilians, the widespread use of drugged child soldiers, and ritual sacrifices.

Mr Taylor brought the case a year ago after Stephen Ellis, a British academic at a Dutch university, claimed in his book The Mask of Anarchy that he had eaten human flesh, reflecting the belief widespread among his fighters that human organs, particularly the heart, gave them more strength. The Times repeated the allegations in its review of the book.

Mr Taylor decided to withdraw after a preliminary hearing in London last week at which the court rejected his request to bar evidence of a range of human rights abuses and the judge ordered him to deposit £175,000 as security for the defendants' costs should he lose the case.

"Counsel has advised that the effect of these decisions is that the English high court has refused to allow me what can be regarded as a proper opportunity to vindicate my reputation, because it has insisted on a form of proceedings which would be too broad, costly and time consuming," Mr Taylor said.

Mr Taylor is known for his immense wealth, so it is unlikely that expense would be an obstacle to him pursuing the case, had he wanted to.

The defendants could have required him to testify in London, where human rights groups have been pressing for his arrest and prosecution for crimes against humanity.

Liberia has been threatened with international sanctions because of his backing, since he won power there, for rebels in Sierra Leone responsible for hacking children's' arms off and illegal diamond and weapons trafficking

fields.headline: Sega's UK marketing chief gets European remit
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The computer games company has promoted Alison Turner to European marketing director, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Sega has promoted its UK marketing chief Alison Turner to a European role.

The move comes in the wake of the departure last week of European marketing director Jeremy Stern.

The computer games group has restructured its UK and European marketing departments following yesterday's announcement it is to stop making the Dreamcast console.

Ms Turner has been promoted to head of European marketing, Sega Europe.

She replaces Mr Stern, who left Sega after less than six months in the job.

The UK director of marketing role has been axed and the UK and European marketing departments have been consolidated under Ms Turner.

A Sega spokesman said the Dreamcast announcement has resulted in redundancies across the company.

Marketing operations have been affected but he was unable to confirm how many people were involved.

"Sega Europe is restructuring its business to enable it to go forward with a focus on software. This has led to a number of job losses, which are to be regretted," he said.

"Sega Europe is a now a leaner and fitter company that is ready for the challenge ahead."

Sega Europe is without a creative advertising agency at present.

Bartle Bogle Hegarty resigned the £60m pan-European account in December in order to work on rival games console Microsoft Xbox.

The Sega spokesman said the company was talking to creative agencies about an advertising brief for the company's software products.

The company will continue to produce software for various platforms, including consoles, PDAs, mobile phones and TV set-top boxes.

Carat handles the company's media buying.

webTitle: Bob the Builder's owner has designs on dinosaur

fields.headline: Bob the Builder's owner has designs on dinosaur
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Hit Entertainment is understood to be close to agreeing terms for a takeover of US firm Lyrick Studios, which would see Bob the Builder and Barney the Dinosaur come under the same ownership. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
Hit Entertainment is understood to be close to agreeing terms for a takeover of the larger, privately-owned US entertainment firm Lyrick Studios, which would see children's favourites Bob the Builder and Barney the Dinosaur come under the same ownership.

British-based Hit, valued at around £400m, is thought to have agreed a price with Texas- based Lyrick that would more than double its size and cement its position in the lucrative US market. Terms are likely to be finalised within the next 10 days.

The deal might also be a prelude to a bid this year for The Jim Henson Company, the Muppets firm, which is owned by troubled German television firm EM.TV.

Shares in Hit were suspended yesterday at the company's request after it told the stock exchange that it was "in advanced negotiations to make a significant acquisition... that would classify as a reverse takeover". It refused to name its target.

Barney, a purple dinosaur, is one of the best known children's characters in the US and its merchandising revenues would reduce Hit's dependency on Bob the Builder, which accounts for around 60% of group sales.

Lyrick's largest shareholder is Dick Leach, a father of nine and former printer who dipped into his own pocket to fund the first Barney video in 1988. Mr Leach's daughter-in-law, Sheryl Stamps Leach, came up with the idea for Barney as a way of keeping her hyperactive two-year-old son entertained.

Since then more than 130m Barney videos and books have been sold as the television show Barney and Friends has topped the ratings charts for the un der-sixes in more than 100 countries. A touring stage show has also been established.

Lyrick's other children's properties include Wishbone books about a Jack Russell terrier who leaps into classic stories, Australian music group the Wiggles and a new series called Little Suzy's Zoo.

Hit chief executive Peter Orton is thought to have initiated the deal and is likely to take over the day-to-day running of the combined group.

fields.headline: Levi's ad sparks organ donor controversy
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Levi Strauss has become embroiled in a row with organ donors in the US, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Levi Strauss has become embroiled in a row with organ donors in the US over a tongue-in-cheek ad that shows doctors rushing a pair of jeans to a critically ill man.

The ad, "Jeans donor", shows a medical team removing a pair of Levi's from a dead man, who is shown to carry a jeans donor card.

The medics then rush the jeans by helicopter to a second man, who is revived as soon as he puts them on.

A group representing organ donors in the US has condemned the ad and demanded it be pulled from TV screens.

The ad was broadcast on CBS during last Sunday's Superbowl - traditionally the time when advertisers showcase their new commercials.

Levi's said it has no plans to run the ad again.

fields.headline: Blair's 'call to Hindujas'
fields.standfirst: PM backed brothers' bid to buy Express, says Gopichand
fields.trailText: Gopichand Hinduja told Express execs Tony Blair was supporting the brothers' £100m bid to buy the titles. By Kevin Maguire.
fields.body:
Gopichand Hinduja, the billionaire businessman at the centre of an Indian arms controversy, told senior figures at Express Newspapers that Tony Blair was supporting the Hinduja brothers' £100m bid to buy the titles.

Mr Blair is said to have indicated his backing for the family's hopes to become newspaper barons during a telephone call with Mr Hinduja, who is currently in India, where he could face corruption charges over an arms deal.

Gopichand, known as GP, said he had spoken to Mr Blair before 8.30am on October 18 last year, a few days after it had emerged the Hindujas wanted to buy the tabloids.

A senior figure at Express Newspapers, who was told of the conversation later that day during a meeting with GP and his brother SP, said the pair were convinced they had Downing Street's support if they acquired the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star.

"GP said they really wanted to buy the Express and had had a long call from Tony Blair," said the figure, who was close to the brothers during the discussions. "He said Tony Blair would support them and thought it would be a good idea. GP was absolutely clear."

Downing Street last night denied Mr Blair had discussed the Express with the family.

"The prime minister has not spoken to any of the Hinduja brothers or had any contacts with the Hindujas about the Daily Express," said a No 10 spokesman .

A spokesman for the Hindujas said he was unable to contact the brothers.

No 10 was forced to launch an inquiry into how the Hinduja brothers, particularly SP, obtained British passports after interventions by ministers in a crisis which triggered the resignation of Peter Mandelson and left the Europe minister, Keith Vaz, fighting for his political life.

The Hindujas, who enjoyed the support of Rosie Boycott, then editor of the Daily Express, would have targeted Britain's 3m Asians to boost sales if they had bought the newspapers. Boycott lobbied Mr Blair on the brothers' behalf but United News & Media accepted a £125m bid from porn baron Richard Desmond, who subsequently received an invitation to No 10 for tea with the prime minister.

The courting of newspaper editors and proprietors is a central part of Mr Blair's campaign to secure favourable coverage for New Labour. Rupert Murdoch is a regular visitor to Downing Street and three years ago it was revealed that Mr Blair called the prime minister of Italy to discover if the media mogul would be allowed to buy an Italian television station.

The Hinduja brothers - SP, GP and Geneva-based Prakash - plan to appeal tomorrow in the New Delhi high court against a ruling yesterday that they must remain in India while allegations they took "commissions" in the mid-1980s from an arms deal involving Swedish firm Bofors are investigated.

The Hinduja brothers, who spent £1m sponsoring the Millennium Dome's faith zone, had sought bail to return to London.

Lawyers for India's central bureau of investigation opposed bail on the grounds that the brothers might not return if they felt the investigation was "not going their way".

fields.headline: Loaded question
fields.standfirst: As lads' mag Loaded gets a new editor and prepares to revamp, can it reinvent itself for a new decade?
fields.trailText: February 2: With a new editor at the helm, can the original lads' mag reinvent itself for a new decade? Maggie Hyde investigates.
fields.body:
The monthly magazine is a ballsy Taurus Bull (coverdated May 1 1994), with an opposition of the Sun to over-the-top Jupiter in the sex and money signs of Taurus and Scorpio.

The Moon, symbol of women, is placed next to outrageous Uranus, targeting the mag defiantly against New Nappy Man and marking the end of political correctness.

Loaded Man is shown by macho Mars in Aries, packed with testosterone but isolated and oddly disconnected from all the other planets in the horoscope.

Full of balls, he's always coming but doesn't know where he's going.

Founder James Brown and his gang caught the 90s mood and had a runaway success.

However, the unsustainable rebel stance has gone limp and Brown now thinks the men's magazine sector, including Loaded, has become "stale" and "embarrassing".

New editor Keith Kendrick is a forceful Aquarian (January 30 1964), full of ideas, principles and prejudices and, with a strong Mars himself, he loves a fight.

He has great connections with the mag and his crusading, visionary Jupiter on its Mars allows him to give Loaded Man a purpose in life, beyond bonking.

Kendrick was worth the year-long wait to find a new editor and, given a big advertising campaign, he'll soon get Loaded talked about again.

But there is a downside shown in an uncanny parallel between the two horoscopes. Both Kendrick and Loaded get hit this coming year by Mercury's progressed opposition to Pluto.

Mercury is the communications planet and Pluto symbolises the underworld, the realm of Hades. In mythology, he is a god of rape and hidden desire and represents the shadowy side of man's bestial instincts.

According to astrologer Howard Sasportas, this Mercury-Pluto combination stirs up primitive instincts and brings "overwhelming sexual images, powerful aggressive urges, angry and destructive thoughts and impulses.

"Pluto grips the mind and draws forth images and thoughts that we have usually managed to keep hidden or have previously denied were there." (The Gods of Change).

As Mr Kendrick gropes around for something more substantial than men behaving badly, he'll feel the pressure to shake taboos and be daring, provocative and rude - and he's got to risk making his current readers uncomfortable.

One way he could give Loaded more impact would be to evoke Pluto as the planet of psychology and poke around in the murky depths of what makes Loaded Man tick - cute little motifs such as masturbation, castration and Oedipus (mother fucking).

But however Mr Kendrick deals with the scary issue of the male shadow, expect controversy this summer.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Euroland prepares for real money
fields.standfirst:
Ian Black on how the euroland countries are preparing their citizens for the arrival of euro notes and coins in 333 days' time

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Ian Black in Brussels on how the euroland countries are preparing their citizens for the arrival of euro notes and coins in 333 days' time.
fields.body:
Lise has a sweet smile and wide eyes - and she wants to make it easier for her fellow countrymen and women to adapt to the biggest currency changeover they have ever seen.

''L'euro est plus facile ensemble'' - the euro is easier together - she says.

Lise's pretty pre-teen face and encouraging message have been splashed all over newspapers and TV screens in France in the last few days, the first sign of the ambitious advertising campaigns getting under way as euroland prepares for the big day.

The timetable is clear - and immutable: euro notes and coins go into circulation in just under 11 months, next January 1, and there is much hard work to be done before then.

Everyone knows that their deutschemarks, francs, lira, guilders, drachmas, pesetas and schillings will be disappearing for good.

But over 300m people in 12 countries must also get used to the fact that what has been a "virtual'' currency since January 1999, used only for paper financial transactions, is about to become the real thing.

And real means the staggering 15bn banknotes and 56bn coins which will have been shipped to banks and retail outlets by December 15 and will be in full use a fortnight later.

Yet there is still far too little understanding of this enormous change.

''Surveys show that public knowledge of the euro is improving,'' Pedro Solbes, the European commissioner in charge of economic and monetary affairs, said this week.''But many people still have only a vague idea about the actual changeover timetable. And most consumers have still not begun to acquaint themselves with the new scale of values. To remedy this, far more information will have to be made available.''

In Frankfurt, European central bank officials agree, but are careful to emphasise the distinction between the role of the euro system - the ECB plus the 12 national central banks - and that of national governments.

''National campaigns are addressing more political themes in the sense that they are selling the euro to their population and trying to foster confidence,'' said one. ''The Euro System is focussing on a product - the banknotes and coins. The scope of these two messages is quite different.''

Here is snapshot of how the information is being conveyed to ordinary people 333 days before E-Day.

In Germany, euroland's largest member, the euro action committee began its campaign in December with its central message that ''real values will prevail'' scheduled to increase in intensity in a five stage campaign throughout the year.

Plans include newspaper adverts, TV spots, a ''euro-tent'' tour, a telephone hotline and internet sites.

Ireland, one of the zone's smallest economies, is having an advertising campaign on the theme ''one year to go.'' People are being encouraged to use up hoarded coins before what is being dubbed Changeover Day.

In the Netherlands - which has the best euro website of the 12 - information efforts double this year compared to 2001. Campaigns will focus on the dual display of prices, characteristics of the new notes and coins and guidelines on how to act in the period of dual circulation.

Special programmes are being prepared for the mentally handicapped and ethnic minorities.

Italy has concentrated on a TV campaign using actors struggling with euro calculations in ''normal'' daily situations. In one sketch a man flirts with a pretty shop assistant while his wife waits outside.

And the public are being encouraged to learn an easy conversion formula - ''take out the zeros, divide by two, and there you are.'' Soccer games are to be used to explain basic issues.

In Belgium an operation to collect hoarded national coins will be conducted from October 15 to November 15. Everything, of course, has to be published in both French and Dutch.

Portuguese are using touch screens for euro information and there are campaigns tailored specially for schools and the tourist industry. The Lisbon underground has done its own dedicated work.

Some of the 12 euroland countries are more advanced than others. France's slick publicity campaign, run by the Publicis group, puts it at the top of the preparations league: all civil servants are due to be paid in euros from July 3.

And since last month all electricity and gas invoices have been detailed in euros only - though the total is still in dual display.

Finland is placing special emphasis on small and medium enterprises - identified by Mr Solbes as the key problem everywhere: one in every three believes it is too early to make preparations and has not worked out how the changeover will affect them.

Ominously for Finnish consumers, tabloid newspapers have already rounded up their prices from five to six markka -the exchange value of the euro.

Right across euroland there is a recognition that a smooth transition is vital for political reasons and thus that the millions of citizens for whom the whole thing is still a distant nightmare must be helped to master the intricacies ahead.

''Conversion to the euro remains an abstract notion in the minds of many,'' admitted the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, as he launched little Lise's face across the land. ''Our intention is to make each of us feel concerned.''

And in France, as everywhere else, old habits will certainly die hard, as one journalist neatly illustrated, writing: ''The learning campaign will cost France 120 million francs each year - Oops, that's 18.3 million euros a year.''

webTitle: Martin Woollacott on the nonsense of European decision-making

fields.headline: Germany's strength shows up the union's weakness
fields.standfirst:
European decision-making is often negotiated into nonsense

Special report: European integration
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: European decision-making is often negotiated into nonsense.
fields.body:
If the Archduke Francis Ferdinand had not married beneath himself, it has been speculated, Europe might well have avoided its 20th-century wars. The archduke would still have been assassinated in Sarajevo in June 1914, but instead of the meagre 15-minute funeral ceremony which Emperor Francis Joseph then ordained, there would instead have been a full gathering of the crowned heads of Europe. They, while consoling the old man, would have backed Austria's demands on Serbia, or in some other way arrived at a solution to the problem.

Hence, perhaps, no first world war and no second world war, but instead a long period of order and democratic evolution. Coming to our times, Prince Charles might have contemplated marriage with a Hohenzollern princess. If such a different century had happened, given the energy and capacity for growth that Germany had shown before 1914, it would have been a "German century" marked not by conflict and destruction, but by economic success and by a hegemony peacefully achieved.

The Germany of today cannot be blamed for occasionally musing that what did not happen in the 20th century might still in some way be possible in the 21st. The other European states, however, spent the same years protecting themselves against German power, and the habits of the past are not easily set aside. Such shades do still loiter behind the arras when France and Germany debate today's issues of reform and change in the European union, or when Britain considers joining the common currency. Of course, Germany's recent pressure for a constitutional definition of powers in the union is not a bid for dominance in Europe. Yet the combination of Germany's economic prowess and Germany's reforming instincts in Europe do give other countries cause for concern.

The reason is that Germany, alone among European states, has nothing to lose in advocating a more federal union. Germany has the largest population in Europe, and generates a third of the eurozone's gross product. Its corporations are embarking on a new phase of expansion in this continent and in North America characterised both by much friction and by large ambitions. It is the dominant outside economic power in eastern Europe, where local firms fall to its investors every month.

France is economically vigorous as well, and Britain and other countries are not wholly out of the race, but Germany's greater weight is clear. Germany is reorganising its armed forces and will, in the not too distant future, be able to match French and British military capacities. The simple point in this is that the most powerful member of a federation is not often outvoted or outclassed. Its derogation of powers to the supranational level is more nominal than real, since it will frequently get its way at the centre without great difficulty. Indeed, its power may well be enhanced by federation.

The German demand for extra votes for Germany at the Nice summit, a demand that was only headed off by other concessions that also give Germany a numerical advantage in European decision-making, dramatised these issues. At the same time as Germany argued for constitutional changes, it tried to ensure that, when those changes came, it would be in a strong position to win most of the arguments.

If one was to be completely cynical about the German line on the definition of powers, it might be said that the aim is to reserve to Germany the powers it deems essential to keep under absolutely full control while arranging to dominate the use of the powers that Germany and all the rest of us would pass to European institutions. The truth, no doubt, is more middling: European idealism and the German left's tradition of anchoring German power within a containing European framework play as much a part as any calculation of self-interest.

Yet Joschka Fischer and Chancellor Schröder have not been shrewd or considerate in their timing. Schröder's sudden enthusiasm for his foreign minister's views, from which he earlier preserved a certain distance, suggests a lurching quality to Germany's policy-making. France is already deep into the campaign for this year's local and next year's general elections, a campaign in which Lionel Jospin and Jacques Chirac will both try to steer a delicate course on European matters. Britain also faces an election in which Europe will be an issue, to be followed (assuming a Labour victory) by a referendum on the euro. Other members of the union have their special difficulties. Not the moment, perhaps, at which to stir the pot.

But this is not how Germans see the problem, which arises instead, as Gunther Nonnenmacher of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung puts it, from the "fixed fundamental beliefs" of the French political class. These beliefs are that the union provides a structure within which French rivalry with Germany can be peacefully pursued with the aim of ensuring "precedence over Germany or at least equal status". Nonnenmacher adds that France seems equally disturbed when Germany fails to lead as when it tries to do so.

Other members of the union might not disagree with that thumbnail sketch of French attitudes. What can be held against both countries is their failure to grasp the alienating effect on others of their continuing pre-occupation with each other. Even if Germany sees itself as weaning France away from a too exclusive relationship, the effort to do so still leaves other states in the irritating position of onlookers, or being forced to choose sides when they do not wish to do so. French and German leaders came out of their informal summit on Wednesday, supposed to ease the strains of Nice, stressing that the Franco-German relationship was as strong as ever and that the "deepening" of Europe was a joint priority. What that means, if anything, we will wait to see, but French and German differences have surely not disappeared this week over a few plates of foie gras and choucroute in Strasbourg.

The European story is a strange one. Every day we argue the merits of various schemes of governance that will make Europe more united, and every day we demonstrate a refusal to arrive at common policies in everything from the regulation of telecommunications to relations with Iraq. Javier de Solana, in charge of Europe's common foreign and security policy, complained recently that we either cannot arrive at one or, when we do, that it is so "over-negotiated" as to be useless.

It might be deemed sensible to try to achieve an informal unity of policy before trying to impose unity institutionally, and that is the main objection to Germany's present approach. That, and the fact that it is less selfless than it appears. If German leaders were to admit that the federal path is significantly easier for them to take than it is for others, more honest discussions might then be possible.

webTitle: Working families miss out on tax help

fields.headline: Working families miss out on tax help
fields.trailText: Too many of Britain's needy families are failing to claim a new top-up tax credit because it is just to complicated to understand, according to research from a tax pressure group.
fields.body:
Too many of Britain's needy families are failing to claim a new top-up tax credit because it is just to complicated to understand, according to research from a tax pressure group.

The Working Families Tax Credit (WFTC) was introduced in October 1999 and was designed to make returning to work worthwhile. It replaced an existing scheme called Family Credit.

But the pressure group Low Incomes Tax Reform Group (LITRG) says there are up to 1.5 million working families who could claim the benefit, but only 1,223,000 have already done so.

It says the reasons include complexity and that many people have not heard of WFTC. This is despite the fact that the Government spent £5 million on an advertising campaign last November, which has now ended.

David Robinson, the author of the LITRG group, said those who most need to claim were likely to be "more financially unsophisticated, and yet unlikely to seek or be able to afford professional advice. It seemed to us vital that the rules and processes should be both simple and accessible."

The LITRG is particularly anxious to sort out problems for self-employed people as they have faced an administrative nightmare trying to obtain the benefit.

There have been some moves in the right direction here. At the end of last year, in response mainly to representations from the LITRG and charity TaxAid, the Inland Revenue did agree to allow make matters easier. Now self-employed people with a low turnover send in a three-line statement of account, showing receipts, expenses and profit, in line with the requirement for self-assessment. Before then, they had to send in a full set of accounts, or work through more than 30 boxes on the application form, to claim their entitlement.

But, even after that relaxation, the self-employed still face the hurdle of computing their income twice, once for self-assessment, and again for WFTC.

WFTC has led to some unfair results, particularly in the treatment of couples, according to LITRG. It says the basic and child tax credits for a lone parent with, for example, two children can be no different from those for a couple with two children of the same age and with the same after tax income. This means the children of a couple in work are less likely to be taken out of poverty by the WFTC than are the children of a working lone parent.

Although LITRG has made recommendations as to how this can be improved, it has come up against a stumbling block since the Inland Revenue says the computer system it inherited from the DSS would not be able to cope with necessary changes.

Despite this, the Government is already claiming some success and says the take of WFTC is better than Family Credit. It says some 2.2 million children are now better off as a result of WFTC. He says over 1.1 million families are already receiving the WFTC, some 300,000 more than claimed Family Credit at its peak.

Chancellor Gordon Brown said on average each family is receiving over £76 a week, which is around £30 better off than the average family would have been under Family Credit.

With the UK economy still strong, the Government wants more unemployed people to move back into the workforce. It says there are around a million vacancies and believes it is a real incentive when wages are boosted by WFTC.

Paymaster General Dawn Primarolo said: "WFTC means that working families will no longer need to apply to the social security office to take home a living income."

The amount of WFTC available is dependent on a number of factors such as income, number of hours worked each week, number and ages of children, savings and amount paid in childcare. Any family with a full-time worker is guaranteed a take-home pay at least £208 a week - equivalent to £10,700 a year.

WFTC can be contacted on 0800 597 5976

fields.headline: Disgraced pathologist to lose job
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Dick van Velzen, the pathologist who was severely criticised in the Redfern report for systematically stripping organs from hundreds of children at Liverpool's Alder Hey hospital, is about to lose his job at a Dutch hospital.
fields.body:
Dick van Velzen, the pathologist who was severely criticised in the Redfern report for systematically stripping organs from hundreds of children at Liverpool's Alder Hey hospital, is about to lose his job at a Dutch hospital.

Staff at the Medisch Centruk Haaglanden hospital in the Hague, where Professor van Velzen has been on extended leave, said he would be dismissed as soon as they could make contact with him. The disgraced pathologist regards himself as a misunderstood genius and claims he has been made a scapegoat by the Redfern report.

Prof van Velzen, who was in charge of pathology at Alder Hey between 1988 and 1995, has not been seen at his home since Monday night when he fled with his wife and daughter.

A spokesman for the Dutch hospital said: "The board of directors of the medical centre hopes to terminate its contract with Dr van Velzen soon. He will not be returning to work at this hospital."

The disgraced professor, 51, was defended by another pathologist, Mathilde Boon, who said he had been used as a scapegoat by politicians. She said: "They blamed him because he was a Dutch national working in a British hospital. The politicians needed someone to blame for a failing NHS." She added that Prof van Velzen was a champion of pathology, but he had been hounded out of his job.

The director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith QC, is considering whether any charges will be brought against Prof van Velzen. He will make his recommendations to health secretary, Alan Milburn. Many of the parents caught up in the organ reten tion scandal have called for the pathologist to be prosecuted.

Yesterday, Alder Hey hospital received a much needed boost when it was announced that a wealthy businessman had donated £1.5m to its Rocking Horse appeal.

John Hargreaves, the reclusive millionaire founder and chairman of the Matalan discount chain, handed the money over after a private visit to the hospital, several months ago.

A spokesman for the appeal said it was a "wonderful, phenomenal boost" to Alder Hey. The money had been handed over several months ago, but the hospital chose not publicise the news until after the Redfern report came out, in order not to upset the families affected by organ retention.

It will be used to build the first integrated cancer unit for children in the country. Building work on the new unit will begin in spring.

The appeal spokesman said: "John Hargreaves made a private visit to the hospital and offered this magnificent contribution in memory of his mother Christina."

The money was also in return for the care that Mr Hargreaves's three children received at the hospital.

"The money is very significant for us and now work is under way to build the unit," he added.

The appeal, which needs to raise £10m to build the new unit, has reached £7.8m as a result of the donation.

Mr Hargreaves, 57, who began his business from a market stall and is now Britain's second highest earner, does not give interviews, but he did say: "I am very much behind this appeal."

webTitle: Patient asks for right to die

fields.headline: 'After 300 operations, just let me die'
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old man who has undergone 300 operations, including 17 colostomies, to correct a rare bowel disorder, has asked surgeons to let him die rather than risk another failed operation.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old man who has undergone 300 operations, including 17 colostomies, to correct a rare bowel disorder, has asked surgeons to let him die rather than risk another failed operation.

Danny Bond, who lives in Southampton with his mother and stepfather, has lived in constant pain since being born with chronic pseudo-obstruct, a condition which prevents the nerves between the brain and the bowel communicating. He has never been able to empty his bowel and is fed through a tube, which requires him to be attached to a feeding machine 10 hours a day.

Currently in Southampton general hospital, Mr Bond is refusing treatment, but said that if an illiostomy were to be offered to him by Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridgeshire he would consider having it.

It is a transplant operation and of the nine people who have undergone it, only two have survived.

"I used to cope," Mr Bond told BBC 2's Southern Eye programme. "But not any more. The decision I made was not to have any more surgery and that would end in dying, which is a gift really, because it would take away the pain."

Three years ago Mr Bond's system was further weakened by the penicillin-resistant superbug, MRSA, a recurring illness which infects the line in his chest and requires him to undergo operations to remove the tube. He has twice attempted suicide because of the pain.

"Have you ever seen [the film] Aliens?" he said. "It's like one of these little creatures inside your stomach trying to pop out.

"The pain is excruciating. Doctors have likened it to that of a woman in labour."

Mr Bond's mother, Beverley Dodds, said: "Of course I don't want him to die. But I love him enough to let him die.

"There's just got to be a better way because this is awful."

She added: "Half of me wants to give him the [pill] box and say, 'There you are, Dan,' and the other half, as a mum, wants to protect him."

During the making of the documentary, Mr Bond attempted to kill himself by injecting painkillers down the line in his chest. He became unconscious before he was able to administer a lethal dose.

His stepfather Mike, a hostage negotiator, said: "I am frequently called to incidents where somebody is indicating that they want to end their life. My function is to try to talk them out of it.

"But if somebody genuinely wants to end their life, then I don't think anybody should interfere."

Sir Ludovic Kennedy, president of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society, said: "This makes a cast-iron case for the decriminalisation of euthanasia.

"Danny has had more than 300 operations. It's terrible that anyone should suffer that. It is the quality of life that is important rather than the length of life. And Danny has no quality of life."

Mr Bond said: "I have had no childhood, no teenage years at all. I've always been stuck in a hospital cubicle or in my own room doing nothing. I have had enough."
