fields.headline: Welsh reforms may prompt row
fields.trailText: The Welsh assembly could trigger a "postcode lottery" row after publishing a radical NHS reforms package that includes plans to make free prescriptions more widely available than in England. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly could trigger a "postcode lottery" row after publishing a radical NHS reforms package that includes plans to make free prescriptions more widely available than in England.

The plan, called Improving Health in Wales, also confirms that community health councils (CHCs) - the local patient watchdog bodies set to be abolished in England for being outdated - are to be retained.

It proposes to freeze prescription charges at current levels and provide free prescriptions and dental checks to all under the age of 25. In England, free prescriptions are available to those under 18 or in full-time education.

The initiative effectively creates a two-tier prescription drugs pricing system enforced by postcode which will give young Welsh residents and students a cheaper service to that available in England.

The move follows last week's decision by the Scottish executive to use their devolved powers to introduce free personal care for elderly people in residential homes - also in the face of UK government policy.

That decision - and the Welsh CHCs decision - will further encourage Westminster MPs and lobby groups who want the UK government to amend its health and social care bill currently going through parliament.

UK ministers have refused to budge on providing free personal care for the elderly in long-term care in England and have made it clear they have no intention to reprieve CHCs.

A spokesman for the Association of CHCs in England and Wales welcomed the Welsh NHS plan and said Welsh CHCs would expect to have the right to check conditions in English hospitals to which Welsh residents have been referred.

Welsh first minister Rhodri Morgan today formally introduced the plan. It has been dubbed as a "re-launch of the NHS in Wales" that will transform the health of Welsh people and drive up the quality of NHS services.

But the Welsh NHS Confederation, which represents trusts and health authorities in the principality questioned whether the all the proposals would be affordable.

"The cost implications are enormous. Not everything is affordable and politicians will have to bite some very hard budgets over what services they will stop doing in order to afford all this," said Welsh confederation director Richard Thomas.

The plan abolishes Wales' five health authorities and effectively brings NHS strategic planning under direct control of the Welsh assembly.

A raft of initiatives will be introduced to put patients at the centre of health care provision and decision making, and to give local authorities more of a say in health planning.

The abolished health authorities' commissioning role will taken on by GP-led local health groups - the Welsh equivalent of English primary care groups.

The plan also heralds the closure of "traditional" local hospitals and their replacement with new forms of secondary care provision. A health and well-being partnership council, chaired by assembly health minister Jane Hutt, is to be created to implement the reforms.

webTitle: Main points of the Welsh NHS plan

fields.headline: Main points of the Welsh NHS plan
fields.trailText: Main points of the Welsh NHS plan
fields.body:
The main points of the Welsh NHS plan:

A patient-centred NHS

 A fresh approach to NHS accountability, with new rights for patients, lay involvement in NHS appointment panels and a more accessible complaints system by 2002.

 Patient advocacy and support working groups will be set up to develop new ways of supporting patient's needs. A network of "expert patients" will be set up by 2003 to support individual patients in the treatment of specific conditions.

 The introduction of patient-held "smart cards", which electronically hold individuals' medical records, will be considered.

 A Wales-wide health and social care charter will be published, making clear to the public how they can access health and what their rights and responsibilities they have within the NHS. Local services will issue their own charters.

Partnership working

 A "new pluralism" approach to decision making that involves patient representatives, staff, managers, local government and the voluntary sector.

 "Dynamic partnerships" between NHS Wales, local government, the independent sector and the community. "Joint working is an essential plank of renewing the NHS," the plan states.

 Local authorities will set up "local health alliances" with their communities to identify local health and well-being issues.

NHS restructuring

 Abolition of Wales' five health authorities - with their strategic role being taken on by the Welsh Assembly and local health groups consisting of GP practices.

 The retention of community health councils - which are being abolished in England.

Health improvement and promotion

 A reduction in health inequalities by closing the gap between Wales and the best of Europe in relation to life expectancy, long-term illnesses and death rates from major illnesses.

 Creation of community health development programmes aimed at giving the public better access to health and social information, and allowing them to identify their own health needs, access care, and develop "self-esteem, confidence and personal skills".

 A review of the public health function in Wales by the Wales chief medical officer, together with production of a new public health strategy by 2002.

 New targets to improve services and outcomes for cancer, coronary heart disease, diabetes, mental health services, children's services, oral health and care of the elderly.

Development of primary care

 A "one-stop shop" approach to primary care provision by developing teams of GPs, practice nurses and community nurses, voluntary organisations, social care and agencies, where possible working together under one roof.

 Freeze prescription charges at current levels, and provide free prescription to all people under the age of 25. There will be free dental checks for the under 25s and those aged 60 or over.

Raised standards in secondary care

 Improved outcomes from hospital treatment, including shorter waiting times for operations, improved provision for emergency admissions, and survival rates to match the best in Europe.

 A more strategic "health economy" approach to service planning, together with "an overall reduction in the number of traditional hospitals over the next generations", to be replace by new forms of secondary care provision, including "hospitals without beds" called primary care resource centres.

 Reforms to the funding of long-term care, including the provision of free nursing care, and measures to reduce the pressure to sell a person's home to pay for care. There is no reference to funding arrangements for personal care in residential homes.

NHS staff

 A partnership approach to workforce issues, including staff representation on NHS boards in Wales during September 2001. A health leadership centre will be established at Wales NHS staff colleges. Human resources innovation teams will be introduced to promote good workplace practices. Increased access to staff development and training.

webTitle: Off-line Whitehall fails to make e-grade

fields.headline: Off-line Whitehall fails to make e-grade
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of government departments are "flunking" the challenge of moving online effectively and endangering Tony Blair's commitment to deliver 100% of public services over the internet by 2005, a survey claims.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of government departments are "flunking" the challenge of moving online effectively and endangering Tony Blair's commitment to deliver 100% of public services over the internet by 2005, a survey claims.

Internet consultancy Forrester Research graded the operations of 14 government departments from A to E - their average D.

Among the worst offenders were the crown prosecution service, Department of Social Security, customs and excise and office of national statistics which all scored E grades. The best were the inland revenue, Department of Trade and Industry, and the Department for Education and Employment, but they only gained C grades.

Deep seated cultural issues and unwieldy processes are the most common reasons blamed by leading technology providers who contributed to the report.

"The UK government's current strategy for delivering online services fails to make the grade," said Forrester analyst Caroline Sceats. "The technology exists to achieve the 2005 targets, but the reality is that the government won't be able to deliver."

Firms like Microsoft, Oracle and IBM said departments had to build external partnerships with organisations outside the public sector if they are to improve.

The figures will be a blow to the government which on Wednesday appointed a former inland revenue chief, Andrew Pinder, as its new e-envoy. "While not wishing to denigrate Mr Pinder's strong abilities it appears there was a big opportunity to appoint someone from the commercial sector to drive this through," said Ms Sceats.

Despite the criticism the government has made several positive strides in the e-commerce arena and remains confident of hitting its 2005 target. Information portal UKOnline has proved a popular source of government information and the government estimates that 40% of its services are already on the web.

webTitle: Was there a plot to get rid of Mandelson ?

fields.headline: Was there a plot to get rid of Mandelson ?
fields.standfirst: MPs' questions over Northern Ireland secretary's departure will not be resolved easily by inquiry
fields.trailText: In his hour of need Peter Mandelson may be conspicuously short of political friends on the Labour benches at Westminster. But, even among his foes, he does not lack conspiracy-minded colleagues who believe he was set up for last week's precipitous fall from power.
fields.body:
In his hour of need Peter Mandelson may be conspicuously short of political friends on the Labour benches at Westminster. But, even among his foes, he does not lack conspiracy-minded colleagues who believe he was set up for last week's precipitous fall from power.

As Labour MPs head for their constituencies nine days after the Northern Ireland secretary's resignation they take with them a spread of theories as to who pushed Mr Mandelson - and why?

A cock-up or a plot? Some of Mr Mandelson's sworn enemies think his resignation must mean there is more Hinduja-related skulduggery to emerge from Sir Anthony Hammond's inquiry. Others think he was stitched up. Either version makes better sense than what is currently known.

The prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, started out as the conspiracy theorists' prime suspect on Wednesday January 24, the day of the resignation. But as the drama unfolded the focus of attention shifted to the Home Office, specifically to Jack Straw and his octopus-like entourage. This weekend, as Mr Mandelson broods on his fate, it is swinging back again.

Last Wednesday it was the Downing Street spokesman whose candid 11am briefing alerted startled reporters to the fact that Mr Mandelson was already astride a horse with a noose around his neck, awaiting only Tony Blair's pat on the horse's rump. It came when he faced TV crews at 1.33pm.

The immediate conspiracy theory was that, in the fight for Blair's ear, Mr Campbell had seen his chance to finish off his old-friend-but-most-serious-rival. Mr Mandelson had been forced out once for a lack of candour over Geoffrey Robinson's £373,000 loan, then allowed back after 10 months. He could not be allowed to embarrass Tony again.

Jonathan Powell, the prime minister's chief of staff, was present at the "kangaroo court" which decided that Mr Mandelson must go. So was Derry Irvine, lord chancellor and Tony Blair's old legal patron, a clumsy politician but forceful. Both are unelected, some MPs note.

Whatever the details (or the threats from his lawyers) both sides agree that Mr Mandelson had been guilty of a series of misjudgments in dealing with the Observer's January 20 inquiries about the Hinduja passport application, with Mr Campbell in the succeeding 48 hours and - by implication - with Mr Blair.

In short, unless Mr Mandelson was right to say he could not remember the June 1998 phone call to Mike O'Brien because it had never taken place, he must have lied. Mr Mandelson wavers on the point: at one stage he was saying that the very fact that civil servants had listened in proved he had nothing to hide.

But the plot quickly thickened. Once Mr Campbell had told reporters of the error - his friend, Peter, had indeed spoken to Mr O'Brien - and Mr Mandelson had contradicted him publicly on TV on January 23, the man dispatched to get to the bottom of it all was the also unelected cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.

Before he got the top job Wilson was permanent secretary at the Home Office. Though billed as a former Treasury solicitor by Downing Street, Sir Anthony Hammond QC, now in charge of the investigation, was himself legal adviser to the Home Office. Few MPs expect him to prove a better Sherlock Holmes than Sir Richard.

Some Labour MPs with ministerial insight into the ways of Whitehall say: "Peter was a loose cannon on the deck, roaming too far across Whitehall. During his trip to Syria over Christmas he was treated as if he was already foreign secretary. The permanent secretaries, led by Wilson, saw their chance and took it."

By that theory Mr Straw was their chosen instrument. But was he a conscious agent or an unwitting one? In Mr Mandelson's own version, his ill-judged, rambling account in the Sunday Times (dictated at intervals on the hoof) acknowledges that the home secretary had reminded him of the O'Brien call the previous week.

They spoke because Mr Straw wanted to agree what his junior minister, Barbara Roche, should say in her Commons answer to the Lib Dem MP Norman Baker. Mr Straw is usually thought of as straight-acting "with complete consistency and integrity" Mandelson wrote. Yet Labour critics of his proudly-illiberal stance on civil liberty say that he has also misled the Commons. Mr Blair himself is notoriously slack with mere facts at question time.

After all, say the Westminster conspiracy theorists, Mr Straw wants to be foreign secretary, the post Mr Mandelson coveted until recently, and possibly prime minister. It also happens that Keith Vaz, a fellow barrister, shares his legal chambers, it emerged last night.

If the Home Office granted the Hindujas their UK passports, despite their unsavoury reputations in India, it might be wise to deflect whatever scandal looms. Who better to take the hit than Mr Mandelson, a man famously short of friends on the backbenches ?

One shrewd Labour MP said this week that Mr Mandelson reminded him of Al Capone. "We all know he went to jail for tax evasion, but that tax evasion wasn't the real reason."

Robert Harris, the fallen minister's novelist friend, thinks that Captain Dreyfus, the French-Jewish officer jailed for treason in 1894, is a better parallel. As with the suggestion that homophobia lay behind the fall, both comparisons are extravagant.

But the questions which hover over the affair will not be resolved easily by secrecy-minded Whitehall investigators on the eve of an election. That is why Mr Mandelson and his allies are fighting in public.

For once the prince of darkness fears the dark. And he should know.

Suspects for the conspiracy theorists

Alastair Campbell

Did he want to be rid of a rival for Blair's ear? The press secretary told reporters on the Monday after the fateful Observer report that Mr Mandelson had had no direct contact with Mike O'Brien over the Hinduja passport . "He [Campbell] briefed further than he had to," say critics. On Tuesday he volunteered a correction of the error. On Wedneday he virtually told lobby journalists that the Northern Ireland secretary was out two hours before the announcement.

Sir Richard Wilson

Did he want to remove a powerful minister who used Blair's friendship to roam across too many Whitehall departments causing trouble? As cabinet secretary, Sir Richard drew up the who- said-what report which convinced Mr Blair that Mandelson had lied (again), as he did over his mortgage. But he did not speak to officials in his Cabinet Office team who might have backed Mandelson's version. Incompetence or a skilled courtier's manoeuvre?

Jack Straw

Did he want to destroy a rival who also coveted the foreign secretaryship ? It was the home secretary's phone call to Mr Blair that contradicted the Mandelson line that he never spoke to Mr O'Brien. He also put the boot in on Sunday's Dimbleby TV show.

Part of the "kangaroo court" which condemned Mandelson. Both are close to Blair, the lord chancellor his old legal boss, Powell his chief of staff.

Tireless Lib Dem MP for Lewes and scourge of the dome. Was he primed by Mandelson's enemies in Labour's ranks with shrewd Commons questions?
fields.bodyText: In his hour of need Peter Mandelson may be conspicuously short of political friends on the Labour benches at Westminster. But, even among his foes, he does not lack conspiracy-minded colleagues who believe he was set up for last week's precipitous fall from power. As Labour MPs head for their constituencies nine days after the Northern Ireland secretary's resignation they take with them a spread of theories as to who pushed Mr Mandelson - and why? A cock-up or a plot? Some of Mr Mandelson's sworn enemies think his resignation must mean there is more Hinduja-related skulduggery to emerge from Sir Anthony Hammond's inquiry. Others think he was stitched up. Either version makes better sense than what is currently known. The prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, started out as the conspiracy theorists' prime suspect on Wednesday January 24, the day of the resignation. But as the drama unfolded the focus of attention shifted to the Home Office, specifically to Jack Straw and his octopus-like entourage. This weekend, as Mr Mandelson broods on his fate, it is swinging back again. Last Wednesday it was the Downing Street spokesman whose candid 11am briefing alerted startled reporters to the fact that Mr Mandelson was already astride a horse with a noose around his neck, awaiting only Tony Blair's pat on the horse's rump. It came when he faced TV crews at 1.33pm. The immediate conspiracy theory was that, in the fight for Blair's ear, Mr Campbell had seen his chance to finish off his old-friend-but-most-serious-rival. Mr Mandelson had been forced out once for a lack of candour over Geoffrey Robinson's £373,000 loan, then allowed back after 10 months. He could not be allowed to embarrass Tony again. Jonathan Powell, the prime minister's chief of staff, was present at the "kangaroo court" which decided that Mr Mandelson must go. So was Derry Irvine, lord chancellor and Tony Blair's old legal patron, a clumsy politician but forceful. Both are unelected, some MPs note. Whatever the details (or the threats from his lawyers) both sides agree that Mr Mandelson had been guilty of a series of misjudgments in dealing with the Observer's January 20 inquiries about the Hinduja passport application, with Mr Campbell in the succeeding 48 hours and - by implication - with Mr Blair. In short, unless Mr Mandelson was right to say he could not remember the June 1998 phone call to Mike O'Brien because it had never taken place, he must have lied. Mr Mandelson wavers on the point: at one stage he was saying that the very fact that civil servants had listened in proved he had nothing to hide. But the plot quickly thickened. Once Mr Campbell had told reporters of the error - his friend, Peter, had indeed spoken to Mr O'Brien - and Mr Mandelson had contradicted him publicly on TV on January 23, the man dispatched to get to the bottom of it all was the also unelected cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson. Before he got the top job Wilson was permanent secretary at the Home Office. Though billed as a former Treasury solicitor by Downing Street, Sir Anthony Hammond QC, now in charge of the investigation, was himself legal adviser to the Home Office. Few MPs expect him to prove a better Sherlock Holmes than Sir Richard. Some Labour MPs with ministerial insight into the ways of Whitehall say: "Peter was a loose cannon on the deck, roaming too far across Whitehall. During his trip to Syria over Christmas he was treated as if he was already foreign secretary. The permanent secretaries, led by Wilson, saw their chance and took it." By that theory Mr Straw was their chosen instrument. But was he a conscious agent or an unwitting one? In Mr Mandelson's own version, his ill-judged, rambling account in the Sunday Times (dictated at intervals on the hoof) acknowledges that the home secretary had reminded him of the O'Brien call the previous week. They spoke because Mr Straw wanted to agree what his junior minister, Barbara Roche, should say in her Commons answer to the Lib Dem MP Norman Baker. Mr Straw is usually thought of as straight-acting "with complete consistency and integrity" Mandelson wrote. Yet Labour critics of his proudly-illiberal stance on civil liberty say that he has also misled the Commons. Mr Blair himself is notoriously slack with mere facts at question time. After all, say the Westminster conspiracy theorists, Mr Straw wants to be foreign secretary, the post Mr Mandelson coveted until recently, and possibly prime minister. It also happens that Keith Vaz, a fellow barrister, shares his legal chambers, it emerged last night. If the Home Office granted the Hindujas their UK passports, despite their unsavoury reputations in India, it might be wise to deflect whatever scandal looms. Who better to take the hit than Mr Mandelson, a man famously short of friends on the backbenches ? One shrewd Labour MP said this week that Mr Mandelson reminded him of Al Capone. As with the suggestion that homophobia lay behind the fall, both comparisons are extravagant. But the questions which hover over the affair will not be resolved easily by secrecy-minded Whitehall investigators on the eve of an election. That is why Mr Mandelson and his allies are fighting in public. For once the prince of darkness fears the dark. And he should know. fields.headline: MPs accuse 'interfering' chancellor
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A cross-party Commons committee last night enraged Gordon Brown by accusing the Treasury of sticking its nose too much into other departments' business under his leadership - instead of concentrating on its own responsibilities.
fields.body:
A cross-party Commons committee last night enraged Gordon Brown by accusing the Treasury of sticking its nose too much into other departments' business under his leadership - instead of concentrating on its own responsibilities.

The Labour-dominated Treasury select committee complained that the influence of Whitehall's biggest department had "substantially increased" in recent years with the result that "the Treasury as an institution has recently begun to exert too much influence over policy areas which are properly the business of other departments".

The result "is not necessarily in the best interests of the Treasury or the government as a whole," says the committee. It quotes a former official as saying that macro-economic policy "is very boring [so] we are getting very interested in social policy."

The passion of Mr Brown's frequent speeches on poverty and social exclusion bear out that claim.

It did not stop Treasury officials protesting last night that the chancellor has devolved power and control over their new three year budgets to departments, and gave control over interest rates to the Bank of England in his first week in office.

Though the latest report from the committee, chaired by the Labour loyalist Giles Radice, praised the Treasury's reputation as a worldwide innovator in reform of public finance, it also complained that it lacked the in-house expertise to vet the likely effect of tax changes on the economy.

A third significant complaint, which the Treasury may be forced to address if Tony Blair decides to intervene, is that the new performance-related public service agreements with individual ministries and agencies are set by Mr Brown and audited by him too.

That makes him "too powerful". More external audit by the national audit office or another independent body is needed, the MPs concluded. A non-Treasury chairman of the cabinet's public spending committee, more in the honest broker role once played by Willie Whitelaw, would also help, they said. Without naming Mr Brown, the committee's bland prose amounted to a criticism of the chancellor's restless influence across Whitehall which has upset many ministers since 1997, even those who regard him as the moral and intellectual linchpin of the Blair administration. "Witnesses commented that the political strength of the chancellor of the exchequer was one factor explaining the current power and influence of the Treasury," the report confirmed.

That makes Mr Brown the Conservatives' chief target and last night Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor, led the attack. Mr Brown "has spent three years trying to micro-manage other government departments while he is actually guilty of mismanaging his own," Mr Portillo said.

Treasury committee member David Ruffley, Tory MP for Bury St Edmunds and an adviser to Kenneth Clarke at the Treasury, said Mr Brown was "guilty of messing up the tax system". Mr Radice himself called it a "very balanced report" that had voted against splitting up the Treasury as some countries have done.

The Tory charge that Mr Brown's £25bn of "amateurish" extra taxes since 1997 (mainly the result of rising economic success) have hurt working families and damaged business is not quite what the Radice committee said.

But the committee's conclusions will increase pressure on Mr Blair to assert his prime ministerial authority over the Treasury. Part of the problem, the MPs noted, is success after decades in which the Treasury "lurched from macro-economic crisis to crisis unable to take a long-term view of the policy issues it encountered because of short-term contingencies". In other words Mr Brown now has time on his hands.

The committee said Mr Brown gaves the impression of having taken over wholesale key policy-making areas such as welfare reform from departments like social security and trade and industry.

"It is important, however, that once expenditure priorities have been set, departments are left with the task of detailed delivery," said their re port. The result was a failure to grasp the problem of tax reform, supposedly one of New Labour's main objectives.

"Tax policy may be less exciting than reforming the welfare system but it is no less important... we firmly believe that, in the area of tax policy, the Treasury could do better."

webTitle: Thousand would-be castaways vie for chance of 20 years on Welsh island

fields.headline: Thousand would-be castaways vie for chance of 20 years on Welsh island
fields.trailText: More than 1,100 people from across the world have applied to become professional castaways on a remote Welsh island populated by one nun, two nature reserve wardens, 400 sheep and the spirits of 20,000 Celtic saints.
fields.body:
More than 1,100 people from across the world have applied to become professional castaways on a remote Welsh island populated by one nun, two nature reserve wardens, 400 sheep and the spirits of 20,000 Celtic saints.

The trust which owns Bardsey Island, in Cardigan Bay off the Llyn peninsula, wants to recruit a farmer (or two) willing to commit him/herself to 20 years of hard work on a 444 acre mix of rock and pasture stuffed with Celtic legends.

The farmer would have to buy a lease costing up to £30,000 and invest in a tractor, and a boat to reach the mainland. He/she would also be required to manage the sheep.

News of the trust's hunt for a tenant broke after Christmas and applications have since flooded into the office of Simon Glyn, the trust's director. "We were flooded with calls, letters and emails from as far away as Australia," said Mr Glyn. But many applicants have turned out to be dreamers.

Bardsey, or Ynys Enlli, may have been the Isle of Avalon to which King Arthur was taken after the battle of Camlann, and Merlin, his magician, is said to sleep in a magical glass castle on the island.

Many British applicants showed interest after watching Castaway, the BBC television series which followed for a year the lives of voluntary exiles on the Hebridean island of Taransay.

Mr Glyn said:"The flood of applicants tells me that there are some very sad people out there who are dissatisfied with their lives."

Many had no practical experience or useful skills.

"We are looking for a very special kind of person who is happy to collect rainwater from the roof of the cottage, who can live without electricity when supplies of diesel for the generator run out, and who does not mind using a composting toilet at the bottom of the garden. We want people who are very resourceful and self-sufficient, people who like their own company."

Mr Glyn has sent out almost 60 tenancy application forms and just 10 have been returned, including one from two Welsh-speaking US citizens who met in a Welsh language class in New York.

"I am confident there is someone out there who fits the bill," he said.

fields.headline: Indonesia starts impeaching Wahid
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The future of President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia looked precarious yesterday after his vice-president and the army deserted him, and parliament began the process of impeachment by censuring him for his alleged involvement in two financial scandals.
fields.body:
The future of President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia looked precarious yesterday after his vice-president and the army deserted him, and parliament began the process of impeachment by censuring him for his alleged involvement in two financial scandals.

The MPs asked for the the two cases to be forwarded to prosecutors for possible criminal proceedings.

More than 10,000 demonstrators marched through Jakarta to the parliament, demanding clean government and a clear reform agenda.

The parliament's deputy chairman said the memorandum to Mr Wahid stated that he had violated his oath of office and a decree on main taining clean government. The president has three months to reply to the memorandum and improve his performance.

If MPs are still dissatisfied at the end of April they can issue a second warning, after which he will have 30 days to change. If he has not done so, a vote to remove him can be held.

Last night Mr Wahid repeated that he was innocent of the charges and had no intention of resigning. "It's up to the voters," he said. "They still support me, so why should I desert them."

Alvin Lie, the MP who began the inquiry into the scandals, said the president"should opt for a graceful exit and resign".

"The legitimacy of the president has dropped to almost zero," the parliamentary speaker, Amien Rais, said. "This has created problems for the economy, politics and the country's social fabric. The quicker this [impeachment] process goes, the better."

It became clear that Mr Wahid would not survive the impeachment debate when Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri's Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP) said it would no longer support him.

Mr Wahid's party has only 10% of the seats, the PDIP is the biggest party, with 35%.

"We're mandated by our constituency to uphold the law and the constitution, so we should not tolerate any corruption," Laksamana Sukardi, who read out the PDIP's stance on the financial scandals, said.

The military representatives in the parliament also voted against Mr Wahid.

"This is a matter of morality and we have to take a stance," General Hari Sabarno said.

A four-month parliamentary investigation found that Mr Wahid "could be suspected of playing a role" in his masseur's the theft of £2.75m from the state logistics agency.

It also said he had been deliberately inconsistent in explaining how he spent a £1.4m gift from the Sultan of Brunei, which was intended for social welfare.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Smallest robot unveiled
fields.body:
Smallest robot unveiled

Engineers at US government labs in New Mexico have unveiled the world's smallest robot. It is less than 7mm in any direction, but has wheels, a processor, temperature sensor, two motors and three watch batteries on board. The next generation could also carry a miniature camera, communication device and chemical microsensor.

Double blunder hits girl, 3

A three-year-old girl sent home from hospital when her broken leg was not diagnosed returned five days later - and had the wrong leg put in plaster. Doncaster royal infirmary in South Yorkshire said it was carrying out an inquiry and staff had visited the family to apologise. Courtney Blake's mother Kelly Ann, of Rossington, said: "I'm totally disgusted."

Singer taken ill on stage

Buster Bloodvessel, frontman of 80s band Bad Manners, is seriously ill in hospital after collapsing on stage during a gig in Italy. The 30 stone singer, real name Douglas Trendle, has a strangulated hernia.

Free nature trips for u-16s

Children under 16 could be allowed free entry to nature attractions in the capital. The Greater London authority's Passport to Nature project proposes free trips to London Zoo, Kew Gardens, and nature reserves.

Gene research gets £33m

British scientists and companies were yesterday invited to apply for a share of £33m offered by the biotechnology and biological sciences research council to help them exploit gene discoveries.

fields.headline: Charmer Bush woos Democrats
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush is mounting a charm offensive to persuade senior Democrats that he is ready and willing to work with them as he begins to push his legislative agenda through the US Congress.
fields.body:
President George Bush is mounting a charm offensive to persuade senior Democrats that he is ready and willing to work with them as he begins to push his legislative agenda through the US Congress.

The most dramatic example of his detente strategy came when the White House confirmed yesterday that the Republican president will take the unprecedented step of addressing Democratic members of the House of Representatives at their private annual retreat this weekend at a Pennsylvania mountain resort.

A White House adviser, Don Eberly, claimed that the new administration's approach was "the ultimate third way". In a Washington Post interview, Mr Eberly said Mr Bush aimed at nothing less than "to rethink social policy" in line with communitarian principles set out by thinkers such as Robert Putnam and Amitai Etzioni.

The idea of Bill Clinton attending a meeting of House Republicans during his presidency would have been unthinkable on either side. But Mr Bush asked to be invited to the closed-door retreat of his political opponents at Nemacolin Woodlands, and Democratic leaders accepted.

Mr Bush has gone out of his way on several well-publicised occasions to schmooze his political opponents, making use of the full repertoire of presidential gambits.

Last night he invited Senator Edward Kennedy and his family to watch the new Kevin Costner film, 13 Days, at the White House. It shows President Kennedy's handling of the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Also invited were Congressman Patrick Kennedy and Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, Maryland's lieutenant-governor.

On Tuesday, Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader in the Senate, had a one-on-one presidential lunch at the White House; on Wednesday Dick Gephardt the House Democratic leader, got the same treatment.

That evening, Mr Bush met the congressional black caucus for a 90-minute discussion over coffee and biscuits. Three black congressmen from Florida - where a number of black votes were among those excluded from the count in last year's election dispute - boycotted the event.

The Senate yesterday voted to confirm the most controversial Bush cabinet appointment- former senator John Ashcroft as the new attorney general. The vote was 58 to 42 in the 100-member Senate. Eight of the 50 Democrats voted in favour.

That evening, Mr Bush met the congressional black caucus for a 90-minute discussion over coffee and biscuits. Three black congressmen from Florida - where a number of black votes were among those excluded from the count in last year's election dispute - boycotted the event. The Senate yesterday voted to confirm the most controversial Bush cabinet appointment- former senator John Ashcroft as the new attorney general. The vote was 58 to 42 in the 100-member Senate. Eight of the 50 Democrats voted in favour.

webTitle: Ulster peace hopes pinned on IRA making gesture

fields.headline: Ulster peace hopes pinned on IRA making gesture
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Hopes of an imminent breakthrough in the Northern Ireland peace process faded last night when it emerged the British and Irish governments were still waiting to hear if the IRA was prepared to make a historic gesture on disarmament.
fields.body:
Hopes of an imminent breakthrough in the Northern Ireland peace process faded last night when it emerged the British and Irish governments were still waiting to hear if the IRA was prepared to make a historic gesture on disarmament.

Officials on both sides of the Irish Sea still hope that a deal, which would save the Good Friday agreement, can be reached within a week. It is understood, however, that Tony Blair told the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, he still did not know whether the IRA was "ready to deliver". The prime minister has held talks with all the main players in the past 48 hours, as London and Dublin step up their efforts to broker a deal between the Ulster Unionists, Sinn Fein and the Social Democratic and Labour Party. The two governments hope to choreograph a three-point plan involving:

 a major scaling down of the army's presence in borders areas of Northern Ireland;

 an IRA commitment to reopen talks with the international disarmament body, coupled with commitments on the "modalities" of decommissioning - how weapons will be dismantled;

 a commitment by the SDLP and Sinn Fein to take up their places on the new policing board.

After meeting Mr Blair on Wednesday, the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, said he was confident all sides were narrowing their differences.

However, a senior Ulster Unionist said: "The prime minister is still not sure that the IRA are ready to deliver.

"We cannot have a form of words from the IRA. There is no point in doing this unless we get something really serious. They will have to do more than re-engage with the De Chastelain [disarmament] commission."

An Irish official said negotiations had reached their most difficult point: whether Sinn Fein and the IRA could turn their backs on 70 years of history and offer a deal on disarmament.

One source said: "Decommissioning is the Rubicon for republicans which will mean dismantling their past. Taking their seats on the police board is about the future, but it also means buying into the state."

Mr Trimble said he had made little progress in his talks last night with the prime minister. There was a "limited window of opportunity" to reach a deal before the election, and his party demanded cast iron commitments on decommissioning to remain in the power-sharing executive. "I would like to see matters come to a head sooner rather than later," he said.

British and Irish officials have kicked around ideas on decommissioning methods, such as concreting over several arms dumps or putting chemicals on weapons, and they would want the IRA to start serious discussion on these with General John de Chastelain. If republicans responded positively it is understood the prime minister could signal the start of a choreographed sequence of events with a major speech.

He would expect the IRA to contact Gen de Chastelain immediately and, as simultaneously as possible, there would be some security scaledown.

webTitle: Hospital staff in fear over death threat

fields.headline: Hospital staff in fear over death threat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Staff at a north Belfast hospital are living in fear after police told them loyalist paramilitaries were planning to murder an unidentified worker.
fields.body:
Staff at a north Belfast hospital are living in fear after police told them loyalist paramilitaries were planning to murder an unidentified worker.

The RUC believes gunmen could be planning to kill someone in the support services unit of Mater hospital on the Crumlin Road, but does not know who the person is or the motive.

The health union, Unison, and politicians on all sides condemned the threat and called for anyone with influence on terrorists to get it lifted.

Unison's branch secretary, Denis Keatings, said: "The information is so broad that everybody is treating it as if it could be themselves... and looking over their shoulders.

"Many victims of the troubles owe their lives to this hospital. To target a health worker in this way is sick."

He said support services had around 100 employees who alternated portering, domestic, transport and security duties.

An RUC spokesman said that however vague the in formation, "we will never ignore anything which may put someone's life at risk."

The hospital's chief executive, Patricia Gordon, said: "We are offering support and making sure staff are not working in isolated situations. But we are open to the public 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, and it is very difficult."

The Ulster Defence Association, which is on ceasefire but was involved in the inter-loyalist feud, is being blamed for the threat, although its political wing, the Ulster Democratic party, has denied this.

webTitle: Menatally ill mother detained after killing her children

fields.headline: Mother is detained after killing babies
fields.trailText: A mentally-ill mother who killed her two babies by smothering them was yesterday ordered to be detained in hospital.
fields.body:
A mentally-ill mother who killed her two babies by smothering them was yesterday ordered to be detained in hospital.

Julie Ann Ferris, 29, put her hands over the face of her nine-month-old daughter, Hayley. Years later, she did the same thing with her eight-month-old son, Brandon, without apparently arousing the suspicions of doctors.

Ferris, who was said to have a mental age of six, collapsed last June as a jury at Birmingham crown court decided she had killed both babies.

The court heard that Ferris's daughter died in November 1993, but police only began an investigation after Brandon's death in May 1998.

They found Ferris had been a frequent visitor to hospital with both children, claiming each had suffered fits.

She was remanded on bail to a hostel until sentenced yesterday by Mr Justice Crane, sitting at the high court in London. He ordered that she could not be freed without Home Office approval.

Ferris, of Aston, Birmingham, had denied two charges of manslaughter, but been judged mentally unfit to take part in the trial. Mr Justice Crane said he was making the order on the basis that Ferris posed a serious risk - not only for any future child that she might have - but also any other children for whom she might become responsible.

The jury took 2 hours to find that Ferris, the youngest of 13 children, guilty of manslaughter.

William Davis QC, prosecuting, said in November 1993, Ferris's boyfriend went out to fetch a takeaway meal.

"He returned to find Julie Ferris running down the path in a state saying Hayley had had a fit and was not breathing," he said. A postmortem examination revealed Hayley had died through choking on her own vomit while suffering a fit. Mr Davis said police only investigated Hayley's death after Brandon, who had a different father, died in similar circumstances.

webTitle: Germany to lead Europe against 'son of Star Wars'

fields.headline: Germany to lead Europe against 'son of Star Wars'
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Germany, the frontline of the US military presence in Europe during the cold war, will confront the new American defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, in Munich tomorrow about Washington's plans to build a national missile defence system (NMD).
fields.byline: Edward Pilkington, Richard Norton-Taylor and John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
Germany, the frontline of the US military presence in Europe during the cold war, will confront the new American defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, in Munich tomorrow about Washington's plans to build a national missile defence system (NMD).

The Germans are particularly worried that the Pentagon may ask its European allies come under an extended missile shield. One senior official in Berlin called it a "poisoned chalice".

At an annual conference on security policy, Mr Rumsfeld, a cold war hawk and now a proselytiser for NMD, will come face to face with a formidable coalition of European leaders apprehensive about the proposed system.

It will be lead by a German delegation expected to include Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, and the defence minister, Rudolf Scharping.

The French defence minister, Alain Richard, and Russia's influential national security adviser, Sergei Ivanov, who is strongly opposed to the US missile project, are also due to attend tomorrow's conference.

Mr Rumsfeld can expect a more sympathetic hearing from the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, and the British defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, who is known to be more favourably inclined towards the US project than many of his European counterparts.

Opposition to the NMD-nicknamed "son of Star Wars" - is not the only potential source of tension in Munich this weekend. Europe is nervously awaiting the response of President Bush's team to its plan to set up a common European defence force.

Berlin is afraid that a tough line from Washington, which is suspicious that European force ocould undermine Nato, together with mounting tension caused by the NMD, could prompt the worst crisis in US-European relations in decades.

The Germans will tell Mr Rumsfeld that they have a list of questions about the efficacy and impact of the proposed anti-missile shield.

The first is whether the system, designed to protect America against attack from so-called "rogue" states such as Iran, Iraq and North Korea, would be extended to cover Europe - and, if so, at what price.

Senior foreign policy advisers in Berlin fear that the huge cost of development could make NMD unpopular with highly taxed European electorates.

"How would we explain to the German people why we are spending millions on NMD rather than on health or the environment?" a senior German diplomat asked.

There is also concern that a wider missile system could be used by the US to argue that a separate European defence force was unnecessary.

An offer to extend NMD to Europe would probably be accompanied by an invitation to include European firms in the project's development and manufacture. But German officials said they expected the core technology to be retained by the Americans.

In 1983, a German delegation visited the United States to gauge the extent to which German firms might benefit from inclusion in the earlier "Star Wars" scheme proposed by Ronald Reagan's presidency. They returned unconvinced of the spin-off benefits, officials said.

The NMD project was raised when Tony Blair and Mr Schröder dined in Berlin earlier this, though details of their conversation were not made public. In the absence of a joint European foreign policy - a lack much lamented in German political circles - Mr Schröder and his cabinet are prepared to voice their objections unilaterally.

Senior advisers to the German government are warning that the missile plan could prompt China in particular to develop something similar and defray the vast cost by selling the technology to some of the states against which NMD is directed.

The Germans' other prime objection is that the system would undermine international arms-control treaties.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: UN backs Sierra Leone poll delay |  Belgian nurse eaten by dogs | Bankers first to foot Clinton bill
fields.body:
UN backs Sierra Leone poll delay

The UN and Britain yesterday backed Sierra Leone's decision to postpone its presidential election, saying the war-torn West African state was too unstable to stage a fair ballot.

President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah asked parliament on Wednesday to extend his mandate by six months after his government called off this month's presidential poll, citing insecurity. A parliamentary poll was also put back.
Reuters
Freetown

Belgian nurse eaten by dogs

A nurse in southern Belgium who died of a heart attack after watching her pet dogs attack her husband, was later partly devoured by the 10 mongrels.

Mireille Buisson, 59, was found by her son covered in blood in her bedroom with her arms and legs barely intact. Three dogs have been put down, La Dernière Heure newspaper reported.
Andrew Osborn
Brussels

Bankers first to foot Clinton bill

Bill Clinton is to deliver his first paid speech on Monday since leaving the White House. The cost? A reported £100,000 (£68,000) to a banking forum in Florida.
Reuters
New York

webTitle: Pirates find rich pickings in Asian shipping lanes

fields.headline: Pirates find rich pickings in Asian shipping lanes
fields.trailText: The Global Mars, an ageing, modest-sized tanker bound for India with 6,000 tonnes of palm oil products, was making good time.
fields.body:
The Global Mars, an ageing, modest-sized tanker bound for India with 6,000 tonnes of palm oil products, was making good time.

After 20 hours of watching her bow cut a path from Port Kelang in Malaysia through the busy waters of the Malacca Strait, the Burmese pilot's focus had begun to waver. He had already weaved his way through the 200-odd commercial vessels that ply the 500-mile waterway daily.

As night fell he continued north-west at 12 knots into the Andaman Sea, off the coast of Thailand. The strait's narrowest passage, where most of Asia's pirates lurk, had long dipped below the horizon. The 17 other members of the crew were relaxing in their cabins.

Silently, an unlit fishing vessel glided up to the stern. A masked man threw a shrouded grappling hook over the rail and clambered aboard, lowering a rope to the many waiting hands below.

Within minutes the pirates, masked and armed with guns and metre-long swords, had rounded up the 18 startled sailor, bound and blindfolded them, and transferred them to the hold of the waiting boat.

There they remained for 11 day while their captors anchored the Global Mars at sea, repainted her, renamed her Bulawan, and sailed her into a preselected port, carrying forged identity papers and flying a Honduran flag, to unload 3,500 tonnes of their booty. It was the kind of a professionalism exhibited only by organised crime syndicates.

On the 12th day the crew were dumped into an open boat and set adrift with minimal rations. After five days in the Andaman Sea they were found off the coast of Phuket.

Horrifying though their ordeal may have been, they were fortunate. Last year 72 crew and passengers were killed in pirate attacks, 40 of them in south-east Asia, according to the International Maritime Bureau's annual report on piracy, released today. Twenty six people are missing.

Piracy rose by 56% last year to 469 incidents, of which 119 were reported in Indonesian waters, hostages being taken in 46 of the latter incidents.

Even those attacks which do not result in loss of life or hostage-taking are becoming increasingly violent, the IMB's deputy director, Capt Jayant Abhyankar, said.

"These pirates are extremely brutal. They terrorise the crews, beat them, shoot them and lock them up for long periods, during which they are in constant fear for their lives."

On the Global Mars, when one of the crew locked himself in his cabin the pirates fired shots into the air, telling him they would continue killing his mates if he did not come out.

A spokesman for the cruise company Maersk-Sealands said: "We have had some incidents with charters in south-east Asia in the past. Our scheduling is now arranged to make sure all our vessels only arrive and depart during daylight, to eliminate the risk of having to anchor outside ports, waiting for pilots."

Pirates struck 75 times in the Malacca Strait last year, compared with two the year before. It makes an inviting target: 90% of Malaysia's trade by volume traverses through it and it is 1,000 miles shorter than alternative routes from the Persian Gulf to the Pacific. Its 2,700 miles of coastline is pock-marked with bays, inlets and tributaries that make perfect hideouts

Some experts believe that changes in regional economics drove piracy from its mid-1990s hotbed in the HLH triangle (Hong Kong-Luzon-Hainan Island) further south into and around the straits.

"The aftereffects of the financial crisis was definitely a factor in the rise of piracy in south-east Asia," said David Tan, executive director of the Singapore Shipping Association. "Indonesia's ongoing political instability has not allowed it to recover from that as quickly as some of its northern neighbours."

The global liberalisation of trade has also had some influence, by reducing the demand for some black-market goods, Capt Abhyankar said.

Because smuggling has become less profitable, the crime syndicates which used to control the waterways jealously have moved on, allowing petty criminals to flourish.

In May, four months after the Global Mars was hijacked, the Bulawan was found anchored off Zhuhai, southern China. The authorities, tipped of by the IMB, arrested the 11 Filipinos and nine Burmese nationals on board, but just as promptly released them. They said there was no evidence of any offence being committed in Chinese waters, despite an array of munitions on board.

This, Capt Abhyankar said, illustrates the problems faced by the IMB. There are jurisdictional hurdles to overcome before prosecuting, and some countries, including Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, have no laws governing piracy.

"Piracy is a growing problem and very difficult to prosecute," he said. "The UN has said it may get involved, we hope they do. It may be time for the security council to have a look at this."

"The aftereffects of the financial crisis was definitely a factor in the rise of piracy in south-east Asia," said David Tan, executive director of the Singapore Shipping Association. "Indonesia's ongoing political instability has not allowed it to recover from that as quickly as some of its northern neighbours." The global liberalisation of trade has also had some influence, by reducing the demand for some black-market goods, Capt Abhyankar said. Because smuggling has become less profitable, the crime syndicates which used to control the waterways jealously have moved on, allowing petty criminals to flourish. In May, four months after the Global Mars was hijacked, the Bulawan was found anchored off Zhuhai, southern China. The authorities, tipped of by the IMB, arrested the 11 Filipinos and nine Burmese nationals on board, but just as promptly released them. They said there was no evidence of any offence being committed in Chinese waters, despite an array of munitions on board. This, Capt Abhyankar said, illustrates the problems faced by the IMB. There are jurisdictional hurdles to overcome before prosecuting, and some countries, including Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, have no laws governing piracy. "Piracy is a growing problem and very difficult to prosecute," he said. "The UN has said it may get involved, we hope they do. It may be time for the security council to have a look at this."

webTitle: Hot tub boils up race case in Japan

fields.headline: Hot tub boils up race case in Japan
fields.trailText: The failure of the Japanese authorities to tackle racism is being exposed and challenged by three foreign-born residents who lodged a case yesterday against a "Japanese only" bathhouse.
fields.body:
The failure of the Japanese authorities to tackle racism is being exposed and challenged by three foreign-born residents who lodged a case yesterday against a "Japanese only" bathhouse.

The Yunohama bathhouse on Hokkaido island has become a focus for racial equality groups in a country that has shown little enthusiasm for tightening its lax rules, even though it has signed the UN convention on eliminating all forms of discrimination.

The plaintiffs are seeking damages of 2m yen (£11, 500) for being refused entry to the bathhouse, which erected a "Japanese only" sign in 1994, aimed at the many Russian sailors who land at the port of Otaru, nearby.

The owner, unnamed, said the sailors were often drunk and noisy. Worse, they ignored the instructions to wash their bodies before entering the bath, the custom in fastidious Japan.

Horrified that the Russians were driving away his customers, he introduced a foreigner ban. The German and Russian embassies have complained about it, and a number of civil rights groups.

One of the plaintiffs, the American-born Debito Arudou, who was denied entry to the bathhouse despite taking Japanese citizenship, said: "We need a judicial statement that says this is not permissible."

It is not an isolated incident, Tony Lazlo of Issho Kikaku, a human rights group, said. A number of Hokkaido bars also displayed "Japanese only" signs in Russian.

"People who aren't Japanese can be turned away from any shop in Japan," he said. "It is up to the government to do something." But only 1.5m of the country's 126m people are foreign nationals, and none has the vote.

Issho Kikaku submitted a report to the justice ministry this week listing what it said were 22 blatant cases of racism, including a video arcade with a "no-Chinese" policy.

webTitle: US skier jailed for death on the slopes

fields.headline: US skier jailed for death on the slopes
fields.trailText: The first person convicted by a US jury of a causing a death while skiing has been sentenced to 90 days in jail.
fields.body:
The first person convicted by a US jury of a causing a death while skiing has been sentenced to 90 days in jail.

Nathan Hall, 22, could barely speak as he apologised to the family of Alan Cobb for the accident in 1997. He told the Eagle county district court on Wednesday: "I stand before all of you knowing I've taken a human life - a life that was considered very special."

Hall, whose trial by jury was ordered by the Colorado supreme court after a lower court dismissed the case, was charged with reckless manslaughter but found guilty in November of the lesser offence of criminally negligent homicide .

All the jurors in the case, which was closely watched by the US ski industry, were skiers.

Witnesses testified that Hall, a ski-lift operator in the resort of Vail, Colorado, was careering down the slopes at high speed when he slammed into Cobb, 33, who was skiing with his fiancee Christie Neville. Cobb, who had two children, died of head injuries on his way to hospital.

Hall's lawyer said Cobb's death was a tragic accident. But the victim's mother, Susan Cracknoll, told Hall: "Your need of adrenaline-packed power was ground to a halt only by my son's head."

Judge David Lass took Hall's age and his clean record into account when passing sentence. "I have some concerns about Nathan. He's still a young man and he's done some immature and irresponsible things. But I believe there's a good chance for him," he said.

He ordered Hall to perform 240 hours of community service over three years and stay away from drugs and alcohol, and made him subject to random drug tests. Hall was also found guilty of possessing marijuana and under-age drinking. The judge suspended the sentence pending an appeal.

fields.headline: Tank shells mock Serbia 'safety zone'
fields.standfirst:
Tension rises in peace buffer set up to shield Albanian refugees from Yugoslav troops

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Tension rises in peace buffer set up to shield Albanian refugees from Yugoslav troops.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele, in Gornja Shushaja, southern Serbia
fields.body:
The seven guerrillas cower against a wall as a tank shell crashes in, then creep into a culvert under the road. A second shell falls uncomfortably close, its roar echoing through the cramped tunnel. The rattle of small-arms fire can be heard in the distance. "Our people up in the hills always answer, so that the Serbs don't think we have fled," says the platoon's bearded commander.

After half an hour of shell-silence the group emerges warily to inspect the damage. One of the 20 houses in this small village has been hit, its wall smashed in, and most of the tiles blown off the roof by the blast. No one was hurt because women, children and elderly had fled a day earlier when the Yugoslav shelling began.

Eighteen months after Nato-led peacekeepers entered Kosovo, it was not meant to be like this: tanks blasting villages, hundreds of Albanians under arms, and civilians on the run. Yet this has become Europe's biggest military conflict outside Chechnya, with the bizarre contrast of tanks in combat only three miles from international container lorries trundling from Athens to Vienna along the continent's main north-south highway.

The mounting crisis will top the agenda in Washington today when Colin Powell, the new US secretary of state, meets Serbia's prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, in the first visit to America by a Belgrade minister since the war in Kosovo.

The fighting is going on in the oddly-named Ground Safety Zone that was set up inside Serbia after Nato ended its bombing and Belgrade pulled its forces out of Kosovo. Three miles in depth and running all along the border between Serbia and Kosovo, the zone was meant as a buffer to prevent the Yugoslav army coming close to Kosovo and intimidating Albanian refugees as they came home.

But instead of being an area of calm, Albanian guerrillas have taken over the zone, exploiting a loophole in the hastily drafted peace agreement which also prevents troops from K-For, the international protection force, from entering.

A year ago, after K-For observers with binoculars first spotted armed Albanians in camouflage fatigues in the village of Dobrosin, just inside the zone, I walked with three other journalists from Kosovo into Serbia for what turned out to be the new guerrilla army's first interview. At that time they had only a few dozen men. Now they are embedded in all the 40 Albanian villages in the southern part of the zone, and their influence is spreading further into Serbia, to the the towns of Bujanovac and Presevo, which have large Albanian populations.

Under the peace terms, Serb police could operate in the zone, though only with light weapons. Afraid of ambushes, they withdrew three months ago. Triumphant guerrillas came down from the hills and now brazenly operate checkpoints on the main roads which run through the zone between Kosovo and Serbia.

Sniper

Last week an Albanian sniper killed a Yugoslav soldier, the army's first casualty since the Kosovo war. An army vehicle was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade two days later, wounding three troops. Cocking a snook at K-For, 300 armed guerrillas paraded in Dobrosin on the anniversary of their emergence.

The guerrillas' growing militancy has created a crisis for the new authorities in Serbia, as well as for K-For. But, unlike former President Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian government seems to be trying to deal with the issue politically, rather than militarily.

"We see more clearly than ever how much the Milosevic regime undermined trust between Serbs and Albanians," says Biserka Matic, the senior Serb information official in the region. "Albanians were cut out of all state structures and sacked from the police and other government jobs, just as they were in Kosovo. That's how the problem started in Kosovo and it happened here too. Two parallel worlds began."

To try to win Albanian confidence, the new Serbian government has pumped development money into the town of Presevo, which has a 95% Albanian majority, and Bujanovac, where Albanians form around 55% of the population.

The deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic, has regular contact with Bujanovac's Albanian mayor, Riza Halimi. "This government is trying to turn the page and finally do something smart. We are making friends where Milosevic lost them. We don't want to make war and we want to get Europe on our side." Ms Matic says.

Mr Covic called this week for the buffer zone to be demilitarised in stages. He also promised to give jobs back to Albanians in the public sector.

The trouble is that the slow effort to restore trust is being overtaken by military pressures. Ms Matic estimates that there are about 2,000 guerrillas in the hills and woods, in three separate command structures. "But we don't know how many they have in the towns." she adds.

The Yugoslav army appears to be, literally, a loose cannon. President Vojislav Kostunica has not replaced its chief of staff, General Nebojsa Pavkovic. Gen Pavkovic and Gen Vladimir Lazarevic, the commander of the Third Army which is based in the region, are one-time Milosevic loyalists and veterans of the brutal Kosovo campaign. The only tactics they seem to know are to order tanks and heavy artillery to fire on villages.

Although there is no evidence that they have sent vehicles or men into the buffer zone in violation of the peace agreement, my experience in Gornja Shushaja leaves no doubt that they are firing shells into it.

The inevitable flow of panic-stricken refugees is undermining the government's efforts to win Albanian hearts and minds and playing into the guerrillas' hands. Whereas a year ago Albanians in southern Serbia had reservations about the guerrilla campaign, opinion is more radical today.

'Third force'

Mr Halimi attended the guerrillas' anniversary celebrations in Dobrosin, and it is hard to find any Albanian who will criticise them. People are calling for a "third force" to protect civilians from the Serbs, just as they called for Nato to intervene in Kosovo two years ago.

After the Yugoslav army's first combat death last week, Gen Pavkovic rushed to the area. "The government hoped he would criticise the local commanders but all he did was praise them," said a senior Yugoslav journalist in Bujanovac. "There are serious differences between Pavkovic and Covic, and you cannot exclude the possibility that the army is trying to embarrass the government."

It is hard to see an early solution, if the current polarisation goes on. Mr Halimi says secession from Serbia and union with Kosovo is not the issue, "though if talks with the Serb authorities don't succeed, centrifugal forces will go stronger". He wants the government to open direct talks with the guerrillas. "Demilitarisation is the most urgent thing. Then we need international monitoring." he insists.

But the two sides differ over what demilitarisation means. The Albanians want Serb forces to pull out, while the Serbs say it is the guerrillas who must withdraw. K-For peacekeepers are sticking to the rule not to enter the zone, but are tightening up their searches on the Kosovo border. Around 100 Albanians, including one of the guerrilla leaders, have been arrested for entering the area illegally.

Some Serb officials want K-For to move into the buffer zone and start joint patrols with the Yugoslav army and police.

But the prospect of British and other troops so openly taking sides and being shot at by Albanian guerrillas is reminiscent of Ulster. "It has big implications," says a western diplomat in Belgrade. "What if someone takes a pot shot at the troops? You have to shoot back."

webTitle: Rwandan runs hate website from UN jail

fields.headline: Rwandan runs hate website from UN jail
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A Rwandan newspaper editor on trial for genocide for allegedly inciting the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of Tutsis seven years ago has been running a website from his prison cell and using it to denounce the international judges hearing his case.
fields.body:
A Rwandan newspaper editor on trial for genocide for allegedly inciting the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of Tutsis seven years ago has been running a website from his prison cell and using it to denounce the international judges hearing his case.

UN officials have seized a modem found hidden in Hassan Ngeze's cell, but are at a loss how to shut down the website, which includes pictures illegally taken inside the tribunal's prison in Arusha, Tanzania, and "defamatory" allegations against the judges.

Mr Ngeze, 39, was the chief editor of Kangura, which published the infamous "Hutu Ten Commandments" denigrating Tutsis as sub-human and encouraged their persecution and, ultimately, the genocide.

When the trial began in October the prosecutor compared the work of Mr Ngeze, and two fellow accused who ran a hate radio station, to that of Heinrich Himmler, the head of the Nazi SS.

Mr Ngeze's lawyer said his client was doing no more than exercising the freedom of the press.

The tribunal's regulations allow Mr Ngeze access to a telephone and a fax machine, and allowed him to have computer in his cell, which he has used to write long denunciations of the international court.

He alleges that the judges - from South Africa, Norway and Sri Lanka - are under the control of Rwanda's Tutsi-led government, and that prosecution witnesses are lying.

"Witnesses are contacted, taught stories to be told against me and given big amounts of money in return. Even people that I have never met are brainwashed to testify against me," he writes.

Mr Ngeze, who has refused to attend his trial, also accuses the prison staff of conducting a "campaign of intimidation and threats" against his "witnesses, family members, friends and members of my defence team".

The website pictures show Mr Ngeze inside the prison, including working out in the gym. There is an email address for writing to him.

The UN is trying to find a way to shut down the website, which is registered in Mr Ngeze's name but is probably maintained by a supporter.

"We are looking now into some legal process that we can take against the providers of the website," the tribunal's registrar, Agwu Okali, said.

"If this was a national jurisdiction it could be contempt of court, but we are looking into proceedings for defamatory material published on judges and staff of the tribunal."

Security staff searched Mr Ngeze's cell after the photos appeared on the website and found a modem, which was described as "not in use".

"We have launched an investigation into the issue of the photographs because that is a breach of security and we need to find out what happened," Dr Okali said.

"We cannot search the lawyers and investigators. We only do security screening, and that is how materials get smuggled in and out by people who have the attorney-client privilege."

Mr Ngeze created another security scare in 1998 when he tried to commit suicide.

webTitle: Leader: Mr Profumo earned society's thanks

fields.headline: A life to be honoured
fields.standfirst: Mr Profumo has earned society's thanks
fields.trailText: Unnoticed except by his friends, this week marked the 86th birthday of John Profumo. For nearly 40 years now he has led a remarkable life devoted to what would once have been called good works.
fields.body:
Unnoticed except by his friends, this week marked the 86th birthday of John Profumo. For nearly 40 years now he has led a remarkable life devoted to what would once have been called good works. He has never once commented on the events which so summarily ended his career in politics, though the other players in the drama continue to milk it for headlines and royalties. He is said never to have known a day when he has not felt shame. His life has become an inspiring story of the possibility of redemption.

It is difficult to think of a single other figure in public life over the same period who, having been through this degree of turbulence, has behaved with such grace and worked so wholeheartedly for the benefit of others.

When he dies, the eulogies will drown out the reheated dregs of the scandal. Would it not be good to find a way of acknowledging an exemplary life while John Profumo is still among us? If we must have an honours system, surely it should be used to honour such a man?

webTitle: Leader: There are others to blame besides Corus

fields.headline: Shutting down steel
fields.standfirst: There are others to blame besides Corus
fields.trailText: Governments are no longer expected to intervene to prolong the lives of ailing industries. It is also true that if there have to be closures, it is better to suffer them now when unemployment (claimant count) has dropped to only 3.6%. But neither of these factors can justify the decision of Corus to cease steel output at Llanwern and other UK plants with the loss of 6,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Governments are no longer expected to intervene to prolong the lives of ailing industries. It is also true that if there have to be closures, it is better to suffer them now when unemployment (claimant count) has dropped to only 3.6%.

But neither of these factors can justify the decision of Corus to cease steel output at Llanwern and other UK plants with the loss of 6,000 jobs. That may be small compared with the 140,000 UK steel jobs lost between 1978 and 1999, but these cuts are concentrated in small areas heavily dependent on steel and with scant chance of alternative employment.

Corus has been arrogant and uncommunicative, both with its own employees and with local and national government. It may now be a privatised company but it is not a good advertisement for them.

Living in a globalised age does not remove the need for a communitarian response to common problems. Nor does Corus earn respect for its tactics. Much of the trouble is due to the overvaluation of sterling, a problem that may be evaporating as the euro recovers. Such is the short-termism of Corus that it was not prepared to sit it out. The needs of vocal shareholders, particularly in Holland, triumphed over long-term strategy.

But Corus is not the real villain. It is a Labour government which by acquiescing in an overvalued exchange rate has accelerated the decline of manufacturing industry. Corus cannot export steel profitably, not because there isn't a market for it (demand rose 28% in the US over the past decade and 10% in Germany) but because the overvalued pound makes sales unprofitable abroad while its home market shrinks.

And why is it shrinking? Partly because imports are more competitive (the pound again) but also because the whole of British industry is now buying components - containing foreign steel - from abroad. The strong pound has forced it to desert UK suppliers. It is a vicious circle, from which the only escape is a root change in Labour's attitude to manufacturing.

During the next two weeks Corus must be made to change its mind, or at least its timescale. But the government must not pretend it is just picking up the bits. It broke the mould in the first place. Yesterday something was said that would have been unbelievable a decade ago. The shadow industry secretary castigated Labour for its "shameful neglect of the manufacturing sector". Unhappily, he is right.
