fields.headline: Why care charges matter
fields.trailText: My 92-year-old mother suffers from dementia, arthritis and incontinence. For too many years she resisted suggestions that she should move to a care home, despite her manifest inability to look after herself (Scotland confirms care charge divide; Letters, January 30).
fields.body:
My 92-year-old mother suffers from dementia, arthritis and incontinence. For too many years she resisted suggestions that she should move to a care home, despite her manifest inability to look after herself (Scotland confirms care charge divide; Letters, January 30). Social service carers visited three times a day, but she refused to let them wash her, nor would she wear clean clothes. There were soiled clothes, bed linen and faeces round the house.

It took several years before I secured an assessment by a geriatric psychiatrist. He refused to detain her against her will because, as he wrote to her GP: "She was keen to tell me that our prime minister, Mr Blair, has betrayed the elderly, so she clearly retains essential cognitive faculties!"

Some months and several crises later my mother was prised out of her home to a residential home. Within six weeks she was moved to a nursing home in the same group, because the residential home could not offer the care she needed - cure her pres sure sores, for example. The nursing home fees are £105 a week higher, so in Plymouth, where she lives, that is the cost of dementia, bedsores and incontinence. Because she has more than £16,000 in savings, my mother is self-funded. (I have power of attorney and sold her bungalow for this purpose.) She must pay the fees out of already taxed income; thus her taxes are subsidising others with the care she so badly needs herself.

Last spring the nursing home fees rose by £8 a week. Set this in the context of the 75p increase in the state pension and the 60p increase in the attendance allowance. New Labour is now boasting that the pension will rise by £5 a week. My response is "too little, too late". And did you know that if you are in a nursing home, even if you are paying for yourself, you don't receive the spin doctors' headline grabbing £200 winter fuel allowance, but only £100?

I am grateful to the Scots for focusing on this issue and incensed at the way the Westminster mob has tried to sweep it under the carpet. Pretty smart of Tony Blair to issue his government's response to the royal commission on the care of the elderly at the end of July, when parliament was shutting up shop and everyone was going on holiday. That certainly ensured it sank without trace.

Over the past couple of weeks it has been brought home to us yet again, as if we didn't know already, that the men and women who take the decisions affecting our lives will prostitute themselves for a glass of champagne in some rich man's penthouse. While the rich, famous and wannabes schmooze and hobnob, others of us are on hands and knees cleaning up our mothers' faeces. This is what this is all about.
Elizabeth Balsom
London

My colleague royal commissioner David Lipsey (Letters, February 1) overstates his case. First, the commission has not proposed free care for all. It recommended that old people in residential care so ill or frail that they must undergo the indignity of being fed, washed and toileted should, after careful need assessment, get that care without charge. The commission took the view that, as a matter of principle, a civilised and progressive state should offer that right to its citizens.

Second, to assert that this policy "will lead inexorably" to cuts in home help and other services is patently wrong. The £1.1bn cost is 0.3% of public spending. If there is political will to implement the policy, there will certainly be a way of financing it that does not mean damaging service cuts. Full marks to the Scottish executive for its just and courageous decision.
Robin Wendt
Co-author, Sutherland commission report

fields.headline: Prisons under pressure
fields.standfirst: Simplistic solutions are not going to help
fields.trailText: Our prisons are heading for crisis. The present population of 63,000 is projected to increase to 70,800 by 2002 and 78,500 by 2007. Despite 24 new prisons and 12,000 extra places in 10 years, the system remains seriously overcrowded.
fields.body:
Our prisons are heading for crisis. The present population of 63,000 is projected to increase to 70,800 by 2002 and 78,500 by 2007. Despite 24 new prisons and 12,000 extra places in 10 years, the system remains seriously overcrowded. It holds today more inmates per head of population than any other country in Europe bar Portugal. Proportionately, there are more inmates in British prisons than in the most hardline overseas regimes - Saudi Arabia, China, Burma. More serious still, many of the conditions that led to the riots of 10 years ago, the most serious in the last century, are unreformed.

And yet, within the Home Office, there lies at hand a cool, evidence-based report which sets out in detail how the system could more sensibly balance the three competing strands of prison policy: security, control and justice. Rightly billed as the most comprehensive prison reform plan since the 1895 Gladstone report, it was handed to the Home Office just 10 years ago this week.

It came from Lord Woolf, in the wake of the Strangeways riots, which alone cost £60m to repair, and disturbances in 25 other prisons. It provides a blueprint for a more humane and riot-free system. Yet, like his hardline Tory predecessor, Jack Straw declines to embrace it. Hence the importance of this week's welcome return of Lord Woolf, now Lord Chief Justice, to a penal reform platform.

There are some improvements in the system, as our reporters in the G2 series on prisons have recorded this week: more drug treatment courses, more intensive literacy and numeracy programmes, much less slopping out. Other reforms noted by Lord Woolf include better physical conditions, a prison ombudsman, the removal of serious discipline cases to courts, an increase in visiting rights along with wider access to telephones. But he went on: "The tragedy is that there was a prospect of doing so much more."

As our series has shown, much is still seriously wrong. Woolf's vitally important idea of community prisons - based on Home Office research showing offenders who maintain links with their families are six times less likely to reoffend - is as far away from achievement as ever. Prisoner after prisoner talked about the difficulties of keeping in touch with their families. And for good reason. More than 26,000 prisoners are 50 miles away from their home base, 6,000 are up to 150 miles away, and 5,000 over 150 miles away.

Similarly, purposeful activity, which is almost as important in rehabilitation, is little better than it was in the locked-in days that helped provoke the 1990 riots. Prisoners get a mere 10 minutes a day more than they did 10 years ago. Liverpool, Exeter and Preston still lock up their inmates for more than 18 hours a day.

Then there is justice. A prison system which insists on justice stopping at the prison gate is guaranteed to produce alienated inmates more intent on revenge than rehabilitation. Read Tuesday's account by Duncan Williams, on remand in Wandsworth for more than six months, but in much worse conditions than sentenced inmates with no explanation for why he was being denied access to educational courses.

Lord Woolf rightly points to one fundamental cause of the system's failure: overcrowding. He has called it a cancer, destroying most progressive initiatives. He wants fewer sent to prison. So does the chief inspector for prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham. He lists in his interview today in G2 the categories - women, boys, elderly, mentally ill, petty offenders - who could be released to slash inmate numbers by 20,000. Constructive community programmes are one-tenth the £26,000 annual running costs of a prison place. And they can be more demanding. Yet the home secretary foolishly continues to resist. Why does Gordon Brown, that prudent custodian of public money, not intervene?

There are two other charges to be made against Mr Straw. First, his refusal to reappoint Sir David for a second term. Prisons need his independent voice. Shutting him up is shameful. Second, managerial bullying. Governors openly talk about a managerial climate of "fear, blame and impending doom". Privately they point the finger at the deputy director, Phil Wheatley, a hardliner. No one has yet been disciplined for the crass invasion by prison HQ on Blantyre House, a supremely successful liberally run prison. A strong home secretary should not need to indulge in tough talk when a clear solution to his problem is lying ignored on his desk.

webTitle: Letters: Religious bodies and social policies

fields.headline: We're not believers
fields.trailText: It seems the idea of handing over money to faith-based welfare organisations is now widely seen as the answer to economic woes (Brown holds court with moralists, February 1).
fields.body:
It seems the idea of handing over money to faith-based welfare organisations is now widely seen as the answer to economic woes (Brown holds court with moralists, February 1). But problems are already arising in the US, where Mr Bush is putting these ideas into practice. The televangelist Pat Robertson is crying "religious discrimination" after the US Department of Agriculture stopped providing bulk food to the Memphis Union Mission because the church was making the receipt of food conditional on attendance at services. No doubt this decision will soon be overturned and religious organisations will find themselves in possession of millions of tax dollars, which they can use in part to proselytise and evangelise.

This frightening state of affairs must not be allowed to take hold in the UK. Our welfare services must be open to all-comers, not just believers. The only way to ensure this is to keep all tax-funded welfare provision secular.
Keith Porteous Wood
National Secular Society

First we lock up all single mothers, courtesy of batty American Professor James Q Wilson. Then we can lock up more and more criminals, courtesy of Jack Straw. With any luck somebody will suggest another category of immoral/unnecessary person to shut away and the few remaining people on the outside will pay more and more in their crime-free, moral, and of course British, country. Count me out.
Pat Parkin-Moore
Leicester

If James Q Wilson's "moral revival" involves locking up single mothers, what exactly does he propose doing to the fathers?
Karen Buck MP

webTitle: Letters: Rank disagreement on the environment

fields.headline: Rank disagreement on the environment
fields.trailText: The criticism the New Economics Foundation directs at the environmental sustainability index we developed jointly with Yale University and the World Economic Forum is misguided (Global warming dangers 'buried' in new rankings, January 29).
fields.body:
The criticism the New Economics Foundation directs at the environmental sustainability index we developed jointly with Yale University and the World Economic Forum is misguided (Global warming dangers 'buried' in new rankings, January 29). It calls the data we assembled "a morass of irrelevant noise" that obscures the importance of climate change. It is particularly galled at the high ranking given to a number of industrial countries .

Our data include measures of respiratory and intestinal infectious disease, freshwater contamination, air quality and levels of corruption. It is hard to call these factors irrelevant when they account for millions of preventable deaths annually. The fact is that environmental sustainability has many dimensions.

Protecting the planet from climate change is an important dimension and we have included a number of indicators that reflect that. But there is more to it than that. Cleaning up our air and water, preserving endangered species and taking other actions that can improve the lives of billions of people in the present are an inextricable part of any meaningful definition of environmental sustainability.
Marc A Levy
Columbia University, USA

 The annual rate of deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon is 1.7m hectares and not 2m ha as you state (Roads plan could destroy Brazilian Amazon, January 20). This corresponds to around 0.4% of the forest coverage. If the same rate of deforestation continues for the next 20 years - highly unlikely, taking into account the measures in place to protect the forest - the loss would amount to 8% and not 95% as stated. The Avança Brasil project foresees investments for the Amazon in 2000-07 of around £8bn, not £27bn. That includes investments in social development, information and environment.

The preservation of the environment and particularly of the rain forest is a top priority for Avança Brasil; infrastructure accounts for no more than £5.3bn. The paving of roads involves only a fraction of this amount; and in the area of infrastructure there is no new road planned, but only the paving of existing roads.
Sergio Silva do Amaral
Brazilian ambassador

fields.headline: EU aid plan
fields.trailText: Neither I, nor the Conservative group, have ever objected to plans for stream- lining the commission's aid delivery system (Comment, January 29).
fields.body:
Neither I, nor the Conservative group, have ever objected to plans for stream- lining the commission's aid delivery system (Comment, January 29). On the contrary, I have long argued against the inefficiencies in aid delivery which can cost lives in crisis situations (such as mine clearance) and specifically welcomed the proposed measures.

My objections focused on a specific amendment to the commission proposal which called for the establishment of a "European public security force". Although police cooperation in many situations is to be encouraged, we object to any suggestion of setting up some sort of "EU gendarmerie" with all its implications.
Geoffrey Van Orden MEP
gvanorden@europarl.eu.int

fields.headline: More (mostly) good news
fields.trailText: Well done, Sarah Wallace (Letters, January 30). Here is some non-news - last August I had a successful (NHS) operation for colonic cancer at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford within 14 days of telling my GP of my symptoms.
fields.body:
Well done, Sarah Wallace (Letters, January 30). Here is some non-news - last August I had a successful (NHS) operation for colonic cancer at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford within 14 days of telling my GP of my symptoms. I cannot speak too highly of the care I received from my GP, the consultant and his team, the ward sister and her staff and the domestic staff.

We have a strong government determined to improve our whole infrastructure; this takes time and big improvements have been and are being made. Let us "emphasise the positive and eliminate the negative" and give them a second term.
Elizabeth Morland
Stanford in the Vale, Oxon

As a visitor from Australia, I feel burdened by the depth of the negativity of the media. Trains, schools, hospitals, political scandals, racial discrimination, factory closures - every day a tale of woe. Gavin and Cathy Cross (Letters, January 31) by sharing their positive Alder Hey experiences help balance the scales. Could the media follow?
Amanda Rowe
Bristol

Good for Sarah Wallace for admonishing us miserable old sods. But wherever her "...four satisfactory train journeys" were from, they certainly were not from her home town of Burgess Hill, where Connex continues to run its appalling service in filthy 60s rolling stock. Being "positive", is it meant to be character-building, like cold baths?
John Austin Locke
Brighton

fields.headline: Visible Unity
fields.trailText: John Newbury's challenging article (Face to Faith, January 27) reached me at the meeting of the central committee of the World Council of Churches in Berlin.
fields.body:
John Newbury's challenging article (Face to Faith, January 27) reached me at the meeting of the central committee of the World Council of Churches in Berlin. He is right to challenge the churches and ecumenical bodies to be watchful that unity of the churches does not slip from our agendas. I don't share his pessimism, though.

Ecumenical life is alive, in rural congregations and in the new housing areas on the edge of our cities, where Christians have been forced to worship together. Recent Anglican-Methodist conversations have also provided practical suggestions for demonstrating visible unity. So there has been progress, but undoubtedly we could still do better.
Rt Rev Barry Rogerson, Bishop of Bristol
President of Churches Together in Britain and Ireland
Bristol

fields.headline: Norman Mailer sued
fields.standfirst: Author's ex-wife claims more maintenance to 'restore dignity'
fields.trailText: Author's ex-wife claims more maintenance to 'restore dignity'
fields.body:
The second of Norman Mailer's six wives, who was stabbed by the pugnacious Pulitzer Prize-winning writer after a party 40 years ago, says she is living in poverty because he will not provide enough money.

Adele Mailer, 75, who lives in a rundown Manhattan apartment, said: "I have a life of deprivation. I have enormous debt. I'm using my credit cards for food."

Mailer pays his ex-wife £800 a month on top of her £200 payment from social security. But she claims in a lawsuit that the author, who has homes in fashionable Brooklyn Heights and Cape Cod, Massachusetts, should pay £5,100 a month.

Six years after the couple married in 1954, Mailer threw a party for guests who included the Beat poet Allen Ginsberg, journalists, boxers, actors and people he called in from the street.

"It was a party that was like a 20-headed, scaled monster sluggishly moving through those rooms, tracking filth, stinking of destruction," she wrote in her memoir, The Last Party. Mailer got into many fights and, by 4am, only he and his wife were left.

He stabbed her twice with a penknife, but she refused to file a complaint. Finally, he admitted assault and received a suspended sentence. The couple, who have two daughters, divorced two years later.

"I have no one to turn to, no means to obtain funds elsewhere, and I am reduced to begging for financial help," said the lawsuit filed on behalf of Mrs Mailer, who claims debts of more than £20,000.

"I do not seek a windfall, merely sufficient funds to live with some dignity and not have to beg for credit, knowing that I am going further and further into a black hole of debt."

Mailer, 78, declined to comment.

webTitle: The ongoing popularity of geek films

fields.headline: Revenge of the nerds
fields.standfirst: The role-playing game Dungeons and Dragons died out years ago. So isn't this the wrong time to release a movie version of it - and to be shooting Tolkien's Lord of the Rings? No, says  Dave Green. Never underestimate the popularity of the geek film
fields.trailText: The role-playing game Dungeons and Dragons died out years ago. So isn't this the wrong time to release a movie version of it - and to be shooting Tolkien's Lord of the Rings? No, says Dave Green . Never underestimate the popularity of the geek film
fields.body:
Tim Robbins' new film, AntiTrust, which has just opened in the US, is a by-the-book techno-paranoid surveillance thriller. For the first 10 minutes, however, the characters spend the majority of their screen time discussing the "Open Source" approach to computer programming. To the casual moviegoer, this lesson in modern software development seems an educational, yet incongruous, digression in a would-be Hollywood blockbuster. But a glance around the auditorium, at the occasional figures convulsing with pleasure at the mere mention of this internet cause célèbre , and you would realise it's there specifically to tantalise one particular segment of the audience. A demographic sometimes shunned in real life, yet no less appealing to marketing executives and movie studios. The demographic of the nerds.

On paper, it makes sense. At the risk of stereotyping this lively and diverse element of the population, they tend to be male, and (if employable) often have a lot of disposable income from their jobs in the hi-tech industries. So, Hollywood figures, they'll more than likely buy into the movie merchandising, the tie-in novelisation, the action figures, and the DVD.

Their interests are well known and well understood, and often the kinds of things that are fun to put in films anyway: science fiction, fantasy, special effects, TV shows, cute girls, comic books and superheroes. Their heroes are nerds too: Wayne and Garth, Jay and Silent Bob, Mulder and Scully. If studios play their cards right, more dedicated enthusiasts might spend months posting every single production rumour on internet fan sites and do your advance marketing for you - the Lord of the Rings adaptation is currently benefiting from such attentions. And, as a bonus, they're believed capable of living entirely off the food groups available in the foyer.

The tricky bit is finding a property that's new. There have been film versions of most of the superheroes, a fair few of the comic books, and a lot of the big TV shows - culminating in the movie version of The X Files, a film of no interest whatsoever to anyone who hadn't seen the 100 or so preceding episodes. Of course, to maximise a movie's geek appeal, the geekier the subject-matter, the better. (There is some technical distinction between "geek" and "nerd", one being more insulting than the other - but, like stalactites and stalagmites, no one can remember which way round it goes.)

Which leads us, inevitably, to the nerdiest of all nerd activities, a pastime considered so deviantly unfashionable that, as far as I'm aware, not even Stuart Maconie has felt the need to sneer at it in I Love the Seventies. I'm talking about an activity that combines the unwholesomeness of video games with the dullness of extensive rulebooks and old-fashioned dice-rolls. I'm talking about Dungeons and Dragons.

For better or worse, Dungeons and Dragons - colloquially abbreviated to "D&D" - became the standard bearer for the entire genre of role-playing games (traditionally shortened to "RPGs"). Not to be confused with the altogether zanier business of dressing up as medieval characters and running around an old castle (that's "Live Role-Playing"), RPGs are considerably more sedentary, involving each player creating a character - an elf or a human, a fighter or a thief - with a range of numerical attributes. This is a process immortalised in satirical newspaper the Onion's story, "Bill Gates Grants Self 18 Dexterity Points, 20 Charisma", and their poignant "Ask a Seventh-Level Magic User" problem page. The "Dungeon Master" then leads the players through a semi-improvised adventure of monster-fighting, treasure-collecting, tavern-brawling and other adolescent diversions, calculating each success or failure with a roll of the 20-sided die.

Developed in the 1970s by individuals with names like E Gary Gygax, D&D swept through the teen years of any right-thinking Tolkien-reader in the 1980s. For those awkward RPG-free moments on the way to school, you had your more portable choose-your-own-adventure "Fighting Fantasy" novels. D&D had its own terrible animated TV series, and even provoked a scaremongering TV movie called Mazes and Monsters, in which a young and impressionable Tom Hanks became so obsessed with mythological gibberish that he actually believed himself to be "Keeper of the Graven Eye of Timor" - a role which Hanks now rarely mentions in interviews.

And then, at the height of its powers, D&D died. Beset by increased competition from more sophisticated video games, newer RPGs like the UK's more violent Warhammer, and the general passing of the craze, the D&D licence was sold in 1997 to Wizards of the Coast, owners of the similarly-themed all-conquering card game Magic: The Gathering. While the new film coincides with the release of a new edition of the rules (and is also the result of the first-time writer-director- producer Courtney Solomon's one-man, 10-year odyssey to bring his favourite game to the screen), you've got to ask yourself: isn't releasing a D&D movie now slightly akin to making a film about breakdancing, or skateboarding, or Rubik's Cube?

On the other hand, it does have almost all the elements to ensure timeless geek appeal. It boasts Cult actors like Tom "Dr Who" Baker and Richard "Rocky Horror Show" O'Brien, who seems intent on capitalising on his most famous role, that of host of TV's The Crystal Maze, by bellowing the line "You finish the maze, you win the prize!" It has monstrous overacting by a British villain (Jeremy Irons); a cute girl or two, including American Beauty's Thora Birch; plus non-stop swordfights and computer-graphics special effects unlikely to disappoint even the most ardent fans of The Phantom Menace - admittedly, its most likely target audience.

What's more, it's still almost a year until the first real Lord of the Rings film gets here - and, let's not forget, it's all about Dungeons and Dragons! But even the most dedicated fans can transform into the most fearsome critics, if scorned. "Clerics are one of the basic character types in D&D," argues James Wallis, a UK-based RPG publisher whose "Dragonmeet" convention aims to restore British role-playing to its mid-80s heyday. "But - there are no clerics in the film!"

Equally alarmingly, the Dungeons & Dragons movie fails to heed the one rule of all great geek movies - that the viewer should, through their shared, perhaps ridiculed hobby, identify with the protagonist as an everyday, put-upon bullied guy. Take WarGames - a dweeby computer hacker is enrolled to defuse a real-life nuclear conflict (which, admittedly, he accidentally initiated, while trying to impress a girl). The Matrix - a dweeby Keanu Reeves is enlisted by Carrie-Anne Moss to overthrow a real-life cybernetic dystopia. Galaxy Quest - dweeby fans assist the cast of a Star Trek-style TV show enrolled by aliens to battle a real-life . . . well, you get the idea.

But the D&D movie isn't about some kids who play D&D and find that the skills they've then acquired turn out to be genuinely useful somehow - it's actually about two thieves, and a princess, and an elf. Still, maybe it's for the best that there are some classic teen-male obsessions - listening to Iron Maiden, building Airfix model aircraft - that can't be cynically marketed into fleetingly fashionable special-effects blockbusters. Sony shamelessly claimed they'd made videogaming socially acceptable by sticking a few Playstations in nightclubs, but no one's ever going to pull off the same trick by getting out their D&D rulebooks and character sheets in the Ministry of Sound.

Dungeons & Dragons opens on February 16.

Nerds to the rescue - Films that were saved by their nerdy fans

Star Trek: The Motion Picture (1979)
Takings: $82.3m

Bold yet flawed attempt to recapture the idealism of the TV series, cancelled a full decade before. Fans of the original series, a cult hit through endless syndication, generated enough interest in Kirk and his increasingly elderly crew to kickstart one of sci-fi's longest-running movie franchises and, ultimately, resurrect the TV format in the form of The Next Generation, Voyager and Deep Space Nine.

War Games (1983)
Takings: $79.5m

Still regarded as the benchmark for the way computer hacking movies should be done: Matthew Broderick is a pale-looking American high-school kid who stumbles into a secret nuclear-launch computer system. Before being lured into the maw of big-budget monster nonsense like Godzilla and Inspector Gadget, Broderick went on to star in uberteen movie par excellence, Ferris Bueller's Day Off.

Mortal Kombat (1995)
Takings: $70m

Movie versions of video games often flounder, but Brit director Paul Anderson knew he was on to a winner with a game - and ultimately, a film - consisting of little but what America's film censors described as "non-stop martial arts action and some violence". Went on to spawn an almost indistinguishable sequel - the equally unapologetically titled Mortal Kombat: Annihilation - and a spinoff TV show.

Tron (1982)
Takings: $33m

Surreal Disney showcase for early computer-graphics special effects, partly inspired by the video games and computer hacking crazes of the 1980s. Still revered among the cognoscenti and arguably the most authentic depiction of PC internals to date. Inspired numerous terrible imitations, including the disgraceful Lawnmower Man 2. Disney themselves are believed to be currently working on a sequel, Tron 2.0.

Clerks (1994)
Takings: $3.2m

Kevin Smith's micro-budget debut captured a dedicated geek fanbase with its Star Wars and comic-book references and affectionate portrait of consumer-store slacker lifestyles. And he's made an effort to stay in touch with them with through his viewaskew.com website - for instance, bemoaning network support for last year's swiftly cancelled Clerks: The Animated Series.

webTitle: A new film about the life of Benjamin, speedfreak and frontman for dozens of doomed bands

fields.headline: Poet of pills
fields.standfirst: Benjamin was a drag queen, a speedfreak and a frontman for dozens of doomed bands. Luc Santé is dazzled by a film about his fast life and sad death
fields.trailText: Benjamin was a drag queen, a speedfreak and a frontman for dozens of doomed bands. Luc Santé is dazzled by a film about his fast life and sad death
fields.body:
It is a melancholy experience to make someone's acquaintance, be enthralled by his wit and passion, become aware you're watching him waste away, and then have him die on you - all in 80 minutes. That's what happens in Jem Cohen and Peter Sillen's documentary Benjamin Smoke. Benjamin, born Robert Dickerson, was the singer and lyricist for a band called Smoke, hence the movie's title. They recorded two CDs (Another Reason to Fast and Heaven on a Popsicle Stick) and were a local sensation, but they weren't well-known elsewhere.

Benjamin, a native of Jonesboro, Georgia, was a speed-freak, a pill-head and a drag queen, as well as a considerable poet and an inspired singer whose deep growl of a voice could slide from rumination to peaks of intensity. The film is not, however, primarily a musical document - and, when they first set out, its makers were not aware how the story would end. "We just wanted to capture something that we knew was remarkable," Cohen said. "And even before we knew that Benjamin was sick, we knew that it might not last."

It's clear that one reason Cohen and Sillen started the movie was that they wanted to record Benjamin talking. What we hear is his dry humour delivered in a languorous southern drawl, a non-stop chatter with laugh lines that crest slowly and break somewhere offshore. The talk emerges from a wide mouth set in a cadaverous face.

He talks about his life with out regret or inflation. He started fooling around with drag when he was nine, found his destiny as a teenager when he heard Patti Smith's album Horses, went to New York in 1978 - only to spend his time there sweeping up broken glass at the CBGB club. He returned to Georgia and got involved in dozens of bands, from ephemeral punk to something harder to pin down. The story involves tiny audiences, lowdown venues and police raids.

There are photographs of Benjamin in drag, looking sleek. Other pictures, ravaged by dampness, have patches of emulsion missing and look contaminated.

Benjamin lived in a part of Atlanta called Cabbagetown, once a mill town inhabited by immigrants from Appalachia. The mill closed in the 1970s and the place became a slum. The camera darts outside to the desolate frame houses scattered around the landscape, and to the young people who, in Benjamin's words, "go to jail early and whose parents use inhalants", working on their go-karts outside.

The place feels lost in time, an outcropping of the 20th century that came unglued somewhere between the Truman and Johnson administrations, and now rattles around like dice in a cup. You get glimpses of faceless downtown Atlanta in the distance, looking like another planet. The atmosphere of Cabbagetown seems a logical extension of Benjamin's presence and the look of his room, with its flea-market panache. It's a scavenger's aesthetic, the unfakeable sort reserved for people with no money, whose only choice is to extract beauty from discards.

By the time we see Smoke play together, the music fits right into the prevailing tone of unpremeditated originality, as if it were the only sort of music possible. The line-up consists of cello, banjo doubling on trumpet, guitar and drums. There are rock elements, a sort of blues, and something related to ancient hill ballads, but nothing you could put your finger on. Like certain kinds of Middle Eastern music, it is dominated by a fluid drone that rises occasionally to frantic peaks that are then reabsorbed by the unhurried flow.

Benjamin can sound as if he is making the words up, even when he isn't, as he growls, talk-sings, and wanders away from the key. The volume is never high, but an intensity emerges from the emotional concentration. The band members are always seated, as if they need to be.

Gradually we realise that Benjamin is in pain. He never says so but, every time he makes a move, the cost is apparent. He has Aids, a matter about which, by his own admission, he is uncharacteristically quiet, because he doesn't want others' impressions of him to be distorted by his disease. The first two-thirds of the picture, which seem to exist in an elastically stretched present tense, give way to urgency and imminence.

Cabbagetown itself is changing - you see the signs of doom: the loft conversions, the antique shops. And then Benjamin moves, at his mother's behest, to government-sponsored housing downtown, where he'll be more accessible. He shows the camera his pill-box filled with his dozens of daily doses. He still manages to perform, even fulfilling a dream - opening for Patti Smith in Atlanta.

Cohen learned of Benjamin from Michael Stipe of REM, for whom he had made five music videos; Sillen is best-known for documenting another southern singer- songwriter, Vic Chesnutt. The scavenger aesthetic guides their film-making here, as they use bits of film left over from other jobs as well as video and Super-8 film to assemble a patchwork that resembles its subject. Cohen's films are all collages to one degree or another: Lost Book Found, his evocation of vanishing New York; Buried in Light, his harshly lyrical east European travelogue.

He will, for example, cut from grainy Super-8 close-up indoor talk to a majestic landscape shot in 35mm but underexposed in a way that suggests it may not be real. You've seen that sort of mix-and-match approach before (Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers comes to mind), but Cohen's use of it is singularly personal.

Despite its subject's illness and death (a day after his 39th birthday), the movie is anything but grim. Benjamin's matter-of-fact humour and incredible resilience won't permit the tone to slide toward solemnity or preaching.

In the stills of his last performance, weeks before his death, he looks as though he weighs maybe 60lb, some of them accounted for by the slightly askew wig on his head, but his eyes don't look the least bit ready to check out. It is Patti Smith who, some time later, eulogised Benjamin in a poem:

With a throat smooth as a lamb

Yet dry as a branch not

snapping

He throws back his head

Yet he does not sing a thing

mournful.

© Luc Santé. Benjamin Smoke is released next Friday.
fields.bodyText: It is a melancholy experience to make someone's acquaintance, be enthralled by his wit and passion, become aware you're watching him waste away, and then have him die on you - all in 80 minutes. That's what happens in Jem Cohen and Peter Sillen's documentary Benjamin Smoke. Benjamin, born Robert Dickerson, was the singer and lyricist for a band called Smoke, hence the movie's title. They recorded two CDs (Another Reason to Fast and Heaven on a Popsicle Stick) and were a local sensation, but they weren't well-known elsewhere. Benjamin, a native of Jonesboro, Georgia, was a speed-freak, a pill-head and a drag queen, as well as a considerable poet and an inspired singer whose deep growl of a voice could slide from rumination to peaks of intensity. The film is not, however, primarily a musical document - and, when they first set out, its makers were not aware how the story would end. "We just wanted to capture something that we knew was remarkable," Cohen said. "And even before we knew that Benjamin was sick, we knew that it might not last." It's clear that one reason Cohen and Sillen started the movie was that they wanted to record Benjamin talking. What we hear is his dry humour delivered in a languorous southern drawl, a non-stop chatter with laugh lines that crest slowly and break somewhere offshore. The talk emerges from a wide mouth set in a cadaverous face. He talks about his life with out regret or inflation. He started fooling around with drag when he was nine, found his destiny as a teenager when he heard Patti Smith's album Horses, went to New York in 1978 - only to spend his time there sweeping up broken glass at the CBGB club. He returned to Georgia and got involved in dozens of bands, from ephemeral punk to something harder to pin down. The story involves tiny audiences, lowdown venues and police raids. There are photographs of Benjamin in drag, looking sleek. Other pictures, ravaged by dampness, have patches of emulsion missing and look contaminated. Benjamin lived in a part of Atlanta called Cabbagetown, once a mill town inhabited by immigrants from Appalachia. The mill closed in the 1970s and the place became a slum. The camera darts outside to the desolate frame houses scattered around the landscape, and to the young people who, in Benjamin's words, "go to jail early and whose parents use inhalants", working on their go-karts outside. You get glimpses of faceless downtown Atlanta in the distance, looking like another planet. The atmosphere of Cabbagetown seems a logical extension of Benjamin's presence and the look of his room, with its flea-market panache. It's a scavenger's aesthetic, the unfakeable sort reserved for people with no money, whose only choice is to extract beauty from discards. By the time we see Smoke play together, the music fits right into the prevailing tone of unpremeditated originality, as if it were the only sort of music possible. The line-up consists of cello, banjo doubling on trumpet, guitar and drums. There are rock elements, a sort of blues, and something related to ancient hill ballads, but nothing you could put your finger on. Like certain kinds of Middle Eastern music, it is dominated by a fluid drone that rises occasionally to frantic peaks that are then reabsorbed by the unhurried flow. Benjamin can sound as if he is making the words up, even when he isn't, as he growls, talk-sings, and wanders away from the key. The volume is never high, but an intensity emerges from the emotional concentration. The band members are always seated, as if they need to be. Gradually we realise that Benjamin is in pain. He never says so but, every time he makes a move, the cost is apparent. He has Aids, a matter about which, by his own admission, he is uncharacteristically quiet, because he doesn't want others' impressions of him to be distorted by his disease. The first two-thirds of the picture, which seem to exist in an elastically stretched present tense, give way to urgency and imminence. Cabbagetown itself is changing - you see the signs of doom: the loft conversions, the antique shops. And then Benjamin moves, at his mother's behest, to government-sponsored housing downtown, where he'll be more accessible. He shows the camera his pill-box filled with his dozens of daily doses. fields.headline: The Sundance quid
fields.standfirst: With their big sponsors and photo-ops, the indie anti-Oscars are no better than the real thing
fields.trailText: With their big sponsors and photo-ops, the indie anti-Oscars are no better than the real thing
fields.body:
Two big media blowouts this weekend - and like a fool I put my money on the wrong horse. As a committed sports bigot of many years' standing I skipped the most fascinating Superbowl in ages. The half-time show was a wildly chaotic corporate rock'n'roll affair, with Aerosmith singing Walk This Way, accompanied by a smorgasbord of ill-matched thug-rappers, meat-rack boy bands and silicone-enhanced boy toys like Britney Spears.

The Baltimore Ravens ate the New York Giants for breakfast, lunch and dinner, but the man voted most valuable player of the game, Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis, was unfortunately linked last year with a still-unsolved double murder that happened just after the 2000 Superbowl. Usually the MVP gets a much-publicised free trip to Disneyland and his face appears on the new Wheaties box, to be admired by sports nuts at breakfast tables nationwide. Not Ray Lewis though, and I'm crushed that we've been denied the surreal prospect of seeing an accused killer on the nation's emblematic cereal box or taking a spin on Mr Toad's Wild Ride at Uncle Walt's Magic Kingdom.

So where was I when all this was unfolding, live and lysergic? I was watching the final awards ceremony of this year's Sundance film festival, the annual jamboree in the Utah Rockies, which affords the opportunity for film-world celebrities, Carmen Electra among them, to pose for photos in a winter-sports setting. The awards were broadcast on - you'll like this - the Sundance Channel. I could have kicked myself when I caught the Superbowl update on the late news. Instead, I'd been watching aghast as the cream of Robert Redford's "indie" film world settled into an orgy of ass-kissing and mutual back-slapping.

Movies really are coming to resemble national politics. If the real Oscars are the Republican National Convention of the Hollywood calendar, what are the Sundance awards, the self-styled anti-Oscars? Are they like the Reform Party? Or the Green Party? No, they're like the Democratic Party Convention, a spin-doctored, politically pasteurised, pseudo-liberal rearrangement of the same ugly elements: the grovelling, the mendacious "incredibly talented guy to work with" garbage, the endless thank-you speeches, the multinational sponsors, the craven supplication before wealth, fame and power, and all the same snouts in all the same troughs.

The trouble is, the participants still act as if every breast-beating utterance they make has the revolutionary intensity of a mimeographed communique from the Symbionese Liberation Army or the Weather Underground. The only place one can locate a comparable wellspring of vanity and self-importance is in the interviews of - oh, let's say Robert Redford.

To quote the host of the awards show, actor Donal Logue: "See, this is just what's so great about Sundance. All that matters here are the artists and the movies . . . But moving right along, our Best Documentary award is sponsored by Mercedes-Benz!" And so on. In its defence, Sundance is a useful forum and marketplace for films and ideas, and has transformed the American cinema, but to style itself the alternative to the mainstream is akin to labelling the Baltic the alternative to the North Sea - it's all the same water.

My aversion to it was probably sharpened by my having read a book I can't recommend highly enough to anyone who wants to learn about the generally corrupt overlaps and sweetheart deals between film festivals, distributors, mainstream film critics and allegedly independent film-makers.

Jonathan Rosenbaum is the 56-year-old critic for the weekly Chicago Reader and Jean-Luc Godard thinks he's America's best film critic. That's good enough for me. His new book Movie Wars: How Hollywood and the Media Conspire to Limit What Films We Can See (A Cappella Press, Chicago) is as trenchant, perceptive and unfoolable as his reviews over the past three decades.

Having attended hundreds of festivals in that time, and having watched as festival press conferences deteriorated from the passionate, obscenity-filled verbal fisticuffs of the 1970s into the castrated photo-ops of today, the man knows whereof he speaks. His father and grandfather also owned a chain of cinemas in southern Alabama, so Rosenbaum saw just about every movie released in his entire childhood for free. Despite feeling he grew up in the golden age of cinema, he won't sit still for the idea that films ain't what they used to be.

The great movies are out there, he says, and he knows because he's bothered to see them. It's just that they are being ignored by distributors who think the people won't accept subtitles (tell it to the Crouching Tiger); or that they can re-edit a film into something "even better" (hello, Harvey "Scissorhands" Weinstein); or that it's OK to buy up twice as many movies as you will distribute, because it keeps them out of the hands of the competition (and of us movie-lovers, too, incidentally - thanks again, Harv).

A lso in the way are critics who downplay anything not from Hollywood. Rosenbaum scorns Pauline Kael's isolationist influence on American film criticism, and Janet Maslin's appalling ignorance at the New York Times, where her every utterance was closely scrutinised by distributors.

Finally, he questions Hollywood's received wisdom that the audience is stupid and bovine, a contention that all the "voodoo" of test-marketing does nothing but reinforce. Audiences have never been so visually sophisticated and cine-literate, and their desire for new thrills can be read into the success of movies such as Crouching Tiger, Being John Malkovich and The Blair Witch Project. Demand isn't the problem: it's the suppliers and their opinion-making lapdogs. We should hate them for treating us like idiots.

And we should love Rosenbaum for treating us like people hungry for great cinema, and for eviscerating the multiple corruptions of the "media-industrial complex". He's this week's MVP. I say put him on the Wheaties carton.

webTitle: An extract from Serge Gainsbourg: A Fistful of Gitanes by Sylvie Simmons

fields.headline: The eyes have it
fields.standfirst: He was an ugly man who loved some of the world's most beautiful women, a shy man who spent most of his life in the spotlight - and a prankster who knew exactly how to outrage the public. Ten years after his death, Sylvie Simmons celebrates France's pop genius, Serge Gainsbourg
fields.trailText: He was an ugly man who loved some of the world's most beautiful women, a shy man who spent most of his life in the spotlight - and a prankster who knew exactly how to outrage the public. Ten years after his death, Sylvie Simmons celebrates France's pop genius, Serge Gainsbourg
fields.body:
When Serge Gainsbourg died in his bedroom on March 2 1991, a month short of his 63rd birthday, France went into mourning. Brigitte Bardot, who had been his lover, gave a eulogy; President Mitterrand, who wasn't, gave him one too. He was "our Baudelaire, our Apollinaire", said the head of state. "He elevated song to the level of art." Flags were flown at half-mast - a less fitting symbol for the priapic pop genius than the bottles of whisky and Pastis and packets of Gitanes cigarettes left as tributes by the crowds who descended, à la Princess Di, on the police barricades erected around his home on the Rue de Vernueil.

"Ask anyone in Paris," said Nicolas Godin of the French band Air, "and they can remember what they were doing when they heard Gainsbourg had died. It was such a shock. Because he was always there, part of our culture. He was always on the television doing something crazy. He was a poet. He was a punk. And he wanted to fuck Whitney Houston."

The man who looked like an elegant turtle cross-bred with a particularly louche, chain-smoking wolf was also a singer, a songwriter, a cutting-edge soundtrack composer, a Eurovision Song Contest winner, novelist, photographer, actor, artist, drunk, director, screenwriter, populist, provocateur, sentimentalist, clown, lover, intellectual, and the man who single-handedly liberated French pop. In spite of - or because of - a singular dedication to cigarettes, alcohol, sensuality and provocation (his infamous "I want to fuck you" offer to fellow-guest Houston on a French family TV show combined all four), his musical output over more than three decades was staggering.

It encompassed a variety of reinventions that made David Bowie look stereotyped - classical, chanson, jazz, girl-group pop, rock, reggae, disco and funk. He displayed a profound knowledge of, and respect for, tradition, while simultaneously giving it two fingers, then used all these disparate things to make something unique.

His lyrics were mind-boggling exercises in Franglais, triple entendres and rhythmic, onomatopoeic word-percussion. Literature, sexual obsession, farting, incest, philosophy, grammar, cabbages, Nazi death camps and the Torrey Canyon disaster were all considered perfectly reasonable subject matter for his songs, which were whistled in the street and printed in poetry books that were studied in universities. And yet on this side of the Channel, Gainsbourg is really known for just one song: his 1969 number one hit with Jane Birkin, Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus.

"There's a trilogy in my life," said Gainsbourg, "an equilateral triangle, shall we say, of Gitanes, alcoholism and girls - and I didn't say isosceles, I said equilateral. But it all comes from the background of a man whose initiation in beauty was art." Brigitte Bardot - or BB, as the French call her - was the actress for whom the term "sex kitten" was invented. Bardot was signed by Gainsbourg's record company, Philips, in 1962, and she had already released two singles that her labelmate had written before they were both booked to appear on Sacha Distel's primetime Saturday night TV show. It was 1967, two months after the so-called Summer of Love, and Gainsbourg fell for BB mightily. She was, Distel said, "the dream of Serge's life".

It must have been a dream come true to find that Bardot was attracted to him too, and that their rendezvous should happen just as her second marriage was on the rocks. She invited him to appear on her Le Bardot Show, and what started as a working relationship soon developed into a love affair. It was a discreet one to start with: unlike Gainsbourg, Bardot had a horror of press attention. Initially they met furtively at friends' apartments, but then threw caution to the wind and allowed the paparazzi to snap them at all the top nightspots or in Bardot's convertible Triumph Spitfire (with Bardot at the wheel as Gainsbourg couldn't drive), gliding through a Paris plastered with photos of BB in thigh-high boots and black leather mini-skirt straddling a motorbike - an advertisement for her latest Gainsbourg-penned single, Harley-Davidson.

On the Le Bardot Show, the stream of Gainsbourg classics inspired by his new love (or demanded by her producers) were performed by the pair in front of outlandish sets of the cod-psychedelic variety that you only ever saw on 1960s TV shows. For Comic Strip, for instance, Bardot was made up as a black-wigged Barbarella character, surrounded by bright "comic-book" balloons bearing "Zip! Pow! Wiz!" exclamations. For Bonnie and Clyde, Gainsbourg played the part of Clyde with shoulder-holster and cigarette, while BB, in a long skirt, short wig and beret, was his loyal moll.

Bonnie and Clyde was the title track of Gainsbourg and BB's album together, released in 1968. It was one of a pair of songs Gainsbourg had written in the space of a night following a disastrous early date with Bardot. Struck dumb with either nerves or alcohol, his usual wit deserted him, the evening was a flop and he thought he had blown it. But Bardot phoned the next day and demanded as a penance that he write her "the most beautiful love song you can imagine". In fact he wrote two - Bonnie and Clyde and Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus.

Late one night in the winter of 1967, Gainsbourg and Bardot went into a dimly lit studio in Paris and recorded Michel Colombier's arrangement of Je T'Aime in an intimate two-hour session. The two singers were squashed into a small, steamy glass booth; engineer William Flageollet witnessed what he described as "heavy petting". Word leaked to the press that it was an "audio vérité" recording, with the Sunday paper France-Dimanche reporting that the four minutes and 35 seconds of "groans, sighs, and Bardot's little cries of pleasure" set to almost churchlike organ music gave "the impression you're listening to two people making love".

The next thing the journalists did was call up Bardot's husband and ask him what he thought of it. His reply made the next day's headlines - "Furious Gunter Sachs Demands the Single Be Withdrawn" - something that Bardot's agent was agreeing to behind the scenes. Bardot was about to star with Sean Connery in Shalako, released in 1968, and it was not a good time for a scandal (in any case, Bardot hated scandals).

She wrote Gainsbourg a letter, pleading with him not to release the record. Gainsbourg protested: "The music is very pure. For the first time in my life, I write a love song and it's taken badly." But he had witnessed the public's love-hate relationship with Bardot, and put the tapes in a drawer. They would stay there until 1986 when she finally gave permission for their "sublime" version of Je T'Aime, as Gainsbourg described it, to come out.

"Well, we all know Bardot is an idiot," grunted Marianne Faithfull of the original decision to proscribe the song. "Of course when Gainsbourg had her, she was in peak condition, tip-top form - but always very conformist." Gainsbourg had later asked Marianne to do the song with him. "Hah! He asked everybody," she said - including the actress-singers Valérie Lagrange and Mireille Darc (Alain Delon's ex-wife).

The affair ended and Bardot went back to her husband. Gainsbourg busied himself recording and meeting film commitments. For the film Slogan, released in France in 1969, it was decided that an English actress was needed. Jane Birkin - "a young actress with that perfect 1960s Swinging London look: long, ironed hair, big eyes and coltish body shoehorned into a belt-sized mini-skirt" - got the part. Initially, the two did not get on. An evening out in Paris was planned to break the ice.

"We were at Regine's nightclub for a long time," Birkin recalled, "and I asked Gainsbourg to dance." (Gainsbourg had been waiting for " un slow " so that he could ask Jane the same thing.) "And he stepped on my feet! I was so surprised. I thought, 'So this sophisticated, arrogant, seemingly confident man doesn't know how to dance' - and I realised it was because he's in fact shy. He seemed so worldly-wise, but at the same time he was very childlike.

"From there he took me to another nightclub - to every nightclub in Paris until six in the morning. We went to Madame Arthur, where his father used to play the piano for the transvestites, who all came up kissing Gainsbourg and saying 'Ooh cheri, how are you?' And he took me to the Russian nightclubs where the Russian violin players played until we got into the taxi on the street and Gainsbourg stuffed 100 franc notes into their violins. He loved them and they loved him, and he told them ' Nous sommes des putes ' ('We're all prostitutes') and asked them to play the Valse Triste, that terribly melancholic slow waltz by Sibelius, which they played right up to the taxi, and which he afterwards always called 'Jane's song'. Then I thought he was going to take me to his parents' house [where Gainsbourg still lived], like all good boys do, but no, he took me straight to the Hilton, where they asked him if he wanted his usual room!"

Birkin was horrified. The evening had started out, quite successfully all things considered, as a quest for an entente cordiale but she was about to become another notch on his rented bedpost. "In the lift as we were going up, I was pulling faces to myself, thinking, gosh, how could I have got myself into such a mess? I had only known John Barry in all my life, and suddenly here I was with someone who had only taken me out for one night." Once in his room she said she wanted to use the bathroom, where she hid out as long as she could - "and tried to tidy myself up and try to look as if I was used to this sort of thing. By the time I got back into the bedroom, he was asleep. There he was, he'd drunk so much that he was out cold. And I was so relieved! It meant I could nip out to the drugstore and pick up a little 45 record of this song we had been listening to all evening which was 'Yummy yummy yummy I've got love in my tummy' by God knows who. I stuck it between his toes - still he didn't move - and went back to my hotel."

The pair became inseparable. Shortly after filming, Gainsbourg asked Jane to record a new version of Je T'Aime.

"I don't know how he got Jane to do it because she was such a lovely English upper-class schoolgirl," said Marianne Faithfull. "But of course, he would have got her to do it by fucking her brains out! And Je T'Aime was perfect for Jane. She was born for it."

Certainly Je T'Aime's languid, almost over-pretty, chocolate-box melody contained some surreal images for a love song - " je vais et je viens, entre tes reins " translates as "I come and go between your kidneys". But then, this was a love song that denied it was a love song, or was too cynical or insecure to own up to it. The lyrical subtleties were lost on late-1960s Brits. What they heard was an expertly stroked organ, orgasmic groans and a soft-focus melody, the musical equivalent of a Vaseline-smeared Emmanuelle movie. It was confirmation that life across the Channel was one of unchecked lubriciousness, and Je T'Aime became as essential a part of any successful seduction as a chilled bottle of Blue Nun.

The press, of course, speculated - as they had with the Bardot version - that Gainsbourg and Birkin had simply recorded a live sex session. To which Gainsbourg said, according to Birkin, "'Thank goodness it wasn't, otherwise I hope it would have been a long-playing record'. We made it, very boringly, in the studio in Marble Arch, both of us in sort of telephone cabins."

As soon as they had finished recording the song, Gainsbourg and Birkin rushed back with it to Paris. "The hotel where we were living at the time, where Oscar Wilde had died - Gainsbourg liked it because of that anecdote - had a restaurant in the wine-cellar where people could sit in the little compartments and have dinner, and there was a man who used to play rather slow and discreet records for background music. Gainsbourg couldn't resist popping on Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus," Birkin recalls. As they sat back and watched, "Everybody's knives and forks were in the air, suspended. Nobody went on eating. Gainsbourg said 'I think we've got a hit.' "

Gainsbourg claimed that his hymn to sexual liberation was, in fact, an "anti-fuck" song, about the desperation and innate impossibility of physical love. Whatever the truth, at the age of 41 and after 11 years in the business, Gainsbourg finally had an international success.

With their success assured, Gainsbourg, with Birkin, decided to record France's first concept album.

Her name is Melody, an English girl, barely 15 years old, with red hair - "her natural colour", he adds, with a mix of poignancy and regret . The stage is set for danger and sex. Melody, does he take us off to the funky Hotel Particulier where, reflected in the mirror above the rococo bed, we watch him deflower her. (Unlike Je T'Aime, Birkin says, there was a tape recorder under the bed - the horsey laugh on this track is the sound of her being tickled in a hotel room).

Young Melody gets homesick (for Sunderland!) and catches a flight back home, but the plane crashes, leaving a tormented, broken, middle-aged man face-to-face with his own solitude, and with "nothing to lose and no God to believe in". The tragedy, of course, was inevitable. Once she had lost her virginity, the underage redhead had to die in order to keep the ideal of beauty, youth and purity alive in his imagination. fields.bodyText: When Serge Gainsbourg died in his bedroom on March 2 1991, a month short of his 63rd birthday, France went into mourning. Brigitte Bardot, who had been his lover, gave a eulogy; President Mitterrand, who wasn't, gave him one too. He was "our Baudelaire, our Apollinaire", said the head of state. "He elevated song to the level of art." Flags were flown at half-mast - a less fitting symbol for the priapic pop genius than the bottles of whisky and Pastis and packets of Gitanes cigarettes left as tributes by the crowds who descended, à la Princess Di, on the police barricades erected around his home on the Rue de Vernueil. "Ask anyone in Paris," said Nicolas Godin of the French band Air, "and they can remember what they were doing when they heard Gainsbourg had died. It was such a shock. Because he was always there, part of our culture. He was always on the television doing something crazy. He was a poet. He was a punk. And he wanted to fuck Whitney Houston." The man who looked like an elegant turtle cross-bred with a particularly louche, chain-smoking wolf was also a singer, a songwriter, a cutting-edge soundtrack composer, a Eurovision Song Contest winner, novelist, photographer, actor, artist, drunk, director, screenwriter, populist, provocateur, sentimentalist, clown, lover, intellectual, and the man who single-handedly liberated French pop. In spite of - or because of - a singular dedication to cigarettes, alcohol, sensuality and provocation (his infamous "I want to fuck you" offer to fellow-guest Houston on a French family TV show combined all four), his musical output over more than three decades was staggering. It encompassed a variety of reinventions that made David Bowie look stereotyped - classical, chanson, jazz, girl-group pop, rock, reggae, disco and funk. He displayed a profound knowledge of, and respect for, tradition, while simultaneously giving it two fingers, then used all these disparate things to make something unique. His lyrics were mind-boggling exercises in Franglais, triple entendres and rhythmic, onomatopoeic word-percussion. Literature, sexual obsession, farting, incest, philosophy, grammar, cabbages, Nazi death camps and the Torrey Canyon disaster were all considered perfectly reasonable subject matter for his songs, which were whistled in the street and printed in poetry books that were studied in universities. And yet on this side of the Channel, Gainsbourg is really known for just one song: his 1969 number one hit with Jane Birkin, Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus. "There's a trilogy in my life," said Gainsbourg, "an equilateral triangle, shall we say, of Gitanes, alcoholism and girls - and I didn't say isosceles, I said equilateral. But it all comes from the background of a man whose initiation in beauty was art." Brigitte Bardot - or BB, as the French call her - was the actress for whom the term "sex kitten" was invented. Bardot was signed by Gainsbourg's record company, Philips, in 1962, and she had already released two singles that her labelmate had written before they were both booked to appear on Sacha Distel's primetime Saturday night TV show. It was 1967, two months after the so-called Summer of Love, and Gainsbourg fell for BB mightily. She was, Distel said, "the dream of Serge's life". It must have been a dream come true to find that Bardot was attracted to him too, and that their rendezvous should happen just as her second marriage was on the rocks. She invited him to appear on her Le Bardot Show, and what started as a working relationship soon developed into a love affair. It was a discreet one to start with: unlike Gainsbourg, Bardot had a horror of press attention. Initially they met furtively at friends' apartments, but then threw caution to the wind and allowed the paparazzi to snap them at all the top nightspots or in Bardot's convertible Triumph Spitfire (with Bardot at the wheel as Gainsbourg couldn't drive), gliding through a Paris plastered with photos of BB in thigh-high boots and black leather mini-skirt straddling a motorbike - an advertisement for her latest Gainsbourg-penned single, Harley-Davidson. On the Le Bardot Show, the stream of Gainsbourg classics inspired by his new love (or demanded by her producers) were performed by the pair in front of outlandish sets of the cod-psychedelic variety that you only ever saw on 1960s TV shows. For Comic Strip, for instance, Bardot was made up as a black-wigged Barbarella character, surrounded by bright "comic-book" balloons bearing "Zip! Pow! Wiz!" exclamations. For Bonnie and Clyde, Gainsbourg played the part of Clyde with shoulder-holster and cigarette, while BB, in a long skirt, short wig and beret, was his loyal moll. Bonnie and Clyde was the title track of Gainsbourg and BB's album together, released in 1968. It was one of a pair of songs Gainsbourg had written in the space of a night following a disastrous early date with Bardot. Struck dumb with either nerves or alcohol, his usual wit deserted him, the evening was a flop and he thought he had blown it. But Bardot phoned the next day and demanded as a penance that he write her "the most beautiful love song you can imagine". In fact he wrote two - Bonnie and Clyde and Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus. Late one night in the winter of 1967, Gainsbourg and Bardot went into a dimly lit studio in Paris and recorded Michel Colombier's arrangement of Je T'Aime in an intimate two-hour session. The two singers were squashed into a small, steamy glass booth; engineer William Flageollet witnessed what he described as "heavy petting". Word leaked to the press that it was an "audio vérité" recording, with the Sunday paper France-Dimanche reporting that the four minutes and 35 seconds of "groans, sighs, and Bardot's little cries of pleasure" set to almost churchlike organ music gave "the impression you're listening to two people making love". The next thing the journalists did was call up Bardot's husband and ask him what he thought of it. His reply made the next day's headlines - "Furious Gunter Sachs Demands the Single Be Withdrawn" - something that Bardot's agent was agreeing to behind the scenes. Bardot was about to star with Sean Connery in Shalako, released in 1968, and it was not a good time for a scandal (in any case, Bardot hated scandals). She wrote Gainsbourg a letter, pleading with him not to release the record. Gainsbourg protested: "The music is very pure. For the first time in my life, I write a love song and it's taken badly." webTitle: David Mamet reveals how film location scouts keep themselves amused

fields.headline: The goon squad
fields.standfirst: How do film location scouts keep themselves amused during the hundreds of hours they spend on the road?  David Mamet reveals all
fields.trailText: How do film location scouts keep themselves amused during the hundreds of hours they spend on the road? David Mamet reveals all
fields.body:
The old film story has a crew shooting a car on top of a mountain. It is the "magic hour" shot, which is to say, sunset. The shot is set up when the location manager says: "This spot is good, but the spot 100 yards away is superb." Everyone schleps over, and there, on a promontory, is the most magnificent view in the world - the valley stretches away below, all is perfect save the one pine tree occupying the only space to put the product. They chop down the tree, put the car there, get the shot and repair to the local airport.

Everyone is having a drink, waiting for the plane, and the bartender says: "You folks look happy."

"Happy?" the director says. "Of course we're happy. We just shot at the most beautiful vista I have ever seen."

"Oh," says the bartender, "you must have been up on Lone Pine Ridge."

Priceless film lore. Van humour.

Most films are made on location, and location shooting means hundreds of hours in the van. We pile into the van to scout locations, to revisit chosen locations with the art department, to revisit with the director of photography and the storyboard artist, to revisit with locations, stunts, effects . . . Four hours a day five days a week times 10 weeks of pre-production is 200 hours in the van; we talk on the cellphone, and gossip and exchange film stories. Getting dishy or silly is an effective strategy to take the edge off The Van - a locale in which it never gets more "entre nous".

The most prized stories, of course, are the morbid: who threw up on camera, who got on the wrong plane and went to Thailand, who forgot to remove his or her body mike and repaired to the camper to make love with an unauthorised person (while the sound man, of course, put it out over the PA). This week my favourite is the couple who leased their house for a shoot. ("We'll leave it better than we found it" - a phrase, in itself, capable of raising a chuckle in the van. Other van howlers: "It plays in one shot"; "I see one bare light bulb"; "Don't worry.") One gag involved the couple's house catching fire. The technicians built a false front on the house and, on the day, set it aflame. The gag went awry and the whole house went up in flames. The owners, standing on a neighbour's lawn, looked at the marvellously believable effect and clapped. "They clapped three times," the eyewitness said.

Then one day we were shooting in a large Victorian house. The owner had grown up there. Her grandfather had built it, after the civil war. "Touch anything," she said, "except the wallpaper." It was original to the house, flocked and multicoloured, irreplaceable, historically significant and so on. And we were So Careful, until the last minute of the last day of night shooting, and the sun was coming up, and we had to get it and get out.

"Why?" they said. "It's green now."

Van dish: What suicide was not a suicide, what marriage not a marriage, who "fixed" the Oscars, who poisoned his wife, who was a bit too kind to animals; and updates on the various run-of-the-mill dope fiends, lushes, psychoneurotics and paedophiles who populate this business that we've chosen.

One feels, and this is much of the joy, that it's always been the same - the stories are the same, the names change: strike out the ones libel laws prohibit mentioning, fill in Ramon Navarro, Wallace Reid, Roscoe Arbuckle, Mary Miles Minter, William Desmond Taylor, Marilyn Monroe.

"It's gonna be a big hit foreign," they say. "We don't want to hurt the German market. How about if instead of being German, the camp guards were Poles? What do you think . . . ?" "I would," says Wilder, "but most of my family died at Dachau."

And, at the end of the day, the van convulses itself with speculation about Location Scouting 300 years hence: "Pluto," they would say. "Man, I love Pluto - you can shoot it for Jupiter, you can shoot it for the Moon, parts of it look like the Asteroids . . ."

Van humour.

webTitle: Teach Chinese at five, urges Lib Dem MEP

fields.headline: Teach Chinese at five, urges Lib Dem MEP
fields.trailText: Children as young as five should be made to study Chinese, the leader of the European Liberal Democrats said yesterday.
fields.body:
Children as young as five should be made to study Chinese, the leader of the European Liberal Democrats said yesterday.

In a shift away from European modern languages, Graham Watson, the leader of the UK Lib Dems in the European Parliament and MEP for the South West, said it was "short-termist" to ignore the relevance of Mandarin in the 21st century. While there is some pressure in business to acknowledge the growth of Chinese, Mr Watson's plans were derided by educationalists yesterday.

Mr Watson, who will visit the Taiwanese government next month to try to win sponsorship for Chinese teaching in schools in the south west, insisted his plan was forward-thinking by stressing the language was spoken by 1.3bn people and was "a passport to communication with the non- English speaking world. Any rational look at the world today will show that English and Mandarin Chinese will be the two most important languages in the world in the 21st century," he said.

"There are more Chinese speakers than the whole population of Europe and North America combined and our EU competitors, such as France and the Netherlands, have already woken up to the importance of teaching it. In Britain we should be training teachers now." The MEP, who speaks fluent French, German and Italian, went on: "I am sure a lot of people with say 'This chap's nuts' but any rational look at the 21st century suggests this would would be great for business, for effective global integration, and for diplomacy."

His proposal, which the LibDems stressed was no part of their manifesto, was attacked by teachers' unions, however.

Nigel de Gruchy, the general secretary of the NAS/UWT, said: "What does he envisage being dropped off the national currriculum, where's he going to find the teachers? He's made a valuable contribution to the 3001 national curriculum - but not for now."

The Department for Education said it recognised the importance of Chinese as a business language, but no primary schools taught it. "Primary schools need to concentrate on the basics of reading, writing and maths," a spokesman added.
