webTitle: The British businessman who aims to make $1bn taking water from the desert

fields.headline: The British businessman who aims to make $1bn taking water from the desert
fields.trailText: In the shimmering beauty of the Mojave desert, some 200 miles from Los Angeles and nestling between the Marbles and the Ship Mountains just off Route 66, lies Cadiz, a tiny settlement built as a watering station for the old railroad and now almost deserted.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in the Mojave desert
fields.body:
In the shimmering beauty of the Mojave desert, some 200 miles from Los Angeles and nestling between the Marbles and the Ship Mountains just off Route 66, lies Cadiz, a tiny settlement built as a watering station for the old railroad and now almost deserted.

The temperature in high summer averages 46C (115F) and has hit 56C (132F). The desolate terrain, with its tumbleweed, coyotes, jackrabbits and breathtakingly clear starry skies, has drawn drifters and film-makers alike. Now Cadiz could be about to play a part in one of the great dramas of California: the battle for water.

The settlement stands at the centre of a $1bn project which supporters claim will solve southern California's water problems for the next 50 years, and which detractors suggest will prove to be an economic and ecological disaster that will damage the delicate desert eco-system for centuries to come.

At the heart of the largest public-private project in the state's history, is a buccaneering self-made businessman from Surrey called Keith Brackpool.

Mr Brackpool, 43, who still has family in England, came to the United States in his 20s as an investment banker. He was head of the American division of Albert Fisher, the food distribution company, until 1991 when it emerged that he had a $10m controlling stake in a subsidiary of Polly Peck, the Asil Nadir-owned company which had collapsed dramatically. Mr Brackpool resigned from Albert Fisher. His spokeswoman said yesterday that his departure from the company was "extremely amicable" and that he had left at the time "so that there was no suggestion of impropriety".

In the early 80s, Mr Brackpool had been shown satellite photos indicating that there was water under the Mojave desert, and he embarked on the scheme which could now come to fruition. His company has gradually bought up almost 60,000 acres of the desert.

Cadiz Inc's tiny office in the Mojave desert consists of a wooden house with a jokey sign inside which warns employees that, if they speak in Spanish, they will be paid in pesos. The company's current business is agricultural - producing grapes and citrus fruits - and it posted a net loss in 1999 of $8,594,000, which, it says, is similar to any project at its early stages of development.

But the company's massive potential is shown by Cadiz's main headquarters - a spectacular skyscraper overlooking the Pacific in Santa Monica. Whether it can realise that promise depends on California's desperate need for more water.

Forced to cut back on the quantity of water it is sucking out of the Colorado river, the state faces a possible critical drought. The Metropolitan Water District (MWD), which provides around 17m people with water in southern California, is seriously looking at the possibility of a $1bn 50-year deal with Mr Brackpool that would both store excess water in wet years and pump water from an aquifer under the desert during dry years.

This month, a decision is due to be made on whether the Cadiz Programme, as it is called, should go ahead, subject to final environmental tests. The crucial decision comes just as California is in the midst of a power crisis, with rolling black-outs across the state.

Mr Brackpool's company has several agricultural schemes on the go, including one with the Saudi royal family in Egypt, which Cadiz Inc says could become the largest single agricultural project in the world.

It is also one of the biggest financial backers of California governor Gray Davis, the man who hopes to take the Democratic nomination for president in 2004. Cadiz Inc contributed $133,000 to Mr Davis's 1998 gubernatorial campaign and a total of $445,000 to all politicians. His spokeswoman said this week that "every publicly-held company in the state" made similar donations and that they were made to "candidates who supported a positive business environment".

Mr Brackpool was appointed co-chairman of the Agriculture and Water Transition Task Force when Mr Davis took office and was appointed to the Commission on Building for the 21st Century. He is bullish about the importance of the Cadiz project and said this week: "Experiencing massive population growth and severe cutbacks on existing water supplies, the state risks its future viability and economic prosperity without efforts such as the Cadiz Programme."

A spokesman for Mr Davis said the governor took advice from "a wide variety of contacts" of whom Mr Brackpool was one, but that he was not influenced in any way by who had, or had not, contributed to his political campaigns. A spokesman for the MWD said there had been no attempt from the governor's office to influence its decision in any way and that it had not received a single call from him on the subject.

Before the scheme can go ahead, environmental studies by the US Geological Survey and the National Parks Service have to be done, a process which could be completed in a few weeks. But the stage is already set for confrontation as the plan is being vigorously challenged by environmentalists.

Steven Krefting of the National Parks Conservation Association, a major opponent of the plan, says that the environmental impact studies done so far have been flawed and that the project could seriously damage both the wildlife and the atmosphere in the desert. "The desert is quite pristine and clear, you expect to see lots of stars at night. What you would get (as a result of the dust storms) is a constant haze. I'm not prepared to sacrifice a desert eco-system so that people can fill up their swimming pools," he said.

Ellen Stern Harris, executive director of the Fund for the Environment and a director emeritus of the MWD, said that the MWD's special committee has yet to address the myriad environmental problems the Cadiz deal presents.

Mr Brackpool is undeterred by the criticism. "We seem to have developed an extraordinary notion that any water solution requires 100% consensus to make it happen," he said in a speech last year. "We encourage and we give incentives to those who oppose progress."

Fiona Hutton, who speaks for Cadiz, says that many others support the scheme and backs this up with a sheaf of positive responses from newspapers such as the Orange County Register, which congratulates the MWD for "thinking ahead". She says that the scheme would only go ahead if it passed strict environmental tests. The company argues that underground water storage has less environmental impact than reservoirs and dams, and that the project will create local jobs.

None of which will satisfy Elden Hughes of the environmental organisation the Sierra Club, who believes that the scheme should be halted because it could destroy the habitat of the desert tortoise, an endangered species, and bighorn sheep in the vicinity, as well as creating the possibility of dust storms.

Mr Hughes says that the scheme is flawed on both economic and environmental grounds and that the MWD might find they had lost $200m before "they find out the truth... they're taking on a very bad bet. If they start pumping, we could lose all the springs - by which time Cadiz will be in Egypt growing melons."

Death and disaster

There is no more emotive issue in Californian politics than water. When, in 1913, Dublin-born engineer William Mulholland opened the 233-mile long Los Angeles aqueduct - the longest in the world - he told the cheering crowd: "There it is! Take it!" But the construction led to the so-called "Owens Valley War" and the deaths of 450 people.

Farmers in the eastern Sierra Nevada who had lost their water supply as a result of the scheme dynamited the aqueduct in1924, and in the same year 70 armed men seized a key aqueduct gate and shut off the entire flow of water. They were joined by 700 supporters in a standoff as businessmen urged the state government to send in the militia and the LA Times hailed them as "honest, earnest, hardworking American citizens who look upon Los Angeles as an octopus about to strangle out their lives".

Sabotage

In 1927, masked men blew up another key section and Mulholland dispatched a patrol with a shoot-to-kill policy. In 1928 a dam collapsed, releasing a 15bn gallon flood that killed 450 people, with bodies washed up as far away as San Diego. Mulholland was blamed and died seven years later. An engineering association exonerated him in 1992.

Water and corruption were the themes of the 1974 film Chinatown, which won its writer Robert Towne an Oscar and in which the character of Mulray was loosely based on Mulholland.

"Every tree, every lawn, every blade of grass... is a forced growth, made possible by man's ingenuity in bringing water to what otherwise would be a treeless waste," was how Boyle Workman, one of LA's turn of the century real estate developers described the importance of water.

Farmers in the eastern Sierra Nevada who had lost their water supply as a result of the scheme dynamited the aqueduct in1924, and in the same year 70 armed men seized a key aqueduct gate and shut off the entire flow of water. They were joined by 700 supporters in a standoff as businessmen urged the state government to send in the militia and the LA Times hailed them as "honest, earnest, hardworking American citizens who look upon Los Angeles as an octopus about to strangle out their lives". Sabotage In 1927, masked men blew up another key section and Mulholland dispatched a patrol with a shoot-to-kill policy. In 1928 a dam collapsed, releasing a 15bn gallon flood that killed 450 people, with bodies washed up as far away as San Diego. Mulholland was blamed and died seven years later. An engineering association exonerated him in 1992. Water and corruption were the themes of the 1974 film Chinatown, which won its writer Robert Towne an Oscar and in which the character of Mulray was loosely based on Mulholland. "Every tree, every lawn, every blade of grass... is a forced growth, made possible by man's ingenuity in bringing water to what otherwise would be a treeless waste," was how Boyle Workman, one of LA's turn of the century real estate developers described the importance of water.

webTitle: Row over u-turn on arms sales to Sahara war zone

fields.headline: Row over u-turn on arms sales to Sahara war zone
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook was embroiled in a fresh row over arms sales yesterday after giving the go-ahead for a £3.5m contract to supply artillery spare parts to a north African war zone.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook was embroiled in a fresh row over arms sales yesterday after giving the go-ahead for a £3.5m contract to supply artillery spare parts to a north African war zone.

The contract is to restore 30 105mm guns of the Moroccan army, which has been involved in a 26-year-old dispute with Western Sahara.

The Foreign Office confirmed last night that ministers had initially rejected the application for a licence from Royal Ordnance, owned by BAE Systems formerly British Aerospace, in August 1998.

At the time, the ministers decided that such a contract could be in breach of the European code of conduct on arms sales, which forbids sales to countries that could use them for aggressive territorial gain.

Morocco occupied part of Western Sahara in 1975 and has been engaged in conflict with Polisario guerrillas fighting for independence. The UN is policing a ceasefire.

The Foreign Office said that ministers changed their mind and granted the licence in June 1999.

A spokeswoman said that they had done so after advice from the UN that refurbish ment of guns was within the terms of the ceasefire arrangements.

The row was sparked on Tuesday when Mr Cook disclosed the contract while giving evidence to a Commons select committee.

Mr Cook, speaking just before the committee went into private session, said that the grounds for the original refusal were made irrelevant by the UN's position on the Western Sahara dispute.

A spokesman for the UN said yesterday: "The UN advice was that there was no violation of the ceasefire agreement in this specific instance." There are no UN sanctions in force against Morocco.

Tess Kingham, a Labour member of the committee, said yesterday: "This is astonishing. At the bottom of this is the staggering admission that we have granted licences for spare parts to refurbish big guns in Western Sahara.

"This plainly goes against our ethical criteria, which state that if there is clear evidence that weapons could be used by a government to enforce a territorial claim, we should refuse the licence.

"What more evidence do you want than the fact that these weapons are actually in the disputed territory."

Steve Tibbett, a spokesman for the campaign War on Want, said: "If these assurances [by the Foreign Office] are true, we are very concerned that the UK government is being forced into endorsing arms exports to a disputed territory. The UN are supposed to be peacemakers in the region."

Coordinator of the Western Sahara Campaign, Richard Stanforth said: "It is a disgrace. The UN is mandated to organise a referendum in Western Sahara, not to help the Moroccans build up their military might in preparation for another war."

There was initial confusion at the Foreign Office over whether Mr Cook's remarks had been made in a private or public session.

Mr Cook was under the impression he had been speaking in private. The Foreign Office confirmed that he had in fact been speaking during the open public session, and the private session began only after the exchanges on the Western Sahara.

Campaigners against the arms trade said last night they were suspicious about a delay in publishing a transcript of Mr Cook's remarks to the committee about the involvement of the UN. The transcript would normally have been available on the internet by now, although ministers and MPs do have access to make "corrections".

webTitle: Government caught out by closure plans

fields.headline: Government caught out by closure plans
fields.standfirst:
MPs predict Labour party will be forced to rethink its contacts with businessmen
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: MPs predict Labour party will be forced to rethink its contacts with businessmen
fields.body:
There were bitter claims among Labour MPs last night that Corus management's refusal to discuss its massive closure programme - and the government's impotence - may mark a turning point in relations between New Labour and British business.

Downing Street was only told of the timing of the announcement on Wednesday evening.

The Labour front bench was unrestrained yesterday in its anger at the cavalier behaviour of Corus management. Backbench MPs denounced the company as greedy, stony faced or vandals.

The front bench tone was markedly different from that during some other recent closures, when the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) shrugged its shoulders at the influence of global market forces.

Cynics may claim that an embarrassed government, nervous of the political impact of the closures in Labour's heartland constituencies, had to distance itself from the management decision. Plaid Cymru, demanding renationalisation of steel, is performing strongly in South Wales.

The Welsh TUC pointed out that a new EU directive on workers' rights to consultation is being blocked by Labour. The Welsh TUC said yesterday: "It was outrageous. Steelworkers were finding out [about the closure programme] by logging on to the BBC website."

But Denis MacShane, MP for the steel area of Rotherham, claimed yesterday that the government frustration was not just for show."This may be the point at which scales fall from the government's eyes about some British businessmen," he said.

It was not until an 8am meeting yesterday between Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and Sir Brian Moffat, the chairman of Corus, at DTI headquarters that steel management finally took the government into its confidence about the scale of the shutdown.

Yet ministers cannot be accused of complacency. Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh first secretary, visited Llanwern steelworks in October. The Welsh assembly offered a package on a cross-party basis. Paul Murphy, the Welsh secretary, met Sir Brian twice in recent weeks, once in the company of Tony Blair. And on Monday, steel constituency MPs, mainly from Wales, lobbied Sir Brian - only to be told no decisions had been made.

However, ministerial sources admit that Mr Morgan was always struggling to compile a package which would have helped Corus management recalibrate the losses. Too much British manufacturing had closed and too many firms were buying steel from abroad.

Nor could Mr Morgan offer better industrial relations. Productivity is already 20% higher at Llanwern than at the Dutch sister plant Ijmuiden.

Mr Morgan discussed relief on business rates worth £8m, and Mr Byers asked Sir Brian whether the £8m annual cost of the new climate change levy was a critical factor. The DTI also examined whether it could provide some help with research and development. The DTI select committee had been highly critical of the way in which R&D facilities were being moved from Wales to the Dutch headquarters. The Welsh assembly also promised that it would quickly buy any surplus property no longer needed by Corus.

Some claimed the rescue package was worth £20m, although the Stockton South MP, Dari Taylor, claimed in the Commons yesterday that the true figure was £85m.

EU competition rules also dictate that direct state aid to the industry through the kind of regional selective assistance given to Rover and Nissan would be blocked by the commission.

The government's best argument with Corus was acting short-term. Sterling was finally falling against the euro and the dollar. Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, claimed a 10 pfennig movement in the exchange rate wiped £80m off the company's losses.

But Mr Morgan had also admitted only a week ago that ministers would not seek to influence the level of the pound. "The high pound has this scissors effect of making the Dutch workers appear to be very profitable and the British workforce appear to be making a loss. It is very difficult for a company if it is export dependent and is combatting the artificially high level of the pound which we are unfortunately suffering at the moment."

Now Corus has given a stay of execution to February 14. With hard information at its disposal, the DTI can offer a more detailed aid package. The steel union will retable its already rejected offer to buy out Llanwern. But few ministers seem optimistic about a change of mind by Corus.

fields.headline: Steel: more jobs may go
fields.trailText: Sir Brian Moffat, chairman of the Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus, yesterday brushed aside the political clamour for a rethink of his savage restructuring plan and warned that there could be more job losses on top of the 6,050 he had just announced.
fields.byline: David Gow, Nicholas Bannister, Patrick Wintour  and  Michael White
fields.body:
Sir Brian Moffat, chairman of the Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus, yesterday brushed aside the political clamour for a rethink of his savage restructuring plan and warned that there could be more job losses on top of the 6,050 he had just announced.

He refused to guarantee that more of Corus's operations would not close, especially if British manufacturers continued to buy cheap steel from abroad.

The announcement of the job losses brought immediate condemnation from MPs, workers and unions. The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and the ISTC and the AEEU unions demanded that Corus rethink its entire strategy.

The Corus chairman indicated that he was unlikely to change the radical restructuring, which will result in the closure of the group's Ebbw Vale plant and the reduction of its huge Llanwern integrated steel facility to a shadow of its former self. He said the group's bankers, who have agreed to provide a £2.4bn loan, had approved the restructuring.

But at a meeting with Sir Brian after the announcement, union leaders won a fortnight's reprieve to give them time to come up with an alternative to the closure programme.

At Westminster, ministers and Labour MPs were furious about being kept in the dark over Corus's plans until the last minute - but admitted that the cutbacks could have been worse. Not even Tony Blair or Mr Byers knew the details until 8am yesterday.

With an election looming, Labour fears a backlash in heartland Labour seats. Whitehall's inability to offer an immediate package reflects its frustration at Corus's refusal to be candid.

Downing Street again made plain Mr Blair's "frustration at the lack of meaningful dialogue."

Mr Byers attacked Corus - formed by the £3.9bn merger of British Steel and Holland's Hoogovens in 1999 - for failing to discuss its plans with the government. "Relevant information has not been disclosed; they have been resistant to any meaningful dialogue and have refused to discuss in detail their plans for the industry. We have expressed our concerns to the company at the highest level."

He later met Labour MPs to plot a strategy designed to put maximum pressure on the company to rethink, including letters to the firm's suppliers, and further meetings with Corus board members.

Barred by EU rules from outright subsidy, ministers will offer research and development grants, business rate relief and the purchase of any excess land, but they admit the package would only be worth less than £80m.

Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "The Welsh plants are Corus's most productive but British workers are the cheapest and easiest to sack. Corus are going for the short-term quick fix with an attack on British workers."

However, Corus's announcement was welcomed in the City where the group's shares rose 10% even though it made a £1.17bn loss for the past 15 months. The cost of the restructuring accounted for just over £1bn of the loss.

The steel unions said they would blitz Corus shareholders at home and abroad in favour of other proposals. Mick Leahy, leader of the main union, the ISTC, whose executive meets in emergency ses sion today, said the drastic measures were short-termist.

But Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh assembly's first minister, admitted that the prospects for a rethink were not high. He said the Corus decision would result in 4,000 job losses in and around the Welsh plants - and as many again in the region as a whole.

Corus blamed the cutbacks on its inability to export flat steel at a profit. Industry experts estimate the group has been losing £65 a tonne on exports from Britain.

Sir Brian said the group had been forced to increase exports to offset a decline in British demand. The new strategy would bring UK production in line with that demand.

He said European steel prices had been falling, and Corus had had to compete with cheap imports triggered by the strong pound.

He admitted that the group's cutbacks would devastate whole communities. But he said action had to be taken to protect the other 22,000 Corus jobs in Britain.

The cash-rich ISTC has dropped plans to make a bid for the Llanwern works because Corus intends to retain the hot strip mill and cold mill operations there.

About 1,340 jobs will be axed at Llanwern and 780 will go with the closure of the tin plate plant at Ebbw Vale. Plants at Shotton, Bryngwyn, Newport, Scunthorpe, Teesside, Corby, Hartlepool and Stockton will also shed large numbers. The first 3,000 jobs will go this year, with the remaining 3,050 by 2003.

webTitle: Man of steel who loathes politicians

fields.headline: Man of steel who loathes politicians
fields.standfirst: Chairman 'interested in making money, not steel'
fields.trailText: Even his close associates call him cold, hard and distant. But Sir Brian Moffat struck union officials at yesterday's fateful 75-minute breakfast briefing at his Mayfair HQ as genuinely shaken and nervous for a man of steel.
fields.body:
Even his close associates call him cold, hard and distant. But Sir Brian Moffat struck union officials at yesterday's fateful 75-minute breakfast briefing at his Mayfair HQ as genuinely shaken and nervous for a man of steel.

As he set out his drastic restructuring plans over bacon sandwiches, the chairman of Corus was, one participant said: "Not at all belligerent as we'd imagined. Not conciliatory either but ready to talk and listen - and clearly, very angry indeed with the political process and with politicians."

Sir Brian, denounced by the cabinet and leading Welsh politicians for failing to take them into his confidence about his plans, simply loathes politicians - and not just socialists. A Scottish accountant who made his mark in the Thatcherite period and run-up to the 1988 privatisation at the old British Steel (which he joined in 1968), he may be a Conservative but he believes politicians of all hues should keep their noses well out of business.

Sir Brian served in Wales as director of the Port Talbot plant in the mid-1970s and early 1980s. Yesterday he was said by Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the Welsh national assembly, to have claimed to be "equally as emotionally affected as any worker because he's spent his life building things and now has to tear them down".

But Sir Brian, 62, who was knighted in 1996, is a past master at wielding the axe to steelworkers' jobs. At Port Talbot, in the aftermath of the 1980 national strike, he laid plans known as Operation Dogleg to merge the plant with its sister 50 miles to the east, Llanwern, and, though it has taken 20 years to achieve this with yesterday's plans, he left behind a legacy of thousands of redundancies.

Last December he enforced the resignation of his protege, the Welshman John Bryant, and his Dutch colleague, Fokko van Duyne, as co-chief executives because they had been too dilatory about satisfying investors by closing down steel plants - even though the two had set in train 4,800 redundancies in the UK.

"It was a classic case of soft cop, hard cop, with Bryant playing the soft guy who had to go and Moffat the hard cop," Rhodri Morgan said. "There was no point in his coming out of semi-retirement [he had stepped down as chief executive in January 1999 but stayed on as chairman] unless it was to be a hard man."

Yesterday Sir Brian insisted that he had acted to safeguard the future of the 22,000 steelworkers who will remain. But his motto is "I'm interested in making money, not steel" and, after seeing the merger he masterminded produce losses of £1.2bn in 15 months, he has little time to prove it.

webTitle: Business:  British Midland press for European review

fields.headline: New image Airline decides the young won't buy British
fields.standfirst:
Newly named British Midland pressed European Commission to review the lack of competition on transatlantic routes from heathrow

Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: British Midland yesterday changed its name to BMI British Midland and pressed for a review by the European commission into the lack of competition on transatlantic routes from Heathrow.
fields.body:
British Midland yesterday changed its name to BMI British Midland and pressed for a review by the European commission into the lack of competition on transatlantic routes from Heathrow.

Sir Michael Bishop, BMI'S chairman, said the company had met EC officials following legal advice that the "open skies" negotiations between Britain and the United States may be inconsistent with EU competition law.

Speaking at the launch of the airline's new brand identity and aircraft livery, Sir Michael said that the Bermuda II agreement was not only an unfair shackle on British consumers, but flouted EU competition law. "We believe that there are clear indications that this agreement acts against the interests of competition and consumers, and that this requires further investigation by the commission," he said.

webTitle: Drivers go ahead with tube strike

fields.headline: Drivers go ahead with tube strike
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Three million commuters face heavy disruption on the London Underground on Monday when 2,000 train drivers are expected to strike over safety, despite a decision by a high court judge yesterday to outlaw parallel industrial action by 7,000 other tube workers.
fields.body:
Three million commuters face heavy disruption on the London Underground on Monday when 2,000 train drivers are expected to strike over safety, despite a decision by a high court judge yesterday to outlaw parallel industrial action by 7,000 other tube workers.

Mr Justice Gibbs refused the Rail Maritime and Transport union leave to appeal against his ruling that its strike call was "defective" because the union had failed to supply managers with details of where each group of affected workers was employed. The smaller train drivers' union Aslef is to press ahead with the planned stoppage.

The high court decision came as Ken Livingstone's London transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, resumed face-to-face talks with John Prescott aimed at breaking the deadlock over government plans to press ahead with the break-up and part-privatisation of the tube.

Union leaders reacted angrily to London Underground's resort to the courts and the fact that, despite a nine-to-one strike ballot vote in favour of action, RMT members have been prevented from legally striking on the basis of the Labour government's industrial relations legislation, intended to simplify the requirements for a legal strike.

The walkout by Aslef, which represents most tube drivers, is nevertheless likely to lead to chaos in what is planned to be the first of a series of strikes.

webTitle: Cricket: England caught in their own web

fields.headline: England caught in their own web
fields.standfirst:
Cricket board is embarrassed by critical player profiles on its official site
More net news
fields.trailText: The England and Wales Cricket Board was embarrassed last night after discovering criticism of England players on its own website.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board was embarrassed last night after discovering criticism of England players on its own website.

Nasser Hussain is one of several senior players portrayed unflatteringly, along with more obvious targets such as Graeme Hick and Robert Croft.

The website insisted that Hussain "needs to score some runs... the team simply cannot afford regular failures from their No3". Hick is apparently "quite fortunate to make the trip" after his poor form in Pakistan and is "unlikely to be a first choice for the Test team".

Croft was described as "a surprise recall" who "will need to improve his performance markedly if he is to make an impression". And Alec Stewart is "relatively uncomfortable against spin... England need him to score much more consistently".

Two highly regarded young batsmen did not escape harsh words either. Marcus Trescothick was told that he "lacks much foot movement and still gives his wicket away too often when set". And Michael Vaughan is "another who needs to deliver". Although he missed all three Tests in Pakistan because of injury, "it should be remembered he failed in all his warm-up innings".

The website also nominated Graham Thorpe as Hussain's likely successor as skipper. It said: "Thorpe is increasingly involved in strategy discussions and his graduation to the ranks of senior player may well herald promotion to the captaincy in due course."

The ECB handed over the running of the site to cricinfo, which runs sites for the boards of all Test-playing countries, in a lucrative deal last year.

Few could argue with some of the comments and they certainly make a change from the banal pen pictures normally produced for official publications. But once the contents were brought to the attention of Andrew Walpole, England's media man on tour, frantic phone calls between Colombo and London ensued.

Eventually he issued a statement: "We will be discussing this matter with cricinfo at the earliest opportunity. The pen pictures were not endorsed by the ECB... The board is keen to see the England team portrayed in a positive light and we believe the pen pictures do not fully reflect the achievements of the team over the last 12 months."

Cricinfo claimed yesterday that the offending profiles, which it had in any event removed "because of all this furore", actually appeared on its Sri Lankan board website. "I can understand the confusion," said Alex Balfour, cricinfo's director of business development. "It was linked from the ECB site, so it may have been thought to have been ECB-endorsed."

The controversy mirrors a row at Euro 2000 after an unflattering report on the England football team appeared on Uefa's official website.

After England's first full day in Sri Lanka, the coach Duncan Fletcher spoke about the danger of his players being beguiled by the social freedom of this island. After eight weeks in Pakistan that included Ramadan, Sri Lanka's sun-kissed beaches and ready supply of alcohol must seem very tempting.

"There might be a temptation for the players to take their feet off the pedal," Fletcher explained. "But we are dealing with professional sportsmen and they know what is expected. I believe they will behave and prepare in an appropriate way.

"And I was pleased that hardly any of the players drank alcohol on the flight over. That was great to see."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Commons unit against steel company

fields.headline: Young Mester David confronts an angry gerbil
fields.standfirst: Commons stick together in rage against steel company
fields.trailText: Commons stick together in rage against steel company.
fields.body:
The Commons has spent much time over the past few weeks being united - over the bodies in the chapel of rest, the Alder Hey scandal, and the sacking of Peter Mandelson - which has brought everyone such warmth and happiness on these freezing winter days.

Yesterday they were united in their rage against Corus, the steel company which is sacking 6,000 people. (Why "Corus" instead of "British Steel"? Did they imagine their Welsh employees might think it was really a male-voice choir?)

The unity in the Commons was lucky for Stephen Byers, the secretary for trade and industry, a man who appears constantly baffled by the peculiar ways of those who work in trade and industry. You may remember that BMW caught him entirely by surprise over Longbridge.

He reminds me of our cat. Every day when I leave for work I lure her away from the radiator and into the kitchen by putting a tiny bit of food on her dish. Every day, as I close the door, she looks up in pained astonishment. Curses, fooled again, and for the 1,853rd time! Mr Byers would sympathise.

He sounded hurt as well as surprised by Corus's sheer wickedness. Relevant information had been withheld. They had been "resistant to meaningful dialogue". He begged them to reconsider. Mr Byers being passionate resembles an angry gerbil: you appreciate the strength of his feelings, but can't take them very seriously.

Anyway, there seems to be a fat chance of Corus doing any such thing. Why should they? According to the Thatcherite ideology eagerly embraced by this government, the market is always right. The steelworkers will find jobs at the local Berlei ladies' underwear factory, or designing computer games, or at lawn care centres. Until then, tough.

Mr Byers was also lucky in his chief opponent. The Tories' feeble Angela Browning was replaced by David Heathcoat-Amory, a more coherent fellow, but not one who stirs any more passion than the minister.

Listening to his bloodless speech (he put the crisis down to a "general malaise", as if the economy just needed a walking holiday), watching him peer over his fine-rimmed glasses, seeing the lights glint on his silvery hair, I was minded of the old Heathcoat-Amory mill, in northern Lancashire. Josiah Heathcoat-Amory built it up from nowt. He's a hard man, but an honest man, and he knows the business from top to bottom. His son, young Mester David, is more of a bookish sort. He is courteous but rather vague, and the hands mutter respectfully when he tours the mill, asking questions such as "What does this little, er, thingy do?" Or, "I say, that's a jolly good, um _" When he's gone they roll their eyes and raise their brows, and hope fervently that the Old Man will last a few more years.

(Mr Heathcoat-Amory was also hamstrung by the fact that the real reason for the debacle is the strong pound. But saying this might sound like support for the euro.)

So he blamed the closures partly on petrol prices. Mr Byers said this had nothing to do with it. Mr Heathcoat-Amory held up a paper on which, presumably, this allegation appeared.

The Speaker rose for one of his strange, surreal interventions. "The Rt Hon member must let the minister reply!" he said, as if in some way the waving of a piece of paper might strike Mr Byers dumb.

It was left to the back-bench awkward squad to express the anger. Paul Flynn produced a controlled explosion of real rage.

And a red-faced Ronnie Campbell bellowed: "Re- nationalise them! Give 'em tuppence halfpenny!" Mr Byers was off the hook.

webTitle: Obituary: The Rt Rev Simon Phipps

fields.headline: The Rt Rev Simon Phipps
fields.standfirst:
Confidant of Princess Margaret and champion of women priests
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Confidant of Princess Margaret and champion of women priests.
fields.body:
The Rt Rev Simon Phipps, who has died aged 79, was a classic example of a senior Anglican cleric who made it to the top on his own merits despite being well-born, well-connected and well off. His father, a naval officer, had been appointed to the Royal Victorian Order. Phipps was educated at Eton and, while still a young subaltern, was picked out by the then Queen Elizabeth (now the Queen Mother) as a suitable escort for her younger daughter, Princess Margaret. He went on, in 1968, to be appointed Suffragan Bishop of Horsham, and, in 1974, to become Bishop of Lincoln.

As for many of his generation, the second world war meant instant transference from boy to man, and Phipps joined the Coldstream Guards straight from school. By the age of 25, he had attained the rank of major, and, in the last year of the war, was awarded the Military Cross.

When finally released from brief spells as an ADC in India and a staff officer at the War Office, he arrived belatedly at Trinity College, Cambridge, to read history, graduating in 1948. He became a star turn in the Footlights review, and, in 1949, was elected the club's president. His amateur theatricals appealed to Princess Margaret, herself no mean mimic, and, on one memorable visit to Balmoral, he was roped in to play charades by the then Queen Elizabeth, the future bishop being obliged to march around ahead of King George VI carrying an umbrella in imitation of a crozier.

After training for the ministry at Westcott House, Cambridge, Phipps was ordained in 1950, and served his title as assistant curate at Huddersfield parish church. In 1953, he was invited back to Trinity College as chaplain. This was the year when Princess Margaret fell in love with the divorcé Peter Townsend, and it was to Phipps that, during the next three years, while struggling with her conscience and the constitutional issues, the princess turned for spiritual advice. At one time, they were in almost daily contact. Later, he became godfather to her son, Lord Linley, after her marriage to Anthony Armstrong-Jones.

While still at Trinity College, Phipps also forged, with Mervyn Stockwood, one of his warmest episcopal friendships. He and his wife, Mary, remained loyal and loving friends to the future Bishop of Southwark throughout his lonely years in retirement.

In 1958, Phipps moved into an area of work for which he seemed least suited but became best known, serving for a decade as industrial chaplain to the Coventry diocese. He played a major role in the sociological development of the new Coventry Cathedral, and always said that the people he felt sorry for were the men who found themselves sitting next to him in the works canteen. Determined to give 10 years to the Coventry post, in 1963 he turned down the prestigious living of the Cambridge University church.

In 1965, Phipps was made an honorary canon of Coventry, and three years later, with Princess Margaret in the congregation at Southwark Cathedral, he was consecrated as Suffragan Bishop of Horsham. He used to recount an amusing story about his night at Lambeth Palace on the eve of his consecration.

He imagined that the Archbishop of Canterbury, Michael Ramsey, would pass on some sage advice. But the time went by in silence. Eventually, Phipps suggested they should go to bed. "The only advice the archbishop had given me," he recalled, "was to take every fifth Sunday off, and to leave a space in my diary every week for the crisis which was likely to emerge. I thought it was wonderfully characteristic of him to say two completely mundane things, and to leave the rest to God."

It was in 1973, while still in the Chichester diocese, aged 52 and seemingly a confirmed bachelor, that Phipps surprised and delighted his friends by getting married. His wife, Mary Welch, was a daughter of Sir Charles Palmer, of the biscuit manufacturers, Huntley & Palmer, the widow of a clergyman, and a practising psychiatrist.

The following year, Phipps accepted the bishopric of Lincoln. Strictly speaking, he was no academic or intellectual, and was chosen for his pastoral qualities, his unshockability and innate comprehension of human frailty. He retained his interest in industrial affairs by serving on the council of the Industrial Society, and by speaking out in the House of Lords on the dangers of unemployment. He was also a member of the home secre tary's inquiry on liquor licensing laws, coming down in favour of more flexible opening hours for pubs.

For some reason, his relations with his dean had not been too harmonious, but when he resigned the see in 1986, Phipps left it in pretty good shape. In retirement, however, he watched with increasing dismay the unfolding of dramas and scandals under a future bishop and dean, which were to rend the cathedral chapter asunder.

He retired to his wife's enchanting Sussex home, with views to Chanctonbury Ring, being invited, most unusually, to act as an honorary assistant bishop in two dioceses, Southwark and Chichester. He always said he enjoyed carrying out duties in Southwark because the people there were fun, whereas in Chichester he was regarded as unsound.

This was hardly surprising. Phipps was in favour of the ordination of women, and, in a paper written for the Association of Pastoral Care and Counselling, accused the House of Bishops of abrogating its vocation to prophecy by attempting to force celibacy upon homosexual clergy who themselves had no vocation to celibacy.

He always extended unqualified affection and support to those of his friends, clergy and lay, who were homosexual, and rejoiced in successful permanent gay relationships.

While undeniably an est- ablishment figure, Phipps lacked the pomposity or condescension typical of some senior clergy of his generation, retaining always an easy familiarity. Late in life, he discovered a talent for painting. He was also an excellent cook.

His wife died last June, aged 89.  Simon Wilton Phipps, clergyman, born July 6 1921; died January 29 2001

webTitle: Analysis: Religious groups and social policy

fields.headline: Pious policies
fields.standfirst:
There is a fear that politicians are being tempted to turn to religious groups to deliver social services in a bid to save money rather than souls
Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: There is a fear that politicians are being tempted to turn to religious groups to deliver social services in a bid to save money rather than souls.
fields.body:
This week, in one of his first policy measures, President Bush handed over social services to religious groups - using public money to encourage them to do welfare work.

The idea was formed when Mr Bush was a candidate. "Where my administration sees a responsibility to help people, we will look first to faith-based organisations, charities and community groups that have shown their ability to save and change lives," Mr Bush said on the stump in 1999. He says he converted to Jesus after meeting Billy Graham in 1985.

But political enthusiasm for social action by the churches is not confined to America. Compare Hilary Armstrong, the Labour minister for regeneration: "Faith leaders should press local authorities to make more use of the resources faith communities can offer in regeneration."

Or Tory leader William Hague last November: "I want to denationalise compassion where the state is failing to deliver results. I want to roll back the frontiers of the state so that more work of faith and secular community-based initiatives can flourish. Religious people have as much right to a place in public life as any other citizen in our country."

It is easy to see the political appeal. Religious people are more caring and benevolent, aren't they? Charities operating under their ethos are more likely to inculcate spiritual values and social concern. They have been at it for years too - some since Victorian times. And, if they take things over, it will be one more means of rolling back the state and even, maybe, reducing public expenditure.

Not necessarily, say religious charities and the church people who support them. The idea of being drafted has left them less than ecstatic. "We are in danger of being used as pawns. Christian groups, even those which are sympathetic, need to look carefully at who they are getting into bed with," says Rob Taylor, of the evangelical charity Adullam Homes, which runs centres offering support and accommodation for drug addicts, ex-offenders and others in 33 local authority areas across the Midlands and north of England. It receives £6.5m in public funding.

"I think there is a degree of naivety by the politicians as if giving services over to faith-based groups will prevent some of the things which have happened in local authority care but the standard of professionalism is no easier to achieve.

"I have a suspicion that certain people are looking to do the job on the cheap. Many Christian groups already operate with a minimum of staffing and without employing people on the correct salary levels. If Mr Hague is looking to find £8bn of cuts this might well be attractive to him."

According to Malcolm Davies of Methodist Homes for the Aged: "Our priority is to offer quality provision. That is how we sell ourselves to local authorities. We develop care in a Christian context but we are available to all."

Jim Richards, director of the Roman Catholic diocese of Westminster's Children's Society, has similar fears. "Is it the role of the church to replace the state? You could be tied in to a very tight contract which leaves you little room either for manoeuvre and innovation, or to criticise the authorities," he says.

"We work with families and children of all faiths and none. We don't thump the Bible at them. It is the church's mission to reach out irrespective, not to proselytise. If people have not got a roof over their heads, if they are in extreme distress, you cannot say you have to come to Jesus first."

Churches form an enormous and well-established network supplying education and social care. By long tradition, church schooling is state-supported. Some 1.7m pupils attend the almost 7,000 schools shown in the pie chart. In addition, church groups are prominent in the movement for social housing, hospices and care for the elderly. Much of the help is inside the community. Jewish Care assists some 5,000 people every day. Sikh and Muslim places of worship also serve as social services centres.

Father James McCarthy, who runs a Blackburn organisation working with excluded groups such as drug addicts, believes faith organisations can offer spiritual aid and meet needs that state provision may miss. "The vicarage or presbytery can be a sanctuary when the offices close down. We can be a bridge to get round bureaucratic systems. But we complement, not replace."

Even the largest faith-based charities are puny compared with state provision: National Children's Homes, which is Methodist in origin and one of the biggest, has an annual budget only as large as a single council social services department.

There is a mis-match here between what charities think they are doing and ought to do and the tasks politicians want to impose on them.

Of course, the American experience is not the same as ours. There is no state funding of religious schools in the US, for instance, but a much heavier incidence of church attendance: up to 40% attend church on Sundays (compared with 7% here), 90% say they believe in God, 80% in the afterlife, compared with Britain's 60% who say they have some spiritual belief.

As for whether pushing churches into social services will work, privatisation has not been a happy experience even in the president's home state of Texas. Over 20 years of privatising welfare functions there has not worked and horror stories abound.

webTitle: Internet casinos a cover for crime

fields.headline: Internet casinos a cover for crime
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet casinos are being used as cover by criminal gangs for money laundering operations, according to the Paris-based Financial Action Taskforce (FATF).
fields.body:
Internet casinos are being used as cover by criminal gangs for money laundering operations, according to the Paris-based Financial Action Taskforce (FATF).

The body co-ordinating international efforts to combat money laundering said it had evidence of at least three virtual scams spanning the globe.

It said ease of access, the lack of face to face contact between individuals and the speed of electronic transactions made the internet an ideal vehicle for money laundering.

Lars Oftedal Broch, a supreme court judge in Norway and one of the FATF's key officials, yesterday said: "There's a whole new dimension of anonymity as to who is really behind a computer or telephone on the internet."

To combat crime on the internet, the FATF said it had discussed requiring service providers to maintain reliable subscriber registers with appropriate identification for six months to a year. Experts had also suggested making ISPs keep detailed records of visitors to their sites.

Andrew Clark, the partner in charge of anti-money laundering services at PricewaterhouseCoopers said traditional casinos have long been recognised as vehicles for money launderers.

"You can walk in with wads of cash and buy chips and not even do any gaming and then leave with a cheque," said Mr Clark.

This fulfiled two key criteria for money launderers - the ability to convert the proceeds of crime into a usable asset and distance themselves from the crime. "Internet casino winnings are an allegedly justifiable reason for having wealth," he said.

The first of the three scams identified by the FATF is being investigated by the national police force of a European country. It involves an internet casino located on a server maintained in the Caribbean region.

The police think the casino is run by a company in a European country (country A). "The rules of play for the virtual casino specify that it is possible to make wagers directly simply by providing credit card information," said the FATF.

Customs officials have uncovered movements of funds involving several companies. "Money flows appeared in a bureau de change and a shopping centre in country A, as well as in several companies from the Far East, the Caribbean region, and a neighbouring European country (country B)," said the FATF. "The connections between these various firms still must be determined."

The person in charge of the bureau de change is known to the police for various violations of gaming regulations and another individual was allegedly involved in a bank hold up. "According to the authorities, the virtual casino represents one of the methods for laundering funds derived from criminal activity in country B."

The FATF's second example of criminal activity on the internet involved $178m (£120m) being laundered through a sports tout service, which collected information on sporting events and then sold it to subscribers. It also functioned as an internet service provider.

The FATF said it was common for criminals to use websites to promote fictional gambling companies with names similar to real ones and then exploit the confusion to mask a laundering operation.

fields.headline: Just2Clicks throws in towel
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online trading centre Just2Clicks has put itself up for sale. The company - the first listed business-to-business one - said it was seeking a "major transaction", which could involve a straight sale or the acquisition of an established business.
fields.body:
Online trading centre Just2Clicks has put itself up for sale. The company - the first listed business-to-business one - said it was seeking a "major transaction", which could involve a straight sale or the acquisition of an established business.

Just2clicks has £40m in the bank but is valued on the stock market at £29m. The firm, backed by former Cellnet chairman Sir Michael Bett and entrepreneur Luke Johnson, hit the headlines last year after its flotation turned former European Parliament Labour leader, Alan Donnelly, into a dot.com millionaire. He made a £3m paper profit from an initial investment of £1,250 in seven weeks.

Chief executive Karl Watkin said: "We are looking either for an acquisition where we contribute to the management, where they have a good product and a good business and are running out of cash or a straight sell."

Analysts yesterday said it was more likely the company would be sold.

Tim Feather, corporate finance director at company advisers Brown Shipley, said there had been a number of enquiries. The firm also said it would restructure the business to halve its cash burn from £650,000 a month, by disposing of three of the group's seven subsidiaries -Webfreight, Pulp&Paper.net and Granite Rock.

The four others - Translinx, e-cement, Powernet and Best Value Zonegroup - will focus on markets where volumes are guaranteed or expected in the short term. Shares have dived from a high of 295p in March to a low of 26p in December. Yesterday they added 2.25p to 31p.

Just2clicks is one of the first high profile business-to-business ventures to plunge into trouble. Mr Watkin said it had outperformed some competitors by 400% and had lost only 85% of its value, compared to other businesses losing 95% in the technology sector crash.

"The whole market has been down. I am absolutely convinced that eventually B2B will work, its just a question of when."

fields.headline: Science tracks down cheese frauds
fields.standfirst:
The game could soon be up for fraudsters who trick consumers into thinking they are eating some of the country's favourite cheeses
>Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: New squads of dairy detectives could soon track down fraudsters who fool consumers that they are eating some of Britain's favourite cheeses instead of cheap imitations.
fields.body:
New squads of dairy detectives could soon track down fraudsters who fool consumers that they are eating some of Britain's favourite cheeses instead of cheap imitations.

Tests of the authenticity of famous EU foods are being developed by an international team of scientists who have already trapped German and Dutch companies involved in a cross-border butter scam.

They are investigating a potential cheese conspiracy in Italy and hope soon to be able to refine the techniques to establish whether cheeses labelled as protected products, such as single Gloucester, Buxton blue, or West Country farmhouse cheddar cheeses, really do originate from where the name suggests.

Scientists from Britain, Germany, Austria, France, Spain and Italy have been collecting data on the chemical content of soil in pastures used by dairy herds, and of other aspects of the herds' diets, to establish models against which milk, butter and cheese claiming to come from particular regions can be measured.

The characteristics of the soil in which cattle feed is grown are important since they pass into the diary products.

A three year, £1m research project includes the government's central science laboratory in York, and similar techniques could prove the origins of foods and drinks such as rice, shellfish, meats, wines and beers.

Those who pass off false claims in this country would be liable to £5,000 fines and heavy costs.

The food standards agency said the EU was concerned that fraudsters were charging premium prices for fake products.

"We have to ensure that if consumers are paying a certain price, they are paying for the genuine article and not being conned," a spokesperson said.

The methods, still in their infancy, have already uncovered butter fraud in Europe.

Butter imported by Germany from Estonia was in fact EU-produced butter that had attracted subsidies on the way out and had then been rela belled to take advantage of Estonia's access to EU markets without paying high tariffs.

Tests revealed that the butter had traces of maize, fed to herds in the EU but not to those in Estonia. The German and Dutch companies involved were ordered to pay DM1.4m (£500,000) in import duty.

Tests on more than 100 elements are under way to check that some producers of Italian Alpine cheeses such as Grana Padano and Grana Trentino really are using the appropriate milk and not inferior alternatives from Germany or Austria.

About 130 EU cheeses, nine of them in Britain, have protected status. Genuine suppliers are said to be providing information.

fields.headline: Body blow to close-knit community
fields.standfirst: Llanwern Workers furious at treatment by company
fields.trailText: Llanwern Workers furious at treatment by company
fields.body:
Whispers had started before Christmas, as the men of Llanwern and Ebbw Vale went to buy presents for their families.

By Wednesday night the whispers had grown to clamour and the men were sitting down for tense kitchen table conferences with their wives. The blow finally came on a day of unending fog and drizzle, bringing fury and despair.

Many of the older workers had already taken early retirement packages as the steelworks "slimmed down" in previous years. The employees losing their jobs now are the younger and middle-aged men with young families.

No-one received a redundancy notice yesterday - that will not happen for some months - but everyone was prepared for the worst.

Llanwern worker Kevin Williams, 32, a father of two girls, said: "Corus have been so underhand. They said we'd be the first to know. Most of us found out from watching the news this morning.

"It's a sign of the times. They've got to keep the shareholders happy and they don't seem to care for the working man."

Fellow employee Steve Williams, 39, a father of a 13-year-old boy, said: "The share price went up this morning - what's that supposed to tell us? We've been told we're the most productive steel plant in Europe."

The impact on his family is perhaps the hardest part of this. "My son knows that for the next few months we've got to watch what we're doing and take it as it comes, but it's difficult to tell kids they can't have what they had before."

The trouble is that for the men who toiled in the heat and glare of the forge, turning molten steel into slabs of metal, Llanwern has been a nice earner.

It may have been a semi-skilled job, but it paid better than some trades, with workers typically taking home around £30,000. In this part of South Wales that meant a semi-detached house in a pleasant location, the toys the children wanted and holidays in the sun.

Now they're at the mercy of the marketplace, in an area where male unemployment stands higher than the national average at 4.8%.

Andy, 33, who declined to give his surname said:"We are all out of our jobs in one go. The employers are going to recognise that and start paying less because there's going to be a glut of people."

In its leader comment, the local evening newspaper, the South Wales Argus, declared: "The name of Corus and its chairman Sir Brian Moffat will be for ever tainted in this area ... Corus has shown a callous disregard for its workforce, doing nothing to deny rumours in the media of job losses and plant closures."

Steve Down, councillor for the Llanwern ward with Newport county borough council said: "I live in a village called Underwood that was built specifically to house people when they were starting up the works in the early 60s.

"We exist because of Llanwern. Up until today there has been extreme frustration because nobody knew what was going to happen.

"Today there is anger - people are saying what do we do now?"

Paul Collier, regional official for the AEEU union said: "It is a fairly small community around here and certainly every family will be affected by this."

The day before the axe fell at Corus came the news of the closure of the Unigate Dairy Crest milk processing plant at Newport, with the loss of 275 jobs.

The jobs of 319 workers at Shotton steelworks, near Chester, are also to be axed. The steelworks once employed more than 13,000 people but numbers dramatically reduced in the 1980s, when 8,000 jobs were shed in one day, writes Helen Carter.

Barry Jones, MP for Alyn and Deeside, said: "I have looked into the eyes of young steel workers who have large mortgages, car hire purchase payments to make and school uniforms to buy, who now have no way of paying for these things.

"There is a feeling of intense anger among the workforce.

"These cruel Corus cuts are unacceptable. They are bad for Britain, Wales and the Shotton works."

The move was also condemned by Flintshire county council.

Councillor Derek Butler, the council's member for economic development and tourism, said they were bemused and appalled by Corus's decision, as Shotton was one of the most highly productive plants in Europe.

"The reality is that this latest round of job cuts will affect many more than the 319 job losses identified. Corus employs many contractors at the plant and it is possible that the announcement could affect up to 1,000 people employed directly or indirectly by the company."

fields.headline: Gadafy says Libyan is innocent
fields.standfirst: Leader defies Lockerbie verdict and calls for lifting of sanctions
fields.trailText: The Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, defied the west yesterday by declaring that the Libyan agent convicted of the Lockerbie bombing was innocent and claimed he would produce evidence on Monday to prove it.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Gerard Seenan, Richard Norton-Taylor  and Kirsty Scott
fields.body:
The Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, defied the west yesterday by declaring that the Libyan agent convicted of the Lockerbie bombing was innocent and claimed he would produce evidence on Monday to prove it.

He refused to bow to US and British demands that Libya accept responsibility and pay compensation. In a further show of defiance, Col Gadafy embraced the other Libyan accused of the bombing on his return home yesterday after his acquittal.

The US and Britain, which have refused to support the lifting of UN sanctions against Libya, hope Col Gadafy's reaction is mainly for Libyan public consumption and as the days pass he will adopt a more conciliatory attitude.

A senior Libyan agent, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, was sentenced to life imprisonment on Wednesday for the bombing of the Pan Am flight in 1988. Lawyers at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands, where the trial was held, were yesterday preparing the grounds for an appeal.

His co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, emerged from a Dutch air force plane at Tripoli airport after nearly a year in custody, shaking his fist and shouting, "Allahu akbar" (God is most great).

A crowd of about 100 relatives and friends gathered around him, chanting: "Justice has triumphed! Down with America."

Over the past year Libya has been trying to rejoin the international community and its government sent out confusing signals yesterday. Some of its foreign ministry staff and ambassadors hinted that Libya was willing to agree a deal on paying compensation to the families of the 270 people who died when Flight 103 came down over the Scottish town of Lockerbie, and on accepting responsibility for the blast, two key concessions that Britain and the US say are necessary for lifting sanctions.

But Col Gadafy, in his first public response, told reporters: "I have proven evidence that he [Megrahi] is innocent and I'll reveal the evidence on Monday."

Clutching the arm of Mr Fhimah, the Libyan leader said the verdict at the end of the nine-month trial had been "influenced by the US government, by pressures from the US government".

Contrasting the responses of the international community towards Lockerbie and the US bombing of Tripoli in 1986, he called for the immediate lifting of sanctions.

"We must not forget the victims of the 1986 massacre," he said. "What do courts have to say about these victims? What do the United Nations and America have to say about them? Are these victims human beings or cattle?"

The former South African president Nelson Mandela, who played a vital role in persuading Col Gadafy to hand over the two men, joined many Arab countries, as well as China, in calling for an immediate lifting of sanctions. He accused western leaders of "moving the goalposts".

The 22-member Arab League, based in Cairo, said the UN security council "should immediately take measures to lift the sanctions _ in response to Libya's flexible stance in dealing with the issue".

The British families of the Lockerbie victims also ex pressed sympathy for the call to lift sanctions. At a press conference the relatives said there were still many unanswered questions surrounding the atrocity. They want the west to pursue reconciliation with Libya in the hope it will help a public inquiry establish who ordered the attack.

Jim Swire, spokesman for UK Families Flight 103, said yesterday it would be a mistake to leave Libya out of the international fold. "The course of reconciliation between nations is a better course than that of confrontation," he said, adding:"For many of us it would help to know the identity and motives of those who ordered the murder of our loved ones."

Although a civil action against Libya is pending in the US, the British relatives said compensation was not a paramount issue. They are more concerned with discovering who ordered the bombing.

They want Tony Blair to order a public inquiry to look at airport security, the security warnings received by the British and foreign governments about the possibility of a terrorist attack and, ultimately, who was behind the bombing.

A Foreign Office source said those calling for an inquiry misunderstood its possible scope: it could look at airport security and what intelligence had come in but the issue of who was ultimately responsible was for the courts alone. He added that he had seen all the intelligence reports and there was nothing of significance in them.

In their 84-page ruling, the Scottish judges who sat at Camp Zeist made it clear that Megrahi was acting with others.

Scotland's most senior law officer, the lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, yesterday ruled out the immediate prospect of any further trials.

He said: "The question arises as to whether it might be possible to bring further proceedings against those who are alleged to have been acting along with Megrahi _ my judgment at present is that there is insufficient evidence to justify further proceedings at this time."

webTitle: Five held as police raid 'bomb factory'

fields.headline: Five held as police raid 'bomb factory'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Five men were arrested yesterday in an early morning armed raid on a suspected bomb factory in west London. Two other addresses were also searched.
fields.body:
Five men were arrested yesterday in an early morning armed raid on a suspected bomb factory in west London. Two other addresses were also searched.

Scotland Yard said inquiries were focusing on criminal rather than terrorist activity after three raids and the seizure of explosives.

Officers from the Metropolitan police anti-terrorist branch and firearms unit raided the flat in Sutherland Road, Ealing, just after 7.30am and arrested the five men on suspicion of conspiring to cause explosions, taking them to a central London police station for questioning.

Neighbours were evacuated and fire engines and ambulances called to the scene as officers searched the flat and removed items believed to be pipe bomb components.

Scotland Yard refused to say if material was seized in a related raid at nearby Fosse Way in the afternoon. Residents said they saw officers combing the adjoining grounds of Ealing rugby club with rakes, and questioning builders.

In another related operation, Essex police questioned a man in Southend, but released him without charge. Fifty officers, some armed, later searched a house in the area with a warrant issued under the Explosives Act.

Chief Superintendent Peter Goulding, commander for Ealing, said: "We believe that as a result of the operation we have prevented a potential pipe bomb attack."

There was speculation that the raids were connected to dissident republican activities because the five men are thought to be Irish.

The Ealing flat is near the sites of two terrorist bomb attacks last year and the raids coincided with David Trimble's visit to Downing Street yesterday.

But Scotland Yard said: "At this stage of the investigation there is no evidence to suggest these activities are linked to Irish terrorism or the three terrorist attacks in London last year. We are focusing inquiries on alleged criminal activity."

Suggestions that the arrests were connected with animal rights campaigns are also thought to be unlikely.

The five men were believed to be living in a one bedroom ground floor flat owned by the Ealing Family Housing Association.

Nicole Plosker, a teacher who lives in Sutherland Road, said: "There are always people coming and going, with people moving in and out - it's hard to keep track of who lives there.

"We have had plainclothes police officers hanging around outside before, but we thought they were just dealing with the fights and drinking at the house."

Pipe bombs are crude but lethally effective devices that can be packed with shrapnel or nails to maximise the damage they cause.

They can be made from readily available materials, including fireworks, and instructions are available on many internet sites.

The neo-Nazi David Copeland built them for his attack on the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho and the blasts he set off in Brixton and Brick Lane.

But their use is rare on the British mainland and bombs are not commonly used by criminals, although the Mardi Gras bomber, Edgar Pearce, used explosive devices in his four year extortion campaign against Barclays Bank and Sainsbury's in the 1990s.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: EasyJet agrees Luton deal
fields.body:
EasyJet agrees Luton deal

Discount airline EasyJet said yesterday it had agreed to an interim charging deal with Luton Airport, despite having previously rejected the arrangement.

EasyJet, which floated on the London Stock Exchange in November, rejected an offer from Luton of an unspecified discount to an earlier tariff of £7.89 per departing passenger.

But the group said yesterday it had decided it had "no alternative but to take the prudent approach and pay the discounted-per-passenger charge proposed by Luton Airport for a period of six months"

280 jobs cut at DC Cook

Receivers for car seller DC Cook yesterday said 280 staff had been made redundant since its troubles were highlighted last month.

Accountant Grant Thornton, which is acting as administrative receiver to the Rotherham-based company, said that after a review nine sites had been closed in Derby, Bracknell, Shrewsbury, South Shields, Warrington, Rotherham, Newcastle-under-Lyme, York, and the Fiat franchise in Doncaster.

Stock from these sites is being redeployed, where possible, to sites in Barnsley, Macclesfield, Sheffield, Manchester, Rochdale, the Jaguar franchise in Doncaster and Coventry, which are trading normally.

AstraZeneca signs up IBM

Drugs group AstraZeneca has signed a $1.7bn (£1.15bn) outsourcing agreement with IBM, under which the US technology firm will take charge of its computer infrastructure in 45 countries. Up to 1,200 AstraZeneca staff will transfer to IBM in the seven-year deal, although no redundancies are expected.

Rolls-Royce faces strike

Workers at a Rolls-Royce engineering factory are to stage a one-day strike over jobs next week after talks "collapsed" yesterday.

The walkout will hit the Ansty plant, near Coventry, next Friday in protest at plans to cut jobs and transfer some work to Canada.

The Manufacturing Science and Finance union said that workers were being forced to take industrial action.

The strike will be the first at the plant in more than 20 years.

Imagination issues warning

Chip designer Imagination Technologies yesterday issued a profits warning after analysts predicted scrapping of Sega's Dreamcast games console could cut a quarter off turnover next year.

The Hertfordshire company makes graphics chips for the Sega console. It conceded that earnings had already begun to fall short of market expectations and would continue to do so into 2002.

Shares in Imagination fell 69.5p to close at 160p.

EC to examine gas link

The European commission yesterday agreed to look into the price of gas in the UK after the secretary of state for trade and industry, Stephen Byers, demanded an inquiry into the running of the pipeline between Belgium and Britain.

fields.headline: Genome drives up drug costs
fields.trailText: The completion of the Human Genome Project could herald a period of drastic belt-tightening for the drugs industry, as companies struggle to meet soaring bills for new technology, according to the US bank Lehman Brothers.
fields.body:
The completion of the Human Genome Project could herald a period of drastic belt-tightening for the drugs industry, as companies struggle to meet soaring bills for new technology, according to the US bank Lehman Brothers.

Lehman believes pharmaceuticals firms are heading for a profits slowdown until 2005, when the benefits of genomics research, and the recent mapping of the human genetic make-up, will finally emerge.

The bank asked management consultancy McKinsey to interview hundreds of executives from leading drugs companies. It concluded that there were growing fears about the cost of investigating the thousands of new potential medicines thrown up by genome maps.

Lehman's analysis shows that the "net present value" - or average benefit - in investigating a new drug was likely to fall from $263m (£178m) to $34m. It adds: "A slight but reasonable change in our analysis can actually give a negative value to these programs, suggesting that the industry could go bankrupt by trying to innovate."

In 1995, the average drugs firm worked on 50 new drugs a year, of which only a handful reached the market. Lehman reckons that this is set to rise to 200 a year, of which 70% are "unprecedented", or completely new classes of medicine. These unprecedented projects are more likely to flop in late, rather than early, clinical trials - by which point they will have cost many millions of pounds to develop.

Lehman Brothers analyst Jo Walton said: "We're going to find that as products associated with genomics go into the clinic they have higher failure rates. But the inflection point will come in 2005 - beyond then knowledge of new technology will be such that we'd be likely to see more success."

Figures from Lehman suggest that to support their current valuations, British firms AstraZeneca and Glaxo SmithKline must grow by 18% annually between 2005 and 2015.

webTitle: Business: BT loses battle with Oftel

fields.headline: Oftel keeps cap on BT
fields.trailText: British Telecom lost another battle with Oftel yesterday when the regulator said it would continue in effect to reduce prices the company charges for phone calls.
fields.body:
British Telecom lost another battle with Oftel yesterday when the regulator said it would continue in effect to reduce prices the company charges for phone calls.

David Edmonds, head of Oftel, said BT was still "profiting excessively" from its residential phone business, and extended by one year price controls that should have expired in August 2001. Oftel also reduced the prices BT charges competing telecoms companies for using its network.

"Oftel's price controls will protect consumers while competition continues to develop," Mr Edmonds said. "Once competition is effective, Oftel can withdraw from controlling BT's prices."

Rival company One.Tel, part-owned by Rupert Murdoch, said Oftel was acting in the best interest of the market. "We welcome competition of all kinds," said Bradley Keeling, joint managing director. "One of the greatest opportunities for companies like One.Tel is where the regulator steps in and determines the pace of regulation."

The price controls were welcomed by consumer groups, which were unimpressed by some rivals' complaint that if BT is forced to lower prices, new companies will have greater difficulty undercutting it.

"We've heard from other companies that they would like price regulation to be relaxed," said Linda Lennard, senior policy officer of the National Consumer Council. "The implication is that consumers would be paying for competition, which rather defeats the purpose. We want the end result to be lower prices, not higher prices."

BT had lobbied Oftel to allow the operator to set its prices under open market conditions from August. A company spokesman said the restriction, setting changes in phone charges at 4.5% below the retail price index, will be "difficult, but achievable."

BT is already under pressure from shareholders to reduce its £30bn debt, which execu tives will have to deal with before its third-quarter earnings announcement on February 8.

"We feel that there is sufficient competition in the market and that it was time to get rid of the control altogether," a BT spokesman said. "BT on most counts rates very favourably. We are pretty cheap already."

This week, a well-timed, BT-sponsored study carried out by consultancy Deloitte and Touche found that BT was cheaper by 24% than all other UK telecoms operators.

One analyst said price controls, which Oftel says will cost BT £270m over the next year, was insignificant compared to the debt overhang.
