fields.headline: Deutsche's City staff celebrate
fields.trailText: Thousands of City-based investment bankers, traders and analysts at Deutsche Bank were celebrating bumper bonuses last night after making their best ever profits for their German parent.
fields.body:
Thousands of City-based investment bankers, traders and analysts at Deutsche Bank were celebrating bumper bonuses last night after making their best ever profits for their German parent.

The investment bank, just one division of the Frankfurt-based institution, made £2.5bn of profits in 2000, a 79% rise on the previous year.

Celebrations were tainted by a reorganisation of the bank which will involve 2,600 job cuts, the majority in Germany. About 600 jobs are expected to be lost in the City, where Deutsche employs almost 11,000 people, and the losses will be felt in the back offices rather than the front line.

City sources calculated that the figures from Deutsche Bank showed it was one of the most profitable investment banking operations last year. It also reflects a dramatic improvement in its fortunes since taking over merchant bank Morgan Grenfell five years ago and Bankers Trust of the United States two years ago.

The results also counter allegations that Deutsche Bank had lost its way after its embarrassing failure to merge with local rival Dresdner.

The investment bank now makes 60% of Deutsche Bank's profits before tax, and under the restructuring an nounced yesterday will be encouraged to work more closely with other areas of the group, such as asset management.

Rolf Breuer, the chairman of Deutsche who is stepping down next year, said: "In the past few years we have expanded our capital markets business strongly ... and substantially increased our revenues. With the new structure, we shall trigger corresponding growth in business with private clients and asset management."

The bank yesterday reorganised along two business lines: corporate and investment banking, and private clients and asset management.

Overall the German bank made a record pre-tax profit of £4bn, helped by a quadrupling of profits in the retail and private banking operation.

webTitle: Business:Anglo-American propse $16bn takeover of De Beers

fields.headline: $16bn bid for De Beers
fields.standfirst: Oppenheimers and Anglo American aim to corner diamond market
fields.trailText: Anglo American, the mining company, yesterday signalled its desire to seize greater control of the world diamond market by proposing a $16bn (£10.8b) takeover of De Beers, the world's biggest miner and distributor.
fields.body:
Anglo American, the mining company, yesterday signalled its desire to seize greater control of the world diamond market by proposing a $16bn (£10.8b) takeover of De Beers, the world's biggest miner and distributor.

If talks are successful a consortium led by Anglo and the wealthy Oppenheimer family would take private the diamond group established in 1888 by merchant adventurer Cecil Rhodes.

It would allow Anglo and De Beers to untangle a network of cross holdings but would be a bitter blow to the Johannesburg stock exchange already hit by a number of high-profile defections to London.

Shares in De Beers, whose diamonds were recently at the centre of a daring but failed Millenium Dome robbery, surged 17% to a record 300 rand (£26) in Johannesburg, while Anglo rose 172p to £43.25 in London where it was listed in 1999.

The Oppenheimers, who bailed out De Beers during the 1920s depression, and Anglo are talking about an offer of around $40 per share for De Beers Consolidated Mines and De Beers Centenary depositary receipts.

They already hold 40% of De Beers, while the rest is controlled by a wide grouping of South African investors.

Nicky Oppenheimer, son of the late Harry Oppenheimer, is chairman of De Beers and non-executive deputy chairman of Anglo. His family holds a 2% stake in De Beers and 8% of Anglo.

The consortium talking to De Beers is made up 45% by the Oppenheimer family's holding firm Central Holdings, 45% by Anglo with the remaining 10% being held by Debswana, De Beers joint venture with the Botswana government.

fields.headline: Rules create unnecessary steel curtain
fields.standfirst: Cuts victims kept cruelly in dark
fields.trailText: Cuts victims kept cruelly in dark
fields.body:
That innocent sweetie Alastair Campbell, the Downing Street spokesman, was huffing and puffing this week over the apparent rudeness of Corus boss Sir Brian Moffat. "It's a pretty extraordinary state of affairs where, as the government, if you were to ask us when is this decision [to sack umpteen steel workers] going to be announced we would say we don't know," he stated, angrily.

Setting aside the pain and perversity of the Corus announcement (if the company was planning to cut British steel production it would have made more sense to do it when the euro was going down rather than up), it should be pointed out that Sir Brian's silence on the timing of the announcement was dictated by City legislation. This states, in the harshest terms, that any price-sensitive announcement by a publicly listed company has to be first broadcast formally to the City community, so its members can make decisions on whether to buy or sell the shares.

The rules are designed to create a so-called level playing field among investors, even though such a financial pitch does not, and never will, exist.

"Real" price-shifting information - such as takeover plans, rights issues or better than expected trading figures - tends to leak in advance. Job cuts, such as those being imposed by Corus, are also routinely predicted by analysts or commentators covering particular business sectors.

Yet the legislative culture dictates that, when it comes to formal announcements, corporate - not Whitehall - bureaucrats rule the roost.

It is a crass system. The regulations should be amended to allow all companies the freedom to deal with the human pain of sacking people without having to worry about esoteric danger of creating a false market in their stock.

Shell shock

At the height of the dot.com boom, the Just2Clicks flotation story had it all.

First there was the board. On a non-executive level alone it boasted a former director of a blue-chip technology firm, a professional investor whom punters watched like a hawk for signs of where the next big killing was coming from and a high-profile member for the European parliament who three months after quitting as a euro-public servant found himself sitting on a multi-million pound paper fortune.

Then there was the chief executive - a fast-talking, thoroughly engaging and successful businessman who had become something of a local hero in his native north-east.

Finally there was a business model which, with both pre-sight and hindsight, amounted to little more than new-economy e-guff.

Two days after Valentines Day last year Just2Clicks shares went on sale to a love-struck public, almost doubling on their first day's trading. A year on, the affair is well and truly over; the tale of the £200m company turned out to be lacking a chapter or two. Revenue was thin on the ground, there were no profits and no sign of a dividend.

Just2Clicks now has cash in the bank but little idea how to spend it. Its management now suggest the business might be best described as a "cash shell". Did they every believe it was anything else?

Carat and stick

The $16bn takeover of De Beers planned by Anglo-American and the mega-rich Oppenheimer family was welcomed yesterday by City analysts and investors.

The diamond cartel has long been shunned by investors. They did not like the complex cross-shareholdings with Anglo-American, or its South African listing. The net result has been a stock market valuation that vastly underrates the true value of the company, which still controls 60% of the world market in uncut diamonds.

The De Beers/Anglo move comes in the wake of similar action taken by blue-chip groups such as South African Breweries, mining group Billiton, insurer Old Mutual and software group Dimension Data, which have all transferred their primary listings away from Johannesburg.

Under the terms of the deal proposed - which analysts reckon is generous - the cross-shareholdings will be unravelled and De Beers will almost be a normal company.

If investors want a slice of De Beers, which following a deal with LVMH last month will include a new, joint-venture, luxury goods business to cash in on the famous name as well as exposure to the uncut diamond market, they will simply have to invest in Anglo-American on the London Stock Exchange.

The only downside is that they won't be able to punt on diamonds alone - but will have to take a stake in the rest of Anglo-American's decidedly unglamorous assortment of businesses, which include coal mining and Tarmac.

fields.headline: Official - penguins don't topple over
fields.trailText: Good news for king penguins: the Royal Navy mission sent to Antarctica to investigate whether they fall on their backs when aircraft pass overhead has completed its rigorous experiments.
fields.body:
Good news for king penguins: the Royal Navy mission sent to Antarctica to investigate whether they fall on their backs when aircraft pass overhead has completed its rigorous experiments.

For five weeks scientists filmed the earthbound birds' reactions as they peered up at Lynx helicopters from HMS Endurance criss-crossing the skies above the island of South Georgia at heights of between 1,500ft and 6,000ft.

Would the unbalanced penguins, as veteran Falklands war pilots claimed, be so mesmerised that they would swivel round, craning their necks and topple over? Sadly, for those attached to the popular myth, king penguins are more level-headed than was previously assumed.

"We saw birds moving away from the noise," said Dr Richard Stone, of the British Antarctic Survey. "Not a single bird fell over after 17 flights. As it [the helicopter] approached, the birds went quiet. They didn't appear to turn around and look."

He did notice some penguins waddling away from the helicopters. Others became quiet, but a few minutes later, they waddled back. "We don't know if it's the noise or the visual aspect - whether it looks like a potential predator," Dr Stone said.

His findings are a relief for countries which operate aircraft in the southern Atlantic and Antarctica: they are less likely now to come under pressure from environmentalists to change flight patterns. King penguins, the second biggest penguin in the world, weigh 35kg and are about a metre tall.

The survey may not convince pilots who served in the South Atlantic in 1982, who first claimed to have seen the phenomenon, nicknamed "penguin topple". Stuart Matthews, an operations officer on board Endurance, said last year: "The penguins always look up at the helicopters flying over and follow them all the way until they fall over backwards."

The survey team is planning a second set of experiments using fixed-wing aircraft.

webTitle: Number of trains passing red signals increases

fields.headline: Number of trains passing red signals increases
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Paddington train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
More about transport
fields.trailText: The number of railway signals passed at red is increasing only 15 months after the Paddington crash - caused by the failure of a driver to see the red light on signal 109 - official figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The number of railway signals passed at red is increasing only 15 months after the Paddington crash - caused by the failure of a driver to see the red light on signal 109 - official figures revealed yesterday.

The health and safety executive reported 29 instances of trains passing signals at danger in December last year, six more than December 1999.

Eleven of these were regarded as serious, and in three cases trains ran past danger signals by more than 200 yards. One of the incidents occurred at signal 107, a neighbour of signal 109.

Signal 107 was passed by 20 yards by a train operated by Thames, the company whose train went through signal 109 in the Paddington accident.

The HSE said that although the December figure showed an increase, it was only 72% of the average figure for December over the past six years. Last year 482 signals were passed at danger, a 22% drop on the 1999 total of 618.

The figures showed that during December one incident led to track damage, and 11 others occurred where there was a history of signals passed at danger. In seven instances it was not the first time the driver had passed the signal at red.

The HSE said that the number of instances of trains leaving station platforms although the signals were against them was disappointing.

The HSE also announced yesterday that passengers will be able to travel for the first time at 125mph in sprinter-style trains pulled by powered coaches without the need for locomotives.

It said the trains, operated by First Great Western between London, the west country and south Wales, would be introduced in the summer.

Clive Burrows, the company's director of engineering, said that it had been working closely with the designers and manufacturers for the past three years to ensure that the trains incorporated the best features of train protection and design.

A strong bulwark has been designed on the leading coach which separates the driver from the passengers. FGW said yesterday that the passengers would be protected "within a strong safety cage which will improve the crash worthiness of the carriage".

According to GWT, safety features include an improved braking performance. The trains will be equipped with an automatic train protection system which prevents trains passing through signals at danger.

fields.headline: Life after death
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
With two graves to look after in our churchyard, I frequently enjoy wandering on God's acre. Too often churchyards are tidied and pruned and mown too frequently; burial grounds should not resemble gardens. Lichen grows on my parents' tombstones and I leave it.

Of nearly 1,800 species of lichens in Britain, 300 of these are only found in churchyards, and some cemeteries boast yew trees which are centuries old. An overgrown churchyard is not disrespectful; the idea is to keep it tidy and enjoy the natives, the birds and wild creatures, the trees and wild flowers - should you have any left.

Trees are of greatest value, particularly oak, ash, birch, holly, rowan, yew, field maple and wild cherry. A church yard is often the last refuge for cowslips and early purple orchids in the parish. Moles have to be discouraged, but even those can be tolerated within reason. Several churches I visited have introduced bird boxes to tempt avian residents.

The parish church is the heart of a community, the true cathedral of locality - or it should be. Sadly, this year to date we have only two weddings booked in our lovely Norman church of St Mary Magdalene in Whalton and both of those are churchwardens' children.

Our churches have been, for hundreds of years, our Christian stately homes. Too many are under-occupied, overtaxed, vulnerable to decay and a strain on their custodians. As part of our millennium celebrations in the year 2000, every household in our village was given a disposable camera to record images of what this small community means to them. Sections of these photos have now been used by a graphic artist to produce a stunning montage of Jesus Christ.

webTitle: Fears for teenager who swallowed drug

fields.headline: Fears for teenager who swallowed drug
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A boy aged 16 has been told by doctors he could die at any moment, after he swallowed £400 worth of heroin to avoid being caught by police.
fields.body:
A boy aged 16 has been told by doctors he could die at any moment, after he swallowed £400 worth of heroin to avoid being caught by police.

The unnamed teenager was spotted by officers who were targeting drug dealers on a housing estate in Nottingham. He has so far spent five days in hospital, where medical staff say they are waiting for heroin in cling film "wraps" to pass through his body.

Inspector Dave Shardlow, who runs the police operation in The Meadows area of the city, said his officers had been patrolling on mountain bikes when they "saw this lad in circumstances which were suspicious and went to talk to him. But he started to choke and they realised he had swallowed something."

Two wraps - street deals of heroin - were found in the boy's pockets, and in hospital he admitted having stuffed between 30 and 40 wraps into his mouth.

The teenager, who is known to police for being involved in drugs, was under police guard yesterday at Queen's medical centre in Nottingham.

An accident and emergency specialist, Paul Temple, said: "If just one package breaks or leaks you will initially get the best trip of your life, but that can rapidly turn to death."

Mr Shardlow added: "We will stay at his bedside until the drugs are recovered or he dies."

He said the boy had been arrested on suspicion of possessing Class A drugs, but officers might have to wait as long as 10 days to take the case further.
Press Association

webTitle: Bombings fear as device left at pub

fields.headline: Bombings fear as device left at pub
fields.standfirst: Bomb found in pub car park has prompted fears of further vigilanty attacks by animal rights activists
fields.trailText: An unexploded bomb found in a plastic bag in a pub car park has prompted fears of a further escalation in attacks by animal rights activists.
fields.body:
An unexploded bomb found in a plastic bag in a pub car park has prompted fears of a further escalation in attacks by animal rights activists.

Bomb disposal experts were called to the Wellington pub in Salford, Greater Manchester, on Wednesday evening after the landlord found a white plastic bag containing what he said looked like wires, a clock and plastic tubing.

The bag had been placed on the ground beneath a red Ford Orion abandoned three days earlier. Police are trying to trace the owner of the car.

A controlled explosion was carried out. No one was injured. Nearby houses were evacuated and Regent Road was closed for 10 hours while forensic experts examined the scene.

It was the fourth time in three days that police had been called to deal with both exploded and unexploded devices. On Tuesday a charity volunteer escaped injury when a nail bomb went off as she opened the morning post at a British Heart Foundation shop in Penrith, Cumbria.

Two devices were defused on Monday. One of the packages was sent by post to agricultural suppliers on the outskirts of Sheffield. The second was sent to a Cancer Research Campaign shop in Lancashire.

Ten nail bombs have been sent through the post to businesses across the north of England and the west midlands since December last year. Recipients include a chip shop, an estate agent, a pet shop and a farmer in Ripon, North Yorkshire.

The number of incidents in volving suspect packages have been increasing despite the home secretary, Jack Straw, declaring a crackdown on extreme animal rights activists.

Earlier this week a judge in Peterborough sentenced a prominent animal rights activist, Charlotte Lewis, to six months in jail after she admitted sending threatening letters to employees of the animal research company Huntingdon Life Sciences.

In parliament on Wednesday the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Taverne asked the junior home office minister, Lord Bassam, if the government agreed that some of the actions of animal rights groups were among "the most dangerous forms of terrorism in the UK at the moment".

Lord Bassam told the Lords: "It is an appalling form of terrorism and the home secretary raised the issue in the criminal justice and police bill."

The proposed legislation has failed to halt the pace of attacks. No group has claimed responsibility for any of the recent attacks.

Greater Manchester police said yesterday that they had so far made no connection between the Salford device and the nail bomb attacks. A spokesman said they were awaiting the results of forensic tests. The device is the first in the latest series of attacks not to be sent through the post.

Sussex and Surrey police are also investigating a number of car bomb attacks against individuals connected with the hunting fraternity. They believe the devices were placed by anti-hunt protesters but say that so far they have not established a connection with the Salford device.

Lord Bassam told the Lords: "It is an appalling form of terrorism and the home secretary raised the issue in the criminal justice and police bill." The proposed legislation has failed to halt the pace of attacks. No group has claimed responsibility for any of the recent attacks. Greater Manchester police said yesterday that they had so far made no connection between the Salford device and the nail bomb attacks. A spokesman said they were awaiting the results of forensic tests. The device is the first in the latest series of attacks not to be sent through the post. Sussex and Surrey police are also investigating a number of car bomb attacks against individuals connected with the hunting fraternity. They believe the devices were placed by anti-hunt protesters but say that so far they have not established a connection with the Salford device.

webTitle: Alarm at rise in women's drinking

fields.headline: Alarm at rise in women's drinking
fields.standfirst: Increase in liver disease prompts call for government action to reduce consumption of alcohol
fields.trailText: Doctors worried by an apparent rise in chronic liver disease among young women called on the government yesterday to consider sweeping measures to cut alcohol consumption, including advertising curbs, higher taxes and restrictions on liquor licences.
fields.body:
Doctors worried by an apparent rise in chronic liver disease among young women called on the government yesterday to consider sweeping measures to cut alcohol consumption, including advertising curbs, higher taxes and restrictions on liquor licences.

Specialists said they were seeing more cases of cirrhosis among women in their 20s, fuelling fears that the spread of the wine bar after-work drinking culture and sophisticated advertising were blurring the gender differences that once saw only men boasting of their alcoholic excesses.

A study by the Royal College of Physicians suggested that alcohol abuse was costing hospitals between £500m and £3bn a year, up to 12% of their budgets, to treat drink related health problems. Campaigners estimated another £3bn cost to society in absenteeism, uenemployment, crime, accidents and premature deaths.

The doctors were worried that 15% of men and 27% of women were drinking more than recommended weekly amounts. They said the problem merited high profile campaigns such as those against smoking and drug taking.

Liver problems that once were rarely seen in women under 40 were now evident in those 15 years younger. Chris Day, professor of liver medicine in Newcastle upon Tyne, said women were once thought to minimise calculations of what they drank or keep it private. "Now they seem quite happy to drink as heavily as men and might even be proud of it."

Advertising controls require companies not to suggest that alcohol enhances femininity or that drinking is an essential attribute of masculinity. But Prof Day pointed out that one of the most popular advertisements, for Guinness, had "a half-naked man on waves with white horses on them". Advertising was "aimed at making people look more attractive when drinking alcohol".

The doctors compared the total cost of hospital services in 1997, £23.4bn, with the £29bn consumers spent on alcohol. They acknowledged the problems in reducing numbers of heavy drinkers: social acceptance of alcohol, growing evidence that some consumption reduces risks of vascular disease in middle and old age, and the importance of the industry to employment and tax revenues.

John Kemm, consultant in public health medicine for the NHS in the West Midlands, said: "We need to be more aware that alcohol is a dangerous drug. Although it has good effects, we need to be careful about how we handle it. We need to be thinking of ways of putting downward pressure on its consumption."

The report called for more hospitals to have specialist nurses who could help to question all patients about their drinking habits so they could be offered preventive advice. Prof Day said doctors at present regarded alcoholics as "a bad bunch and don't want anything to do with them".

Drink industry bodies yesterday insisted that advertising was more about creating brand awareness than promoting alcohol consumption. The Advertising Association, which advises the companies, said promotional spending on beer, wines and spirits had risen by 125% in real terms since 1980, while overall consumption had fallen by 10%. The Brewers and Licensed Retailers' Association said the industry provided £11.5bn a year in duty and VAT.

Eric Appleby, director of Alcohol Concern, said the doctors' verdict was "further proof that the government needs to look at the full health, economic and social effects of alcohol misuse and devise a concerted startegy to tackle the problem. At the moment different departments have responsibility for different aspects of policy, with the NHS generally dealing with the symptoms of inaction."

The Department of Health, whose policy against alcohol abuse has been long delayed, put the cost to the NHS at just over £200m a year, disputing the doctors' suggestion that it was as much as £3bn.

Sales pitches

Bacardi Breezer Available in brightly coloured varieties, this mixture of Bacardi, fruit juice and sparkling water is aimed at the 18-35 age group. The adverts feature men and women equally. One of the most successful campaigns was called "tart", in which a young girl takes tea with her prospective in-laws. The fast moving advert is full of innuendo, with flashbacks to a carnival and a nightclub. Accompanied by the slogan, There's Latin Spirit in Every One

Tia Maria A drink once associated with your parents' drinks cabinet, its image has been updated to a sexy tipple for an independent woman. The adverts, aimed at women aged 18-34, have featured strikingly attractive females dominating males in some way. The most recent shows a man being taken over by a mysterious force coming to the aid of a woman unable to get the lid off a jar of gherkins. The adverts give the brand a female personality and a dark edge with the slogan Princess of Darkness

Baileys Among carefree, young, attractive men and women in a noisy bar, the latest advert shows a woman miming the drink she would like in a sexy manner while joking with friends. It is intended to appeal to both sexes

webTitle: Soldier who promoted women in army gone AWOL

fields.headline: Showcase woman soldier goes AWOL
fields.standfirst: Woman soldier gone absent without leave
fields.trailText: A soldier whose picture has been used to promote the role of women in the army has gone absent without leave, the Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
A soldier whose picture has been used to promote the role of women in the army has gone absent without leave, the Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday.

Lance Bombardier Heidi Cochrane of the Royal Artillery has not contacted the army or her family since disappearing from Cyprus last July. The married 24-year-old, who had just been promoted, went missing at the same time as a male sergeant also serving on the island.

"We haven't a clue where she is", said an MoD spokesman. "We want her back". The ministry would not say what punishment she faced if she surrendered for fear she might be scared off.

Last week a picture of Lance Bombardier Cochrane in combat gear appeared in the Daily Telegraph to illustrate a story on the role of women in the army.

Her father, Chris Martin, who runs the Crab Apple Tree pub in Clevedon, Somerset, said yesterday he had not heard from his daughter, who is married to an army gunner. "Heidi always wanted to be in the army and she was really happy just before she went missing", he said.

A soldier in her regiment has said she had carefully packed her clothes and equipment before she left. She is said to have sent text messages from her mobile phone to friends, telling them she is in Sri Lanka. One message allegedly read: "Come and get me if you can be bothered".

Lance Bombardier Cochrane was attached to the United Nations force patrolling the border with Turkish-occupied Cyprus.

Army regulations give army commanders a wide degree of descretion on personnel going AWOL.

Those found guilty could face "administrative action" by the commander or a court martial.

They could also face a period in custody at the army's correctional training centre at Colchester, Essex, followed by a discharge.

There are about 380 personnel absent without leave across the three services, the ministry said.

The missing lance bombardier has undergone a tough physical training course, including all-night exercises, and was also taught tactical planning - how to avoid detection by the enemy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Prince joins star complainers
Prince William will next week be partying with stars who share with him a problem in their private lives - unwanted press intrusion. He will join the Prince of Wales at the press complaints commission's 10th birthday party next Wednesday at Somerset House in central London.

Airlifted baby 'stable'
A day-old baby airlifted to hospital in Glasgow for life-saving specialist surgery was yesterday "stable and improving". Aine Russell, of County Tyrone, who has severe heart and lung problems, was flown from Belfast airport by a Royal Navy helicopter.

Royal magazine seller jailed
A magazine seller who persuaded the Prince of Wales to buy a copy of the Big Issue during a royal visit was yesterday jailed for three years for dealing in heroin. Karl Grierson, 24, of Peterborough, was imprisoned less than a year after he broke royal protocol by approaching Charles when the prince was visiting the city and offering him the magazine.

Fireman's 999 vehicle alert
A firefighter has invented a device that gives out a message over car radios to let drivers know a 999 vehicle is approaching. The Warn-Tone interrupts the radio, cassettes and CDs when an emergency vehicle is within 100 metres. Jim Hutchinson, 37, of Milton Keynes, has patented the idea.

Lower speed limits call
Lower speed limits need to be introduced in deprived areas if the number of children killed on Britain's roads is to be reduced, the Institute for Public Policy Research said yesterday. It said child pedestrians from deprived backgrounds were five times more likely to die on the roads than those from better-off areas. It wants 20mph limits in all inner city residential areas.

Hain's mining payouts pledge
The energy minister, Peter Hain, yesterday pledged there would be no more "buck passing" to explain away delays in paying compensation to former miners and their widows, and said the government would "deliver justice as quickly as we can". Some miners are seriously ill with chest diseases or vibration white finger and have been waiting years to get compensation.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Week of an emergencies officer

fields.headline: 'It looks like a nuclear strike'
fields.standfirst: Dominic Nutt - emergencies officer, Christian Aid, Bhuj
fields.trailText: Dominic Nutt - emergencies officer, Christian Aid, Bhuj.
fields.body:
Since I arrived in Bombay I've had six hours sleep. I've been sleeping rough and getting up at six in the morning. Last night we slept at a nunnery in the open under some tarpaulin. We were given a bowl of rice and dahl. I had only had a slice of bread that day. There is no food to be had.

It was a surreal scene. The aid workers were sleeping under the stars, the nuns were chanting hail Marys, and children were wandering around, one-legged, no-legged, blind. Satellite phones were going off all night. There was the occasional tremor and people scurrying away into the night. There is a typical kind of gallows humour you'd expect to find in this situation. We're all bantering away.

On Sunday and Monday, I visited the Bhuj district. The only way I can describe it is a vast swathe of land that looks like a nuclear strike has hit. It's 100% devastation - masses of concrete. I saw a town with nothing standing. There used to be 9,000 people in it, but it was reduced to rubble and only 2,500 survived. They were still dragging out bodies by hand.

Villages beyond Bhuj, right on the Pakistani border, are without any official aid. On Tuesday we visited a village 10 kms away from the earthquake's epicentre. The only people getting through were Christian Aid and their local Indian partners. People only survive because of our aid handouts. It's keeping them alive.

My job is to assess the situation and report what is needed, as well as keeping media groups for all the agencies informed about the situation. I'm constantly negotiating. One minute you're talking to Clare Short's bunch, then other aid workers, then scrabbling among the rubble.

I worked in Arissa for the floods and was traumatised, but no one's ever seen anything like this. There is no wide angle lens or satellite big enough to take it all in. The only way to deal with it is treading over the bricks one by one and talking to the people one by one. It's very hard to exaggerate the situation.

Today I was in a town that had been wiped out and looked like a building site. I saw one person coming out from under the rubble alive. He was followed by grotesquely twisted bodies that were thrown on to the funeral pyres that burn constantly like beacons. The smell of death was heavy in the air; it's humid and gut-wrenching.

The idea of offering comfort is madness. People just sit quietly on their haunches in the rubble. Some people talk and tell us what their needs are, but there is nothing we can say.

fields.headline: The one that got away
fields.trailText: Horizon | The Riddle Of Pompeii
fields.body:
The folks at Horizon (BBC2) are trying way too hard to live up to the tagline "Pure science. Sheer drama". There's no other explanation for the hyperbole, melodrama and downright daftness featured in The Missing Link. While you or I would simply describe it as the story of how fish evolved into land-dwelling creatures, Horizon's narrator gushes dramatically, "Of all the tales of life on earth, one is more fabulous than the others. The story of how we got our legs!"

Really, though? Is it the most fabulous of all stories? Isn't How Life Began At The Very Beginning the most fabulous story? Shouldn't How Richard Blackwood Continues To Be Mistaken For Someone Talented be regarded as a more fabulous - not to mention perplexing - tale? And besides, didn't they say that last week? Or maybe that was the week before. Apparently not.

Here was a 360-million-year-old detective story, the quest for the ultimate missing link, a mystery which, if solved, would prove Darwin's theory of evolution: how fish grew legs. DA DA DAAA! Hence Horizon had toddlers, ballet dancers and lizards all moving to a soundtrack of portentous kettle drums and bracing cymbals. It had the Nordic Dr Per eyeing up old fossils. It had jolly scientists proclaiming, "We are modified fish!" (He himself looked like a modified cod.) And, on her motorbike, it had "palaeontology's avenging angel" coming to save the day by saying things like "We have to go to Greenland!"

There were more exclamation marks in Horizon than at an Ann Summers party in a convent. All the fuss was about finding a "transitional form" which could link fish with the first tetrapods. Tetrapods aren't types of orange juice cartons but air-breathing creatures with spines and spurs, pelvises, ribcages and fingers. "Every dog and cat and mammal," Dr Cod helpfully explained, just in case we hadn't quite got the message. Find this transitional form and the mystery would be solved. Fail and let the creationists win, and "we'd descend into another Dark Age". (I told you they were melodramatic.)

So the hunt was on for a fossil of a half-fish, half-tetrapod mutant. Naturally, it wasn't easy. Such creatures are hard to find as they all died out quite quickly when they were superseded by whatever higher life form they were transitional to. A dinosaur with feathers (Shirley Bassey) marking the lizards' transition to birds had been found, but a fish with legs proved more elusive.

Eric Jarvik seemed to have found one though. He was tall, dour and "the least loved figure in all palaeontology" - imagine the competition for that accolade. He took 48 years to analyse his fossil and came to the conclusion that he'd found the missing link. Unfortunately, he got the analysis wrong but didn't tell anyone. "We'll never know why!" boomed Mr Narrator.

Eventually, after much humming and hawing and rewriting of textbooks, Dr Per found the answer. Sifting through a selection of drawers that hadn't been examined in 30 years he discovered the missing link in a Latvian museum. We evolved legs - pause for dramatic effect - to cope with the vegetation-strewn swamps millions of years ago, Horizon concluded. Phew. The kettle drums and cymbals can be packed away, because the most fabulous of all the tales of life on earth had been resolved.

Until a new one pops up next week.

The Riddle Of Pompeii (Channel 4) ploughed a similar furrow. The programme asked what had killed the people of the Roman town in AD79. Technically, you'd be correct with "a volcano", so, like Anne Robinson on The Weakest Link, "I'll accept your answer" (because it's right). Of course, with an hour to fill, the whole Vesuvius thing was a tad more complicated for this cheapo documentary, in which the poor old male narrator had to voice the translations himself, even when it was a woman speaking.

The Riddle Of Pompeii was rather like watching the titles of Hong Kong Phooey. Was it the pumice raining from the sky? Could be. Was it poisonous gas? Could be. Was it the switchboard operator Rosemary, the cutie beauty who's always on duty? Could be.

In the end it was none of the above, but a cloud of red-hot ash and dust travelling at 300mph which seared the Pompeiians' skin, burnt inside their mouths and noses, and left them to die an excruciating death.

The volcano, then.

fields.headline: All-woman court to make history
fields.trailText: The court of appeal is scheduled to make legal history this month when an all-woman court sits.
fields.body:
The court of appeal is scheduled to make legal history this month when an all-woman court sits.

England's most senior female judge, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, is to sit for the week beginning February 12 with Lady Justice Hale and Lady Justice Arden.

They are the only women judges so far to reach the court of appeal, which has 33 male judges. A three-woman bench became possible only last summer, when Dame Mary Arden was promoted from the high court. Officials pointed out that the sittings list, out this week, could be reshuffled up to the day before a hearing.

Unlike the US, Canada and New Zealand, Britain has no woman judge in the highest court, the House of Lords, where all 12 judges are men. Canada has had a woman in its highest court since 1982.

So male dominated is England's senior judiciary that the Supreme Court Act 1981 lays down that appeal court judges are styled "Lords Justices of Appeal".

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Heidi Cochrane

fields.headline: No: 1811
fields.standfirst: Heidi Cochrane
fields.trailText: Heidi Cochrane.
fields.body:
Age: 24.

Status: Married.

Job: Lance Bombardier in 16 Regiment Royal Artillery, attached to the UN force serving in Cyprus.

How inspiring: a woman devoting her life to the defence of her country. Yes, she joined the army as a school leaver, gained promotion, married an army gunner and then had her picture distributed to newspapers in army publicity material promoting the role of women in the armed forces.

So she's a model soldier then? Umm ... well, in one sense, yes. She's a very pretty woman.

I sense a but coming. Well it seems she's been awol since July.

What a scandal! It's worse. She disappeared at the same time as a sergeant she was serving with, fuelling rumours that she was having an affair.

Shocking. Yes, particularly as she was about to start a leadership course, which included arduous physical tasks and all-night exercises.

I take it she'll be completing that course with her lover. Finished?

Please continue. Heidi apparently sent text messages from Sri Lanka to friends, taunting the army to "come and get me if you can be bothered".

How embarrassing. The problem is that it will be blamed on women's emotional irrationality and unpredictability, and may damage the campaign for women soldiers to be allowed to fight in the front line.

I didn't realise they couldn't. Women are barred from fighting with infantry and armoured units for fear that their presence would compromise combat efficiency. They are allowed to serve as RAF aircrew and on Royal Navy warships.

So what will happen to her? She faces a number of sanctions from administrative action to time in the army's correctional centre in Colchester, followed by discharge.

Not to be confused with: That Heidi who skips about among the Edelweiss in the Alps; Hollywood madam Heidi Fleiss; Hi-De-Hi!

webTitle: Antarctic ice cap is getting thinner

fields.headline: Antarctic ice cap is getting thinner
fields.standfirst: Scientists' worries that the south polar ice sheet is melting may be confirmed by the dramatic retreat of the region's biggest glacier
fields.trailText: For the first time, British scientists have detected ominous signs of the ice thinning in west Antarctica. The continent's biggest glacier, which has been systematically measured for the last eight years, has lost a 10 metre thickness of ice and retreated 5km inland.
fields.body:
For the first time, British scientists have detected ominous signs of the ice thinning in west Antarctica. The continent's biggest glacier, which has been systematically measured for the last eight years, has lost a 10 metre thickness of ice and retreated 5km inland.

If the thinning goes on at that rate, the entire glacier could disappear into the ocean within a few hundred years.

There have been fears for more than a decade that the west Antarctic ice sheet could be unstable. The region holds enough ice to raise worldwide sea levels by 5 metres, flooding coastal cities such as London, New York, Tokyo, and Calcutta.

An international panel of climate scientists last week confirmed that the Arctic ice sheet had thinned by 40% because of global warming in the northern hemisphere - but said there were so far no signs of similar thinning near the south pole.

But researchers from University College, London and the British Antarctic Survey report in Science magazine today that the Pine Island glacier, the largest in the west Antarctic, has lost 32 cubic kilometres of ice over a 5,000 sq km area since 1992. The glacier is one of the fastest in the world, flowing at 8 metres a day.

"For the past 25 years there has been speculation about whether a retreat of a west Antarctic glacier could accelerate ice flow from its interior, producing rise in sea level," said Andrew Shepherd of UCL, who led the study.

"We have shown for the first time that such a retreat is indeed occurring. It is of paramount importance to determine whether the thinning is accelerating. Our present the oretical understanding is not sufficient to predict firmly the future evolution of the Pine Island glacier."

The scientists said the discovery added weight to the argument that small changes at the coast of the continent - such as the effects of global warming - could be transmitted swiftly inland, leading to an acceleration of sea level rise.

There had also been dramatic losses of ice in the Larsen ice shelf, on the other side of the Antarctic. But researchers were not yet confident that these two things added up to evidence of global warming around the continent.

"Pine Island glacier is one of 10 large glaciers that drain Antarctica and at present we only see this thinning over Pine Island. If it were a truly global event, you would expect to see it everywhere. We haven't looked in great detail at the others, but it is only this sector which has shown such a change in the past eight years." Dr Shepherd said.

The Antarctic contains 90% of the world's snow and ice. The mountain glaciers in the west get the worst blizzards and some of the harshest cold on the planet. The zone is too hostile for any research station, and scientists had to base their information on satellite studies and aerial surveys.

Pine Island glacier starts at an altitude of 2,500m, and its frozen tributaries gather into a massive river of gradually-accelerating ice, 25km wide and 150 km long, which reaches the sea in a wall 750m high.

"It is a very, very fast glacier, one of the fastest in Antarctica." said Dr Shepherd. "It starts at around 100m-a-year and the ice flows into it gradually. Alpine glaciers generally travel at no more than 50m a year and this one travels at 2,500m a year."

webTitle: G2: Stephen Moss returns home in Llanvern

fields.headline: What next?
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's decision by Corus to drastically cut its UK operations has hit south Wales hard. The axing of 1,340 jobs at Llanwern spells the end of steel making in Newport. Stephen Moss, who grew up in the shadow of this great plant, went back to find out what the future holds
fields.trailText: Yesterday's decision by Corus to drastically cut its UK operations has hit south Wales hard. The axing of 1,340 jobs at Llanwern spells the end of steel making in Newport. Stephen Moss, who grew up in the shadow of this great plant, went back to find out what the future holds.
fields.body:
You get an impression of the scale of Llanwern steelworks when you enter Newport by train. It begins soon after you emerge from the Severn Tunnel and continues to the edge of Newport - miles of tangled, starkly beautiful concrete and metal. Llanwern says welcome to Wales, with all its industrial pride - and pain. For, after yesterday's announcement by the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate Corus, it is to be reduced to a shell, steel making is to end, and generations of endeavour will be laid to rest.

The closure of a factory (and that is what, within 18 months, is likely to happen) is just a statistic, unless you have lived with it all your life. All through my childhood, I could see the blast furnaces of Llanwern from my bedroom window. We used to fish in a stream that ran on to the land it occupies. Amazingly, it was crystal clear. Somebody was taking care. My father - and the fathers of most of my friends - worked at Llanwern, which kept the town afloat, was its beating heart.

The factory was completed in 1961 and almost my first memory is of the Queen coming to pronounce it open a year or so later. The whole town turned out to cheer her as the procession crawled along the high street. She was young and hopeful then, and so were we. Llanwern symbolised the future and ushered in a period of prosperity and self-confidence. Large estates were built to house the families of the 10,000-plus men employed there; young families in decent, well-planned houses buying their first washing machines and Ford Cortinas.

We took it all for granted at the time, but now it seems a period of extraordinary optimism and self-belief. Crime was low; drugs barely heard of; and people had jobs. My secondary school, Hartridge, was less than a mile from Llanwern, on the other side of the London to Swansea railway line; watching the trains and the smoke belching from the giant blast furnaces was a welcome distraction from conjugating German verbs.

I think of the school now, a comprehensive whose intake was drawn mainly from the huge working class estate of Ringland, as having achieved something almost miraculous. It had 2,000 pupils, making it one of the largest schools in the country; covered almost 50 acres; and taught everything from Oxbridge entrants to forestry. It had a large, buoyant sixth form, as well as several villains who were definitely not there to conjugate German verbs. Yet this amazing educational enterprise succeeded. The teachers inspired and the pupils aspired. Somewhere down the line, some thing has been lost.

The school worked because the people worked. Llanwern supplied the money, the belief, the vision of the future - 10,000 men in steady, stable, decently paid employment meant 25,000 children getting by and getting on. Many other thousands of jobs in factories and shops and the busy port fed Llanwern, which in turn fed them. In the white-hot Wilsonian 60s, all that was taken as read. There was such a thing as society, and it was pretty good.

In Newport yesterday, nothing was taken as read. The young men who work there - most of the older ones took early retirement long ago - were still absorbing the news. They knew it was coming, but they seemed, to the last, to believe it could be averted. They earned good money at Llanwern, they said, £22,000 basic - enough to feed a family, run a car, buy a house. Now what: become a security guard for £4 an hour, drive a minicab, sign on the dole? A steelworker's skills are not transferable.

Mostly, they worried about their children, who henceforth would not be able to have the things they were used to: computer games, football kits, proper holidays. These men are mostly in their 30s and 40s, the prime of life. Or not, given yesterday's news. The picture is just as bleak in Ebbw Vale, where the closure of the tinplate works and the loss of 800 jobs is a crushing blow for the town, whose factory once employed 13,000 people.

Metropolitan politicians and New Labour lawyers should spend more time in the industrial constituencies to understand the extent to which life here has always revolved around work. Not content with spending most of their waking hours at work (my father used to more or less live there, working endless double shifts and weeks of night shifts), they then drink together in works-based pubs and clubs. Work provided not just the means to live, but the mode of life: a shared experience and identity.

I left all this behind in 1975 to go to university, so perhaps it is hypocritical for me to laud the culture now, but it had a strength and vitality, a belief in the power of collective action, and a commitment to progress that we appear to have lost.

As the men gathered in the pubs on the Ringland estate yesterday recognised, Llanwern is being sacrificed at the altar of market forces, the victim of an overvalued pound and a distant management that does not give a damn about the workforce, that did not even have the courtesy to tell them before it told the media.

Another 1,340 people on the dole (plus contract staff), to add to the 7,000 jobs lost at Llanwern since Thatcher came to power. More would-be recruits to the growing army of low-paid shelf stackers and security personnel; more children with disaffected, bored, impoverished parents; more encouragement for alcoholism, drugs, depression and violence; another blow to a community denied a reason for being.

Over the past 20 years, the workforce at Llanwern has been cut and labour systematically casualised. Stable jobs of the 60s and 70s have become contract-based; the sense of purpose of the workforce been lost; the right to a democratic role in the application of its labour has largely been denied. As unemployment in the town has risen - and jobs have become more short-term - Newport has changed in character, with rising crime, a growing drug problem, a reputation for violence, and poor educational performance. Only a fool would say that the two trends - the denial of decent jobs and the rise in social instability - were unrelated.

Communities need to understand what they are. Newport, Ebbw Vale and the towns of the Welsh valleys did once, when mining and steel making gave them their raison d'etre. They had enormous pride and passion for the jobs they did, the products they made. Think of the brass bands and the choirs and the great rugby teams produced in south Wales. In 1963 Newport beat the All Blacks, the most powerful rugby nation in the world. That was the town's field of dreams, and dreams could come true.

Culturally, south-east Wales is a confused place: certainly not English, but highly suspicious of Welsh-speaking Wales. Plaid Cymru hardly registers here (though it might now); the region did not vote for the assembly; the number of Welsh speakers is low. The resurgence of the Welsh language over the past 30 years that has given new strength to west and north-west Wales has let in no light here. All it had was its industrial might; now that has gone too. Llanwern was a symbol as well as a practical provider of jobs, and symbols matter.

It was wet and bleak in Newport yesterday, as it often is. When I first moved away, I could not understand why it no longer rained every day. The older men in the club looked on, believing nothing could be done to save the jobs or the plant. "It'll be closed in 18 months," said one. "There'll be nothing left." They had seen it all before, lost their jobs or been pensioned off in the Thatcher years. Now their sons were getting the same treatment. "Will you take industrial action?" the young men were asked. "What's the point?" said one. "That would just be playing into their hands."

In 1839, the people of south-east Wales, tired of political marginalisation and economic exploitation, marched on Newport. The aim of what came to be called the Chartist Rising was to seize the town and trigger a series of insurrections across Britain that would result in the implementation of the movement's demands for democracy.

Planning was rudimentary, the dragoons positioned in the Westgate Hotel were ruthless (20 bodies were left in the high street when the marchers were put to flight), and the nascent revolution failed. The marchers were led by John Frost, a former mayor of Newport, who was sentenced to death but ultimately transported for his part in the uprising.

The main square in the town centre is today named after Frost, but it is a fair bet that not one in a hundred of the shoppers in the square who hurry past the town's museum on their way to the discount shops in the John Frost Centre know who he was, or why civic leaders once thought that his protest should be remembered so publicly.

A more appropriate target for anyone who might wish to raise a squeak of protest on this occasion would be the monstrously ugly 400-room Celtic Manor Hotel, with its three championship golf courses and £10m luxury clubhouse. Presumably, the dragoons would this time be strategically positioned to guard the impeccably kept greens. Sadly, I do not think they will be needed: there is no Frost to lead, and no apparent will to follow. The fight went out of the town in 1981, when the long steel strike in opposition to job cuts finally crumbled.

The Labour MP for Newport East is Alan Howarth, who became the Conservative MP for Stratford-on-Avon in the Thatcher landslide of 1983 and served the Tories for 12 years before crossing the floor in 1995. Newport, a Labour pocket borough for 60 years, was his reward for having defected. Perhaps at the next election his constituents will wish to pass comment on his support for Lady Thatcher and her New Labour offspring. It isn't insurrection, but it's a start.

fields.body: Kyra Vane (Obituary, January 15) was an amusing, not to say scurrilous, speaker about her colleagues and the opera world, but seemed genuinely touched, when she spoke to the Recorded Vocal Art Society, that people remembered her career and her rare recordings. As a very minor part of the Italian Opera Company at the Stoll Theatre in the 1950s, I remember she was badly treated by some of the company of visiting Italians, which included such luminaries as Tito Gobbi, Margherita Carosio and Ferruccio Tagliavini, her Cavaradosi in Tosca. She claimed, not implausibly, that one reason her career failed to take off in Italy was that she refused to pay the claques which notoriously operated at the opera houses.

fields.headline: Isabella Wallich
fields.trailText: In the early 1950s, Isabella Wallich, who has died aged 84,  decided there was a gap in the record market. The result was a Welsh catalogue for her own label Delysé, founded in 1954, and worldwide sales.
fields.body:
In the early 1950s, on an overnight journey, Isabella Wallich, who has died aged 84, was talking to the Welsh cellist David Ffrangcon Thomas and the harpist Osian Ellis. She decided there was a gap in the record market. The result was a Welsh catalogue for her own label Delysé, founded in 1954, and worldwide sales.

Wallich had no connections with the principality, but was entranced by its music and committed herself with a cosmopolitan style and expertise that Welsh musicians found mysterious but magnificent. She recorded classical musicians, such as Ellis, performing Welsh music, as well as traditional performers, cymanfa ganu hymns, male voice choral singing, and even the investiture of the Prince of Wales. She also recorded children's stories, and pioneered Thomas The Tank Engine tales with Johnny Morris.

Born Isabella Valli in Milan, her father was an Italian businessman; her American opera singer mother was the sister of HMV's Fred Gaisberg, who recorded Enrico Caruso and created the Abbey Road studios in London.

She grew up close to Gaisberg, seeing him at work and meeting great contemporary musicians. She played bridge with the tenor Melchior during a dinner interval at Covent Garden, and, while studying piano at the Paris Conservatoire, looked after Sir Edward Elgar before the Paris premiere of his violin concerto. She became the lifelong friend of Friedelind, Wagner's anti-Nazi granddaughter.

Isabella became a concert pianist, but the second world war curtailed her career, and in 1939 she married Dick Corbett, an Englishman who, after RAF service, worked in his family's City firm, but was killed by communist guerrillas in Malaya in 1951. She had dreamed of making her own records, but her first job after widowhood was as a manager for the Philharmonia Orchestra's 1952 European tour. Then came Delysé.

From the mid-1960s, Isabella recorded Mahler, starting with Das Knaben Wunderhorn, with Geraint Evans and Janet Baker; its worldwide success prompted a more ambitious and costly Mahler programme, with Wyn Morris as conductor. Her independent enterprises ended in 1979, but she continued as a record producer for some years.

In her final years, she moved to Paris to be near one of her sons, and completed her memoir, Recording My Life. Her second husband, Aubrey Wallich, died in 1960. Her two sons survive her.

 Isabella Wallich, recording entrepreneur, born March 12 1916; died December 26 2000

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: Longing for a tummy tuck, breast enlargement or other anatomical enhancements has considerably benefited Community Hospitals.
fields.body:
Longing for a tummy tuck, breast enlargement or other anatomical enhancements has considerably benefited Community Hospitals.

The Bedford-based company, which operates 21 hospitals, has seen 20% growth in revenue from cosmetic operations, contributing to a 35% surge in half-year profits to £9.4m. This will help push up the value of the business to bidders, who have been circling since a takeover by private insurer Bupa was blocked by trade secretary Stephen Byers in December.

Community revealed yesterday that it had a shortlist of "a handful" of potential buyers, although it is keen to point out that remaining independent is a viable option. The leading contender is General Healthcare, the country's biggest private hospitals operator, which has asked the office of fair trading for clearance to bid.

There is a good chance the OFT will give the green light to a tie-up between General and Community, on the grounds that a bigger group could insist on better terms with the two nationwide healthcare insurers, Bupa and PPP, leading to cheaper prices for the public.

Several US companies, including HCA Columbia and United Surgical Partners, have been tipped as suitors. But General could probably offer more money, because of the potential savings.

Recent deals have valued hospital firms at eight to nine times annual earnings. For Community, this would mean a price in excess of the 650p a share offered by Bupa last year. Trading across the industry is strong, private operators benefiting from disillusionment with the NHS. Community's revenue from "self-paying", uninsured patients rose 10%.

The price rose 10p to 619p yesterday, valuing the business at £217m. A takeover is likely because Bupa's adviser, Schroder Salomon, has been ordered to sell its 27% stake. However, if a deal fails to materialise or the OFT takes a harsh view, investors could face a sharp slump. Hold.

fields.headline: BAE's nosedive deepens
fields.trailText: It is just over three weeks since defence group BAE Systems saw a quarter of its market value disappear after it stunned the City with news of slower profits and a massive £525m restructuring charge. It shares have yet to recover.
fields.body:
It is just over three weeks since defence group BAE Systems saw a quarter of its market value disappear after it stunned the City with news of slower profits and a massive £525m restructuring charge. It shares have yet to recover.

Yesterday they fell a further 13p to 283p after Merrill Lynch lowered its rating on the group to "reduce" and trimmed its earnings forecasts, following further analysis of the complex restructuring programme.

But what should concern shareholders most are Merrill's comments on BAE's chosen strategy. Merrill says being a vertically integrated operator across a number of different fields (air, sea and land in BAE's case) is a significant and complex challenge that may not be worth the risk.

As things stand, Merrill feels that a further downward move in the share price of 10-20% is appropriate to reflect that risk.

webTitle: Shot of Elan for drugs gossip

fields.headline: Shot of Elan for drugs gossip
fields.trailText: There was a speculative edge to trading in London yesterday. Having sat more or less idle at their desks all week, suddenly the market's rumour-mongers found themselves with a couple of juicy takeover stories.
fields.body:
There was a speculative edge to trading in London yesterday. Having sat more or less idle at their desks all week, suddenly the market's rumour-mongers found themselves with a couple of juicy takeover stories.

The first, and most interesting featured drug delivery specialist, SkyePharma. As usual the speculation was short on detail - that SkyePharma had received an approach from Irish company Elan.

But what the tale lacked in detail was more than made up for in the use of a little lateral thinking.

Elan used to be a front-runner in the drug delivery market but has fallen behind in recent years because it has been too busy competing with its clients by marketing its own drugs. If Elan wanted to recapture its former position what better way than to ac quire SkyePharma? After all SkyePharma is cheap - its shares have gone nowhere in five years.

However, not everybody was impressed with this line of argument. Senior traders were yesterday reporting nothing but interest from big institutional investors, who regard the company as significantly undervalued. SkyePharma ended 5p better at 96p.

Plenty of speculative money was also heading in the direction of bombed-out healthcare group SSL International.

Formed by the merger of Seton Scholl Healthcare and London International, the company ran into problems late last year when it warned that a glut of condoms and surgical gloves would hit profits. That news wiped 40% off SSL's market value and ever since it has been perceived as vulnerable to takeover.

With that background, it was hardly surprising that traders heard rumours of a North American bid approach. SSL, at 805p before the profits warning, rose 24p to 489p.

In the meantime, leading shares closed lower as investors backed away from the market to consider the implications of the Federal Re serve's latest interest rate cut. Although most investors were expecting the 50 basis point rate cut, secretly they had been hoping for more, particularly given the weak economic data which continues to come out of North America.

Yesterday's data showed manufacturing activity falling to its lowest level since March 1991.

The dread of a US recession combined with a weak perfor mance from the banking sector resulted in the FTSE 100 closing 45.7 points lower at 6,251.8.

Banking shares retreated en masse, as investors decided to take profits in the likes of Barclays, down 55p to £21.50p, Standard Chartered, off 55p to £10.60, and HSBC, 20p lower at £10.44 after recent outperformance.

Over in the tech sector, things were little better. Under pressure from poor performances by Sage , off 13.75p to 367p, and Autonomy, 72p weaker at £20.75, as investors moved into more defensive stocks, the FTSE Techmark 100 ended down 36.97 points at 2,771.03.

Lower down, Turbo Genset, the maker of revolutionary lightweight power generators, rose 37.5p to 555p as it updated City institutions at the offices of WestLB Panmure on recent developments.

Around 50 people were said to have showed up to hear Turbo state that its products are addressing a market that could be worth $50bn by 2010. WestLB reckons the shares, recently adjusted for a four-for-one stock spilt, are heading to 875p.

In the meantime, Recognition Systems slipped 44p to 271.5p after heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch started coverage with an unfriendly "reduce" recommendation and a 220p target price.

Wiggins, the airport management group that was recently threatened with court action by the financial reporting review panel, advanced 0.125p to 27.75p, after a sell order of some 13m shares was finally completed.

webTitle: Flying budget class across Davos divide

fields.headline: Flying budget class across Davos divide
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tom Hadfield, co-founder and executive director of Schoolsnet, was this week named one of the 100 Global Leaders for Tomorrow by the World Economic Forum at its meeting in Davos. This is the diary of his visit to Switzerland
fields.body:
Tom Hadfield, 18, is co-founder and executive director of Schoolsnet (www.schoolsnet.com), the leading education website, currently valued at £25m; at 12 he created Soccernet, one of the world's most popular football websites. This week he was named one of the 100 Global Leaders for Tomorrow, by the World Economic Forum at its meeting in Davos. This is the diary of his visit to Switzerland.

My A-level politics teacher had unwittingly told me what to expect: a small group of peaceful protesters fighting heroically against the evil forces of international capitalism. My classmates had joined in, all of them condemning globalisation and the wicked businessmen and government ministers working towards it.

I sat in silence. None of them knew that the following day I was flying to Davos for the World Economic Forum's annual meeting. I was going to be on the "wrong" side of the barriers. I thought little of it when I received the invitation from the WEF, confirming that someone unknown to me had nominated me as one of the Global Leaders of Tomorrow.

Apparently it meant getting involved in brainstorming sessions and setting up task forces to see how technology can improve the lives of people around the world. I had told very few of my friends; the title made me cringe and them laugh.

Having lent my PlayStation to a friend, and forged my parent's signature on a college absence form, all I needed to do was find a goalkeeper to stand in for me for my Saturday football team. What were the other GLTs doing? I wondered. I was already starting to feel out of place.

I was determined to try to fit in. I bought a suit at the airport and took some background reading for the plane. After several years running an internet business, I feel comfortable working with adults. But you could write what I know about globalisation on the back of a stamp.

As I walked in to the hotel in Zurich, two Saudi businessmen smoking cigars gave me a funny look. I glanced down the list of people in town: the senior vice president of Coca-Cola, the chief executive officer of Yahoo!, even Bill Gates... bloody hell! Doing my best to mix and mingle at the initial GLT reception, it occurred to me that I wouldn't bump into many of these people on the bus in my home town of Brighton.

On my second night in Switzerland, I attended a dinner with an impressive line-up of speakers. I was, not for the first time, 20 minutes late and took the only seat left in the restaurant. I did my best to discuss European economic policy with the man on my left, but rapidly got the impression from the others on my table that he was more important than I realised. I was told on my way out that he was the head of the Grameen bank in Bangladesh, and would be speaking later in the evening.

That same evening I recognised George Soros, whom I greatly admire, at the next table. I plucked up the courage to blurt out a few words. We had a brief conversation about what I wanted to study at university, although he probably had more important things on his mind.

Despite all the rich and influential people in Davos, the most impressive were a blind woman and her partner from Germany who run a school for blind children in Tibet. Sabriye Tenberken talked passionately of how she found blind children totally excluded from society and often left on the streets by their families. In the past two years, Sabriye had invented a Tibetan braille script and set up a boarding school to educate and care for 30 children.

It gave me a lot to think about. I had thought this would be a good opportunity to find something to do during my gap year. GLT "task forces", among many other things, work to introduce new technologies in developing countries, and encourage economic and social co-operation in war-torn and divided societies.

I tracked down Martin Varsavsky, an Argentinian businessman who has given $11.2m towards getting schools in South America online, and Craig Cohon, from London, who provides funding for local projects in developing counties. They were both enthusiastic about keeping me busy during my gap year.

As the youngest person at the forum, I felt like an observer rather than a participant. I now understand better the concerns of my classmates. But only through participation in constructive dialogue are people beginning to make a difference. However, the WEF needs to do more to involve dissenting voices, rather than leave them out in the cold.

As the coach dropped us back at Zurich, I realised I was on a different flight from the other GLTs travelling back to England. None of them was flying easyJet to Luton.

tom@schoolsnet.com

fields.headline: Are the old ones still the best?
fields.trailText: Zippin' up their boots and going back to their roots, Virgin Radio last week announced a return to their original music policy: classic rock and pop, with an emphasis on "real music" for a perceived "musically disenfranchised" audience between 30 and 40.
fields.body:
Zippin' up their boots and going back to their roots, Virgin Radio last week announced a return to their original music policy: classic rock and pop, with an emphasis on "real music" for a perceived "musically disenfranchised" audience between 30 and 40.

Virgin has a point. Because as Radio 1 spirals ever-yoofwards, Radio 2 still has an average audience age of 52, for all the hype about its transformation. Commercial stations, by the very nature of the beast, tend to rely on formulaic chart-driven music-scheduling, at least during daylight hours, and that means Ronan Keating, Ricky Martin and all their chums. Just what is a musically minded middle-youther, unmoved by the latest S Club 7 single, to do?

I've spent the week in the company of Virgin to find out. If the Suffragettes were trampled under horses' hooves so women could have the vote, it was the very least I could do in the name of radio enfranchisement to suffer a few mouldy old Dire Straits tracks. Potentially the perfect demographic for this new policy, I switched on.

And I found Oasis, Police, Talking Heads, REM, Joe Jackson, The Clash, U2, Depeche Mode, Pink Floyd, Queen, Bowie and, of course, the boy Knopfler. There are a few new singles in among the oldies, but only by "real" musicians (ie white, blokey, respected ones with guitars - like the Manics, Aerosmith and Toploader), but mainly it's a back-to-back nostalgia jukebox.

The stuff of those 100 greatest tracks polls, and the Saturday-night retro gorge-fests on the television, Virgin's playlist never surprises, never plays "real" music at all in fact. Real - that would be the diverse, the one-hit wonders, the tiny bands who came, were loved and then disappeared. By Wednesday I knew I wasn't going to hear the 70s classic I was after - The Rezillos' My Baby Does Good Sculptures.

On the station's website, there was broad support, however, for this mainstream, indigestible mass of MOR. This is scarier than Virgin scheduling the stuff in the first place. Can I be the only thirtysomething who doesn't want Ronan but only as much as I don't want cultural stagnation with only Pink Floyd for company?

Seventy-four per cent of logged-on listeners said Hurrah!, 23% How Dare You. A perspicacious 2% "can't tell the difference". That leaves a missing 1%. He probably ricked his back in an air-guitar moment with Aerosmith.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Radio picks of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play - Chandra | Night Waves
fields.body:
When the Nobel physicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar died in 1995 he was internationally eulogised as one of the key figures of 20th-century science. However, as George Fraser shows in his Afternoon Play - Chandra (2.15pm, Radio 4), recognition came only after decades of ridicule and abuse. As a mere student Chandra had proposed the existence of what we now know as black holes. The established experts fell on him to a man, until they realised that he was right.

In 1901 the British Library received one of its most generous bequests, 15,299 volumes assembled by a Victorian silk merchant after 40 years of assiduous research. Even now, however, few readers have ever seen the books: Henry Spencer Ashbee was a manic collector of pornography. In Night Waves (9.45pm, Radio 3) Patrick Wright talks to Ian Gibson, the latest to piece together Ashbee's life.

webTitle: TV and Radio: TV picks of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Woman Of The Year | Once Upon A Time In America (Part I) | Live Golf
fields.body:
Films

Woman Of The Year
(George Stevens, 1942)
9.55pm, TCM
The first inspired pairing of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn. He's a sports hack, she's a high-flown political columnist pontificating on the banning of baseball. The gender politics don't bear close examination (when will she settle down?) but the pair clash beautifully and comically, thanks to Michael Kanin and Ring Lardner Jr's Oscar-winning script.

Armored Car Robbery
(Richard Fleischer, 1950)
6pm, FilmFour
Taut, semi-documentary-style heist movie that helped set the tone for any number of thrillers, from Kubrick's The Killing to Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs. Charles McGraw stars as Cordell, the determined cop seeking revenge when his buddy is killed in a shoot-out, with an armed gang escaping with the loot. He almost meets his match in William Talman's calculating criminal mastermind, Pervus.

City Of Angels (Brad Siberling, 1998)
6pm, Sky Premier
A loose reworking of Wim Wenders' marvellous Wings Of Desire, Siberling's sweet romance has Meg Ryan as a down-to-earth surgeon being wooed by Nicolas Cage's angel: he's one of many roaming Los Angeles doing good deeds, but now he's prepared to hand in his wings for love. An intelligent, funny and appealing film, despite the pedestrian climax.

Once Upon A Time In America (Part I)
(Sergio Leone, 1984)
10pm, Sky
Cinema Leone's homage to America and its movies is a sprawling gangster saga spanning nearly 50 years in the lives of five Jewish hoods. Like his westerns, it's a potent mix of grand vista, intense violence and reflection. Robert De Niro is compelling as Noodles, a powerful man eaten up by the guilt of a betrayed friendship; James Woods highly charged as a manic crook. There's also an swirling Morricone score.

Meet The Applegates
(Michael Lehmann, 1990)
2.15am, FilmFour
There's at least a chuckle a minute in this sci-fi horror spoof from the director of the wickedly funny Heathers. The Applegates are in fact giant intelligent bugs who have left their threatened Brazilian rainforest community to pose as humans in Median, Ohio. Their mission: to destroy the local nuclear power plant. Except that the insects are quickly subsumed into the smalltown rat-race, mum Stockard Channing hooked on shopping, the kids on dope and sex - daughter Cami Cooper having a disconcerting tendency to revert to her true form when over-excited. Mandible-sharp parody.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Golf
8pm, Sky Sports 3
The first day of the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, a tournament so popular they need three courses to accomodate the golfers. Among the Ams this year are Kevin Costner, Clint Eastwood and Joe Pesci and, less predictably, the ageing but still noisy hellraiser Alice Cooper. All the US PGA Tour regulars will be there too, although Tiger Woods' knee injury makes him doubtful to start.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: Monitor pins down bulletin board fraud

fields.headline: Monitor pins down bulletin board fraud
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet surveillance and monitoring company IBNet yesterday introduced Sharedetec, which it says can thwart the growing problem of fraud perpetrated through bulletin boards.
fields.body:
Internet surveillance and monitoring company IBNet yesterday introduced Sharedetec, which it says can thwart the growing problem of fraud perpetrated through bulletin boards.

The product was developed by IBNet and its broker, Old Mutual Securities. "Stock markets are particularly susceptible to internet abuse," the IBNet said. "The advent of internet bulletin boards and chat rooms has not only provided investors with a forum to discuss ideas and opinions but has also opened the door to new types of fraud."

These can include misinformation and share price ramping - buying shares at a low price, then putting out rumours on bulletin boards to raise the price.

Sharedetec tracks the information on stocks being posted on boards and alerts companies and their advisers about any relevant reports.

Mark Ommanney, chief executive of IBNet, said affected companies could make "proactive decisions" such as asking internet service providers to remove false information or posting responses on bulletin boards.

IBNet, which plans a product for later this year that searches the internet for copyright and corporate reputation abuse, hopes to be profitable by June 2002.

Shares in IBNet yesterday rose 2p to 83.5p.
