webTitle: Richard Williams on the rising tide of football violence

fields.headline: From Rochdale to Rio via Rome hooliganism is alive and kicking
fields.standfirst: Three months of violence
fields.trailText: While violence breaks out throughout the global game, the Nobel committee announces a nomination for this year's Peace Prize. Let's look at the facts.
fields.body:
In Strasbourg, an assistant referee is hit by a firecracker during a French first division match. In Milan, a Molotov cocktail is thrown at the coach carrying the players of Internazionale. In the Argentine province of Isidro Casanova, a 17-year-old boy is killed during rioting between the supporters of two neighbouring second division clubs. In Nicosia, players' dressing rooms are besieged and a stadium is severely damaged after a referee ends a derby half a minute before the end of the indicated stoppage-time. In the Netherlands, Den Bosch supporters riot for three days and nights after the cancellation of a match following the shooting of a fan by police. In Johannesburg, the African women's championship final is abandoned after rioting by supporters of South Africa when the referee ignores an offside flag and allows a goal by Nigeria to stand. In Rio de Janeiro, the climactic match of the Brazilian championship has to be replayed after 60 people are injured in a fracas sparked off when two spectators - fans of the same team - start fighting each other after disputing the wisdom of a substitution.

In Oslo, meanwhile, the Nobel committee announces that the game of football has been nominated for this year's Peace Prize. French referees, who threatened a national strike this week unless their federation takes action, and Italian players, who held up the kick-off of their pre-Christmas matches by 15 minutes to protest against the rising tide of violence, might not be impressed by the gesture.

In England, too, aggro seems to be back in fashion. A few weeks ago several hundred fans of Manchester United and Leeds United, en route to matches at Bradford and Maine Road respectively, met in Rochdale for a Saturday morning head-to-head that seemed to have been prearranged. Pitched battles in the centres of Sheffield and Burnley, with associated damage to property, have followed recent bitterly contested derbies. On the internet, gangs associated with Queens Park Rangers and Arsenal exchanged taunts about last weekend's fighting in the streets around Loftus Road. Coventry supporters reacted to losing a Cup match in injury-time at Maine Road last Saturday by attacking their Manchester City counterparts in the main grandstand. And at the other end of the scale the officials of Burton Albion, unused to trouble in the Dr Martens Premier League, were shocked this month by the behaviour of two coachloads of visiting Bishop Auckland supporters, who staged two pitch invasions and fought with police during an FA Trophy tie.

These events appear to contradict the image that football is trying hard to create. After several decades spent skulking in society's shadows, the game seemed to emerge during the 90s into a world of light and joy and festivity, a world in which Thierry Henry could perform pirouettes that would not shame Sylvie Guillem while David Beckham got in touch with his feminine side. If Nick Hornby's Fever Pitch provided the prologue to this new football culture, then its defining event was surely the party on the Champs-Elysées on a summer night in 1998, when more than a million citizens of France celebrated the winning of the World Cup. When English fans rioted in Marseille during that tournament and again in Charleroi two years later, their misbehaviour was dismissed as a mere echo of the past, an aberration that could occur only in special circumstances.

But the catalogue of recent events suggests that football's social makeover may have been less than entirely successful. The new image may, in fact, be no closer to the truth than the old vision of uninterrupted mayhem which made it a pariah sport in the 80s. And if football has indeed been enjoying a period of relative calm, in which the increasing affluence of the players seemed to exist in a direct inverse ratio to the decreasing violence of the spectators, then it seems to be over now. From places as far apart as Hong Kong, Kurdistan, Leipzig, Brunei, Palo Alto, Shiraz and Nairobi, reports of violence suggest that the game has once again become a focus for people who want to fight and need an excuse.

Terraced streets
But weren't we supposed to have outgrown all that? In England, particularly, weren't the side-effects of all-seat stadiums and stock-market flotations supposed to include the removal of the game, both literally and metaphorically, from the Victorian terraced streets through which gangs once chased each other? "Only God, if he exists, would know what the present rate of football hooliganism is," Professor Eric Dunning said this week. "What we can say for certain is that in the last two years the reporting of hooliganism in the media has increased."

In the 80s, he said, the extent of the phenomenon had probably been exaggerated. "But in the 90s there was the appearance of a decline, probably because the Major and Blair governments were putting pressure on people to ignore it in order to help the English bid to host the World Cup. When England fans rioted in Europe, people tried to explain it away by saying that it only happened when they went abroad, or it only happened when they drank. They claimed that in general hooliganism had been removed from the Premier League and displaced to the lower leagues. But we can see that none of those arguments really holds good."

Professor Dunning's work at the University of Leicester's Centre for Research into Sport and Society made him one of the world's foremost experts on the sociology of football-related violence, which he refuses to see in terms of the conventional definition - a single phenomenon caused by a mixture of the effects of drunkenness, unemployment, violence on the field of play, and the permissive society. His analysis tends towards a view, expressed in a recent article in the European Journal on Criminal Policy and Research, that football hooliganism is "basically about masculinity, territorial struggle and excitement ... fighting is a central source of meaning, status or 'reputation' and pleasurable emotional arousal".

And, as such, it is highly resistant to attempts at suppression - particularly since it takes so many forms. Not long ago in Kandahar, for example, spectators rioted when Taliban police attempted to take action against a visiting Pakistani team, to whose shorts the Islamic fundamentalist authorities took exception.

"Football is the world's most popular spectator sport," Professor Dunning continued, "so I don't think it's surprising that it should be the vehicle for what you might call the pathologies or the fault-lines of organised societies, which might include racial, tribal or sectarian differences."

In England, that fault-line is generally the one running between two neighbouring clubs - hence the trouble in Sheffield, or between the fans of Burnley and Blackburn Rovers. "The hard core of English hooligans, like the Chelsea Headhunters, have an interest in getting publicity for what they're doing, either for the National Front or simply for themselves," he observed. "But there are people whom we've come to call football hooligans who just like a punch-up."

Although the history of football hooliganism in England goes all the way back to the 19th century, the recent outbreak indicates that it is no longer the English disease, if it ever was. After watching the England fans rioting in Charleroi during Euro 2000 on his hotel TV, the Italian player Angelo di Livio asked a reasonable question: "How is it possible that such an advanced nation can't shake off this plague?" But this season Di Livio's own nation has been the epicentre of football-related violence. A 31-year-old Leeds fan was stabbed in the centre of Milan on the night before a Champions League match in November. In Rome a few weeks ago, visiting Bologna fans fought police at half-time and set fire to vehicles in a car park underneath the grandstand - an event which rated barely a paragraph in the next day's paper. The rival Sicilian supporters of Palermo and Messina staged a ferocious street riot last month after their match in the Italian third division.

Lacking other means of expression - a proper war, for example - man's perennial instinct for violence seems to have identified a reliable outlet. It is football's bad luck that, along with all its virtues, it has spent the last 100 years creating the perfect setting and equipment for small-scale conflict: an international code, tribal identities, a variety of locations, and an inbuilt emotional trigger. And there seems little reason to suppose that change is imminent.

Professor Dunning himself attended the FA Cup tie between Aston Villa and Leicester City last weekend, in his capacity as a fan. "Yes, there were a few fights," he said. "Nothing special."

fields.headline: LSO/ Rostropovich
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
On the face of it, Mstislav Rostropovich's concert with the London Symphony Orchestra could not have presented two more contrasted Russian masterpieces: Tchaikovsky's beguiling Nutcracker Suite and Shostakovich's terrifying Eighth Symphony. Yet Rostropovich's interpretations eschewed the conventional conceptions of these pieces.

Rostropovich's Nutcracker illuminated both the light and dark sides of Tchaikovsky's fairy-tale world. The Dance of the Sugar-Plum Fairy galumphed rather than glittered at Rostropovich's slow tempo: the tinkling celeste and drooping clarinet were as grotesque as they were otherworldly. In the Chinese Dance, he emphasised the grit and grain of Tchaikovsky's orchestration, highlighting a rustic bassoon line rather than creating a sumptuous orchestral sheen. But Rostropovich allowed the LSO to sparkle in the Miniature Overture and indulge in the glorious Waltz of the Flowers.

Shostakovich's Eighth is famous as one of the composer's bleakest works, and is therefore a candidate for the most pessimistic symphony of the 20th century. Composed in 1943, it was expected to be a triumphant celebration of the Russians' epic victory over the Nazis at Leningrad. The gloominess of Shostakovich's vision in the Eighth Symphony offended the Soviet authorities, and the work was effectively removed from the repertoire just after its premiere.

The problem for contemporary conductors is to cut through this weight of history and make the piece work as a symphonic drama. For all Rostropovich's unique relationship with Shostakovich and his music, his performance assumed, rather than articulated, the power of the Eighth. The climax of his first movement was a chillingly brutal soundscape, as the full force of Shostakovich's enormous orchestra - including seven percussionists - was unleashed. Yet the journey towards this peroration was never totally convincing. Rostropovich's performance of the huge sweep of the first movement was self-consciously desolate, and at his slow tempo the music was robbed of its momentum.

In seeing the work as "pessimistic", he did not allow the symphony to generate its own emotional trajectory. His approach affected the whole piece, especially the finale, which seemed more episodic than epic. Yet he whipped the inner movements into a brilliantly noisy frenzy, as the LSO relished the warped waltzes and twisted fanfares.

fields.headline: Adora a perfect band for angst and alienation
fields.standfirst:
King Adora
Manchester Roadhouse
**
fields.trailText:
King Adora
Manchester Roadhouse
**
fields.body:
At one time, outsiders cowered in the shadows. No more. Birmingham's King Adora would, no doubt, be mortified if kids, teenagers, and mums and dads didn't all shout "Freak!" at them in the street.

There's a red cowboy shirt here, make-up there, jewellery, leopardskin guitar-straps, hair dye and, at the centre, drummer Dan Dabrowski's bizarre intergalactic Sid Vicious barnet. They look like a motley crew. But also as if they are meant to be together, a bunch of oddballs who perhaps find salvation in one another.

They open - well, they would - with We Are Heroes. Like all their other songs, it merges the Pixies, Manic Street Preachers and Suede, while singer Matt Browne skips between a daft falsetto, Axl Rose-whine and Black Francis shouting. To an extent, their lack of originality is counteracted by their energy. Listening to The Law is like being chased down a runway by a jumbo jet. Super Muff-Diver (yes, it's an ode to cunnilingus) is an itchy rash of faster/harder guitars.

But after just 30 minutes, the band's one-dimensional sound and fondness for cheap electronic effects begins to grate. And that's before you really start to analyse the songs. "Shoplifting and shirtlifting," Browne sneers at the start of The Law, oh-so-controversially. He is desperate to provoke us but, like Brett Anderson and Brian Molko, is all cheap innuendo and stylised soundbites. Unlike Bowie or the Manic Street Preachers, he says nothing significant or new.

Not that any of the pogoing 18-year-olds straining to touch him care. "It's you and me for ever," he declares, during his new single, Suffocate. His teenage legion in tiaras, glitter and ties (but in a punk way) swoon at the rhetoric.

Big Isn't Beautiful - its lyrics buried, thank goodness - may be a terrible, sixth-form rumination on male anorexia, but Browne's titillating, unsophisticated mix of sleaze'n'teen angst actually speaks to people. He makes those who would label themselves ugly feel beautiful. Confused, mouthy, overwrought and - snigger - named after a dildo, King Adora are, in many ways, the perfect teen band.

"Please go out and buy it," urges Browne, as Suffocate ends, "no one else in this country will." Well, stoking that shared sense of alienation may just keep King Adora afloat.

 King Adora play Liverpool Lomax (0151-709 4321) tonight, and Sheffield Leadmill (0114-221 2828) tomorrow, then tour.

fields.headline: Fascist art with a contentious focus
fields.standfirst:
Futurism and Photography
Estorick Collection, London
**
fields.trailText:
Futurism and Photography
Estorick Collection, London
**
fields.body:
Here's yet another celebration of Italian futurism, the modern art movement that began with the publication of Filippo Tommaso Marinetti's Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism in Le Figaro in 1909 and was a kind of aggressive pastiche of the cubist art then emerging in Paris.

If you want to silence the movement's critics - those who see Marinetti's enthusiasm for Mussolini as a downside - the way is to emphasise futurism before the first world war: Boccioni's paintings and sculptures exposing the "dynamism" of bodies in space; the paintings of Balla and Severini. This exhibition takes another route, following the relationship between futurism and photography through the 1920s and 1930s, and in the process achieves the opposite of its celebratory intention, as one half-baked "futurist" photograph follows another.

This show claims futurism came to terms with photography after the first world war, but it fails to demonstrate that. The photographs are patchy in quality and have no distinctive aesthetic. They mix second-hand montage and double-exposure techniques with soft porn or military subject matter to produce a futurist "look".

In the 1920s other avant-garde movements put photography at the centre of their understanding of the modern world. In Russia, Rodchenko more or less gave up painting for photography, while Man Ray and Brassaï were among the creators of surrealism. There is no futurist innovation in photography to compare to this. The only two post-1920 futurist photographers who hold your eye are Enrico Pedrotti and Wanda Wulz; but Wulz's self-portrait fusing her face with a cat's owes more to Man Ray than Marinetti.

With myopic self-confidence, this odd exhibition behaves as if fascism had been a minor aspect of Italian life. Marinetti was a dedicated follower of fascism, and it's hard not to see futurism's attitude to photography as a clue to its true nature. That was what the German radical critic Walter Benjamin thought when he contrasted the democratic, factual art of photography with the romantic aestheticism of Marinetti: to him, futurism and fascism were the same. Looking at its continuation in the 1930s, you see futurism doing its bit for the destruction of humanity. No wonder younger Italian artists rejected the fantasies of futurism and turned to neorealism, with its insistence on truth caught by the film camera.

 Until April 22. Details: 020-7704 9522.

fields.headline: Feelgood
fields.standfirst:
Hampstead Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Hampstead Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
Timing is everything in theatre, just as in politics. And Alistair Beaton's very funny satire on the hidden panic that underlies Labour's obsession with spin could hardly come at a choicer moment. The larger point is that comedy is always at its best when it feeds off current reality.

The setting is a seaside hotel on the eve of the prime minister's party conference speech. Eddie, his control-freak press secretary, is hammering out the verbless uplift ("A job culture, not a yob culture") with a young speechwriter when disasters erupt. Anti-capitalists are rioting in the streets. Environmentalists hijack the well-oiled conference. Worst, a key minister confesses that his land has been used for secret trials on genetically-modified hops. These have got into the beer supply, with the unfortunate side effect that male drinkers are developing female breasts.

The mammaries certainly linger on in the plotting. But Beaton's strength is that he anchors a fantastic scenario in a world of plausible detail. He captures particularly well the Machiavellian Eddie's desire to keep control of escalating events. At one point the deputy PM cum transport boss is stuck on a train and trying to escape angry commuters. Meanwhile the BBC is planning a story on conference chaos. It is better, Eddie decides, to shop the deputy PM than let activist greens hog the bulletins.

Satire relies on a moral positive, and Beaton's point is that Labour needs to put radical policies before presentation. In the second act, the laughter thins out to make room for the message. Beaton never fully acknowledges that, in a media-dominated world, all political parties are preoccupied with news management. But you feel he knows the backstage world of conferences first hand and his image of Labour's hierarchy fighting like ferrets in a sack is borne out by the latest shenanigans.

But the main joy of Max Stafford-Clark's production is Henry Goodman's Eddie. His particular gift is a vaudevillian precision: at one point he does a sexy swivel of his hips as if Eddie is a born performer. Even funnier is the sense of panic beneath the desire for control. Nigel Planer, as the minister, also gives a wonderful display of hapless dither in a play that, while not perfect, brings political rudeness and cheek back to a theatre stifled by cautious conservatism.

And Alistair Beaton's very funny satire on the hidden panic that underlies Labour's obsession with spin could hardly come at a choicer moment. Eddie, his control-freak press secretary, is hammering out the verbless uplift ("A job culture, not a yob culture") with a young speechwriter when disasters erupt. Anti-capitalists are rioting in the streets. Environmentalists hijack the well-oiled conference. Worst, a key minister confesses that his land has been used for secret trials on genetically-modified hops. These have got into the beer supply, with the unfortunate side effect that male drinkers are developing female breasts. The mammaries certainly linger on in the plotting. fields.headline: Getting your own back
fields.standfirst: Revenge is sweet - but be careful what you say at your leaving do. In a fast changing world old colleagues can always resurface, says Judi James.
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Revenge is sweet - but be careful what you say at your leaving do. In a fast changing world old colleagues can always resurface, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Are you a simmerer, seether, plotter, or revenger? Do you tend to take every atom of excrement that your job cares to throw at you right beneath the jutting chin without a murmur of complaint? Or do you spend quiet moments at your desk surfing the net in the hope of finding a website titled ExecutiveHitman.com?

British culture has always been one of turning the other cheek, but all that seems to be changing. Once upon a time people who refused to go without a fight were reviled as heinous whinge-bags and jolly bad losers.

Revenge is this season's new emotion, then. But exacting it in your job can be harder than you would think. Whether you are hell-bent on immediate retaliation, or you are saving the best bits of action for the day you finally tell your boss where to stuff his/her job, some calm reflection might not come amiss if you want to be on the winning end of the encounter:

Virtual revenge

This is the safest type. You sit at your desk, stare at the screen-saver and dream.... No holds are barred in this encounter and no-one ever gets hurt. You get to visualise your boss in any number of torture or humiliation situations while everyone in the office thinks you're working on that overdue spread-sheet. Less imaginative but more IT-skilled types can work on scanning a shot of the boss onto the screen and inflicting their own choice of torture with the aid of the mouse. Mind you don't leave the programme on-line when you dash off for a fag, though.

Silently but deadly

One of the oldest and most painful forms of revenge is the silent snub routine. Kids do it at school and it stinks. People do it in business and it is known as acting with constraint. I have had reports of colleagues behaving like rowing married couples, asking other members of the team to act as message-carriers between warring factions.

The problem with this type of plotting is that it tends to stressful on both sides. You look childish and this can put the other person at the advantage, especially if he/she is the boss. Colleagues get fed up with passing messages and start telling you to grow up and get a life.

The barbed wittticism

Books could be filled with all the wonderfully clever, cutting comments we all would have said - if only we had thought of them at the time. We each have an Oscar Wilde wit inside us, just waiting to get out, but unfortunately it's never around when we need it.

I have a colleague who memorises famous one-line put-downs, just in case the occasion should arise. In calmer, lucid moments she can rival Anita Loos at her most acerbic best. Unfortunately, under pressure from a dressing-down from the boss, the best she can come up with is a one-word riposte that rhymes with merchant banker.

Well-honed put-downs can be both clever and humbling. The longer you rehearse them, though, the more stale they tend to sound. If you can't perform ad-lib style then don't bother.

The horses head in the bed

There is a touch of the Sicilian Don in all of us when it comes to planning real big-time revenge. A passive response may be all that's allowed when the boss starts throwing his/her weight around in the office, but for some it is easier to bear when they know they can take quiet delight in the knowledge that they will get their own back later on.

This type of hard-nosed revenge can range from petty pilfering from the stationary cupboard to well-planned, more long-term acts of retaliation. Coins scratch the sides of the executive Jag, kippers are nailed under desks overnight, cress is sprinkled over boardroom rugs and watered regularly, teas are spat into, spouses are posted items of underwear or fake mail-outs from the clap clinic, and toilet seats are superglued. For the more viciously-inclined this type of overt revenge might be therapeutic. The increased use of security cameras in business means you are likely to get caught red-handed, though. Remember that court appearances for letting down the boss's tyres always tend to give a negative message when added to a cv. The last word

Leaving dos tend to be the traditional place for having the last word. What could be better than slagging your boss from hell off in public a mere ten minutes before he/she quits the building for good? If you're lucky you could volunteer to do the leaving speech, which will give you a full twenty minutes or so for some unfettered insults.

The trouble is, leaving dos bring out the maudlin in all of us, especially after a few plastic cups of warm chardonnay. One sight of that Freddie Kruger-style boss standing suddenly misty-eyed and sniffing as he/she clutches a sherry in one hand and a carriage clock in the other, and even legendary avengers have found themselves blubbing and saying how sorry they are to see them go.

And you never know where you might bump into that person again. One company's redundancy is another's new-hire. The face that wilted under the barrage of withering wit from your own tongue may be the one waiting to interview you in your next company.

webTitle: Abbey habitually loses current account customers

fields.headline: Abbey habitually loses current account customers
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National, now resisting a £20bn takeover bid by Lloyds TSB, lost a greater proportion of its current account customers than any of its peers last year, according to confidential industry data.
fields.body:
Abbey National, now resisting a £20bn takeover bid by Lloyds TSB, lost a greater proportion of its current account customers than any of its peers last year, according to confidential industry data.

The information, compiled by an arm of NOP and obtained by The Guardian, also shows that Abbey lost out in the race to attract current account customers who transferred their business to an other provider. The statistics from FRS show that more people are now starting to move their current accounts, an area of the financial services industry dominated by the big four - Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Barclays and HSBC - who control at least 70% of the market.

The proportion of accounts switched from one provider to another rose to 30% last year from 25% in 1996. While the big four won 60% of the business, the rest went to relative new entrants, a group which includes Abbey. The figures were compiled before a new initiative from the big banks to swap customer information about direct debits, regarded as one of the potential inhibitors to customers moving their current accounts. Since then new entrants such as Abbey and Halifax have been widely advertising their new current accounts.

The FRS figures could ignite the debate surrounding Lloyds TSB's £20bn bid, tabled earlier this week for Abbey. It is yet to receive clearance. A decision is expected on or before February 23 and has been clouded by speculation that it might be referred, delaying the bid by up to six months, because of the more than 25% share of current accounts a combined Lloyds TSB and Abbey would hold.

Abbey is trying to position itself as a competitor to the big four. In yesterday's press it took out full page ads claiming it had attracted more than 6,000 current account customers from Lloyds TSB, Bar clays, NatWest and HSBC in January.

Yet, the FRS data, which contains last year's data, shows that last year it lost 4% of its current account customers -more than any of its rivals.

Abbey said last night: "We have been advertising since the end of December and since bringing in the 0% overdraft."

The data also shows Lloyds TSB and Royal Bank of Scotland were more successful than any other current account providers in attracting new business, closely followed by institutions outside the "big four", including Nationwide building society, First Direct, the arm of HSBC, Alliance & Leicester and Woolwich, now owned by Barclays.

According to FRS, Lloyds TSB has the biggest share of current accounts - 22% - but took in 18.5% of new business. Halifax, which is widely advertising its new current account, took in 4.9% of new accounts compared with its historic market share of 4.7%.

webTitle: Bank lets down Brown on inflation

fields.headline: Bank lets down Brown on inflation
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The inflation rate will dramatically undershoot the government's target by a full percentage point, a respected independent think-tank predicts today.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny, Mark Atkinson  and  Rupert Jones
fields.body:
The inflation rate will dramatically undershoot the government's target by a full percentage point, a respected independent think-tank predicts today.

Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George will be forced to write a letter to Gordon Brown later this year explaining why inflation is likely to hit 1.5%.

Forecasters at the National Institute for Economic and Social Research believe inflation will miss the government's 2.5% target - requiring Sir Eddie to explain why the deviation happened and what the Bank is planning to do about it. "When the chancellor established the inflation target regime, it was generally expected that any failure to meet the 2.5% target by more than a percentage point would be through an overshoot rather than an undershoot," the institute said.

"But [our] central forecast is that inflation will fall below 1.5% by the end of the year."

The institute's analysis backs the views of leading doves on the Bank's key rate setting committee - DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani - who have been calling for the Bank to cut rates since last December, arguing that inflation is no longer a threat to the UK economy. "At this juncture the risk of the Bank undershooting its target is the highest since it was given the mandate back in June 1997," said Claudio Piron, an economist at Standard Chartered bank.

The NIESR says that, even if the monetary policy committee cuts borrowing costs at next week's meeting, as the City expects, it will be too late to get inflation back on track.

However, the forecasters at the institute predict the MPC will leave rates on hold because, after a sharp dip at the end of the year, inflation is set to rise again early next year.

Strong growth in house prices and retail sales figures, released yesterday, added weight to the institute's view that the UK economy is more robust than many City analysts believe. According to the NIESR's forecast, output will grow 2.9% in 2001, a better performance than the chancellor pencilled in for his pre-Budget report last December.

Nationwide building society said house prices rose 2.5% in January, the biggest monthly rise since the boom days of 1988-89, excluding a 3.5% monthly increase in June 1993, which is seen as a blip.

Separate figures from the Confederation of British Industry showed that retail sales leapt in January, after a disappointing performance in December. Even the struggling manufacturing sector recorded its strongest activity level for a year in January, figures from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply show.

The latest snapshot of the sector released yesterday shows European factories suffered a slowdown in activity in January but the European Central Bank ignored calls for it to follow the lead set by the United States Federal Reserve earlier this week and cut borrowing costs.

Shrugging off fears that the US will export its recession to Europe, the ECB left interest rates for the eurozone unchanged at 4.75%.

"Growth is very likely to continue at a reasonably robust pace," the ECB's president Wim Duisenberg said.

Further evidence of the severity of the US slowdown came last night with new figures showing that the manufacturing sector contracted for the sixth month in a row in January.

fields.headline: Papa Roach
fields.standfirst:
London Astoria
***
fields.trailText:
London Astoria
***
fields.body:
After the obligatory taped preacher-man promising us he will "lay my vengeance down", a heavy-metal crescendo signals the emergence of Californian nu-metallers Papa Roach. The lights come up to reveal three young men pogoing up and down to a trouser-flapping riff of bass, drums and guitar. They are all dressed neatly in black shirts and are as fresh-faced as a boy band. As is the case with boy bands, each has a different hair style. The bassist, for example, needs his forehead waxed; the guitarist is experimenting with a goatee; and the slightly pudgy vocalist - the group's Gary Barlow figure - boasts cheeky gelled spikes.

The vocalist's real name is Cobe Dick, so I shall call him Gary. At the end of the first number, Gary screams "Fuck you!" at the audience, recalling nothing so much as South Park's Cartman shouting at his mother. An illicit thrill pulses through the audience of slam-dancing 12-year-olds.

Gary enjoys swearing at the audience while making hip-hop shapes with his arms. The summit of his Wildean wit throughout the evening comes when he tells the audience in the gallery, who are all sitting down, to "eat a bowl of fuck". Audience participation is encouraged, too: at one point we are coached to shout "Dead cell!", for what is presumably a song about E coli.

Papa Roach owe a large debt musically to rap-metal bands such as Faith No More, although they mostly lack FNM's operatically decadent way with a chorus. They also miss the jazzy swing and musical variation of the late, lamented nu-metal kings Rage Against the Machine.

Apart from one swerve into pleasant, choppy-guitared reggae stylings, like over-distorted Police, the songs mainly blast along at a single tempo, unenlivened by much dynamic variation or instrumental virtuosity. The guitarist, especially, seems to be scrawling fuzz over the top of the riffs, rather than sitting right in them alongside the terrifyingly hairy bass player.

But a couple of songs (the titles inaudible over the shattering low-frequency mix) manage to blast happily into tuneful refrains. One even has Gary whistling, magically invoking the image of Roger Whittaker in hell.

Papa Roach are surely only toying with us when the stage darkens for a sub-Eminem-style tape of dramatised domestic violence. This music is not about adult fears and loathing, but the perfect way to express an aggressive discinclination to tidy your bedroom.

They end with the chirpy singalong of their current single - the suicide-themed Last Resort - and their energetic, insectoid rumbling is leavened with a haunting prettiness.

 At Birmingham Academy (0121-262 3000) tonight, Manchester Academy (0161-275 2930) on Sunday, and Brixton Academy (020-7771 2000) on April 16.

fields.headline: Kings of Lagos rock and rule
fields.standfirst:
The Kings of Lagos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
The Kings of Lagos
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.body:
It was an inspired way to start a show. A middle-aged Nigerian, in flowing robes and traditional headgear, walked across the stage holding a radio-mike and singing the first verse of a soulful lament unaccompanied. Then another, similarly-dressed man emerged to sing the second verse, with a slightly different interpretation to the song - and so it continued until all eight of the Kings of Lagos had arrived on stage.

They looked more like a studious convention of African lawyers than a band, but then they danced around the row of eight bottles of water that had been laid out for them across the stage, as they began trading their highly amplified solos and harmonies.

The Kings come as a surprise for those who equate Nigerian (or more specifically Yoruba) music with the big-band styles of King Sunny Ade and the rousing, angry Afro-beat of Fela Kuti or the contemporary soul-Afro-beat of his son Femi. This vocal group - a west African answer to South Africa's best-selling Ladysmith Black Mambazo -tackle anything from dance songs to Yoruba traditional material, hymns and pop.

They have one other ingredient, crucial to survival in Lagos - a truly wicked, sometimes vicious sense of humour, often directed at fellow band members. Jide Akinwunmi, who leads the Kings with an infectious delight, demonstrated the dry, street-wise wit of one used to living in a country that for years seemed on the verge of falling apart.

He introduced the band by asking: "Why do we have so many Kings of Lagos? Well, it's a confused place." And then he explained why religious songs were so popular in the city: "We have a lot of problems and people are used to saying, 'Oh God'." I suspect the jokes are different every night.

As for the songs, they ranged from full-blooded spirituals to modern line-and-response street songs, and bursts of chanting mixed with an early form of rap, just to prove that "most music comes from the Yorubas, from blues to rap". There was none of the slick dance routines favoured by Ladysmith, but none was needed. Some pieces were performed unaccompanied, and some had backing from an eight-piece band who ambled on and off stage.

If there is one change the Kings should make, it's to restructure their show and look after these backing musicians better. fields.bodyText: It was an inspired way to start a show. A middle-aged Nigerian, in flowing robes and traditional headgear, walked across the stage holding a radio-mike and singing the first verse of a soulful lament unaccompanied. Then another, similarly-dressed man emerged to sing the second verse, with a slightly different interpretation to the song - and so it continued until all eight of the Kings of Lagos had arrived on stage. They looked more like a studious convention of African lawyers than a band, but then they danced around the row of eight bottles of water that had been laid out for them across the stage, as they began trading their highly amplified solos and harmonies. The Kings come as a surprise for those who equate Nigerian (or more specifically Yoruba) music with the big-band styles of King Sunny Ade and the rousing, angry Afro-beat of Fela Kuti or the contemporary soul-Afro-beat of his son Femi. This vocal group - a west African answer to South Africa's best-selling Ladysmith Black Mambazo -tackle anything from dance songs to Yoruba traditional material, hymns and pop. They have one other ingredient, crucial to survival in Lagos - a truly wicked, sometimes vicious sense of humour, often directed at fellow band members. Jide Akinwunmi, who leads the Kings with an infectious delight, demonstrated the dry, street-wise wit of one used to living in a country that for years seemed on the verge of falling apart. He introduced the band by asking: "Why do we have so many Kings of Lagos? Well, it's a confused place." And then he explained why religious songs were so popular in the city: "We have a lot of problems and people are used to saying, 'Oh God'." I suspect the jokes are different every night. As for the songs, they ranged from full-blooded spirituals to modern line-and-response street songs, and bursts of chanting mixed with an early form of rap, just to prove that "most music comes from the Yorubas, from blues to rap". webTitle: A reckoning at the Russia house, SW16

fields.headline: A reckoning at the Russia house, SW16
fields.standfirst:
Ex-police officer investigating pirate CDs uncovers £5m credit card scam

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: When Vladimir Stroguine boasted a forged credit card could be produced within hours it was to impress a new contact. The Russian con man was convinced that his new "friend" would become an important customer and a potential route to riches.
fields.body:
When Vladimir Stroguine boasted a forged credit card could be produced within hours it was to impress a new contact. The Russian con man was convinced that his new "friend" would become an important customer and a potential route to riches.

Over a six-month period he had grown to trust the quiet, unassuming man whose interest initially centred on bulk buying counterfeit CDs but had suddenly switched to purchasing hi-tech "skimming" machines capable of copying credit card details within seconds.

The client soon became a regular visitor to the Russian's west Hendon home and privy to details of his criminal empire which, he was to discover, included a key role in a £5m credit card fraud, dubbed the most sophisticated ever seen in Britain.

In reality Stroguine's new friend was not a businessman but an undercover investigator who was secretly recording all conversations and compiling a dossier on behalf of the City of London police.

The plant, an ex-policeman whose identity is a closely guarded secret, infiltrated the gang on behalf of the IFPI, a body representing the international recording industry, after being tipped off about Stroguine's leading role in importing counterfeit CDs from Russia. Once inside it became clear to him that the operation was far bigger than had first been imagined.

"[Vladimir] was a very good salesman and happy to tell our man exactly what was on offer," said one police source. "This guy had become well trusted by Vladimir as they had been talking for months."

Today those confident claims will come back to haunt the tall, 44-year-old Russian when he appears at Southwark crown court for sentencing, alongside fellow countryman Alexandre Tanov, after pleading guilty to conspiracy to defraud.

In covertly recorded conversations, Stroguine said he could supply forged credit cards, to order, for £300 each and also admitted distributing hi-tech skimming machines - the size of a cigarette pack and able to be easily clipped on to belts.

Stroguine was - in police parlance - a middle man fixer. He sold the fake cards and controlled a network of eastern European waiters, working at top London restaurants including Caravaggio, who were equipped with skimming machines.

On one occasion officers tracked one group who had visited Stroguine's home and were equipped with counterfeit cards. The gang were watched enjoying a spending spree in the west end with at least three being dispatched to buy clothes in Harrods.

Investigators were anxious to find where the cards were produced. They did not have to wait long. The undercover agent returned a skimming machine to Stroguine and Tanov arrived to take it away and download the information. Officers staking out the house then followed Tanov on an exhaustive five-hour journey across London, by taxis, trains and buses, as he travelled from Kings Cross to Seven Sisters and finally to Streatham, SW16.

He was tracked to his front door and the pieces of the jigsaw had finally come together in late January last year.

Confident they now had enough information, officers carried out dawn raids on addresses across London, including those of the two main suspects, but even they were surprised by what was found at Tanov's home.

The 33-year-old Russian had turned a small bedroom into a credit card factory, at a cost of no more than £3,000, complete with computers, embossers and hologram making equipment, capable of producing near perfect replicas of Visa, Amex and Master Card.

The raids also recovered a quantity of false passports, national insurance cards and thousands of fake CDs from artists such as Mary J Blige, Boyzone and Melanie C.

The pair were immediately arrested and stood trial towards the end of last year at Southwark crown court in south London. The case, which was initially disrupted after Stroguine's son Andrei was found dead on the opening day, heard their actions had defrauded cardholders of more than £200,000 but would have reached £5m. Both men decided to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge, with Stroguine admitting a second trademark charge relating to the CDs, but legal sources believe they may still walk free from court today owing to the time spent on remand.

The final hearing held last month, at which stringent reporting restrictions were lifted, was adjourned for medical reports after the court heard Stroguine, who claimed to have worked for the military missile division in the former Soviet Union, suffered from a heart condition.

The Guardian reported on Monday that two waiters, who went under the names of Sorin Lasculescu and Ivan Guzun at the time of their arrest, were wanted in connection with this inquiry after both jumped bail.

Lasculescu, aged 30, was charged with conspiracy to defraud but jumped bail. Guzun, who is also believed to use the name Ronny Gundersen, was questioned but released on bail without charge.

Swiped - your card details and your cash

To steal account holders' information, the Russians employed waiters who wore swipe machines while they worked in restaurants, hotels and wine bars across London.

The waiters would carry a tiny machine, often on their belts, which they would use to reswipe a customer's credit card after they had been used to pay the original bill.

The data in the black boxes was downloaded through a computer and sent to a blank card's magnetic strip. The fake was embossed and, using a hologram stamp imported from Russia, the gang were able to produce near-perfect replicas of Visa, Amex and MasterCard.

Experts say that the interlocking globes and flying dove marks used by MasterCard and Visa were said to be of such high quality that they were almost impossible to detect.

The fake cards could be hawked on the black market for £300, anticipating a month's leeway before the cardholder noticed and reported the fraud.

fields.headline: Brave drama from Sheffield's Third Angel
fields.standfirst:
Where From Here
Sheffield Crucible
****
fields.trailText:
Where From Here
Sheffield Crucible
****
fields.body:
In a stark white room, a man sits listlessly on a chair while a woman practises target shooting behind him. "Sometimes he pisses me off so much I just want to blow his brains out," says the woman. This is what happens when love dies: after the passion of love comes hate. Intimates act like murderous strangers.

Sheffield has already given us Forced Entertainment, one of the most influential new British theatre companies of the last 20 years, and in Third Angel it has produced another brave young company that is crossing boundaries and redefining the nature of theatrical experience.

Where From Here is like a postmodern version of Pinter's Betrayal crossed with Sartre's Huis Clos. It is set in a white, cell-like room from which the protagonists can never escape. The possibility of murder or suicide is ever present. The knives, guns and nooses are readily available, but the act cannot be done. The man and woman are paralysed by nostalgia, trapped by the constructs of their own lies and what once was and now isn't. They cannot go back and cannot go forward. They are like souls in purgatory. It is sweet torment to watch them.

One of the best things about this show is its complete accessibility. So much work that challenges theatrical conventions is obtuse, cloaked in an armour of deliberate difficulty. Not this show. It is direct, fresh and grimly funny. There is a truth in the detail: the fag ends in the satsuma skin at the dinner party that leads to the affair's consummation; the admission in a cheap, dirty Indian hotel room that he didn't want to be with her, he simply didn't want to be alone.

The man and the woman map out their shared past, drawing pictures of rooms they have both known, drawing on memories to excavate the past. But it cannot be recaptured. It is now a distant foreign land to them, its terrain made impossible to negotiate by a mixture of lies, evasions and sheer bloody-mindedness. All that is left for them is a retreat into nostalgia.

At the end, they sit on a chair awaiting a death that will not come, clutching at each other like the victims of some terrible natural disaster. But this is a tragedy of their own making that they will be forced to relive over and over.

 At the Bowen West Theatre (01234 219333) tomorrow, Alsager Arts Centre (0161-247 1306) on Tuesday, and the ICA, London SW1 (020-7930 3647), from February 8-10.
